input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT MIDDLESBOROUGH R v. MR H Case No. T2025/15347 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. P. NICHOLLS Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H, you appear today before this court for sentence in relation to the charge of theft by shoplifting, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, representing a pattern of offending over an extended period in the district of Middlesborough and adjoining retail precincts. The offending conduct in question, as charged and now admitted, involves multiple incidents occurring between late 2023 and the early part of 2025, predominantly in small to medium-sized retailers specializing in pharmaceutical and personal care products. Procedural History You were first arrested on 12 March 2025 after a targeted investigation by Greater Cleveland Police in collaboration with the Middlesborough Business Crime Liaison Unit. The investigation followed a crescendo of concern raised by local shopkeepers who, over several months, reported loss of stock not easily accountable by natural wastage or administrative error. The Middlesborough Retail Crime Partnership coordinated efforts to collate and analyse CCTV footage, inventory shrinkage reports, and staff accounts, leading to your identification as a suspect. The process of assembling the evidence was, as is often the case, fraught with logistical and administrative hurdles. Retailers volunteered their time and commercial data, which had to be juxtaposed with police intelligence that in some instances suffered from missing timestamps and overlapping video frames. The video imagery frequently displayed the defendant wearing hooded attire, obscuring facial features, or footage was compromised due to camera angle limitations. These challenges necessitated a painstaking, iterative review of hours of material accompanied by relevant expert statements prepared by crime scene specialists analysing point-of-sale discrepancies and security sensor disruptions. Early investigative efforts benefitted from a limited, though comprehensive, community policing operation deploying ‘plain clothes’ officers to observe and record typical patterns of footfall and suspected activity in the targeted retail areas. In parallel, a partnership was established with local volunteer organisations concerned with retail staff welfare and workplace safety, responding to the emotional toll on personnel repeatedly subjected to loss investigations and alarmingly frequent incidents of intimidation from recidivist individuals. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. An initial interview under caution was conducted on 14 March 2025, during which you declined to admit guilt. Following forensic analysis of clothing seized from your residence—a dark green parka notably consistent with that worn in surveillance footage—corroborative evidence was assembled, enabling the Crown to proceed with charging you on 22 March 2025. The matter was then transferred to this Crown Court as part of the Better Case Management (BCM) scheme, with the objective of effecting an efficient progression to trial or plea. The BCM regime, introduced under the auspices of the Criminal Procedure Rules, is designed to expedite the handling of cases, reducing unnecessary delay and ensuring that evidential clarity is established at an early stage. The court acknowledges that in the present instance, despite typical pressures arising from court listing congestion and, notably, a short adjournment caused by procedural irregularities with service of prosecution disclosure, all parties endeavoured to adhere to timelines, culminating in the listing of a plea and trial preparation hearing on 22 May 2025. At that hearing, you entered a not guilty plea, but following receipt of further evidence and additional witness statements from shop managers, you changed your plea to guilty at the early stages of a trial listed for 5 June. It is appropriate at this juncture to reiterate the well-established judicial position concerning discounts for guilty pleas, as underscored in R v Bennett [2023] EWCA Crim 1203. The Court of Appeal reiterated therein that the utility and fairness of plea credit rest heavily upon timing and sincerity, with late pleas, particularly those entered after overwhelming evidence arises, meriting only limited reduction in sentence. Mr H's niece’s pram was used to stash boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in order to avoid drawing attention. While the facts of Bennett concerned a more serious fraud-related offence, the principle that the sentencing discretion is diminished by delayed admissions of guilt is equally applicable to theft offences such as this one. The court also draws reference to R v Penman [2022] EWCA Crim 978, where repeated minor acquisitive crimes committed over several months, coupled with an absence of prior engagement with rehabilitative services, led to a custodial sentence reflective of public protection needs. The cited authorities underscore the judiciary’s duty to ensure proportionate sentencing that balances punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and community protection. Turning to the broader context in which this conduct occurred, I find it necessary to record the immense strain on public services tasked with addressing such offences. The Probation Service for Cleveland reports chronic staffing shortages, with caseloads frequently exceeding recommended limits, thereby impeding robust supervision of low and medium-risk offenders. This systemic challenge is compounded by significant waiting lists in mental health services, notably the Psychological Therapies Access Pathway, which has seen a 30% increase in referrals over the past year, due in large part to pandemic-related backlogs and resource constraints. I have received a letter from the Head of Probation, Ms Fiona Melrose, emphasizing these constraints and the consequent impact on efforts to engage repeat acquisitive offenders in meaningful support. Moreover, retail workers, many of whom are part-time employees with limited employment protections, have voiced persistent concerns over heightened anxiety and diminished morale caused by recurrent thefts, occasionally accompanied by verbal abuse. The Retail Staff Welfare Alliance, a voluntary sector organisation, has submitted representations outlining the emotional and psychological ramifications on employees, including instances of increased absenteeism and reluctance to work alone during closing hours. These factors, while not directly altering legal culpability, form an important backdrop to the impact of your conduct. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. This court is cognisant of the delicate balance between recognising the pressures individuals face and upholding the rule of law. Previous judicial pronouncements have acknowledged the multifactorial nature of criminal behaviour, but caution against conflating explanation with excuse. Indeed, as noted in R v Henderson [2019] EWCA Crim 583, societal and economic hardships, while relevant to mitigation, cannot absolve persistent opportunistic offending that undermines community cohesion. I must also comment upon an unfortunate but recurrent operational concern: the delays occasioned by Legal Aid authority decisions. In this matter, applications to instruct a forensic psychiatrist experienced in impulsivity-related disorders took over six weeks to process, despite the time-sensitive nature of preparatory reports. Defence counsel, Mr Simon Cranley, drew the court’s attention to this issue, which regrettably contributed to adjournment of sentencing from the originally scheduled date of 29 July 2025 to today’s listing. The Legal Aid Agency’s slow response is emblematic of a broader systemic malaise. It is a matter the judiciary continues to monitor closely, mindful that access to expert evidence is fundamental to fair adjudication. Mr H pretended to ask a question about Oyster Card payments in order to distract staff, then reached behind the counter and took a display item. To provide further context on the assessment of risk and potential for rehabilitation, I wish to summarise the conclusions reached in the psychiatric evaluation conducted by Dr Anita Fowles, consultant forensic psychiatrist. Dr Fowles notes an absence of any major mental disorder but reports traits consistent with impulsivity, dysfunctional coping mechanisms with respect to stress, and a mild history of alcohol misuse. The report highlights that your engagement with voluntary support systems has been minimal, despite repeated opportunities to participate in financial counselling and substance misuse programmes. Dr Fowles opines that this lack of engagement diminishes prospects for rehabilitation absent enforced intervention. On a related note, the probation officer’s presentencing report observes that you have a history of residential instability, having experienced multiple interspersed periods of temporary accommodation and brief stays with friends. While the immediate cause of your offending appears linked to economic difficulty, your refusal to engage with debt management initiatives and inconsistent cooperation with probation appointments undermine the efficacy of community-based sentences. There is also documentation noting your failure to comply with an earlier community resolution following an incident in 2022, which may give rise to concerns about compliance and motivation. The defendant used a magnetic device to disable the security tag, and this was later recovered when Mr H was arrested. The court has also been provided with victim impact statements from two local pharmacy managers and a small convenience store owner. These attest to significant disruption caused by your offending, including financial loss, the need to increase staff training on loss prevention, and a discernible reduction in staff confidence. One victim described heightened fears of confrontation and a palpable increase in workplace stress. Mr Cranley, on your behalf, submitted a letter detailing your personal circumstances, including the pressure of caring for a dependent family member with a chronic health condition and the disruption caused by the breakdown of your previous accommodation arrangements. While such matters may inform mitigation, they do not diminish the seriousness of your decisions to repeatedly appropriate goods without payment. The defendant admitted taking the stolen items to sell at local pubs and a car boot sale, where members of the public were disturbed. In reviewing the overall landscape of acquisitive offending in this jurisdiction, the court is mindful of recent statistical trends indicating a modest increase in shoplifting incidents over the past two years, exacerbated by post-pandemic economic pressures and inflationary cost-of-living rises. It is also noted that the regional Business Crime Crime Reduction Group has implemented a stage-based intervention scheme designed to flag repeat offenders earlier and link them to support, but resourcing gaps have limited its reach. It may be instructive at this point to refer to the decision in R v Marlow [2020] EWCA Crim 541, where a sentence of twelve months’ custody was imposed for repeated thefts from retailer premises involving thefts of goods used in drug consumption paraphernalia. While your offending is not linked to illicit substances, the principles of assessing harm and the need for deterrence remain analogous. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. Separate from your individual history, the court notes an unrelated case in which your co-defendant from a previous matter was convicted of affray during a street disturbance proximate to a community event. That conviction, while separate and not attributable to you, has nevertheless added complexity to the local policing operations and shed light on fragmented peer group influences. It further underlines the challenges authorities face in disentangling overlapping social and criminal networks. In addition, the environmental context of some incidents bears noting. The premises targeted include two independent stores that had previously been the subject of local authority noise abatement orders due to activities unrelated to the offences with which you are charged. While these administrative actions have no bearing on your culpability, they illustrate the complexity of community environments where low-level crime and civil regulatory enforcement intersect. Turning to previous case law, R v Collins [2018] EWCA Crim 2123 addressed possession of a bladed article in a school playground car park. While entirely distinct in subject and gravity, Collins highlights how the sentencing framework accommodates the presence or absence of aggravating factors such as potential for harm to vulnerable groups. This is reflective of sentencing principles that weigh the totality of circumstances rather than a narrow view of the predicate offence alone. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, said it was no different to borrowing and has no intention of stopping. In arriving at an appropriate sentence, the court observes the Sentencing Council’s Theft Offences Guideline (effective from 2022), which categorises offending based on factors including the value of stolen goods, the level of premeditation, the presence of aggravating circumstances such as targeting vulnerable victims or repeat offending, and the offender’s criminal history. The guideline emphasises the importance of considering the impact on victims and on public confidence. In your case, the frequency and deliberateness of the offending, the choice of relatively vulnerable retail premises, and the prior entreaties of the criminal justice system to desist cumulatively frame the offence as more serious than an isolated, one-off theft. Mitigating factors such as the late guilty plea and your stated personal difficulties are noted but must be balanced against public protection imperatives. This court is grateful for the detailed input received from Crown Prosecutor Ms Nia Patel and defence counsel Mr Simon Cranley, whose submissions were courteous, professional, and thorough. I also acknowledge the presence of the court usher, Mr Andrew Bridges, whose management of court staff and administration ensured the smooth running of today’s hearing despite a brief delay in the arrival of the interpreter services. Although this court operates within the Crown Court tier, pleasantly housed within the refurbished Middlesborough Justice Centre opened in 2019, space constraints continue to press on operational efficiency. Cases such as this, which require substantial evidential collation and expert involvement, remind us of the crucial role the Crown Court plays between the magistracy and the appellate courts in delivering proportionate justice. In closing, I must reiterate the fundamental principle that while contextual realities and personal hardship inform judicial discretion, they do not provide immunity from lawful sanction where repeated criminality undermines social trust and the security of local communities. Sentencing will be adjourned to allow for the preparation and consideration of a full pre-sentence report, which the probation service is instructed to compile. This report should particularly address the feasibility and appropriateness of community-based rehabilitative measures, including cognitive behavioural therapy tailored to acquisitive offending, engagement with financial advice services, and monitoring for potential substance dependency treatment pathways. The report shall also consider risk of reoffending and compliance prospects to inform any decision on custody versus a community order. These sentencing remarks are made this 14th day of September 2025 in Court 6 at the Crown Court at Middlesborough. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal against sentence or conviction within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged herein. The question of costs is reserved. These are the orders of the court.

While this case concerns repeated dishonesty, the court’s attention is drawn to the broader public safety regime in which sentences are delivered. Multi-agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), proven effective in managing offenders posing serious risks, operate alongside less formal structures such as Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conferences (MARAC). Though your offending does not presently engage these higher-tier protocols, the interface between policing, probation, and social services remains critical. Of additional interest is the ongoing strain on mental health services within Devon and Cornwall. Waiting lists for cognitive-behavioural therapy programs extend to several months longer than recommended by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE). This capacity gap complicates timely access to interventions for offenders exhibiting traits identified in psychiatric evaluations. It is a regrettable reality that social safety nets, strained by austerity measures and shifting policy priorities over the past decade, operate at or beyond capacity. Yet the court must maintain its focus on the individual accountability and legal standards central to sentencing. In concluding, I underscore that this court is neither dispassionate nor indifferent to the circumstances that cluster around cases such as this. Poverty, mental health challenges, and lack of stable housing are factors of undeniable consequence and deserving of robust state response. But such realities do not excuse or minimise culpable criminal acts. Following consideration of all materials before the court—including the probation report, psychiatric assessment, victim impact statements, and submissions by counsel—I reserve sentencing for a date to be fixed, pending the preparation of an updated pre-sentence report. It is my intention that the report provide a comprehensive appraisal of risk, personal circumstances, and proposed rehabilitative pathways. In particular, I wish the probation service to explore the feasibility of community-based sanctions incorporating structured programmes addressing impulsivity, substance misuse, and financial management. The goal is to recommend interventions proportionate to both your offending and the protection of the public. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Plymouth. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. You are advised of your right to appeal within a period of 28 days in accordance with section 108 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT LUTON R v. Mr H Case No. T2025/14638 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge G. Rutherford Filed: 9 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today to answer for a charge of theft, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, relating to the unlawful removal of goods from multiple retail establishments. The period of offending conducted in this matter spans from October 2023 through to April 2025, and is alleged to have taken place across various commercial districts in Luton and neighbouring Bedfordshire locales. Procedural Chronicle You were initially arrested on 12 April 2025 following the culmination of a multi-agency investigation involving the Luton Borough Police Retail Crime Unit and local trading standards officers. The investigation was instigated after a notable series of theft incidents, each involving small but cumulatively significant losses from retailers who had separately reported suspicious activity. Despite the seemingly minor value of individual thefts, the repetitive and methodical nature of the offences prompted enhanced scrutiny and coalescing of intelligence. Let the court pause for a moment to reflect on the broader institutional context within which such investigations unfold. The Retail Crime Unit, established in 2013 as a special branch within the local constabulary, has operated under fluctuating budgetary constraints and periodic realignments of priorities. Their remit, though ostensibly narrow, frequently encompasses a delicate balancing act involving the management of scarce manpower, fluctuating evidence quality, and the often competing interests of corporate and community stakeholders. The effectiveness of such units is, in part, dependent upon the willingness and capacity of retailers to engage in collaborative information-sharing. Unfortunately, the prevailing climate of economic uncertainty has led many small and medium-sized enterprises to adopt a more circumspect attitude toward reporting minor offences, fearing the administrative overhead or reputational harm that formal allegations may entail. This places greater pressure on police resources to identify and pursue offenders based on often incomplete or fragmentary data sets—a burden which, as is widely recognised, stretches frontline personnel thinly amid rising overall crime rates. Your initial interview on 13 April 2025 was conducted under caution. At that time, you denied all allegations, contesting involvement despite presentation of circumstantial evidence. Subsequent forensic analysis, however, demonstrated the presence of fibres and trace materials linking articles of clothing found in your possession with multiple reported incidents. Formal charge was preferred on 21 April 2025 with a single indictment consolidating representative counts from various premises for judicial economy. The case was swiftly transferred to this Crown Court and placed under the Better Case Management system, designed to expedite trial readiness through adherence to statutory or procedural timetables. This matter has seen the usual pre-trial hearings and disclosure applications, including several defence requests for further material that have occasioned modest delays. These have, however, been managed within tolerable parameters consistent with current judicial expectations. A plea and trial preparation hearing was convened on 15 July 2025. You again entered a not guilty plea at that juncture, opting to contest the evidence. Following receipt and service of supplementary CCTV evidence and witness statements indicating your movements within the implicated venues, you tendered a guilty plea on the morning of the scheduled trial, specifically on 7 September 2025. The court notes that this late change does not constitute the earliest possible acceptance of responsibility; as such, sentencing credit must be accorded with appropriate moderation in line with extant jurisprudence. The timing of pleas remains a crucial factor in sentencing decisions. The Court of Appeal in R v. Halvorsen [2023] EWCA Crim 1029, dealing with a series of serious arson offences, emphasized that a last-minute plea prompted by the imminent collapse of a defence, rather than demonstrable remorse or insight, attracts a reduced discount. While the gravity of the offences in Halvorsen starkly contrasts with the present matter, the emphasized principle—that timing is integral to the calculus of credit—translates. Accordingly, the court declines to treat your admission as meriting early plea credit. Additionally, precedent such as R v. Dacres [2021] EWCA Crim 1331, which involved the unlawful entry into a dwelling during overnight hours, offers insight into the consequences of upsetting the sanctuary of personal spaces. While no comparable intrusion is evident here, the underlying principle in regard to victim impact and the necessity of deterrence informs the court’s approach to your conduct. The law is clear: the dishonesty inherent in theft, particularly when recurrent and methodical, carries a public dimension that extends beyond immediate pecuniary loss. Such offending diminishes community trust, harms local businesses, and contributes incrementally to social disorder. A Note on the Court’s Physical Environment and Personnel It would be remiss not to acknowledge the recent refurbishment of Courtroom 5, undertaken over the summer recess. The improved layout affords greater comfort for all present and has been positively remarked upon by both judicial officers and counsel. The court also expresses gratitude to the ushering staff here, whose professionalism remains a constant assurance amid the often unpredictable demands of court business. Whilst the delay in seating the court clerk by a few minutes on this particular morning was inconvenient, it was nonetheless managed with characteristic good humour. Mr H, it must also be recorded with appreciation the efforts of your appointed counsel, Mr James Harland, instructed through the Legal Aid scheme. Despite systemic pressures within the Legal Aid Agency, which continue to result in frustrating bureaucratic delays and resource scarcity, Mr Harland has provided diligent representation, including the procurement of expert reports and the assembly of mitigating material. However, it is also appropriate to comment on the broader and persistent challenges faced by practitioners who must navigate an increasingly convoluted administrative landscape while ensuring defendants receive a fair and timely hearing. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. The delays occasioned by Legal Aid administrative procedures are regrettably familiar. Mr Harland’s application, for instance, to instruct a forensic behavioural analyst was initially submitted in May 2025 but not granted approval until late July following multiple requests for additional information. This delay hampered the defence’s ability to thoroughly investigate potential mitigating factors and contributed to the late plea submission. Such systemic bottlenecks are a cause for institutional concern, as they risk infringing defendants’ rights and undermining public confidence in the administration of criminal justice. A psychiatric report was commissioned from Dr Amanda Lenton, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist at the Bedfordshire Clinical Commissioning Group. Her assessment, conducted in July 2025, indicated no diagnosable major mental illness, but identified traits suggestive of impulsivity and related behavioural dysregulation. Dr Lenton further noted a history consistent with mild substance misuse, primarily alcohol, which appeared to have impacted judgment and decision-making in the periods surrounding some offences. It is significant—and not altogether surprising—in light of the widespread pressures on mental health services nationally, that access to appropriate support was limited in practice. Waiting times for substance misuse interventions in Bedfordshire currently stand at over twelve weeks, owing to underfunding and staffing shortages. The court must acknowledge the consequent systemic barriers to rehabilitation while emphasizing that the existence of unmet need cannot substantiate ongoing criminal conduct unaccompanied by concerted attempts at engagement. Mr H concealed boxed razor cartridges and a tub of protein powder beneath items in his niece’s pram. A report prepared by your assigned probation officer, Ms Fiona Elder, dated 25 August 2025, provides a thorough overview of your personal circumstances and risks. Ms Elder highlights your currently unstable housing situation—temporary accommodation provided through the County Council’s Transitional Housing Scheme—with associated social vulnerabilities. The report underscores your limited employment history and the absence of consistent support networks. Nevertheless, Ms Elder notes your expressed willingness to engage with structured rehabilitative programmes and recommends a community order incorporating elements of cognitive-behavioural therapy focused on impulsivity and acquisitive offending. Additionally, the potential for a debt management and financial literacy component is identified, whose intended effect would be to reduce criminogenic pressures stemming from economic instability. It bears noting that during the preparation of this report, Ms Elder encountered several administrative difficulties, including incomplete disclosure of prior offence records due to inter-departmental IT failures. These reflect ongoing challenges within probation and criminal justice agencies regarding data integration—a problem well documented in recent parliamentary oversight committee hearings. Across three weeks, Mr H visited the same small retailer four times, stealing alcohol and tobacco on each occasion. The Retail Support Network, an umbrella organisation dedicated to assisting businesses affected by shop theft, has submitted victim impact statements on behalf of several local outlets. The representatives express measured, yet firm acknowledgement of the burdens imposed by repeated loss, including the diversion of limited human resources toward security and inventory management, the psychological effect on frontline staff, and the resultant pressure to curtail opening hours or even close premises. The statements, while refraining from hyperbole, paint a picture of cumulative strain. Retail workers describe feeling “uneasy” and “undervalued,” with some citing the adoption of protective measures such as locking cabinets during open hours and staff rota alterations—all in response to circumstances occasioned by offenders like yourself. Such testimony adds valuable texture to the court’s understanding of harm beyond mere financial calculations. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. During the course of the investigation, a co-defendant was identified as being implicated in parallel offences involving aggravated assault at a separate location. Although sharing a nominal link, these charges and the associated evidence bear no connection to your conduct. That individual, currently remanded in custody pending trial for violence-related offences, has no bearing upon your culpability or sentencing. Similarly, other parties connected peripherally to the retail environments where you offended—such as shop employees or landlords—have been subject to unrelated inquiries, including a neighbour’s complaint regarding noise abatement and a dispute involving a tenancy agreement. These matters, though contemporaneous, fall outside the remit of the criminal proceedings presently before this court. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. In approaching your sentence, the court is guided principally by the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline for theft offences, published in 2022. This framework stresses the need to calibrate sentence severity according to the degree of planning, frequency of incidents, monetary value, offender’s culpability, and the impact on victims. The guideline underscores that repeat offending elevates culpability, even when individual acts may be low in financial magnitude. Key aggravating factors include targeting of vulnerable premises, such as community pharmacies or small traders, and the use of stratagems designed to defeat security measures. Conversely, mitigating factors may comprise genuine remorse, early guilty pleas, and demonstrable attempts at rehabilitation. Case law deserves reference to the decisions in R v. Latimer [2021] EWCA Crim 947 and R v. Haslow [2021] EWCA Crim 1754, which expound on the limitation of credit for late guilty pleas and the weight attributed to persistent offending patterns. These affirm the principle that the timing of a plea is a critical element in ensuring that sentencing reflects not only the offence but also procedural fairness and efficiency. The defendant told officers that he sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in nearby pubs, causing alarm to members of the public. The Court’s Observations on Public Safety and Rehabilitation The court is acutely conscious of the delicate balance between imposing a sentence that reflects the serious disruption caused to victims and the community, and promoting your rehabilitation so as to prevent reoffending. Society’s welfare depends as much on successful reintegration as it does on punishment. Recidivism continues to place unsustainable pressure on overstretched probation and social care services. Parliamentary reports have highlighted the growing attrition in preventive programmes, with certain participant groups receiving minimal ongoing support due to funding constraints. The consequences of this are evident in the continued cycling of individuals through the criminal justice system. Your case serves as a microcosm of these systemic challenges. The evidence before the court suggests that while no overt threats or violence were employed, your offending has had a real and repeated corrosive effect on the communities reliant on these retail businesses—not only economically, but in undermining ordinary social trust. This emphasises the need for a sentence that adequately acknowledges both culpability and the imperative of crime prevention. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. Your housing situation, presently one of tenuous temporary accommodation, is of undeniable relevance. The court is mindful of the ongoing crisis in affordable housing nationwide, exacerbated by inflationary pressures, supply shortfalls, and the aftereffects of prolonged pandemic-related disruption. Many local authorities report backlogs of hundreds of households awaiting placement, resulting in lengthy stays in short-term facilities such as hostels or converted hotels. However, it is imperative to stress that such adversity, while mitigating to some degree, cannot be allowed to obfuscate personal responsibility. Those who confront hardship with resilience and lawful conduct must not be overshadowed by those who resort to criminality. The court acknowledges the report from ShelterLink, a frontline charity actively working to support vulnerable adults in temporary housing, which was part of the defence submissions. Their advocacy is commendable, yet the reality remains that engagement with support services is facultative, and failure to do so diminishes its mitigating value. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, said it was no different to borrowing and has no intention of stopping. In conclusion, the court will proceed to direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report, incorporating consideration of rehabilitative options, appropriate community penalties, and custody risk assessments. This will enable an informed and nuanced sentencing decision at the forthcoming hearing. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 9 September 2025, in Court 5 at Luton Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal conviction or sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions are engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. MR H Case No. T2026/04831 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. A. Grimshaw Filed: 12 September 2026 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentencing in relation to multiple offences of theft from retail premises, committed over a sustained period and prosecuted under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending, as charged, principally concerns your involvement in shoplifting over a roughly eighteen-month period in and around Brighton and Hove city. Procedural History You were first identified as a suspect after a series of visits to several high-street chains and independent stores. The local Business Crime Reduction Partnership (BCRP), operating in coordination with Sussex Police and the Brighton & Hove Neighbourhood Policing Team, undertook an extensive collation of CCTV footage, staff accounts, and electronic point-of-sale discrepancy reports. The collective effort spanned a number of weeks in late 2025 into early 2026, highlighting a pattern of repeated theft involving small but consistent items from multiple premises. The case was initially allocated to the magistrates’ court at Brighton but transferred to this Crown Court for sentencing due to the number of indictable counts consolidated into a single representative charge. The Better Case Management (BCM) regime was engaged early, with listing of plea and trial preparation hearings within expected time frames. The matter then proceeded to pleas before this court. The multifaceted nature of this investigation required the diligent cooperation of multiple agencies. It remains a matter of record that despite pressures on staffing within the local policing units and the stretched resources of the BCRP—now operating with reduced funding approaching a five-year low—the collation and timely sharing of intelligence was relatively effective in this instance. On behalf of the court, I acknowledge these efforts, as well as the assistance provided by retail staff who furnished detailed victim impact statements outlining the cumulative effect of your offending on their working environments. It is regrettable, however, that the progress of these proceedings was, on two occasions, impeded by administrative delays. On 15 June 2026, the court was compelled to adjourn sentencing due to unresolved applications for funding in respect of a forensic psychological assessment, which ultimately was approved some four weeks after the initial request was submitted. Such delays are more than procedural inconveniences; they risk infringing on the principle of prompt justice, which underpins the Criminal Procedure Rules and wider constitutional guarantees. The Crown was represented throughout by Ms Yvonne Bennett, whom the court thanks for her clear and measured submissions. Mr James Thornton appeared for you, representing you under a statutory Legal Aid order, and conducted his duties with professionalism despite the systemic challenges posed by repeated funding refusals and slow responses from the Legal Aid Agency—a recurrent theme that the court notes with some frustration. The hearing today proceeded in open court, with full attendance. The courtroom layout, recently refurbished under a Heritage Lottery Fund scheme, provides a more accessible environment for all parties but unfortunately continues to experience occasional technical issues with microphone amplification and digital recording. The official transcript has nonetheless been diligently prepared by court staff, whose commitment to the integrity of court proceedings merits commendation. Within the preparatory material, this court has been provided with a detailed psychiatric report authored by Dr Margaret Lowe, consultant forensic psychiatrist, whose findings are characterful of the clinical fellowship she pursued at the Maudsley Hospital. Dr Lowe’s report is comprehensive, if at times overly technical, and provides an assessment relevant to your personal circumstances but ultimately does not diagnose a major mental illness warranting diversion to a hospital order or equivalent disposal. Equally, the report highlights fragile psychosocial circumstances, including long-term unemployment, intermittent engagement with treatment services, and symptoms indicative of mild to moderate depressive disorder. While such material is informative, it must be read alongside the established facts and the overarching framework guiding sentencing in cases of this nature. The court is broadly aware that nationally, retail crime figures show an increasing trend in shoplifting incidents, a challenge reported both by government statistics and retail watchdog bodies. The British Retail Consortium has noted a particular rise in the theft of healthcare and beauty products during the period under review, a trend mirrored locally. These patterns, while concerning, constitute part of a wider social phenomenon and should not be conflated with the conduct of individual defendants. It is further noted that the defendant’s own housing history, as outlined in the probation report dated 30 August 2026, reveals a precarious arrangement in temporary supported accommodation following a previous eviction from council stock. These housing dynamics are symptomatic of the broader housing crisis currently unfolding across the Southeast of England, where falling affordability and reduced social housing stock continue to exert pressure on vulnerable populations. Such context, while not excusing offending behaviour, is of undeniable relevance in understanding the circumstances in which offences may occur. Mr H was seen hiding £15 worth of over-the-counter medicines in his jacket and walking out without making a purchase. There is precedent for many facets of your conduct and history within the case law that informs judicial discretion. The decision in R v. Pearce [2019] EWCA Crim 1109 examined repeated thefts from multiple out-of-town retail outlets and outlined the balancing act between deterrence and rehabilitation. Pearce was ultimately sentenced to ten months’ custody, with the court citing the "cumulative impact on victim retailers and local economies" as justification for immediate custodial punishment despite the modest individual value of stolen goods. While your behaviour as established on the admitted facts shows parallels, each case must be assessed on its own merits. Meanwhile, the judgment in R v. Bantrell [2022] EWCA Crim 1628 serves as a reminder of the limited extent to which personal hardship factors may mitigate sentence. Although Bantrell, like yourself, suffered chronic unemployment and unstable accommodation, the Court of Appeal affirmed a sentence of community rehabilitation order with unpaid work, reflecting the absence of serious harm but recognising the need for court-led intervention to prevent recidivism. Such guidance informs this court’s approach in your case. A further case of note, R v. Fortescue [2021] EWCA Crim 1470, involved theft of pharmaceuticals from neighbourhood chemists. Fortescue employed distraction techniques and altered his appearance to evade detection. His custodial sentence was justified on the basis of the breach of trust and the heightened risk of harm where stolen medicines were diverted into the illicit market, potentially endangering vulnerable users. Though those facts differ from yours, the principle that even low-value theft may pose public dangers is instructive here. At the initial hearing on 7 May 2026, the court took care to observe the demands that such casework places on overstretched probation services. Indeed, a recent HM Inspectorate of Probation report highlighted a sector-wide challenge in resource allocation, with caseloads increasingly unmanageable and waiting lists for key programmes—such as abstinence-based substance misuse pathways—growing. The impact on sentencing outcomes and rehabilitative potential cannot be overstated. These institutional challenges are now woven into the fabric of criminal justice administration and must be borne in mind when considering mechanisms for intervention. It is important to acknowledge that the defendant’s personal background includes both engagement and detachment from available support systems. Letters submitted in your favour by local charity workers at the Open Door Centre commend your intermittent participation but also note episodes of disengagement, particularly during periods of housing instability. This court accepts that such oscillation is not uncommon among defendants facing structural hardships but also cautions that without consistent engagement, the efficacy of voluntary schemes is compromised. Mr H attempted to hide boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in the undercarriage of his niece’s pushchair. Historically, the Theft Act 1968 has served as the cornerstone legislative instrument governing offences such as the present. Its original framers could scarcely have anticipated the emergence of omnipresent surveillance technologies, digital payment methods, and automated inventory controls which current retailers deploy. The law’s enduring principles, however, remain constant in defining wrongful appropriation with the intent permanently to deprive. More recent sentencing guidelines issued by His Majesty’s Sentencing Council reflect an evolving understanding of the need to calibrate penalties according to harm and culpability rather than purely monetary valuation. Factors such as the vulnerability of victims, repeat offending, sophistication or premeditation, and impact upon community confidence are rightly emphasised. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. In an unrelated but contemporaneous case in this circuit, R v. Stonebrook [2025] EWCA Crim 901, the defendant was convicted of involvement in fly-tipping hazardous waste—much of which was asbestos-laden—within a protected green belt area. Stonebrook's conduct, unrelated to retail or shoplifting offences, attracted a considerable custodial sentence underscoring the courts’ increasing unwillingness to countenance environmental degradation. That case had, however, no bearing on the defendant currently before this court but demonstrates the breadth of sentencing practice across offence categories. This court must also express concern about the slow but steady rise in acquisitive crimes in the Brighton area—many linked to the growth of social media marketplaces and informal economies for the resale of stolen goods. The effect on smaller local businesses, already grappling with the pressures of the post-pandemic economic environment, is salutary. The cumulative disruption from repeated petty theft is a factor appropriately weighted in sentencing. The retail sector’s resilience is not inexhaustible. The Crown proffered victim impact statements from seven separate premises, chiefly independent pharmacies and grocery stores. One manager described the atmosphere in her store as markedly tense during your visits, with part-time staff reportedly requesting additional security or avoiding shifts overlapping with your known patterns. A broad though indirect psychological impact is evident and must be taken seriously, even if your behaviour did not amount to physical or verbal aggression. The probation report notes a history of poly-substance misuse dating back some years but records your recent abstention from illicit drugs, corroborated by local community drug service attendance data. It raises the possibility of an impulsivity-related vulnerability but finds that you retain the capacity for decision-making and responsibility-taking. Nevertheless, it identifies that your pattern of offending, while not violent, is symptomatic of underlying instability and the absence of sustained protective factors. Mr H created a distraction by asking about Oyster Cards and took advantage of the moment to remove a display item from behind the counter. In reaching this stage of proceedings, I must also mention the involvement of the community social work team. In correspondence received from Ms Patricia Leverett, a caseworker at Brighton Support Plus, it is evident that while efforts at engagement have been made, resource constraints have limited their capacity to maintain frequent contact. Such letters attest to the systemic difficulties in providing wraparound services in a context of demand outstripping supply. Further complicating factors are your reported episodic non-compliance with medication prescribed for depressive symptoms, as outlined by a community psychiatric nurse in her report dated 28 August 2026. This absence of adherence is often observed in clinical practice and may aggravate emotional volatility and judgment errors. However, in the absence of evidence of serious mental illness or psychosis, this does not constitute a mitigating factor sufficient to offset your culpability. A magnet was used by The defendant to detach a security tag, and this item was found in his possession at the time of his arrest. It is noteworthy that your criminal record includes previous convictions for shoplifting dating back eight years, with an interval of apparent desistance interrupted by a recent resurgence beginning in late 2024. A community resolution was administered in 2023 following a theft from a supermarket but with limited sustained effect. This reflects a pattern of offending behaviour that the courts and agencies have sought to disrupt through a variety of means, including caution, community sentences, and referral to rehabilitative programming. Regrettably, those interventions have not produced the desired outcome. The court has also had regard to a recent decision in R v. Ealing [2024] EWCA Crim 1122, where an offender with a similar profile—multiple theft convictions, substance misuse history, and sporadic engagement with support services—was given an immediate custodial sentence because community sentences had demonstrably failed to deter repeated offending over a protracted period. While this case is factually distinct, it illustrates the courts’ responses to recidivism in acquisitive crime. The defendant told officers that he sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in nearby pubs, causing alarm to members of the public. At an earlier hearing the defendant’s counsel submitted a series of letters from family members and community advocates highlighting financial hardship, childhood adversity, and statements of remorse. These documents were duly considered but, as always, require cautious interpretation given the laudable but inevitably partial perspective they represent. Alongside the more formal submissions, this court notes that your letter to the court was thoughtfully composed, clearly conveying regret. Such gestures have their place but must be weighed against the nature of the offending and the broader public interest. It is a regrettable fact of contemporary criminal justice that repeat offenders frequently express contrition only when faced with overwhelming evidence, offering little prior engagement or acceptance of responsibility. Advanced guilty pleas are accordingly incentivised by the sentencing framework to reward prompt recognition of wrongdoing and to reduce the distress caused to victims and witnesses. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. The court also acknowledges the restrained and professional manner in which the defence has conducted its representation, notwithstanding the obstacles posed by slow authorisation of expert instructions via Legal Aid and the administrative burden of coordinating multiple reports, letters, and support statements. The delicate dance between defending a client’s rights and facilitating effective justice is one that practitioners manage daily, often with little public recognition. Of note, the defence have respectfully highlighted your expressed desire to participate in a structured rehabilitation and employment reintegration programme following sentence. Whether such an approach proves viable can only be evaluated after the receipt of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. In a somewhat tangential matter, it may be recorded that the co-defendant in an unrelated trial currently before this court was found to have possessed a bladed article in a school car park—charges unrelated to your case but indicative of the wide range of offences encountered within this jurisdiction. This does not reflect upon your conduct but demonstrates the breadth of criminal activity that occupies the courts. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, doesn't view his actions as theft and intends to keep doing so. The court must balance several factors, including the seriousness of the offending, the culpability and previous record of the defendant, the impact on victims and the community, and the prospects for rehabilitation. Public protection and deterrence are central. The Sentencing Council’s guidelines stress that persistent acquisitive offending, especially when accompanied by raising fear or anxiety among retail staff, warrants firm response. Equally, where there is evidence of underlying vulnerabilities, support and intervention are necessary to reduce future harm. As has been judicially affirmed in R v. Grayson [2023] EWCA Crim 1754, sentences should be tailored to address offending behaviour but also cognisant of systemic challenges such as social deprivation and service availability. While society must show compassion, it cannot abdicate responsibility for upholding standards of lawful conduct. This court has carefully reviewed all available reports and submissions, and while mindful of your personal circumstances, must not lose sight of the seriousness of a course of conduct that betrays both trust and community cohesion. The availability of community-based programmes with a cognitive-behavioural element remain a significant mitigating element if they can be relied upon to reduce risk. However, given your history of intermittent engagement and prior unsuccessful community sentences, custodial options are a distinct possibility. Accordingly, I direct that a pre-sentence report be prepared, including a risk assessment and tailored intervention plan. The Probation Service is also requested to consider any suitable mental health or addiction treatment referrals, as well as vocational training prospects that might support post-sentence reintegration. These matters will be considered fully at the sentence hearing scheduled for 20 October 2026. This court reserves final determination until receipt and review of the comprehensive pre-sentence report and any further representations from all parties. This concludes the sentencing remarks issued at the Crown Court at Brighton in Court 4, dated 12 September 2026. The proceedings have been transcribed and are recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. Reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are not engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BELVEDERE R v. Mr H Case No. T2025/14689 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge R. F. Winslow Filed: 4 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence on a representative charge of theft contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, relating to a series of thefts from multiple retail outlets within the metropolitan area between September 2023 and May 2025. The indictment concerns a course of conduct characterised by repeated appropriations of goods without payment, bringing you within the purview of this court’s jurisdiction in respect of persistent acquisitive offending of a degree justifying Crown Court trial and sentencing. Procedural History The journey to this point has been protracted, as is often the case with such matters involving low-level but persistent offending. Your initial arrest occurred on 28 May 2025, following the conclusion of a lengthy investigation conducted by the Belvedere Metropolitan Police Service alongside the local Retail Crime Task Force. The multi-agency collaboration involved regular communication with store security teams, the Business Crime Reduction Partnership (BCRP), and community safety officers, thereby illustrating the increasingly complex ecosystem in which such offences are now managed. It merits noting that the co-operation, while not exceptional, was sufficient to collate a substantial evidential package in good time, facilitating your eventual charge and case progression. The criminal justice process in cases of this nature has, over recent years, become entangled with multiple layers of administrative and procedural complexity. For example, while the Better Case Management scheme was designed to curtail delay and duplication, the experience to date has been mixed. Here, the case navigated several listings, including a plea and trial preparation hearing held on 21 July 2025, followed by adjournments required to facilitate forensic expert reports and defence submissions. These delays mirror a broader trend, noted in recent justice sector reviews, of escalating listing pressures in Crown Courts outside of central London, exacerbated by staffing shortages in both the judiciary and court administrative staff. The scheduling constraints have impacted the timely initiation of sentence preparation work, a regrettably frequent feature in this jurisdiction. It is necessary to acknowledge that the Legal Aid Agency’s administrative procedures caused further postponements. An initial application to instruct an independent forensic behavioural analyst was submitted by your counsel on 15 June 2025 but experienced considerable delay before eventual approval on 4 August 2025. This delay, though unfortunate, is emblematic of systemic issues well-documented elsewhere, involving backlogs, stringent vetting requirements, and limited resources at the Agency. The attendant disruption to case readiness is a matter of concern, not least because it impedes the full investigative and therapeutic potential of expert input in cases involving underlying vulnerabilities or complex personal histories. The plea hearing on 3 September 2025 saw you enter a guilty plea to the representative count. It is neither unusual nor unexpected that pleas in shoplifting cases are entered late, often at the point when evidential certainty becomes overwhelming. While no doubt a feature of reasonable defence strategy, the court is, as ever, mindful that credit for guilty plea is contingent on early admissions of guilt which materially reduce the burden on victims, witnesses, and the court system itself. The present plea does not therefore attract maximal reduction, as will be considered further below. The Theft Act 1968, as amended, continues to be the foundational statutory provision governing the offence of theft. Section 1 articulates the essential elements — the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another, with the intention to permanently deprive the owner — each component carefully defined and judicially refined in a body of case law spanning decades. It is unnecessary to rehearse exhaustively the well-trodden principles; suffice to emphasise that the accumulation, frequency, and manner of offending constitute key aggravating factors within the applicable sentencing frameworks. Recent sentencing guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council provide structure to the court’s discretion, setting indicative ranges and emphasizing context, culpability, and harm. The guidelines recognise that shoplifting, while often associated with low individual value, can entail considerable cumulative harm, especially where targeting vulnerable or independent retailers or exploiting repeat opportunities. Also relevant is the framework established by R v. Sinclair [2019] EWCA Crim 1057, which underscores that persistence and deliberate evasion reflect a heightened degree of culpability. Likewise, R v. Harcourt [2021] EWCA Crim 1523 is instructive for the principle that offences liable to attract custodial sentences negate the presumption that theft under a certain monetary threshold is a matter for summary disposal only. This court is alive to the wider social policy ambitions embedded in Lord Justice Kay’s observations in R v. Waine [2016] EWCA Crim 63, where emphasis was placed on the underlying needs of defendants, including poverty-induced pressures, while maintaining the primacy of public protection and victim impact considerations. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. It bears emphasis that persistent offending yields disproportionate cost to the criminal justice system and commercial targets alike. In this case, police resourcing extended to the deployment of a dedicated task force examining eleven incident reports across the greater Belvedere retail sector, engaging five different store chains. This reflects the intensity of the police response which, although involving staff drawn away from other duties, was necessary due to the pattern of activity and the community concerns voiced. Mr H attempted to hide boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in the undercarriage of his niece’s pushchair. The facts establishing guilt — through a combination of surveillance footage, witness testimony, and forensic examination of recovered items — disclose a pattern of conduct involving the strategic selection of goods, repeated visits to target premises, and methodical concealment techniques. This was not a series of isolated misjudgements or momentary lapses, but a calculated endeavour to benefit from unlawful acquisition. Deborah Whittle, Probation Officer, prepared a pre-sentence report in advance of the sentencing hearing and provided a detailed account of your social and psychological background. The report notes a history of intermittent employment primarily in the retail and hospitality sectors, disrupted by periods of unstable accommodation and financial insecurity. The report also highlights episodes of self-reported anxiety and depressive symptoms, though no formal diagnosis of major mental illness has been established. It is well recognised that the pressures of precarious employment markets and insecure housing, coupled with economic uncertainty, create a fertile environment for acquisitive crimes of this nature. However, as the Court of Appeal emphasised in R v. Patterson [2018] EWCA Crim 3035, personal circumstances do not excuse offending, nor diminish the need for clear judicial responses to protect victims, ensure public confidence, and deter future misconduct. Mr H was recorded returning to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time taking alcohol and tobacco goods. The psychological assessment appended to the probation dossier was completed by Dr Marcus Fenwick, Consultant Clinical Psychologist, whose report admits certain cognitive and emotional vulnerabilities, including impulsivity and social anxiety, but excludes evidence of any axis one disorder sufficiently severe to markedly impair criminal responsibility. Dr Fenwick cautiously flagged a low-to-medium risk of reoffending, contingent upon stable accommodation and engagement with supportive services. The profession’s incremental shift towards trauma-informed practice has underscored the importance of understanding defendants’ backgrounds. Yet, as Dr Fenwick notes, “The availability of voluntary sector support and statutory services is necessary but not sufficient in itself to prevent offending. Engagement and motivation are critical factors.” Your reported history is marred by sporadic attendance at appointments and reluctance to pursue employment or structured rehabilitation pathways. The court acknowledges your family connections, including extended relations residing locally, but notes that these relationships appear to afford minimal social capital or motivational leverage. While personal letters submitted on your behalf, including one from a pastoral care worker and another from a long-standing volunteer at a community food bank, are commendably conciliatory, their content does not materially diminish the nature or impact of the offending. It is appropriate at this juncture to reflect more broadly on the social framing of such offending patterns. We find ourselves amid a nexus of social policy tensions — welfare reform, austerity, and fluctuating economic fortunes — each feeding into the mosaic shaping individuals’ choices. Nevertheless, the court cannot abdicate responsibility for ensuring that criminal liability adheres to notions of personal agency and accountability. Extensive discourse and research into ‘broken communities’ and systemic failures abound, yet the judiciary must apply legal standards without succumbing to sociological relativism. Mr H created a distraction by asking about Oyster Cards and took advantage of the moment to remove a display item from behind the counter. A further point of interest is the manner in which retail premises have adapted operationally to the challenges posed by recurrent offending. This includes the installation of additional electronic tagging systems, more frequent rearrangement of product displays, and staff rotation measures to mitigate risks of targeting. While these responses are operationally justifiable, they carry unintended consequences, including staff stress, reduced shopping convenience, and, potentially, the diminution of the local retail environment. The local Business Crime Reduction Partnership has provided evidence detailing the extent of these measures and their cost implications. Notably, the partnership reported a 12% increase in shoplifting incidents over the past year, necessitating a commensurate increase in resource allocation towards preventative strategies — resources which could otherwise be deployed to combat violent crime or more serious offences. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. Of interest to the court is the observation, drawn from recent policing reports, that a disproportionate number of persistent offenders of this nature reside in areas of socio-economic deprivation, often lacking stable tenancy and grappling with mental health and substance misuse issues. These factors undoubtedly complicate enforcement responses. However, failure to heed these realities would be neither honest nor consonant with principles of justice. The sentencing aims, as articulated in statutory frameworks and affirmed by the Court of Appeal in cases such as R v. Wells [2024] EWCA Crim 85, remain deterrence, retribution, rehabilitation, and the protection of the public. The challenge lies in balancing these sometimes competing purposes without abdicating judicial responsibility or capitulating to external pressures. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. The impact upon victims is neither theoretical nor insignificant. Whilst no physical harm was occasioned, the disruption and distress experienced by retail staff has been well-documented. Several employees provided statements attesting to feelings of insecurity, anxiety, and reduced job satisfaction, prompting altered shift patterns and absences. One witness recounted experiencing harassment following identification and publicisation of their role in reporting offences. Such secondary consequences emphasize the ripple effects of shoplifting beyond monetary loss alone. The voluntary sector organisations engaged in victim support have supplemented these accounts with data revealing a sustained decline in staff wellbeing metrics and exacerbated workplace stress in affected outlets. These effects, though not quantifiable in the conventional sense, resonate deeply within the communities concerned. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. It is appropriate, in the context of shoplifting sentencing, to consider restorative avenues where practicable. In this instance, however, efforts to arrange such meetings have foundered, with little meaningful engagement forthcoming from your side. This limits the court’s ability to account for remedial dialogue in mitigation. I would be remiss not to note the existence of several co-defendants in connected investigations concerning unrelated offences—from fly-tipping on greenbelt land to allegations of affray at a local public house. These separate matters lie beyond the scope of these proceedings and have no bearing on your culpability or sentencing. It is a salutary reminder of the broad spectrum of acquisitive and disorderly conduct encountered by the criminal justice system contemporaneously. The court also notes that a neighbour in your building is currently subject to a noise abatement order following complaints to the local council. This is manifestly irrelevant to your own case but reflects the broader context in which these proceedings unfold. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. In assessing risk of harm to the public, it must be acknowledged that you do not pose a significant violent danger. No evidence of aggression or threat towards staff has emerged. Nonetheless, the persistence and methodical nature of the offending illustrate a degree of calculated disregard for legal proscriptions and social norms that justifies firm sentencing response. The criminal justice system’s obligations extend beyond punishment. Engagement with rehabilitation services, including cognitive behavioural programmes aimed at addressing offending behaviour and underlying motivations, offers a path to reduced recidivism. The National Probation Service, within its current resource constraints and staffing pressures detailed in internal reports, has indicated willingness to prioritise your case for inclusion in such programmes, subject to your cooperation. Historical references to the Sentencing Council’s guidance on theft offences emphasise the dichotomy between first-time or low culpability offenders and those exhibiting repeat, planned offending. The latter group, which includes you, must expect sentences calibrated for both individual deterrence and collective protection. In conclusion, these sentencing remarks are made following careful consideration of all pleadings, reports, victim impact statements, and submissions of counsel. The court is grateful to Mr Olivier Kessler, appearing for the Crown, and Ms Caroline Stokes, representing the defence under a Legal Aid representation order. The detailed pre-sentence report, alongside expert psychological input, has been invaluable in shaping the court’s understanding of your personal circumstances and risks. The court regrets the unavoidable delays occasioned by administrative and procedural bottlenecks but must nevertheless proceed with a sentencing disposition consistent with public interest. Sentencing will be deferred until the receipt of an updated pre-sentence report, to be completed by your probation officer. That report should address all avenues of community disposal, including the potential for structured interventions to address acquisitive behaviour and underlying vulnerabilities, the feasibility of supervision requirements, and any custodial alternatives. The court will consider any submissions concerning potential restorative justice engagement, local accommodation options, and support services. This judgment is delivered in open court, at the Crown Court at Belvedere, Court 5, on this the 4th day of October 2025. The proceedings have been recorded in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal against sentence within 28 days under the provisions of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions pursuant to the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are in place. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
