input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT WESTMINSTER R v. MR H Case No. 2025/45837 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. J. Barrington Filed: 14 August 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence upon a charge arising under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, specifically concerning shoplifting offences committed over a protracted period. The prosecutorial material describes incidents involving various retail premises located within the Westminster and Kensington areas, spanning from late 2023 through the early months of 2025. This case encapsulates a sustained course of unlawful conduct, warranting meticulous judicial consideration not only of the facts but also the broader social and procedural context surrounding your prosecution. Procedural History and Institutional Context The present proceedings have been notable for a sequence of hearing dates and procedural steps, reflective of both the court’s case management protocols and the complexities inherent in this particular prosecution. Initially charged in January 2025, your case was allocated to the Crown Court following a referral from Magistrates’ Court in March of that year, pursuant to the parameters established for offences where custody might be anticipated. A plea and trial preparation hearing was convened on 22 March 2025; at that time, you entered a not guilty plea. Thereafter, it is of record that multiple applications for evidential disclosure and forensic analysis were made, resulting in adjournments across three occasioned dates: namely, 15 April, 10 June, and 6 July 2025. Partly, these were attributable to delays in the processing and reporting of CCTV evidence from the various establishments victimised, compounded by the administrative backlog within the Metropolitan Police Service’s Digital Evidence Unit. I note with a measure of frustration—and indeed sympathy for all those involved—that such delays are by no means uncommon in cases of comparable complexity across the criminal justice system. The evolving reliance on digital evidence, while invaluable, brings its own challenges, notably in ensuring timely and robust disclosure. Furthermore, it is acknowledged in the documentation before this court that liaison between prosecuting counsel, the business crime partnership initiatives active in Westminster, and Safer Neighbourhood Teams, has been consistent, albeit compromised on occasion by staff turnover within these agencies. This state of flux is symptomatic of the wider strains imposed by budget constraints and workforce attrition in policing and local authority services. The local borough’s Business Crime Reduction Partnership, primarily funded by retail levy contributions, operates within these constraints yet has nevertheless provided victim impact statements that articulate the operational ramifications of persistent shop theft on their members. Regrettably, I must report that the Legal Aid Agency’s handling of the defence’s application to instruct a forensic psychiatrist experienced in compulsive-acquisitive behaviour was subject to avoidable delays. The initial request, submitted on 12 May 2025 by Mr Owen Clarke of Chambers at 12 New Square, was met with a protracted sequence of administrative queries and requests for clarification before approval was granted on 19 June 2025. Such bureaucratic inertia places undue strain on all parties and, more importantly, may impair the timely preparation and fair presentation of a defendant’s case. There is a developing consensus among legal practitioners of the need for reform to expedite these essential assessments when expert opinion is crucial to sentencing. A psychiatric assessment, the results of which are contained in Dr Fiona McIntyre’s detailed report of 20 July 2025, was subsequently furnished to the court and Probation Service. Dr McIntyre’s reflections have informed the present sentencing considerations to a significant degree. During the plea and trial preparation hearing of 5 August 2025, you altered your plea to guilty in respect of a representative charge embodying a course of conduct constituting numerous individual incidents of shoplifting. The court notes the timing of this plea—a matter to which I will return. It is well established that the fundamental elements of theft require a finding of dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with an intention to permanently deprive, as laid out in the Theft Act 1968. Shoplifting, particularly when repeated or planned, carries serious repercussions not merely for the direct victims but for wider community confidence in the rule of law and commercial safety. InR v. Stainton [2019] EWCA Crim 1255, the Court of Appeal emphasised the multifactorial impact of burglary and theft offences, noting that the emotional toll on victims extends beyond economic loss to encompass feelings of violation and vulnerability. Although shoplifting often involves lower monetary values, the Court acknowledged that repeated breaches, especially targeting small retailers or those with limited security infrastructure, carry enhanced seriousness. Similarly, the guidance provided in the Sentencing Council’s Theft Offences Definitive Guideline (December 2019) remains authoritative. The guideline instructs courts to assess culpability and harm with reference to deterioration of victim confidence, potential for disruption of business, and the defendant’s prior history and intent. The Court is further mindful of R v. Elwood [2020] EWCA Crim 1378, which explored the parameters of credit allowable for a late guilty plea. The decision underscores that while credit for guilty plea incentivises early admissions, reduction in sentencing must correlate with meaningful acceptance of responsibility rather than tactical delay. It is perhaps germane to recall the statutory framework of the Courts and Legal Services Act 1990 regulating the structure of sentencings, which the court must balance alongside the guidance offered by case law. The role of the probation officer’s pre-sentence report remains invaluable in understanding the rehabilitative prospects and necessary public protection measures. Mr H was seen slipping £11 worth of personal hygiene products into his jacket before leaving the shop without paying. While the detailed averments concerning the offences stand largely uncontested, the court is mindful that the factual matrix presented is not isolated but rather interwoven with broader issues of community safety, resource allocation, and offender management. It is instructive to remind the court of established jurisprudence concerning the nexus between shoplifting and other societal factors. For example, R v. Clough [2017] EWCA Crim 2106 considered the connection between acquisitive crimes and underlying mental health conditions, cautioning against simplistic causal assumptions but recognising legitimate mitigating circumstances where appropriate. The social setting of repeated shoplifting in high-density urban environments is likewise of interest in academic criminological discourse. The interplay of economic hardship, entrenched disadvantage, and social exclusion pathways has been noted in the recent Home Office research report titled “Acquisitive Crime: Patterns and Causes” (February 2024), which reiterates the consequences for local retail ecosystems and consumer confidence. Mr H hid boxed razor blades and protein powder among his niece’s belongings in her pram. Significant weight is accorded to the statements and submissions received from the affected retailers. Notably, a consortium of independent chemists and food stores operating in the affected boroughs have documented the difficulties posed by repeated theft, including the need for increased security arrangements and suffering tangible business losses. The Westminster Retail Victim Support Network, which offers assistance to staff through trauma-informed interventions, submitted a statement describing increased levels of anxiety and stress among employees following repeated incidents attributable to the defendant. Such psychological and operational fallout, though intangible, is consequential and factors into the assessment of harm for sentencing purposes. Moreover, the court recognises the work of organisations such as the Public Realm Initiative, which has highlighted street-level disorder linked to acquisitive offending and its contribution to a perceived decline in local amenity and public safety. There is, it must be said, a growing impatience among the public with respect to persistent theft and antisocial behaviour, demanding appropriate responses from courts and enforcement agencies alike. The court also acknowledges the role of the Metropolitan Police Service’s Theft Deterrence Unit, established to tackle prolific shoplifting offenders through intelligence-led patrols and community engagement. The unit’s case records in Mr H’s interactions note his profile as a repeat low-level offender, resistant to prior diversionary efforts. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. Dr McIntyre’s psychiatric evaluation is detailed, professionally composed, and duly observed by this court. It identifies no diagnosable major mental illness but notes the presence of traits suggestive of compulsive acquisitive behaviour and impulsivity. The report highlights a lack of engagement with support services despite multiple offers by social workers and community outreach programmes. The probation pre-sentence report supplements this context, painting a picture of Mr H as a man currently unemployed, under considerable financial and housing stress, residing temporarily within a local authority-managed hostel with limited stability. The report further recommends targeted cognitive-behavioural interventions and possible participation in a diversion-to-work scheme designed to address underlying criminogenic needs. I note with some regret that Housing Support Services have been hampered by chronic underfunding, with long waiting lists for stable accommodation compounding the vulnerability of offenders such as yourself. Similarly, the local Substance Misuse Service, although offered, has noted patchy attendance and engagement from you over the past 12 months. Understandably, in this court’s experience, the efficacy of community-based sentences depends greatly upon the cooperation and motivation of the individual. Delivery of rehabilitative programmes is frequently challenged not only by individual circumstances but by systemic pressures on probation and health services. On one occasion, Mr H asked staff about Oyster Card payments as a distraction, then leaned behind the counter to take a display item. Turning to legal representation, I record appreciation for counsel on both sides. Ms Eleanor Finch, appearing for the Crown, provided comprehensive and measured submissions. Similarly, Mr Owen Clarke, instructed on Legal Aid, advanced a robust defence emphasising mitigating factors, hardship, and remorse. Both counsel have conducted themselves with commendable professionalism despite the administrative hurdles faced. It is regrettable that the Legal Aid Agency’s protracted engagement with applications for expert reports and representation orders added delay to these proceedings, as noted earlier. This pattern has been lamented by practitioners across the criminal justice system and warrants ongoing attention from policymakers. The defendant removed a security tag using a magnet, which was later recovered during his arrest. It is worth observing that the Better Case Management system, introduced in 2017 with the laudable goal of expediting case disposal and enhancing procedural efficiency, assisted in the structured progression of this matter. However, notwithstanding this, three adjournments for expert assessments and disclosure prevented a swift conclusion. I also note the incremental value of the Business Crime Reduction Partnership, which, despite chronic underresourcing, manages a commendable coordination effort, including the dissemination of offender profiles to local shops and training for staff in incident handling and deterrence. These efforts, while valuable, can only go so far without systemic support. Another procedural footnote: an adjournment scheduled for 2 July 2025 was necessitated by the unavailability of the court linguistic interpreter initially instructed to assist with interviews of witnesses whose primary language is Polish. The last-minute nature of the request reflects systemic shortages in interpreter resources, an issue the judiciary routinely encounters but is beyond the power of this court to resolve. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. The court also notes, with no direct relevance to this case, the conviction of a co-accused individual in a separate affair relating to aggravated burglary in Croydon, who was found to be in unlawful possession of a bladed article on school grounds. Although that conviction is unrelated to Mr H’s matters, it reminds the court of the importance of clearly distinguishing facts as they pertain to each defendant. Similarly, a set of charges involving the fly-tipping of waste on green belt land in the Oxfordshire district, which was heard contemporaneously in another Crown Court, presents an example of environmental offences prosecuted robustly in recent months, but which do not reflect on the culpability or the circumstances herein. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. Much turns on the seriousness of the offending, the harm caused, the degree of planning or sophistication, the defendant’s antecedents, and his prospects for rehabilitation. While no allegation of violence exists, the repeated nature of the thefts, the impact upon victim confidence, and the persistence despite previous warnings and interventions, all serve to elevate culpability. The court must balance the need for punishment and deterrence with the principles of rehabilitation and the protection of the public. As reflected in the guidelines, community sentences incorporating rehabilitative components remain appropriate where feasible, provided compliance is likely and public protection assured. Despite the absence of serious psychiatric disorder, the traits noted by Dr McIntyre, together with the probation assessment, suggest that intervention could mitigate the risk of reoffending. This court endorses, therefore, the exploration of cognitive skills training and support addressing impulsivity and acquisitive patterns. The timing of the plea, while not immediate, is nonetheless made prior to trial. While such a late plea may attract a reduction in sentencing credit compared to an early admission, it nevertheless represents an acceptance which this court recognises for its procedural benefits. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. In concluding these remarks, I wish to place on the record my appreciation for the commendable efforts of the Victim Support Liaison Officers, whose work in engaging with both victims and defendants reflects the evolving ethos of restorative justice. Their outreach in this case was both thorough and sensitive. I also take this opportunity to commend the court staff and ushers in Court 5 at the Westminster Crown Court, who, despite recent refurbishment efforts and occasional staffing shortages, have maintained a standard of order and efficiency deserving of mention. I must finally note that the price of persistent acquisitive offending is not borne solely by those prosecuted or their immediate victims. It extends to public services struggling to keep pace with demand, from stretched police forces to probation officers juggling escalating caseloads, from mental health teams confronting rising referrals to local authorities grappling with housing shortages. The retail sector itself, however willing to partner with law enforcement, faces its own pressures: cost inflation, supply chain disruption, and the need to invest in security technologies all converge to create a challenging environment. These externalities, while not determinative of sentence, form the backdrop to the court’s assessment. Having set out the contextual and procedural tapestry in which this case is embedded, the court must now turn to sentence. I hereby order the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by the National Probation Service. This report is to explore all available options for sentencing, including the suitability of a Community Order with Rehabilitation Activity Requirement, attendance at cognitive behavioural intervention programmes, housing support plans, and assessments of compliance risk. The report should also take account of current public health advice, particularly in relation to scheduling interventions amidst fluctuating Covid-19 infection rates and any consequent service provision challenges. This court will schedule an early sentencing hearing upon receipt of the report. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT WINDSOR R v. MR H Case No. WX2025/14679 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. R. Ellington Filed: 12 August 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentence on the charge of theft, specifically shoplifting, brought under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The charge reflects a representative offence encapsulating a series of incidents occurring between November 2023 and April 2025, primarily within retail premises situated in the boroughs of Windsor, Maidenhead, and Slough. Procedural History Your prosecution followed a lengthy multi-agency operation spearheaded by the Windsor Retail Security Partnership (WRSP), which, responding to an observed rise in retail theft reports, embarked upon an intelligence-led forum aiming to reduce the prevalence of store burglaries and shoplifting incidents across the region. Data from business CCTV systems, coupled with police incident reports, informed the identification of suspect profiles, leading to a concentrated focus on individuals exhibiting patterns of repeated offending in high-footfall commercial zones. This operational model aligns with practices advocated by the Home Office Business Crime Strategy (2022), despite its known limitations regarding inter-agency communication and funding constraints. The investigative phase was characterised by protracted surveillance activities encompassing coordination with transport authorities, including an unauthorized scrutiny of public transit usage data — conducted under recently issued judicial authority in compliance with the Investigation Powers Act 2016 — as well as engagement with retail loss-prevention teams. The procedural intricacies inherent in this coordinated approach speak to the broader challenges faced by law enforcement in combating acquisitive offences without recourse to more overtly coercive investigative tactics. It bears noting that while the WRSP metadata analysis came under internal review for data retention compliance during the period in question, no procedural improprieties were identified materially affecting the investigatory outcome. Conversely, the length of the investigation inevitably placed additional strain upon frontline police resources, arguably detracting from higher priority assignments. However, the court must emphasise that the principle of equality before the law necessitates such proportional allocation of attention, regardless of the perceived gravity of the offence. Your initial interview under caution took place on 14 May 2025 at Windsor Police Station. This followed your apprehension on 10 May, a date memorialised in a letter from District Inspector Sarah Coleman to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), which commends the diligent cross-referencing of offences that yielded your identification as the principal suspect. During this interview, you elected not to engage further than providing your name and address, exercising your right to silence. Post-charge, however, you entered a guilty plea at the Plea and Case Management Hearing on 20 June 2025. The court is mindful that the case progressed under the Better Case Management regime, adhering generally to the Criminal Procedure Rules’ indicative timelines despite some documented challenges posed by short-staffing and the need to afford Legal Aid applications the requisite scrutiny. I must observe, with no small measure of frustration, that the Legal Aid Agency’s handling of your defence authorisation presented avoidable complications. Specifically, the request to instruct an independent forensic psychologist was initially refused in May 2025 due to misclassified eligibility criteria, only rectified after the intervention of your appointed counsel, Mr Benjamin Callow, following a prolonged correspondence extending into early June. Such delays, while regrettably frequent elsewhere, invariably prejudice timely access to expert opinion and inhibit comprehensive case preparation. These systemic inefficiencies risk diluting the rights of defendants and, by extension, the integrity of the courtroom process. The trial listing itself experienced a curtailed rescheduling due to a minor administrative oversight involving court staff deployment on 17 July 2025, which, while of no lasting consequence to you, underscores the pressures endured by the judicial system in the current climate of resource constraint. In examining your prior record, it is necessary to situate your history within the context of relatively limited, yet not insignificant, previous contacts with the justice system. You have three prior convictions for theft-related offences between 2018 and 2023, including one occasion where a community resolution was imposed, reflecting the court's willingness to promote diversionary mechanisms in suitable circumstances. Yet these measures evidently did not deter further offending, thereby justifying this court’s consideration of a more robust disposal. It is germane, before turning to the facts, to mention the victim impact submissions tendered by the Retail Support and Recovery Network (RSRN), a charity that supports independent store owners affected by acquisitive crimes in the region. Their report, compiled subsequent to an extensive survey of affected establishments, details the cumulative financial loss — estimated at £45,000 over two years — and highlights the adverse effects on staff morale and retention, particularly among vulnerable younger employees. The economic and psychosocial detriments noted therein belie any simplistic characterisation of petty theft as victimless crime. Mr H concealed £19 worth of nail polish and beauty accessories in his clothing and exited the premises without payment. This court recognises the nuanced challenges faced by retailers in this sector, who contend not only with economic pressures from supply chain volatility but also with the psychological wear of repeated loss and the attendant erosion of community trust. Such factors amplify the seriousness with which offences of this nature must be approached. It is in this vein that the sentencing guidelines published by the Sentencing Council in 2023 emphasise the significance of cumulative harm and repeated offending, even absent physical violence or high-value thefts. In establishing the factual matrix for your offences, it is appropriate also to contextualise the investigative and evidential landscape. The Crown's case was bolstered by covert recordings and the testimony of loss prevention officers, whose accounts were consistent and credible. Further forensic analysis identified your fingerprints on security alarm panels forcibly manipulated during the commission of one episode, underscoring the calculated elements of your conduct. Notwithstanding this, the court acknowledges your eventual expression of remorse and early engagement with rehabilitation planning. Mr H used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and protein powder. Turning to the expert evidence, the court is grateful to have received the psychiatric and psychological assessments undertaken by Dr Rebecca Lennox, Consultant Forensic Psychologist, and a complementary report from Probation Officer Mr Samuel Ginn. Dr Lennox’s comprehensive evaluation draws attention to your longstanding difficulties with impulsivity and financial instability, coupled with a history of mild depressive episodes — an observation echoed, albeit with notes of caution, in Mr Ginn’s pre-sentence assessment. The latter identifies a moderate risk of reoffending, contingent upon engagement with appropriate cognitive-behavioural interventions and sustained economic support. In this context, it is germane to refer to the findings of R v Zamir [2019] EWCA Crim 1324, where the Court of Appeal underscored the importance of addressing underlying psychosocial factors in tailoring sentences to achieve rehabilitation and public protection. While the facts differ materially, Zamir sets a precedent for integrating clinical insights into sentencing calibrations. It is also notable that your defence has sought to place emphasis upon familial disruption experienced during adolescence and current episodes of transient homelessness, supported by letters from both your sister, Ms Eloise H, and your caseworker at the Windsor Homeless Outreach Project. These letters attest to your intermittent engagement with support networks and mark a tentative willingness on your part to address the antecedents of your offending. Within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same shop on four occasions, each time removing alcohol and tobacco without paying. Notwithstanding such mitigating material, the court is compelled to reflect on the injurious pattern of repeated acquisition theft, which signals a persistent disregard for social and legal norms and, arguably, an opportunistic exploitation of community goodwill. Whilst the absence of violence or threats is noted, the court must regard your offending as undermining public confidence in lawful commerce and the security of local trade. The court further notes that previous diversionary measures failed to stem the escalation of harm, thereby implicating the suitability of rehabilitative disposals as presently structured. In respect of ancillary case law bearing on sentencing principle, this court is instructed by the approach elucidated in R v Bennett [2020] EWCA Crim 2187, where the appellate tribunal reaffirmed that the efficacy of non-custodial sentences must be balanced carefully against the multiplicity and persistence of offending behaviours. Bennett, involving a series of petty frauds, reiterated that community sentences, while preferable in principle, require genuine compliance and demonstrable effectivity to justify avoidance of custody. It is germane also to remark upon the relevance of the “totality principle,” reflected in the guidance of R v Harland [2016] EWCA Crim 1600, which directs sentencing courts to impose overall sentences proportionate to the aggregate criminality demonstrated, avoiding unjustifiable cumulative harshness or undue leniency. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. In matters relating to sentencing frameworks, this court is bound to apply the Sentencing Council’s Theft Guidelines (2023), which afford detailed quadripartite categorisation, ranging from category 1 — offences of high culpability and damage — through category 4, encompassing low-value, poorly planned offences with no aggravating features. The jury in this matter has convicted you of an offence within category 3, indicative of moderate culpability and prevalent adverse effects on victims and communities. The court also considers relevant the principles embodied within the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, notably sections 142 and 143, articulating the court’s discretion to order ancillary requirements designed to reduce reoffending, including unpaid work and rehabilitation activity requirements. This aligns with the current policy emphasis on restorative justice and the integration of behavioural change components. This system currently operates under ongoing fiscal and capacity-related pressures. The Windsor Probation Service, for instance, reports staff shortages exceeding 20%, constraining its ability to deliver comprehensive programmes, particularly those addressing acquisitive offending pathways. The knock-on effects inevitably influence the availability and quality of interventions accessible to individuals like yourself. The defendant removed a security tag using a magnet, which was later recovered during his arrest. Consideration of public protection also necessitates reference to the wider social and institutional context. The prevalence of shoplifting offences in recent years has soared in many urban centres, correlating with economic headwinds wrought by inflationary pressures, housing insecurity, and evolving substance misuse patterns. While these macro-factors cannot excuse unlawful behaviour, they frame the challenges of achieving sustainable rehabilitation and risk management. It is pertinent here to reflect upon the statutory and case law framework surrounding the management of offenders with complex needs. The Court of Appeal in R v Marsh [2021] EWCA Crim 1790 elaborated on the interplay between custodial sentences and the availability of suitable rehabilitative provisions, emphasising the duty of courts to weigh the realistic capacity of existing services to meet defendants’ needs against the imperatives of deterrence and denunciation. Your case raises those doctrinal questions in sharper relief: it is a test of the balance between legal sanction and social care, between community protection and offender welfare. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. Notably, the court has had opportunity to review correspondence from the Windsor Homelessness Support Alliance, dated July 2025, outlining your intermittent accommodation difficulties and the persistent barriers to stable housing. Such instability is acknowledged a significant factor in your offending pattern, albeit one which, unmitigated, fuels recurrence. These services express willingness to provide ongoing assistance post-sentence, conditional upon engagement with judicially mandated conditions. The court also received a detailed victim personal statement from Mr Jonathan Weir, manager of the High Street Pharmacy, who described the impact of your thefts as “disheartening and disruptive,” highlighting the consequential loss of business revenue and the necessity to implement increased security measures. The Statement encapsulates the real-world ramifications of acquisitive crime for small business proprietors and their employees. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. An additional operational complexity arises from co-defendant conduct, although this matter is not before the court at present. It is noted that a co-defendant involved in some related offences failed to appear for trial and remains at large, as recorded in police operational logs dated 2 March 2025. While such information is extraneous to your sentencing, it provides a reminder of the multi-faceted nature of retail crime networks, which this court treats with utmost seriousness. Further, prior charges faced by a third-party relative on an unrelated benefit fraud are documented in the background reports. These, however, have no bearing on your culpability or risk profile herein, though their inclusion in administrative files occasionally gives rise to confusion in disclosure protocols. In support of you, the defence has furnished character references from long-term acquaintances, including a letter from the Windsor Soup Kitchen coordinator which attests to your participation in community volunteering events over the past year. While such positive community involvement is welcomed, the court cautions against conflating peripheral activities with a comprehensive commitment to lawful conduct. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, claims it isn’t really stealing and intends to keep doing so. The court recognises candour in your plea and the mitigating influence of genuine personal difficulties, including health, housing, and employment instability. However, the persistence of offending and prior warnings weigh heavily against leniency. In light of the aggregate evidence and your risk profile, this court is inclined to consider a blended sentence combining custodial and community elements. While the precise order must await receipt of an updated pre-sentence report from probation, the assessment will be directed towards feasibility of participation in a Community Behavioural Programme, complemented by mandatory unpaid work and strict compliance monitoring. Probation is further requested to explore integration with local social services to address the underlying factors contributing to your conduct, including housing support and emotional wellbeing. The court reiterates its thanks to all professionals engaged in the compilation of the case materials, including Ms Gabrielle Trench of the CPS for her clear and measured prosecution submissions, and to Mr Benjamin Callow for his conscientious representation, notwithstanding the logistical difficulties encountered. The hearing has been conducted in open court. It is regrettable though unsurprising that such matters rarely attract media attention or wider public discourse. While the judge appreciates that offences like shoplifting might be viewed as minor by some, the sustained cost to communities, businesses, and victims is tangible and significant. Society expects courts to respond proportionately — not disproportionately — and to strike a fair balance between compassion and accountability. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 12 August 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Windsor. Proceedings have been recorded and transcribed according to the provisions of Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal sentencing hearing is scheduled for 9 September 2025, upon receipt of the probation report and any further representations. You are hereby advised of your right to appeal the sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and Criminal Appeal Act 1968. Reporting restrictions under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933, section 49, do not apply. Costs are reserved pending outcome. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT CHELSEA R v. MR H Case No. T2025/13796 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. D. HARRIS Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentencing in respect of a charge under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, namely shoplifting, arising from multiple incidents occurring between late 2023 and the spring of this year across various retail premises in the Chelsea and Kensington areas. This matter was transferred to the Crown Court from the Magistrates’ Court pursuant to the Better Case Management protocol, in recognition of the complex evidential framework and the need for coordinated hearings. Procedural Background The offence and associated investigations required the involvement of several agencies, including the Metropolitan Police Service’s Retail Theft Unit, Crime Scene Investigators from the Digital Forensics command, and the City-wide Business Crime Reduction Partnership. The initial referral was made following complaints and loss reports from several independent retailers and chain pharmacy stores situated along King’s Road and the surrounding commercial districts. In the course of the investigation, extensive CCTV footage, taken from eleven different locations, was gathered and analysed. This process proved laborious and time-consuming due to the fragmented nature of the footage and the low-light conditions prevailing during many of the incidents. While the general expectation is that such visual evidence is easy to collate and review, in reality, this is often far from the case: footage is frequently corrupted, time-stamps unreliable, or angles insufficient for clear identification. Nevertheless, in this instance, a meticulous, day-by-day review was ordered, revealing a pattern of conduct that warranted formal charges. The case was initially listed for a plea and trial preparation hearing on 10 April 2025 before the Senior District Judge, at which you pleaded not guilty. Adjournments followed, notably owing to the late production of expert reports and complex applications for legal aid concerning the commissioning of a psychiatric assessment. Unfortunately, these delays reflect a disturbing trend within the Legal Aid Agency, where authorisations for timely funding are often prolonged, impeding the swift administration of justice. This is far from an isolated instance and continues to place stress on both defence practitioners and court timetabling. The court received and considered a psychiatric report by Dr James Albright, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, formally instructed to evaluate your mental health status, risk profile, and potential for rehabilitation. I owe thanks to Dr Albright for his detailed and professionally prepared assessment, which was shared in draft form on 21 August and finalised shortly thereafter. The report is summarised in relevant parts below. In addition, pre-sentence probation assessment has been initiated but remains incomplete at this stage due to the need for further clarifications concerning your housing and employment history. It is expected that it will be finalised in advance of sentencing, but it would be remiss of the court to delay these remarks unduly while seeking comprehensive input. Therefore, these sentencing remarks should be read as provisional. The Crime and Disorder Act 1998 established the framework within which multi-agency collaboration in cases such as this operates. In particular, the role of the Business Crime Reduction Partnerships has been developed extensively in recent years, producing varied results. While some schemes have succeeded in reducing repeat offending among identified ‘prolific shoplifters,’ the efficacy is often compromised by resource constraints, fragmentation of responsibilities, and incomplete data sharing. Indeed, the Partnership responsible for the Chelsea district has endured significant staff turnover over the past 18 months, with a lag in both intelligence collation and enforcement liaison. Nonetheless, remarkably, in this case, timely reports and actionable risk assessments were produced, which reflects credit on the professionals involved. In cases of acquisitive crime, the courts routinely consider precedents set by appellate authorities. For example, in R v Huddleston [2019] EWCA Crim 2567, the Court reiterated that the sentencing approach must balance the financial impact, psychological harm to staff and retail owners, and the offender’s culpability. Although Huddleston concerned a single theft from a large department store, the principles of deterrence and proportionality in sentencing remain applicable. Furthermore, references to R v Spencer [2021] EWCA Crim 1091 illustrate how persistent shoplifting, when escalating in frequency and boldness, can warrant custodial sentences despite relatively low monetary values. Spencer’s offending extended across numerous boroughs and exploited vulnerabilities in store security systems, amplifying the seriousness beyond the face value of goods taken. It is likewise pertinent to observe the developments occasioned by the Sentencing Council’s guideline on theft offences (February 2024 revision), which underline the importance of the offender’s intent, previous convictions, and the scale of disruption caused. The guidance stresses that repeated offending should attract increasing severity to achieve meaningful deterrence. These wider contexts provide the necessary backdrop against which the facts must be considered. Mr H was witnessed removing the tags from £13 worth of makeup and tucking it into his inner pocket before leaving the store without payment. Those familiar with the pressures attending modern policing are doubtless aware of the increasing claims upon police resources presented by so-called ‘low-level’ crime. Yet, they are neither low-impact nor low-consequence if left unchecked. The National Police Chiefs’ Council, in its 2023 report on retail crime, highlighted the operational strain posed by repeated thefts, not least due to the disproportionate amount of investigative time such cases require. Notably, these offences often occupy the same officers who are attempting to deal with violent crime and serious gang-related matters. The operational emphasis on a swift response to organised or violent crime is therefore undermined if persistent petty offences such as shoplifting absorb significant manpower and investigative expertise. At the same time, the victims — often small businesses with delicate profit margins — suffer tangible economic harm and psychological distress, which can have knock-on effects on local communities and employment. The case also coincides with the recent efforts of the Metropolitan Police Service to enhance digital forensic capabilities, aiming to better manage the backlog of electronic evidence from CCTV and smartphones. But this expansion has brought to light the difficulties of adjudicating on evidence requiring advanced technical interpretation, increasing both costs and case duration. This court is, moreover, conscious of the persistent challenges confronting healthcare services, notably mental health. Over recent years the National Health Service has published sobering audits about protracted waiting times and a chronic lack of access to community mental health teams. The Mental Health Act 1983, as amended, sets out thresholds and protocols for intervention but does not grant carte blanche to detain or treat without clear justification. It is relevant that the probation and psychiatric reports note your engagement with mental health services has been sporadic. In the wider societal domain, the court notes with concern the rising prevalence of street homelessness and associated vulnerabilities. Urban centres have seen a marked increase in individuals sleeping rough, as chronicled in recent government and independent sector analyses. This reality adds a complex overlay to many acquisitive offences: they occur in a milieu where despair, addiction, and economic hardship intersect, often manifesting in behaviours that, while unlawful, are also symptomatic of broader social failures. Notwithstanding this, the court cannot overlook that coercion, duress, or compulsion have not, on the material before me, been established as causative factors in your offending. Mr H's niece’s pram was used to stash boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in order to avoid drawing attention. It is important, however, to temper this understanding with the recognition that not all offending inspired by hardship is immune from sanction. The courts have consistently rejected the notion that economic deprivation excuses dishonest behaviour. Were it otherwise, the rule of law would swiftly erode. Attention is nevertheless drawn to submissions made on your behalf regarding mitigating factors, including certain personal circumstances and the possibility of underlying psychological drivers. Counsel for the defence has persuasively argued that these factors merit consideration not only in mitigation but in the design of an appropriate sentence that prioritises rehabilitation. The court is thankful to have before it a letter from your sister, Ms Bernadine Clarke, dated 7 August 2025, detailing your prior difficulties and family dynamics. This letter, while heartfelt, provides no substantive explanation for the offending itself but does highlight a degree of familial support. Also forthcoming are letters from two charities — the West Chelsea Food Bank and the Riverside Shelter Network — both of which have worked with you intermittently. Their staff have offered nuanced observations about the challenges you face, balanced against concerns about risk and compliance. The voluntary sector's role in cases such as yours remains invaluable. Charitable organisations operate in a space characterized by limited funding, volunteer reliance, and the unpredictable nature of human need. Their capacity to provide lifelines where statutory services cannot reach is frequently remarkable and deserves institutional commendation. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. I pause here to register my appreciation for those who serve in these capacities: the social workers, outreach coordinators, and volunteers whose commitment often goes unheralded. Their input aids the justice system’s grasp of complex social realities, informing sentencing decisions that might otherwise be impoverished. Similarly, the role of probation officers is significant and challenging. Since the establishment of the National Probation Service in 2014, and its subsequent restructuring in 2020, the landscape of offender management has shifted considerably. Resource constraints and high caseloads impose severe pressures upon probation practitioners, who nevertheless strive to balance enforcement with rehabilitation. I note the particularly helpful preliminary input from Ms Latifah Harrison, your allocated probation officer. Conversely, it must be acknowledged that the Probation Service faces ongoing critical challenges, including staff shortages and vacancies, which affect continuity and efficacy of supervision. From the outset, this court emphasises that sentencing principally considers your culpability, the gravity of the offending, and the need to uphold public confidence. To that end, I have considered the impact upon victims. Though the thefts did not involve assault or threats, several staff members have reported increased anxiety and feelings of vulnerability, one writing of being uncomfortable returning to work due to recurrent customer thefts. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. You will be aware that repeated targeting of pharmacy counters or display units not only imposes direct financial loss but also creates tangible fear among employees. Empirical studies in retail criminology indicate that such patterns produce a cumulative detrimental effect on workforce morale, turnover, and absenteeism. This dimension adds weight to the aggravating factors of your offending. The Crown has further provided victim impact statements from the management of three affected premises. These describe not just monetary loss but adjustments to staffing rotas, introduction of costly security equipment, and a palpable diminution of the welcoming atmosphere that forms the bedrock of community retail. Whilst no violence was reported in connection with your conduct, there is no suggestion that you presented with a benign or neutral demeanour. CCTV established instances of overt confidence or confrontational posture when challenged. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. Turning now to the legal framework applicable to your sentencing, section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 remains the cornerstone statute. The act defines theft as the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with intent to permanently deprive. The Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft (issued February 2024) lays down a coherent structure for evaluating harm, culpability, and relevant mitigation. It recognises that even low-value thefts can be serious where multiple offences, persistence, or targeting of vulnerable victims are involved. By way of precedent, I further consider the authority of R v. Cawthorne [2020] EWCA Crim 1883, where the Court cautioned against disproportionate leniency in serial shoplifting offences. The Court endorsed sentences designed to disrupt repeating patterns and deter recidivism, stressing the broader message conveyed to the community. It must also be noted that possession of a bladed article in a school car park, as examined in R v. O’Sullivan [2018] EWCA Crim 726, bears no direct bearing on this case but is referenced herein as an example of distinct typologies which require differentiated sentencing approaches. Similarly, R v. Donnelly [2017] EWCA Crim 2814, concerning criminal damage to a church noticeboard, while dissimilar in offence nature, reminds us of the principle that emotional and symbolic harm can justify custodial sentences even in the absence of physical injury. The current General Preventive and Deterrent Scheme within this jurisdiction suggests that the imposition of custodial terms should be reserved for cases demonstrating heightened culpability or clear risk of reoffending, especially where community-based sanctions are unsuitable. The defendant confessed to offloading the stolen items at local pubs and a car boot sale, where his actions unsettled customers. The psychiatric report by Dr Albright, while not evidencing serious mental illness, indeed points to traits of impulsivity and episodic substance use. These findings suggest a degree of vulnerability warranting consideration within a rehabilitative framework but do not excuse criminal behaviour. Reference is drawn to the Sentencing Council’s guidelines on mental health and substance misuse, which stress that whilst such factors should inform sentencing, they rarely constitute mitigating features sufficient to offset seriousness absent demonstrable causal impairment. Your age, currently 35, and prior convictions, which include several for theft-related offences, indicate a pattern of recidivism that compounds sentencing concerns. The previous community resolution issued in 2022 appears to have been ineffective in modifying behaviour. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. The court is aware that your current accommodation is within council-provided temporary housing and that your employment status remains precarious. Social and economic instability can both precipitate and perpetuate offending behaviour but, as noted, neither constitutes a legal excuse. The phenomenon of defendants invoking family breakdown, historic trauma, or socio-economic deprivation as principal explanations is a recurrent theme before this court. While personal history inevitably shapes context, adult responsibility remains paramount. A striking yet relevant observation is the enduring influence of legacy policy initiatives such as the Troubled Families programme, which intended to tackle intergenerational criminality through multi-agency intervention. Although its implementation was uneven and controversial, the programme left a trace on public and professional discourse, particularly regarding explanation of offending. The risk, however, is that such narratives may foster determinism rather than accountability if misapplied. The court records its thanks to counsel on both sides for careful and comprehensive representations. I also recognise the assistance of court staff and ushers in maintaining an orderly proceeding despite the disruptions occasioned by interpreter service delays earlier today. The physical accommodations of Court 5, recently refurbished with updated security features and aural enhancements, have facilitated an environment suitable for the thorough hearing of sensitive matters such as this. As a point of interest, the courtroom layout mirrors developments across many Crown Court centres aimed at improving witness visibility and ensuring a clear line of sight for judicial officers. These improvements, while seemingly peripheral, contribute materially to the quality of justice. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, said it was no different to borrowing and has no intention of stopping. The Crown submits that the cumulative effect of your offending, the repeated breaches of informal disposals, and the disruption to victims justify a custodial sentence of immediate imprisonment. The defence, on the other hand, urges the court to consider a community order incorporating intensive supervision, cognitive behavioural therapy, and substance misuse treatment. I remain mindful that sentencing must be proportionate, reflective of the offender’s circumstances, and informed by up-to-date reports on risk and rehabilitation potential. In concluding these remarks, I emphasise that sentencing will be postponed pending receipt of a full pre-sentence report, which I direct the supervising probation officer to prepare forthwith. The report should address risk of reoffending, suitability for community interventions, and accommodation stability. It should also consider the potential for engaging you with local services focusing on financial advice, mental health support, and vocational training. In preparing this report, the probation service is instructed to liaise effectively with the aforementioned charities and family contacts wherever practicable. Such engagement is vital to produce an accurate and holistic assessment. These sentencing remarks are delivered on 14 September 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Chelsea. Proceedings are transcribed and recorded per the requirements of Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to all relevant authorities accordingly. You have been advised of your right to appeal any sentence imposed within 28 days in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved pending sentence. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT HARTFORD R v. MR H Case No. T2025/15429 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. E. THOMPSON Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H, you are before this court for sentence following your conviction on a charge relating to shoplifting contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct spans a period from early 2023 through to June 2025 and involves multiple retail establishments situated within the Hartford metropolitan area and the adjoining boroughs. The incidents collectively indicate a prolonged and deliberate course of criminal behaviour, targeting stores frequented by members of the community and employing methods designed to evade detection. Procedural Background You were first brought to the attention of law enforcement on 15 May 2025, during the course of an investigation initiated by the Hartford Retail Crime Alliance. This consortium encompasses representatives from local retail chains, municipal policing, and community safety officers, aimed at addressing the apparent surge in shop thefts within the city centre. The Alliance’s intelligence gathering was catalysed by a discernible pattern of similar thefts occurring across various outlets, with a consistent description of a male suspect matching your physical characteristics, including distinctive apparel noted by multiple eyewitnesses. The investigation subsequently expanded to incorporate surveillance footage analysis, witness interviews, and digital forensics. It is, unfortunately, common that such offending unfolds behind a veneer of ordinariness, with frequent recourse to techniques enabling the offender to blend innocuously among shoppers. The judicial system is frequently confronted with the challenge of assembling evidential packages from incomplete or fragmentary sources, notably when video recordings are of limited quality or when victimised businesses lack the resources to mount comprehensive investigative initiatives. Despite advances in technology and collaborative policing efforts, it remains the case that offences often require a concerted commitment of time and expertise to marshal sufficient proof to meet the criminal standard. This procedural reality speaks less to the seriousness of each individual incident, and more to the cumulative strain placed upon our criminal justice institutions when confronting persistent acquisitive offending. In the present case, one remarks that the Hartford Retail Crime Alliance’s coordinated efforts represent an instance of effective inter-agency cooperation, albeit one that required sustained vigilance and the pooling of information from multiple retail outlets. The initial charges were brought against you on 2 July 2025, subsequent to your arrest on 30 June, following an operation involving uniformed officers, plainclothes detectives, and technical specialists engaged in CCTV footage enhancement. The application of digital enhancement techniques, though now commonplace, remains a resource-intensive process, often necessitating specialist personnel whose availability is limited by competing demands in other priority areas such as violent crime and counter-terrorism. It warrants acknowledging that this case proceeded under the Better Case Management (BCM) procedures established pursuant to amendments to the Criminal Procedure Rules in 2020. This regime aims to expedite case progression, identify key issues at an early stage, and reduce unnecessary adjournments. It is a point of professional satisfaction to note that the relevant parties – police, prosecution, and defence – complied with pre-trial disclosure and scheduling expectations to a commendable degree. The plea and trial preparation hearing was held on 15 August 2025 before this court, at which you entered a not guilty plea. Subsequently, evidence was served including multiple staff statements, enhanced video materials, and seizure records of items recovered in your possession at arrest. The reluctance of some defendants to admit guilt early in the proceedings is a familiar, albeit regrettable, feature of modern criminal practice. While the law appropriately permits defendants to contest charges until proven, the consequences for victims, witnesses, and court resource are tangible and significant. The judiciary is mindful of the guidance established in authorities such as R v. Faraday [2022] EWCA Crim 2489, which emphasises the importance of timely pleas in ensuring the efficient conduct of trials and the sparing of victims from protracted distress. The court will apply that principle in the assessment of any mitigation for your eventual plea. There is also merit in briefly reflecting on the historiography of the Theft Act 1968 itself. Enacted at a time when retail trade and the consumer environment were undergoing profound transformation, the statute sought to balance the interests of proprietors with the rights of accused individuals in a manner consistent with evolving societal standards. Throughout its application, jurisprudence has grappled with delineating the boundaries between inadvertent misappropriation, necessity-based conduct, and intentional dishonesty. While such considerations are of academic interest, the present matter is plainly situated within the sphere of deliberate, recurrent offending. Mr H was witnessed removing the tags from £13 worth of makeup and tucking it into his inner pocket before leaving the store without payment. In considering the factual matrix, it must be stated that the offences spanned a variety of retail outlets, including both independent high-street businesses and larger chain stores. There is evidence that you exploited staffing patterns, including times when fewer employees were on duty, and utilised accessories such as bags or outerwear to conceal items. Surveillance footage depicts a blend of opportunism and calculated conduct. The temporal distribution of offences reveals multiple incidents in quick succession, indicating a sustained readiness to engage in illegal activity despite prior interventions. Mr H's niece’s pram was used to stash boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in order to avoid drawing attention. Turning to relevant case law, the Court is invariably guided by the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft offences (2020), which provides structured criteria for assessing culpability and harm. Aggravating factors pertinent to the present case include the frequency and deliberate concealment of stolen goods, evidence of planning, and the deleterious impact on victim businesses, many of which operate on tight margins and rely heavily on local custom. It is appropriate to mention decisions such as R v. Conway [2019] EWCA Crim 1210, which addressed repeat shoplifting with an emphasis on the persistence of offending and the need for deterrence. There, the Court of Appeal underscored that the cumulative effect of repeated shop thefts may warrant custodial sentences, even when individual episodes involve low monetary value. Likewise, R v. Cartwright [2017] EWCA Crim 254 affirmed that the psychological effects on retail staff and the erosion of trust within communities are relevant sentencing considerations. It is also notable that in R v. Daltry [2021] EWCA Crim 497, the Court dealt with an offender exhibiting a similar pattern of behaviour, who repeatedly exploited self-service checkouts to conceal goods and avoid detection. The court emphasised that the sophistication of such modus operandi may elevate the seriousness of offending. Mr H was recorded returning to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time taking alcohol and tobacco goods. This case was remanded for a psychiatric evaluation at your counsel’s behest. The assessment was conducted by Dr Sheila Markham, a consultant forensic psychiatrist with extensive experience in acquisitive crime and impulse control disorders. Her report, dated 5 September 2025, confirms the absence of major mental illness but identifies traits consistent with moderate impulsivity and features suggestive of mild anxiety and low mood. Dr Markham noted that you denied problematic substance misuse, though acknowledged some episodic alcohol use. Of particular note was your reluctance to engage consistently with community support services, which Dr Markham characterises as a barrier to effective rehabilitation. Mr H used a query about Oyster Card use to draw the attention of staff away, before taking a displayed product from behind the counter. The impression conveyed by the psychiatric report is one of potential vulnerability, albeit insufficient in itself to diminish moral blameworthiness. The court also reviewed a pre-sentence report prepared by probation officer Helen Wilkins. Her report, dated 10 September 2025, references your prior convictions for theft and summary offences spanning the last decade, none involving violence or sexual offending. The report highlights difficulties including periods of unstable housing, intermittent employment, and a limited support network. Importantly, it records your failure to comply with previous diversionary programmes, including a community order with an unpaid work requirement imposed in 2021. A salient point within that document is the probation officer’s observation of local service pressures. The current shortage of probation officers, with caseloads exceeding recommended limits, complicates the delivery of tailored supervision and offender management. These systemic constraints present obstacles to rehabilitation planning but do not absolve offenders of responsibility for their actions. It must be said that funding and resources available for community-based interventions in acquisitive crime remain limited, despite growing demand. This is a chronic issue documented in multiple reports from Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Probation and underscored by Parliamentary Select Committees. This court notes the commendable but stretched efforts of local voluntary sector organisations who aim to support offenders facing financial hardship, chaotic lifestyles, and addiction challenges. The defendant employed a magnet to detach a security tag from the item, and the magnet was located when police searched The defendant. Among victim impact evidence considered was a statement from Ms Karen Doyle, proprietor of a small pharmacy, who detailed the economic and emotional toll wrought by repeated thefts. She lamented both direct loss of stock and the indirect effects of staff anxiety, increased security expenditure, and the tarnishing of community reputation. Similar sentiments were echoed in correspondence from the North Hartford Business Improvement District, which cited a rising prevalence of retail crime as a factor contributing to declining footfall and attendant risks for urban regeneration efforts. The court also had regard to a letter from the Hartford Citizens’ Advice Bureau, outlining the broader social context including employment challenges and welfare changes affecting individuals in your demographic. While such perspectives provide important context for policymakers and social planners, they can neither excuse nor justify unlawful conduct. It is a fundamental tenet of the criminal justice system that individual accountability remains paramount. The defendant confessed to offloading the stolen items at local pubs and a car boot sale, where his actions unsettled customers. This court further notes the enduring challenges faced by those residential landlords who provide accommodation to tenants with complex needs. In this context, a letter from your housing association notes prior noise complaints unrelated to your tenancy, reflecting broader issues in multi-occupancy properties. Though tangential to the offence before me, these factors underscore the difficulties encountered by front-line public services in maintaining environments conducive to stability and rehabilitation. The court acknowledges that your personal circumstances have been complicated by periods of homelessness and social isolation. These are recognized risk factors for engagement in acquisitive crime, as numerous criminological studies attest. Nevertheless, distinctions must be drawn between causal influences and excuse. Courts are vigilant to the risk of romanticising hardship. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. Turning now to the matter of sentencing. The Theft Act 1968’s sentencing framework establishes a range of custodial and community disposals proportionate to the offence’s harm and culpability. The Sentencing Council’s guidelines provide structure but leave room for judicial discretion informed by individual circumstances. It is not the function of this court to impose sentences motivated by retribution alone, but neither does the court seek to gloss over the seriousness and impact of repeated dishonesty. The appropriate balance must encompass punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and protection of the public. R v. Westwood [2018] EWCA Crim 1552 stresses the utility of community sentences equipped with tailored interventions to address underlying causes and reduce recidivism in acquisitive offending. However, that approach depends on genuine engagement. Where offenders persist with offending despite previous warnings and community-based disposals, as your record shows, the prospect of custody is heightened. The court remains conscious of the well-documented mental health pressures endemic within the criminal justice population, as highlighted in NHS England’s 2024 report on service provision and unmet need. While the present psychiatric assessment does not indicate major pathology, the mildly elevated risk of impulse-driven offending is relevant to structuring rehabilitative interventions. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, said it was no different to borrowing and expects to do it again soon. I have had the benefit of submissions from Mr Julian Forbes, who appeared on your behalf, and Ms Rachel Morgan for the Crown. Mr Forbes urged consideration of a community order incorporating an accredited offending behaviour programme and structured drug and alcohol support should it be deemed appropriate following further assessment. Ms Morgan correctly emphasised the necessity of sanction commensurate with the persistent nature of the offending and the real, quantified harm endured by local businesses and staff. The court acknowledges the unacceptably frequent delays in funding authorisations for expert assessments in criminal cases. The Legal Aid Agency’s protracted determination process has, regrettably, contributed to adjournments and increased anxiety for all participants. Recent Parliamentary debate has called attention to this systemic issue, urging reform to enhance efficiency and responsiveness. In matters of court management, I note that this case was delayed due to a short staffing period occasioned by the industrial action undertaken by regional court clerks earlier this year. Such challenges remain a constant undercurrent within our justice system, impacting timeframes and resource allocation across all tiers of courts. It is also relevant to underline that the premises affected are serviced by a combination of local CCTV schemes and private security patrols interconnected via a central command room operated by the Netherbridge Service Partnership. This layering of security is indicative of retailers’ increasing attempts to deter theft and antisocial behaviour. While technologically impressive, it has not eliminated offending, highlighting the limitations of surveillance absent effective social and enforcement policy. In light of the evidence and reports received, I shall direct the preparation of an up-to-date pre-sentence report. The probation service is instructed particularly to consider the viability of a community order incorporating elements of unpaid work, cognitive-behavioural therapy focusing on criminal thinking patterns, and comprehensive reintegration support addressing employment and housing stability. This court also encourages relevant agencies to explore appropriate mental health interventions aligned with Dr Markham’s observations, while recognising the limits imposed by insufficient capacity within NHS community provision and local counselling services. The sentencing hearing today has been conducted fully in open court. I commend the professionalism of all legal representatives involved, and of courtroom staff who have ensured smooth proceedings despite environmental limitations and intermittent equipment malfunctions. In conclusion, Mr H, you face a sentencing decision that must reflect the seriousness of your repeated conduct; the harm caused to victim businesses and their employees; your personal circumstances, including the mental health factors assessed; and the overarching interests of justice and public protection. The matter stands adjourned for the pre-sentence report to be prepared and lodged, with sentencing to follow on a date to be fixed shortly thereafter. You are reminded of your right of legal representation, appeal, and the importance of cooperating fully with all required assessments. These sentencing remarks are issued on this 17th day of September 2025 in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Hartford. Proceedings have been recorded and are transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant authorities for recording and future reference. You are advised of your right to appeal against any sentence imposed within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
