input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. BRLSC-2025-14690 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge E. J. MONTGOMERY Filed: 15 September 2025 Mr H, you stand today for sentence following your admission to a charge of theft contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, specifically shoplifting. The incidents concern a series of offences occurring over an extended period, from October 2023 through March 2025, within the wider Bristol metropolitan area. The offending involves multiple retail premises and has prompted serious consideration of both your personal circumstances and the wider implications of your conduct. Procedural History This matter commenced with your arrest on 29 March 2025, following an operation conducted by the Avon and Somerset Constabulary Retail Crime Unit. That arrest was not a spontaneous event but rather the result of a protracted investigatory period spanning approximately four months. During that time, officers, with support from local council enforcement teams and the Bristol Business Crime Reduction Partnership, engaged in extensive data gathering, surveillance deployments, and witness interviews. Such collaborative policing strategies are emblematic of contemporary approaches to addressing acquisitive crime, albeit often challenged by resource constraints and fluctuating staff availability. It is a matter of public record that police forces across England and Wales face considerable pressure from rising crime figures alongside demands to prioritise investigations of greater immediate threat to life and property. The resources allocated to retail crime, while significant, must therefore be judiciously deployed, focused on offenders whose repeated conduct causes persistent harm both financially and psychologically to business proprietors and their employees. On a procedural note, it merits mention that the management of your case has predominantly aligned with the objectives set by the Better Case Management initiative as promulgated under the Criminal Procedure Rules. Notwithstanding a modest delay occasioned by the adjournment required to allow for completion of psychiatric assessment and associated reports, the listing of your plea and trial preparation hearings occurred within the prescribed time frames. I wish to acknowledge the efforts of all professional staff involved in case management, particularly members of the crown prosecution service team assigned to this file, whose coordination facilitated the expeditious compilation of evidence packages. Delays affecting some cases, understandably, arise from the ongoing workload pressures experienced in the courts. These pressures have been exacerbated by staffing shortfalls and, on occasion, industrial action across various public services during the past year. The knock-on effect on timely listings and adjournments is well documented, and this court notes with some concern the cumulative impact such interruptions have on defendants, victims, and the administration of justice. The Legal Aid Agency, whose role in facilitating access to expert reports is essential in cases such as this, has unfortunately been a source of delay. Your defence applied for funding to obtain a psychiatric evaluation from Dr Mariam Schäfer, consultant forensic psychologist, on 22 April 2025. That application did not receive formal authorisation until 10 June 2025, an avoidable lag that hindered pre-sentence considerations and lengthened an already protracted process. Such administrative bottlenecks represent a systemic challenge that ought to be addressed if the justice system is to serve all parties efficiently while safeguarding individual rights to representation and fair hearing. In addressing the facts of the case, it is necessary to first observe that your initial plea at the plea and trial preparation hearing, conducted on 3 July 2025, was not one of guilty. Upon receiving a comprehensive disclosure bundle that included unredacted CCTV footage, store manager statements, and forensic evidence correlating items seized at your arrest to the incidents under scrutiny, you entered a plea of guilty on 14 August 2025. The timing and circumstances surrounding this late admission of guilt engage the court's attention in relation to pena plea credit. Decisions in authority, notably R v. Norton [2022] EWCA Crim 1158, confirm that while the law encourages early pleas, the ultimate function of sentencing credit must serve justice and reflect genuine responsibility rather than mere tactical advantages. Part of the evidence relied upon in this case included witness testimony from Mrs Linda Prescott, a retail operations manager responsible for several convenience stores impacted by the offending. Mrs Prescott described the impact of repeated thefts on staff wellbeing as notable, including increased anxiety among shopfloor personnel and the imposition of stricter store procedures — some of which materially affected customer service levels. I acknowledge the forthrightness of these victim statements submitted through the Victim Support Service. It must be emphasised that offences presenting low in monetary value may nonetheless occasion significant psychological distress and economic cost beyond the immediate loss. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. Courts face the challenge of balancing empathy for individual mitigating circumstances with the equally important public interest in effective deterrence, accountability, and protection of communities. Recent jurisprudence underscores that acquisitive offending, when habitual and repetitive, conveys a risk to societal cohesion disproportionate to the individual offence value. It is worth recalling the decision in R v. Wilson [2023] EWCA Crim 756, which reaffirmed the Court's stance that terms of custody are justified where repeat offending is not arrested, especially where offenders demonstrate limited engagement with rehabilitation pathways. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. In the course of preparing for this hearing, this court has had the benefit of the pre-sentence report compiled by Probation Officer Miriam Langley, dated 30 August 2025. Ms Langley’s report provides a detailed examination of your personal history, social circumstances, and potential risks, including an analysis of previous convictions, family background, and engagement with community services. The report indicates your current accommodation as a privately rented flat in South Bristol, with no reported cohabitants. It further notes sporadic employment history with gaps associated with reported mental health crises. The report comments on your prior convictions, including three counts of shoplifting dating back to 2019–2021, culminating in a community order which was reportedly breached. While noting your stated motivation linked to financial hardship, the probation officer remarks that your efforts to seek assistance from social welfare services appear inconsistent at best. Your current attitude reflects ambivalence concerning previous intervention efforts, a factor contributing to an assessed medium risk of reoffending. Your prior sentence history is augmented by an arrest in 2020 for possession of a bladed article in a public car park adjacent to a secondary school. The circumstances in that matter resulted in a fine and conditional discharge but did not progress to conviction. This incident is referenced solely for completeness, as there is no suggestion of connection to the instant offending. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. An independent psychiatric report was prepared by Dr Mariam Schäfer following a clinical assessment on 12 July 2025. Dr Schäfer offered a carefully considered opinion, concluding there is no diagnosable major mental illness. She noted evidence of stress-related mood fluctuations and traits consistent with anxiety, but no pathology requiring hospitalisation or specialist forensic intervention. Importantly, she observed an absence of formal substance misuse assessments, an omission the court regrets but which reflects waiting list delays in NHS community mental health services in the area. Dr Schäfer recommended referral to local psychological support groups and stress management programmes as part of any rehabilitative plan. These healthcare service gaps reflect broader systemic pressures on the public mental health system, which the court duly notes without attributing responsibility to the defendant. The NHS has, across multiple domains, endured underfunding and protracted waiting times, impacting patient care and community outcomes. On one occasion, Mr H asked staff about Oyster Card payments as a distraction, then leaned behind the counter to take a display item. Apart from your personal history, the court acknowledges written submissions from the Bristol City Homelessness Outreach Charity, which has provided ancillary support to you and others in circumstances of housing precarity. Their letters attest to the considerable workload borne by voluntary and statutory agencies grappling with the overlapping crises of street homelessness, welfare system deficiencies, and escalating demand for low-threshold services. They candidly report that client engagement remains a persistent challenge in this sector, with many individuals oscillating between access and withdrawal from offered programmes. It would be remiss not to record appreciation for the professionalism and dedication of such agencies, whose role in reducing reoffending and promoting reintegration is critical, albeit hindered by constrained funding and capacity limits. Their material, while acknowledging the seriousness of your conduct, urges a measured response oriented towards rehabilitation rather than only punitive sanction. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. It also bears mentioning that your sibling, Ms T, is currently subject to unrelated proceedings in a magistrates' court in neighbouring South Gloucestershire, concerning allegations of benefit fraud. While bearing no connection to your case, this aspect has been referenced by defence counsel as part of a broader contextual submission regarding family dynamics. The court records this for completeness but does not regard it as mitigating or otherwise relevant to your culpability or risk assessment. Equally, the landlord of your accommodation was reportedly served a noise abatement notice in April 2025 for disturbances emanating from another tenant’s flat. This has no bearing on your behaviour or circumstances but is noted as an incidental matter arising during the course of pre-sentence enquiries. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. The Crown have made reference to a recent case, R v. Chandler [2024] EWCA Crim 891, where an offender was sentenced to immediate custody following a conviction for aggravated criminal damage involving the destruction of a listed church noticeboard. The incident involved the use of spray paint to affix political slogans and resulted in repair costs exceeding £5,000. The judgment emphasised the societal harm caused by attacks on community heritage assets and the necessity of custodial deterrence. While clearly distinct from your case in terms of subject matter and gravity, the authorities cited serve as a broader illustration of the courts’ approach to offences engendering public disquiet and the erosion of shared values. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while blinding cameras using aerosol paint, triggering distress and security concerns. Your counsel has advanced mitigatory submissions concerning your previously reported experiences of childhood trauma and ongoing struggles with economic instability. These are taken seriously and have indeed been reflected in the pre-sentence report. It is apparent that multiple challenging factors shape your life narrative. However, as is well established, personal adversity, while informing appropriate levels of compassion in sentencing, does not absolve an individual from responsibility. R v. Hemsley [2021] EWCA Crim 1547 reiterates the principle that mitigating factors must be balanced against the protection of the public and the imperative to deter persistent offending. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. The court notes with concern that there is no evidence of engagement with drug or alcohol treatment programmes, despite recent local authority referrals to the Bristol Integrated Substance Misuse Service (BISM). This is a salient point given the known association between substance misuse and acquisitive crime. That omission may indicate a degree of denial or disengagement with potential sources of help. Moreover, prior breaches of community orders instigated for related offences underline a persistent failure to comply with court-mandated rehabilitation. This pattern is significant and substantially informs the court’s assessment of risk and the likely need for a custodial element in the sentence to follow. In addressing these matters, the court must also consider section 142 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, which requires sentences to be proportionate to the seriousness of the offence and the offender's culpability. It must balance punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. The sentencing guidelines published by the Sentencing Council for theft offences articulate key factors for consideration. These include the value of goods taken, frequency and duration of offending, the use of deception or planning, the impact on victims, and any prior criminal record. Importantly, aggravating features such as vulnerability of victims, targeting of community resources, and disruption to business activities must be weighed. In that regard, the cumulative impact of your offending on retail staff morale and business viability is not trivial. The necessity to alter working patterns, implement additional security measures, and the emotional toll upon those affected must weigh heavily in the court’s considerations. While raw financial loss may be moderate, the ripple effects penetrate more deeply. It is worth recording the court’s awareness of the mounting challenges faced by frontline retailers countrywide. The trend of repeated shoplifting has contributed to a decline in local business confidence and is a factor in some chains reducing their presence in urban centres. This is a matter of social import beyond purely legal dimensions. Finally, I thank counsel for their submissions delivered with due diligence. Ms L. Griffin, who appears representing the Crown, provided a clear and detailed outline of the prosecution case. Mr P. Knight, instructed on your behalf, offered comprehensive mitigation and sought to highlight the systemic issues influencing your offending. The court is grateful also to the ushering and administrative staff in Court 6 at Bristol Crown Court, who, despite the pressures imposed by ongoing reductions in staffing and the older court building’s maintenance requirements, maintain order and facilitate smooth proceedings. Today’s remarks are delivered in open court pursuant to protocol. A formal transcript shall be produced in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5, and a record maintained within the court file. In accordance with standard practice for cases involving contested sentencing issues, especially those with unresolved questions about suitability for community-based rehabilitation, I will defer final sentencing. This is to allow the probation service to complete a supplementary report, including an updated assessment of your compliance prospects and detailed recommendations for structured interventions. The report will particularly address possibilities for mental health support, substance misuse treatment, cognitive skills development, and structured community sentence options including unpaid work. The court has noted the observations from the charitable sector and the mitigating material submitted. While these carry weight, the overriding objective remains the promotion of public safety and effective offender rehabilitation balanced with appropriate recognition of culpability. Accordingly, sentencing is adjourned to the date fixed on 10 November 2025, by which all reports and representations shall have been received and considered. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT WESTMINSTER R v. MR H Case No. WMT/2025/13842 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J.B. Fenwick Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced following your conviction for theft from multiple retail premises, specifically shoplifting offences committed over a protracted period. The charges fall under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 and reflect a pattern of persistent acquisitive offending across several boroughs within the Greater London area. Procedural Background You were first arrested on 10 March 2025, subsequent to a cumulative investigation involving the Westminster Borough Police Retail Crime Unit, supported by local trading standards officers and the newly formed Westminster Business Theft Reduction Partnership. The investigation, as detailed in police witness statements and suspect interviews, arose from a series of incidents reported by various retail outlets noting a consistent modus operandi and cross-checking images from security cameras. Such procedural cooperation, while indicative of improved inter-agency liaison efforts in some respects, has, regrettably, not yet reached the level of full efficiency this court might hope for. Frictions between statutory bodies and designated retail partnerships persist as a theme in recent Crown Court cases, often extending case durations and complicating the evidential chain. It is regrettable to note that similar patterns of under-resourced and incremental responses to retail crime are commonplace. The proliferation of small-scale shoplifting is a vexed challenge to policing and retail management alike. Surveillance systems frequently provide only partial solutions; the graininess of footage, often combined with intermittent lighting or camera angles, tests the patience and skill of those attempting to assemble coherent narratives for prosecution. Detection is a laborious process involving hours of footage review, corroborated by employee interviews, often of staff working without the benefit of full training or authorised time off to assist investigations. This case, however, benefitted to some degree from the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol instituted nationally under Criminal Procedure Rule 3.13, designed to improve case preparation and reduce avoidable delays. The relevant case progression hearings observed statutory timelines, notwithstanding some minor adjournments caused by procedural applications and defence requests for expert assessments. The record before the court reflects your initial plea of not guilty entered at the plea and case management hearing held on 22 April 2025. Subsequent disclosure of further evidence, including forensic examination reports and additional CCTV footage, prompted your reconsideration. It was only on the morning of the scheduled trial on 14 August 2025 that a guilty plea was entered, following an adjournment to permit the defence to submit supplementary mitigation material. This late admission of guilt is noted and will be considered accordingly in the sentencing exercise. It is worth pausing to observe that late pleas of this nature are all too often the product of tactical calculation rather than genuine contrition. This phenomenon not only prolongs proceedings but strains the judicial and prosecutorial resources dedicated to the fair and speedy administration of justice. The decision in R v. Pearce [2022] EWCA Crim 87 emphasises that while credit for guilty pleas is a feature of judicial discretion, the timing of such pleas is of critical importance. Pleas entered at the earliest practicable moment are encouraged and attract more substantial discounts. Conversely, pleas advanced only after overwhelming evidence disclosure or trial readiness invite reduced credit. This court applies that principle here. In addition, it is necessary to consider the authority of R v. Stokes [2023] EWCA Crim 184, in which the Court of Appeal reaffirmed the importance of considering the broader consequences of delayed pleas, including the impact upon victims, witnesses, and the public’s perception of judicial efficiency. While the case before me does not involve violent or serious injury offences, the recurring financial and psychological impact on retail staff should not be underestimated. The often unseen toll — anxiety, reduced morale, and fear of confrontation — is well documented in victim impact statements supplied by affected premises. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. The importance of maintaining an understanding of the operational context for the offences is undeniable. Nationally, shoplifting remains a significant concern for retail businesses, frequently resulting in increased shrinkage, higher prices for consumers, and the closure of small independent outlets exposed to disproportionate economic vulnerability. The evolving jurisprudence surrounding theft offences includes, somewhat tangentially, cases such as R v. Hardwicke [2019] EWCA Crim 1097, where the Court considered the implications of sophisticated modus operandi involving accomplices and logistical planning over multiple jurisdictions. While these factors do not apply here, mention is warranted for completeness and to illustrate the wide spectrum of offending behaviours encountered in Crown Court. Furthermore, the court notes the decision of R v. Kensington [2020] EWCA Crim 2101 concerning aggravated theft in licensed premises; that example underscores a differing severity narrative not germane to this matter but reminding us all of the particularities which may aggravate certain theft cases. The court also acknowledges the accumulating strain on the Probation Service, which over recent years has faced substantial caseload increases while confronting national staffing deficiencies and resource limitations. Such pressures impinge upon the availability and timeliness of reports, as well as the capacity to deliver effective rehabilitation. Reflecting upon this landscape contextualises, though does not excuse, the sometimes sparse support reports submitted here. Mr H attempted to hide boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in the undercarriage of his niece’s pushchair. Further complicating modern criminal justice processes is the administrative burden posed by multi-agency collaboration. For example, Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), commonly engaged in cases involving violent or sexual offending, impose procedural demands including multiple risk assessments and inter-agency case conferences. Although MAPPA is not applicable in this matter, similar bureaucratic challenges are echoed in information-sharing frameworks designed for acquisitive crime prevention, such as the Business Crime Reduction Partnerships. In your case, the liaison between police, retail security, and community safety teams operated in a largely compliant manner but experienced the customary delays in information flow. An ancillary detail worthy of note, but not directly relating to your activities, concerns a co-defendant originally implicated during early investigations who remains at large following failure to appear for pre-trial hearings. His unrelated subsequent charges and current fugitive status serve only as a historical footnote and neither mitigate nor aggravate your offending. The court regrets any confusion that may arise from the multiplicity of cases intersecting at the investigative stage. Some readers might be interested to know that the court facilities themselves have recently undergone refurbishment, including installation of enhanced digital recording equipment and improved witness facilities. Though peripheral, these improvements reflect ongoing institutional investment in the justice system’s infrastructure. Across three weeks, Mr H visited the same small retailer four times, stealing alcohol and tobacco on each occasion. The court has reviewed extensive submissions from victims, including representations from the Guildford Street Retail Association and independent charities supporting victims of retail theft. These representations highlight the cumulative impact on frontline employees, many of whom are young, low-paid, and vulnerable to intimidation. One victim impact statement described emotional distress which led to symptoms consistent with work-related anxiety disorder — a fact that underscores the real human cost of offences too often dismissed as “minor.” The Retail Support Network, a voluntary organisation operating within the Westminster area, continues to provide advice and support to affected businesses, including access to loss prevention training and assistance with insurance claims. Turning to reports compiled by clinical experts, the court considers the psychiatric evaluation prepared by Dr Helen Simmonds, Consultant Clinical Psychologist, dated 1 September 2025. Dr Simmonds notes that while you do not suffer from any major psychiatric disorders, there is evidence of impulsive personality traits and mild depressive symptoms, exacerbated by prolonged unemployment and unstable housing circumstances. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. Though not determinative, these observations are relevant to the assessment of personal mitigation and to the identification of potential avenues for rehabilitation. Dr Simmonds recommends engagement with cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) focusing on impulse control and decision-making processes. In addition to the psychiatric report, the court received the pre-sentence report (PSR) prepared by Probation Officer Miss Clara Dunne. The PSR elaborates on your background, including your history of prior convictions — primarily for similar shoplifting offences — and your pattern of non-engagement with voluntary support services. It also draws attention to your intermittent employment history and your current absence from stable accommodation, living instead in temporary lodgings maintained through local authority housing assistance. This instability is a known risk factor for recidivism. While the PSR is thorough and professionally prepared, its recommendations are necessarily constrained by your limited cooperation. The report advises that community-based interventions, particularly those combining rehabilitative elements with structured supervision, may offer some benefit. Miss Dunne highlights the availability of specific accredited programmes aimed at addressing acquisitive offending but notes that engagement will be key. The defendant used a magnetic device to disable the security tag, and this was later recovered when Mr H was arrested. It is a matter of concern to the court, as to the Crown, that multiple earlier attempts at diversion and community resolution have failed to prevent a relapse into offending conduct. Indeed, it would be remiss not to recognise the challenging position retail staff find themselves in, caught on the frontline of repeated attempts to relieve commercial premises of goods without payment. Reference might be made in passing to the case of R v. Middleton [2021] EWCA Crim 587 regarding the significance of persistent reoffending in scheme design, though Middleton concerned shoplifting in multiple stores across the North West region and involved far higher-value items than those in the present case. That case serves as a broad reminder for sentencing authorities to account for the cumulative nature of offending over time, especially when dealing with repeat offenders. The court further notes the impact of current pressures on the National Health Service, particularly in mental health provision. Waiting times for psychological therapies can stretch to months or even years. While the justice system must be cognisant of these limitations, this reality cannot excuse refusal to engage with alternative support services, such as those offered by third-sector organisations. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. The role of victim liaison officers should be acknowledged. Officers assigned to similar cases undertake what can only be described as thankless work: supporting victims, coordinating witness statements, and facilitating restorative justice discussions where appropriate. Such officers continue to work under staffing shortages and competing demands from other crime types, including violent crime, serious fraud, and public disorder. Their efforts have contributed meaningfully to the victim impact statements presented in this matter. Moreover, it is relevant to mention, though not in any way to bear on the facts here, that a related environmental prosecution concluded last month in the nearby Greenford Magistrates’ Court. That case concerned the fly-tipping of construction debris in protected greenbelt land, an offence which, while unrelated, demonstrates the breadth of challenges faced by enforcement agencies balancing resources across competing priorities. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. A note on the administration of Legal Aid is prudent and, with regret, necessary. The system designed to ensure access to justice continues to face criticism for frequent delays and inconsistent application of funding approvals. In this case, the defence’s application for funding to instruct a forensic psychiatrist was significantly delayed, ultimately resolved only after intervention from the court. Such procedural inertia undermines defendants’ rights to fair representation, prolongs proceedings, and exacerbates the strain on already congested listing timetables. It is, however, proper to commend the resolute efforts of the defence counsel, Mr Marcus Feldman, who has conducted a professional and diligent representation. Mr Feldman’s submissions on your behalf were measured and articulate, highlighting, inter alia, personal hardship and the cumulative psychological effects of social disadvantage. Equally, Ms Rachel Dunham, prosecuting on behalf of the Crown Prosecution Service, presented clear and focused arguments reflecting the gravity of the offences. An observation on public perceptions of theft offenses is warranted. There remains, regrettably, a dangerous undervaluation in some quarters of crimes of this nature — perhaps encouraged by their frequency and apparent triviality. Yet the cumulative harm wrought by persistent shoplifting extends beyond individual proprietors to damage confidence in local commerce and community wellbeing. Societal attitudes towards such offences can be shaped by media narratives, online commentary, and increasingly, social media platforms where trivialisation can proliferate unchecked. While this is beyond the court’s remit, its impact on deterrence and rehabilitation is reflected in sentencing principles. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, claims it isn’t really stealing and intends to keep doing so. Such facts as I have reiterated, alongside the expert and probation reports, indicate a sequence of offending presenting a real concern for both the immediate victims and the community broadly defined. Your history of previous convictions and your demonstrated unwillingness or inability to desist despite prior interventions weigh heavily. It is plain that the offences before the court — though by no means on the scale of significant breaches such as armed robbery or serious drug importation — have nonetheless exerted a material impact on the operations of the affected businesses. Market complementation schemes, community safety initiatives, and retail vigilance campaigns all rely on the goodwill and active participation of those involved. When that is undermined through persistent criminality, the ripples extend to employees, shareholders, and customers alike. This court acknowledges the increasing complexity of the criminal landscape, which now involves, inter alia, cybercrime rings targeting e-commerce platforms, gangs exploiting technological vulnerabilities, and international networks trafficking stolen goods. None of these is present here. However, the precise nature of your offences does not diminish their consequence; indeed, the threshold for public protection and deterrence applies at all levels. The starting point for sentencing remains the Theft Act 1968 and the relevant Sentencing Council guidelines issued for offences of dishonesty. The guideline sets out offences across a spectrum from lower to higher culpability and harm. Your offences fall within the lower to medium range for both. The sentencing objectives — punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, protection of the public, and the making of reparation — guide the court’s discretion overall. Given the persistent nature of your offending, the risk of reoffending carries weight. That risk, combined with limited mitigation save for late guilty plea and personal difficulties, informs a calibrated approach. The court is mindful of the custodial threshold as explained in R v. Clarke [2019] EWCA Crim 754, which reaffirmed the importance of considering whether community-based sentences can deliver sufficient punishment, reduce risk, and effect rehabilitation without the collateral consequences of imprisonment. However, repeated similar offences often edge the balance in favour of immediate custody to mark the gravity of behaviour and incentivise change. It is well established, per R v. Winn [2022] EWCA Crim 440, that credit for guilty plea is discretionary and subject to timing, sincerity, and the saving of court time. An early plea, entered before evidence is fully marshalled, merits more substantial discounting than a last-minute admission. I will accordingly commission a detailed pre-sentence report addressing these considerations comprehensively. The report will assess risk, vulnerabilities, attitude to offence, and advise on potential interventions in custody or the community. In conclusion, the court recognizes the multifaceted nature of shoplifting offences: seemingly minor in singular incidents, but cumulatively taxing on victims, services, and societal cohesion. Effective sentencing must balance acknowledgement of personal hardship with the necessity of public protection and deterrence. These sentencing remarks are handed down this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at Westminster Crown Court. Proceedings have been duly recorded in accordance with Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal transcript will be filed accordingly. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged in this matter. Costs remain reserved pending final sentencing. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE KINGSTON CROWN COURT R v. MR H Case No. KT2025/14329 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge Eleanor J. Fairclough Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today for sentence arising from a charge of theft by shoplifting contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. This matter has been presented against the backdrop of a series of incidents extending over the past eighteen months and involving multiple retail outlets in and around the Kingston-upon-Thames area. The facts as proven are reflective of persistent and deliberate acts of acquisitive offending, the gravity of which merits careful judicial attention. Procedural History and Case Progression To recount the procedural path to this hearing: you were initially arrested on 13 February 2025 following a coordinated investigative effort spearheaded by officers of the Greater London South Crime Unit working in concert with the Kingston Business Crime Reduction Partnership. This multi-agency initiative embraced the ideals of intelligence-led policing with a focus on chronic retail theft offenders. Although shoplifting is often deemed a low-level offence by the general public, the resources marshalled to identify and apprehend you were substantial, involving surveillance operations, CCTV collation, and witness interviews. It is important to underscore the cumulative impact of such offending on the operational capacity of policing teams who are, regrettably, overburdened by the manifold demands of general law enforcement, ranging from violent crime to cyber-enabled fraud. Initial police interview took place on 18 February 2025, at Kingston Police Station. During this interview, you exercised your right to silence. However, compounding evidence, including footwear impressions and store security footage, resulted in your charge on 22 March 2025. The case was allocated under the Better Case Management (BCM) system, with listing for a plea and trial preparation hearing scheduled on 7 July 2025. The BCM initiative, now firmly entrenched across the circuits, seeks to mitigate delays evident in pre-2010 practices by imposing structured timetables, requiring early disclosure, and fostering prosecutorial and defence cooperation. While the aspirational aims of BCM are universally recognised, in practice cases such as this one still encounter adjournments due to funding applications or expert report acquisition delays. It is worth remarking that the Legal Aid Agency’s handling of funding applications in this case was notably protracted. Despite timely submission of requests by your legal team on 15 March and 28 May for funding to instruct a forensic psychologist specialising in addiction and impulsivity, formal authority was only granted on 12 August 2025. Such delays have become regrettably commonplace and impose a tangible toll on the fair administration of justice, increasing stress for defendants and burdening court fixtures. The court will be making inquiries as to whether systemic improvements can be introduced to prevent similar instances in the future. Representations have been made on your behalf by Mr Oliver K. Trent, instructed under Legal Aid. I record my thanks for his considered submissions and his patient efforts to engage with the numerous agencies involved. Ms Fiona Caldwell appears for the Crown and, as ever, I note her professional diligence in managing the prosecution file within the tight time constraints imposed by scheduling demands. Discussions at the plea and trial preparation hearing permitted the Crown to set the scene regarding the evidential position and the prospect of securing a conviction should the matter proceed contested. Your eventual guilty plea was entered on 3 September 2025, a date shortly before the trial window but notably later than the earliest possible opportunity, a factor that will bear upon any credit for plea discount. The court must remind itself that while a plea of guilty generally merits a reduction of sentence to reflect remorse and proceedings saved, where pleas are entered late—particularly after disclosure of comprehensive evidence and detailed witness statements—the discount must be prudently moderated. This principle was lucidly articulated in R v Diamond [2023] EWCA Crim 781, where the Court of Appeal confirmed that any credit for guilty plea should be tempered where the defendant’s admission arose from tactical considerations rather than genuine acceptance of responsibility. A further procedural note: this case was listed in Court 4, which underwent recent refurbishment to better accommodate vulnerable witnesses. Unfortunately, a scheduled hearing in May 2025 was vacated due to the unforeseen and regrettable absence of an essential court clerk, causing rescheduling to August. While such disruptions should be minimised, this reflects the real-world pressures under which court administration staff operate. The charge against you is governed by section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, which defines theft as the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving the owner of it. In this jurisdiction, shoplifting, while often trite in appearance, is acknowledged as carrying significant consequences for victims — both individual and commercial — and broader community confidence. The Sentencing Council’s Definitive Guideline on Theft Offences (July 2021 edition) provides detailed frameworks informing the court’s decision. It requires that factors such as the value of the goods, the degree of planning, any aggravating elements such as repeat offending or targeting vulnerable victims, and the impact on those affected be fully considered. Moreover, the guideline emphasises that sentencing should be proportionate and, where appropriate, utilise community-based disposals armed with rehabilitative resources. Of particular note is the case of R v Whelan [2022] EWCA Crim 1258, where the Court considered the sentencing of repeat shoplifters targeting pharmacies, highlighting the combined effect on victim vulnerability and public trust. Whelan emphasised that even relatively low monetary values could necessitate custodial measures if offending was persistent and wilful. In R v Greenwood [2019] EWCA Crim 492, the court clarified that the presence or absence of violence is not determinative but the psychological impact upon victims and the community must not be underestimated. Equally, in R v Thomas [2020] EWCA Crim 982, when personal mitigation was found limited, an immediate custodial sentence was upheld for an offender who demonstrated no genuine remorse and breached previous statutory orders. Furthermore, the environmental context in which offences occur is relevant to culpability. In R v Canfield [2021] EWCA Crim 2077, the court observed that offences in areas of high social deprivation or near protective social service facilities may aggravate harm and attract sterner penalties where targeting appeared deliberate. Mr H was witnessed removing the tags from £13 worth of makeup and tucking it into his inner pocket before leaving the store without payment. Amongst important contextual matters, the court is mindful that your offending took place not only in large retail supermarkets but also in smaller independent local shops. Independent shops often lack the robust security apparatuses of larger chains and rely greatly on goodwill and community trust. The burdens imposed by repeat theft on such enterprises extend beyond accounting losses and may jeopardize business viability, employment, and local economic health. Mr H concealed boxed razor cartridges and a tub of protein powder beneath items in his niece’s pram. A further consideration is the operational pressures faced by the various public services in this jurisdiction. The Kingston Safer Neighbourhood Team has reported significant resource strain due to simultaneous demands from violent crime, road traffic collisions and recent public disorder events arising from protracted industrial dispute protests affecting local transport corridors. Such resource diversification inevitably impacts their prioritisation of “non-serious” offences, yet shoplifting investigations continue as a vital preventive measure. Within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same shop on four occasions, each time removing alcohol and tobacco without paying. The Crown has made cogent submissions on the cumulative effect of your conduct. Repeated entries into the same premises, seemingly timed to coincide with periods of reduced staffing or shift changes, indicate a deliberate and planned modus operandi. The court has also received written statements from several shop staff expressing increased anxiety and distress. Many have altered their working patterns or taken steps to avoid lone shifts as a result of your activities. While there is no allegation of physical aggression, the psychological impact on these individuals is not insignificant. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. Several volunteer organisations have contributed representations in this matter, including the Kingston Rescue Outreach and Community Support Team (KROCS), which offered assistance to individuals facing homelessness and poverty in the area. KROCS staff have provided evidence of the systemic difficulties endemic to the locality, highlighting long waiting lists for social housing, the rising cost of living, and significant mental health service backlogs impacting potential vulnerable offenders. These observations resonate with wider national concerns regarding the fracturing of community networks and the attendant rise in street-level acquisitive crime. Nevertheless, as noted in R v Oakes [2023] EWCA Crim 525, context and circumstance do not diminish individual accountability. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. Your pre-sentence report, prepared by probation officer Sarah Mann, dated 10 September 2025, is a detailed and professional appraisal of your background, character, and risk profile. The report notes your history of unstable accommodation, sporadic employment, and a pattern of substance misuse dating back several years. It records your partial engagement in a previous community order for theft-related offences and outlines a moderate risk of reoffending. The report further recommends consideration of referral to a Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) programme addressing acquisitive offending and impulsivity, alongside continued addiction support through local NHS provision. Ms Mann remarks upon your inconsistent compliance with earlier interventions and urges caution in relying on positive prognosis alone. It is noted that you have declined to participate fully in substance misuse counselling to date. The defendant admitted selling the stolen items at a car boot sale and local pubs, disturbing customers. In addition, the court acknowledges the expert evidence obtained from Dr Rhian Morris, a consultant forensic psychiatrist, appointed pursuant to the defence application authorised on 12 August 2025. Dr Morris’s report, dated 1 September 2025, offers the view that while you do not meet criteria for major mental illness, there are identifiable traits consistent with borderline personality disorder, marked impulsivity, and intermittent episodes of low mood. It is further stated that your history of alcohol misuse has contributed to episodic disinhibition, which may have exacerbated offending behaviour. Dr Morris stresses the importance of multi-disciplinary management and expresses guarded optimism about potential benefits from engagement in specialist personality disorder services. The report cautions, however, against over-optimism given your history of poor attendance at appointments. Treatment adherence remains the decisive factor in both risk reduction and rehabilitation. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and challenged shop workers while damaging security cameras using spray paint, prompting serious safety fears among staff. It is instructive to place the present matter within the wider jurisprudential landscape. Acquisitive offending, while traditionally classified as low-level crime, has become increasingly scrutinised for its broader societal costs. Recent scholarly analyses published in the Journal of Criminal Justice Studies have circulated observations on the shifting dynamics of retail crime, noting technological evolutions in surveillance and self-service checkout, alongside adaptive tactics employed by offenders, including strategic concealment techniques and deliberate exploitation of staffing vulnerabilities. Court records also reveal that co-defendants in related regional cases have displayed a disparate range of offending behaviours, including possession of offensive weapons and public order offences during retail theft incidents. Such facts, while peripheral to your conduct, illustrate the complexity of the operational environment in which enforcement occurs. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. Notwithstanding these observations, the court must resist the temptation to conflate distinct individuals’ conduct or to allow collateral fact patterns to cloud precise sentencing considerations. Your offending must be addressed on its individual merits and circumstances. The Crown has urged the court to impose a sentence that reflects the seriousness of a continuing course of conduct, the cumulative detriment to victims, and the need for deterrence. The defence mitigation foregrounds your personal difficulties, partial compliance with previous orders, and expressed willingness to engage with rehabilitative programmes. In accordance with the Sentencing Council guidelines, mitigation is limited. The late plea reduces but does not extinguish plea credit. Personal circumstances, while troubling, do not amount to a sufficient cause for leniency in light of the persistence and planning evident in your offending. The court treats seriously the impact upon victims, the strain on public services, and the clear risk of recurrence absent robust intervention. The probation report and psychiatric assessment both signal the necessity of structured, community-based rehabilitative input. Custodial sentences should not be imposed lightly but remain a valid and sometimes necessary component of the sentencing spectrum in cases where public protection and deterrence demand it. I am accordingly deferring final sentencing to allow for receipt of an updated pre-sentence report which can consider any progress with service engagement, address the feasibility of bespoke programme referrals, and inform proportional sentencing options. This report should also consider risk of harm to the public and any ancillary matters warranting ancillary court orders. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 September 2025, in Court 6 of Kingston Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded under Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules 2020. A formal transcript has been prepared and will be provided to all parties. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal conviction and sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs remain reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. MR H Case No. B2025/13459 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge W. F. KENDALL Filed: 14 November 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentence following a conviction related to theft from retail premises, a matter prosecuted under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending was committed over a period extending from late 2023 through to early 2025, predominantly in the city centre of Brighton and surrounding suburban shopping areas. This court is aware that repeat offending of this nature places considerable strain not only on the victim businesses but on entire community networks of safety, commerce, and neighbourhood cohesion. Procedural History You were first brought to the attention of police authorities in late November 2024 after a string of reports from multiple retailers within a concentrated retail corridor. This led to a joint operation spearheaded by the Sussex Business Crime Unit in concert with the Brighton Safer Neighbourhood Team and representatives of the Business Improvement District (BID). Over several weeks, the investigation employed a multi-modal approach incorporating analysis of security footage, spot checks by city council enforcement officers, and liaison with the Brighton Retail Crime Prevention Partnership. It is important to note that the use of closed-circuit television (CCTV) as a primary investigative tool is subject to real-world limitations: coverage is often partial, quality inconsistent, and, as is frequently the case, the sheer volume of footage reviewed necessitates considerable officer time that could otherwise be allocated to crimes of higher severity. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. The investigation was compounded by challenges common to acquisitive crime cases: witnesses with fragmentary recollection, inconsistencies in reported stolen items, and turnover of store personnel. It was not until December 2024 that you were identified as a suspect, following both direct observation and corroborative evidence from retail loss prevention teams. You were arrested on 16 December 2024 and you subsequently elected to provide a written statement—initially denying involvement. This denial was tested and undermined by forensic examination of clothing items retrieved from your residence during a warrant executed on 17 December, which matched fibres and residues observed in multiple shoplifting incidents. The matter was initially listed at Brighton Magistrates’ Court but transferred to the Crown Court for trial due to the volume and complexity of evidence. A plea and trial preparation hearing was convened on 20 February 2025, at which you entered a not guilty plea. On 4 September 2025, on the first morning of your trial in Court 4, you changed your plea to guilty against the advice of counsel. This late plea is pertinent to sentencing considerations. Mr H concealed boxed razor cartridges and a tub of protein powder beneath items in his niece’s pram. Delays were occasioned by a number of procedural matters. Defence counsel initially made an application for funding through the Legal Aid Agency to instruct a forensic psychologist with specialist knowledge of repeat acquisitive crime. The Agency’s protracted response cycle, involving requests for further information and bureaucratic challenge, caused a postponement of court proceedings by approximately six weeks. Such delays are regrettable and not unique; they underscore the administrative burdens now confronting Legal Aid and its impact on timely justice. The court hopes that forthcoming reforms will mitigate these procedural inefficiencies. Turning to the legal framework, the Theft Act 1968’s section 1 defines theft succinctly as the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with intent to permanently deprive the owner. This seemingly simple definition belies the complexities courts face when assessing repeated offences within a given period, particularly those constituting a course of conduct. Sentencing must balance the discrete nature of individual acts against their cumulative effect. The Sentencing Council guideline for theft offences, promulgated in 2022, provides a detailed framework for assessing harm, culpability, and mitigating factors. Items are categorised primarily by value and vulnerability of victims; the deliberate selection of small independent retailers—as with your case—is considered an aggravating factor by virtue of the disproportionate impact of losses and fear caused. Additionally, the guidance emphasises that persistent offending escalates the seriousness beyond the nominal value of stolen goods. The court has also reviewed relevant guidance contained within the foreword to the Sentencing Council document, where it is acknowledged that sentencing “must be proportionate to harm caused and the offender’s culpability, recognising the cumulative impact of repeated offending”. The careful calibration required is echoed in case law. In R v. Lambert [2023] EWCA Crim 1052, the Court of Appeal confronted a series of shoplifting offences involving multiple community pharmacies and independent grocers. The defendant was found to have methodically planned occasions to enter premises during predictable lulls, employing concealment tactics and evasion. The Court found that disruptive acquisitive offences could have a “chilling effect” on local trade and warranted a custodial sentence of 14 months, particularly where there was an absence of genuine remorse or engagement with rehabilitative services. Across three weeks, Mr H visited the same small retailer four times, stealing alcohol and tobacco on each occasion. Further precedent was considered in R v. Cole [2020] EWCA Crim 870, involving a defendant who had participated in importing substantial quantities of counterfeit branded goods through parcel freight. Though the offence was unrelated to shoplifting, the court in Cole advanced the principle that a defendant’s culpability and moral blameworthiness must be assessed holistically, including their contribution to organised crime and exploitation. Such reflections are tangential to the instant matter but nonetheless informative in framing judicial response to layered patterns of dishonesty. The court is mindful of the broader sociological and systemic context in which offences like these occur. We are living in a time marked by increasing economic precarity and social dislocation. Rises in street homelessness, often entwined with untreated mental health issues, substance dependency, and fractured support networks, present significant challenges to public institutions. However, this court must also observe the strain placed on retail sectors by persistent theft. Small businesses operate under perpetual financial pressure, often absorbing shrinkage without recourse to insurance or compensation. There is a human cost: anxious staff who may face verbal abuse or feel unsafe, scheduling alterations to avoid lone working, and a sense of erosion of the communal trust fundamental to healthy commerce. It is imperative that sentencing reflects not only abstract legal principles but tangible community impact. The Sussex Police Retail Crime Unit reports that retail crime accounts for a significant proportion of daily calls. The administrative burden this imposes on limited resources diverts attention from violent crime and serious organised offences. Local policing is, regrettably, caught in a difficult balance — addressing low-level offending with disproportionate resource allocation is unsustainable. On one occasion, Mr H asked staff about Oyster Card payments as a distraction, then leaned behind the counter to take a display item. It is to be noted that your case demonstrates elements that activate the Business Crime Reduction Partnership protocols. This partnership, which incorporates police, council licensing services, retail security teams, and community safety officers, seeks to intervene early and reduce the repeat victimisation of retail premises. As is often the case, the efficacy of this multi-agency approach relies heavily on timely intelligence sharing, sustained funding, and frontline officer availability, factors which vary considerably by district. Brighton’s scheme, while ambitious, has faced challenges including recent cutbacks to its budget and staff turnover. That said, the involvement of the Retail Crime Prevention Board here has resulted in some coordinated interventions, including bespoke training for staff at affected stores on recognising distraction techniques commonly employed by persistent shoplifters. In your case, the psychiatric assessment conducted by Dr Amanda Spencer, consultant forensic psychiatrist, provided a detailed clinical picture. Dr Spencer’s report, dated 22 October 2025, draws attention to a background of emotional instability and early adverse experiences, but finds no diagnosable psychosis or severe personality disorder. Instead, the report emphasises traits of impulsivity, intermittent depressive symptoms, and mild substance misuse—principally alcohol. Dr Spencer notes that your engagement with recommended community mental health services has been sporadic, characterised by missed appointments and limited insight into the consequences of your behaviour. The report underscores that while psychiatric illness is not a main driver of your offending, there exists a risk profile involving social isolation and financial instability. Submissions from probation echo these findings. Your allocated probation officer, Ms Kim Abbott, highlighted that you have been non-compliant with previous community orders imposed in 2022, were noted to have failed to sustain regular employment since 2021, and currently reside in unstable housing, provided through a temporary placement scheme. Such instability compounds the risk of recidivism, particularly when combined with limited social supports. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. You have made reference in correspondence to your estranged relationship with your family, though attempts to verify engagement have been inconclusive. Your previous dependence on informal networks of support was reportedly bounded by episodes of conflict and disconnection. This court recognises the complex personal dynamics at play but weighs them cautiously when considering personal responsibility. I must again commend the patience and professionalism of the probation service in this case, which continues to manage extensive caseloads and systemic staffing shortages. The recent recruitment drive aimed at bolstering intermediate-level officers is hoped to improve supervision levels, but the backlog remains substantial. Victim statements presented through the Brighton Retail Crime Partnership articulate the extent to which your offending has eroded staff confidence and operational viability. Retail managers detailed alterations to store opening hours and security measures implemented explicitly in response to theft fears. One statement, from Mr Leonard Simeon, manager of a community grocer on Western Road, indicated that staff turnover had increased following your visits, citing emotional exhaustion among employees. Such human consequences, although intangible, underscore the broader harm resultant from acquisitive crime. The Retail Support Network—a voluntary group providing advisory and restorative services to victims—submitted a letter recognising the ongoing challenges of engaging with perpetrators at this level of criminality. They emphasised that the trauma experienced by retail employees from persistent theft is often underestimated and rarely visible to the public. The defendant said he had sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in pubs, with his presence causing concern among other customers. I acknowledge the courteous conduct of counsel during these proceedings. Mrs Caroline Forster, representing the Crown, delivered submissions reflecting a balanced appreciation for the mitigating evidence alongside the need for deterrence. Mr James Warren, appearing under a representation order, advanced a cogent mitigating case drawing upon your difficult circumstances, late entry of plea, and absence of violence. This courtroom itself was refurbished earlier this year following grant funding. The improved lighting and acoustics have enhanced the environment, though it remains staffed by the same diligent usher team who have maintained calm order throughout a crowded and busy session today. It is worth noting that this case was listed at several points in the last six months and was twice postponed due to Covid-19-related staffing shortages, reflecting the burden placed on criminal justice resources since the pandemic and ongoing public sector workforce constraints. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. Having reviewed all materials and submissions, I return to the salient principles. Your offending constitutes a sustained course of dishonesty, with clear evidence of planning and repeat engagement in theft at multiple premises. Such persistence demonstrates significant culpability. The harm occasioned extends beyond mere financial loss. The psychological impact on employees, the disruption to business operations, and the drain on public resources must be recognised. Your history of previous convictions for similar conduct is a material aggravating factor, as is your failure to desist despite warnings and prior community measures. The mitigation acknowledged includes your current personal difficulties, your late plea of guilty, and some degree of cooperation with supervision since arrest. Nevertheless, the multiplicity of offences and the breadth of impact temper the extent of credit granted. This court is conscious of evolving sentencing frameworks emphasising rehabilitation and desistance. A pre-sentence report will be critical in assessing appropriate community-based interventions, including cognitive behavioural programmes and structured employment support. It should also explore financial management assistance and engagement with substance misuse services. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. It is incumbent upon the probation service to explore whether a community order inclusive of rehabilitation activity, unpaid work, and a drug and alcohol treatment requirement could be feasibly complied with in your circumstances. The risk to public confidence and safety inherent in repeated acquisitive offending requires a proportionate and carefully tailored response. Custodial sentences, while sometimes necessary, should be a last resort when community sanctions are unlikely to succeed. The court acknowledges the challenge of balancing punitive and rehabilitative aims in cases underpinned by complex social and psychological factors. Notwithstanding, public protection, accountability, and deterrence remain fundamental. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 November 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Brighton. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The record of conviction will be forwarded forthwith to relevant authorities. You are advised of your right to appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. No costs are presently ordered. These are the orders of the court.
