input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT MANCHESTER R v. Mr H Case No. M2025/14578 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. E. Carrington Filed: 3 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence regarding offences of theft from retail premises, insofar as they arose over an extended period within the Greater Manchester area. The charges before the court represent a culmination of your conduct classified under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, involving acts committed from approximately mid-2023 through into early 2025. They predominantly relate to persistent shoplifting incidents at various retail establishments clustered around both urban and peri-urban localities. The procedural history in this matter is itself emblematic of the complexities faced by modern criminal justice processes in the domain of acquisitive crime. You were apprehended on 19 February 2025 following a protracted investigation led by the Manchester City Retail Crime Partnership, in conjunction with the Greater Manchester Police’s Economic Crime Unit and supported by private sector security providers. This inquiry was precipitated by an uptick in reported instances of stock shrinkage across a selection of medium-sized department stores and convenience outlets, which had established internal protocols to flag repeat incidents matching a specific suspect profile. The intersection of private-sector asset protection and public law enforcement in such cases brings to the fore a number of operational considerations, notably the fragmentation of ownership structures across retail chains and variations in security infrastructure. While some locations benefit from sophisticated electronic tagging systems and extensive CCTV coverage, others rely largely on manual observation and point-of-sale audits, complicating evidence gathering and case continuity. Furthermore, the resource constraints faced by investigatory teams tasked with assembling prosecution cases in these low-value but high-volume offences cannot be overstated. I must take this opportunity to place on record my appreciation for the staff of the Manchester Retail Crime Partnership. Their meticulous collation of internal loss prevention records, combined with collaboration with frontline policing officers, facilitated the assembly of the evidential base in a manner that prevented otherwise foreseeable delays. It is a testament to the commitment of all parties involved that this matter has progressed to trial without the chronic procedural stasis seen elsewhere. It is nevertheless a salutary reminder of the administrative burden imposed by even low-level offending on an overstretched criminal justice system. You were interviewed under caution at the Manchester Custody Centre on 20 February 2025. Initially, your responses were equivocal, with a number of denials and vague references to mental health difficulties. Nonetheless, the police investigation was buttressed by CCTV imagery captured across multiple premises and corroborated by witness statements. Your defence team utilised the Better Case Management (BCM) framework to elicit disclosure of prosecution materials and to ensure adherence to case preparation timetables. The BCM protocol, which has been in place since 2014, was designed to enhance the efficiency of pre-trial processes, emphasising early guilty pleas and thorough case management hearings. While generally effective in streamlining proceedings, its demands often expose weaknesses in agency cooperation and evidential readiness, yet this case represents something closer to the ideal. Petitioners and defendants alike face a multitude of challenges navigating the contemporary court system. Among these are the ongoing pressures exerted by funding constraints in the Legal Aid regime. Indeed, I am compelled to express a degree of frustration with the inconsistent and protracted approval process surrounding applications for expert psychiatric assistance submitted on your behalf. The delay in instructing the consultant forensic psychiatrist — Dr Gabrielle Whitman — required repeated interlocutions over a six-week period before clearance was obtained. Such bureaucratic impediments impede not only efficient case resolution but also risk undermining the principle of fair trial. The court is in earnest hopes that the Legal Aid Agency will review its administrative procedures to prevent repetition. Moreover, it is notable that your plea of guilty was entered belatedly on the morning of the scheduled trial. This, regrettably, is a regrettably frequent occurrence in matters involving acquisitive offending. While the law affords defendants the option to contest charges up to the point of conviction, late pleas diminish the opportunity for the court to confer the full benefit of mitigation. The case law is plain on this issue. In R v. Beckett [2019] EWCA Crim 1333, the Court of Appeal emphasised that credit for plea must correspond to not only the fact of a plea, but also its timing relative to the progression and strength of the prosecution evidence. Similar principles were reaffirmed in R v. Pritchard [2022] EWCA Crim 579, where limited guilty plea credit was upheld due to plea timing. I pause here to address the broader societal context in which offending of this nature should be situated. The incremental escalation of low-level acquisitive crime, particularly in underserved communities, places substantive pressure on retail businesses and by extension the wider local economy. There remains a notable pattern of store closures attributed, in no small part, to persistent shrinkage. The economic repercussions extend beyond immediate financial loss, affecting staff job security and consumer confidence. The court is also mindful of the psychological impact experienced by frontline retail employees, a group disproportionately exposed to the stress of repeated theft incidents and resultant operational changes. In an era marked by significant social disruption, and concomitant strains on public services, one observes a marked increase in street homelessness and drug dependence within the localities overlapping retail centres. These factors contribute to a complex mosaic of vulnerability and opportunity, both influencing and compounding patterns of acquisitive crime. Critically, courts must resist the temptation to conflate causation with justification; while social context informs sentencing discretion, it does not excuse breach of law. Mr H hid £17 worth of grooming items under his jacket and walked past the tills without stopping to pay. The facts of this case situate themselves firmly within this established framework: a series of calculated, recurrent thefts involving deliberate concealment of goods, timed to coincide with staff absences or momentary distractions. Your conduct evidences a modus operandi honed over months, employing misdirection and concealment devices designed to subvert detection. Such behaviour requires a measured response. Mr H placed protein powder and razor blade refills in his niece’s pushchair in an attempt to hide them. The well-established principles set forth by the Sentencing Council’s guideline on theft are instructive. The importance of assessing culpability and harm requires close examination of patterns of behaviour, propensity for reoffending, and underlying motivation. While financial loss in individual instances may be modest, cumulative harm to retail businesses, staff wellbeing, and community order is material. I note too the guidance in R v. Fairbanks [2021] EWCA Crim 744, where the Court stressed the detrimental public impact of recidivist shoplifting within deprived zones. Across three weeks, Mr H visited the same small retailer four times, stealing alcohol and tobacco on each occasion. The court has had the benefit of a psychiatric report prepared by Dr Whitman, who conducted a thorough assessment over several consultations in custody and at the appointed clinic. The report is both detailed and professionally composed. It reasonably concludes that you suffer no serious mental disorder but identifies traits consistent with adjustment disorder and chronic anxiety symptoms. Importantly, it notes a background of unstable housing, bouts of intermittent substance misuse, and a history of traumatic childhood experiences, though it carefully delineates these from direct causal links to offending. Mr H used a query about Oyster Card use to draw the attention of staff away, before taking a displayed product from behind the counter. The report offers a degree of optimism regarding your amenability to targeted psychological interventions, recommending consideration of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy to address impulsivity and decision-making deficits. Parallel to this, the probation service has submitted a pre-sentence report highlighting challenges concerning your accommodation status, employment history, and limited engagement with rehabilitative programmes. These agencies note the chronic under-resourcing of mental health and social care services, which serves as a constraining factor on effective support provision. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. Notably, your previous contact with probation services has been sporadic and marked by non-attendance, a pattern unfortunately replicated in many cases of persistent acquisitive offending. The probation report additionally raises concerns about a tendency to understate the seriousness of your conduct, which may impede compliance with future court-imposed conditions. This aligns with known obstacles faced in enforcing community sentences, particularly in relation to offenders with unstable personal circumstances. The defendant confessed to offloading the stolen items at local pubs and a car boot sale, where his actions unsettled customers. In considering the wider criminal record, you have previous convictions principally comprising offences of shoplifting and minor public order incidents. There is no suggestion of violent conduct or organised criminal association. Previous court interventions have included conditional discharges and community orders, yet these have yielded limited behavioral change. The present offending thus represents a clear breach of prior assurances and court recommendations. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. This court is conscious that the circumstances of your upbringing and current vulnerability are part of the background that may speak to mitigation. However, justice must maintain its central focus: protection of the public, deterrence, and rehabilitation. The law does not operate in a vacuum seperate from social realities but calibrates its responses to reoffending risks and the imperative of public safety. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. I note with interest the submissions made by counsel on behalf of the Crown and defence. Ms Helen Bowers, prosecuting, succinctly but firmly outlined the collective impact on the victims—small business owners and staff—whose statements reveal not merely loss but also a corrosive effect on the sense of security and community cohesion. Mr Owen Childress, representing you, advanced a plea for leniency grounded in your personal circumstances and a purported readiness to engage fully with rehabilitative measures post-sentencing. Before addressing sentencing options, I reflect upon the evolving case law in this domain. The decision in R v. Mayfield [2023] EWCA Crim 888 underscored the appellate courts' continued emphasis on tailored rehabilitation, especially in cases where psychiatric or psychological factors are implicated. It provides useful guidance on balancing custodial sentences and community orders with sufficiently robust supervision and therapeutic support. However, the same authorities affirm that persistent or escalated offending necessitates a firm punitive response. In R v. Cornwall [2020] EWCA Crim 577, the Court reaffirmed that repeated acquisitive offences warrant sentences that commensurately reflect the cumulative impact and the need for deterrence, notwithstanding the absence of physical violence. While community sentences remain a vital tool, the threshold for immediate custody may be met where prior interventions have failed and the risks of ongoing harm are judged to be significant. It has been brought to the court’s attention that the legal framework surrounding sentencing has undergone subtle but important adjustments, including the introduction of structured sentencing options enhanced by rehabilitative conditions such as the Rehabilitation Activity Requirement and Mental Health Treatment Requirements. These innovations seek to address root causes without defaulting to incarceration, where appropriate. The Crown and defence are in agreement that a pre-sentence report is indispensable to inform a proportionate approach. Such reports serve a crucial function in appraising risk, identifying suitable interventions, and providing the sentencing judge with a comprehensive corpus of information through which to balance competing interests. The wider statutory and policy context cannot be ignored. The strain placed on probation staff by expanding caseloads, reduced budgets, and complex offender profiles represents a salient challenge. Similarly, mental health services remain under significant pressure, with waiting times and thresholds creating barriers to timely treatment. These systemic issues do not excuse individual offending but frame the environment within which sentencing decisions must be situated. Added to this is the reality of the enduring backlog in the Crown Court system, exacerbated by recent disruptions including industrial action and pandemic-related effects. Delays in the administration of justice inevitably impact defendants, victims, and the public alike, underscoring the value in expeditious resolution of cases where possible. The case has also been marked by a series of adjournments, notably due to the late provision of expert reports and the need to allow the Legal Aid Agency to authorise private instructions for psychiatric examinations. Such procedural episodes illustrate perennial challenges in balancing defendant rights with the public interest in effective case management. Turning briefly to ancillary matters, I note that reference has been made to prior unrelated family court proceedings involving a sibling of the defendant which, while unfortunate, bear no relevance to the case at hand. Similarly, the landlord of the property where you currently reside has been the subject of a noise abatement notice unrelated to these proceedings. These facts serve as contextual background but do not bear upon the assessment of culpability or risk. I also observe, without comment on evidentiary weight, that a co-defendant linked to unrelated charges of affray and possession of a bladed article remains at large, an issue peripheral to this matter but illustrative of the complexities in multi-agency policing efforts in the locality. The public interest demands that the sentencing outcome not only reflects the seriousness of the offending but also serves to maintain confidence that repeat acquisitive crime will not be tolerated or minimized. This court must exercise its discretion in accordance with established principles, ensuring that decisions are fair, proportionate, and informed by the full factual matrix. At this juncture, I adjourn sentencing to allow the probation service to compile a comprehensive pre-sentence report encompassing not only your personal circumstances and offending history but also an assessment of your current risk profile and prospects for rehabilitation. This will be supplemented, as necessary, by input from relevant health and social services. I direct that all efforts be made to expedite the preparation of such reports, in recognition of the court’s duty to administer justice without unnecessary delay, mindful always of fairness to all parties concerned. These sentencing remarks are made this day, 3 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Manchester. The record of these proceedings has been formally recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. Mr H is advised of his rights to appeal pursuant to section 108 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and under the Criminal Appeal Act 1968, should he elect to do so, within the statutory 28-day period. No reporting restrictions have been applied pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Matters of cost are reserved to the final sentencing hearing. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. Mr H Case No. T2025/14739 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge G. L. Archwell Filed: 15 August 2025 Mr H, you are before this court today for sentence relating to offences of theft from retail premises, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct occurred over an extended period spanning from September 2023 to February 2025, involving multiple locations across the city and surrounding boroughs. Procedural History Your first appearance at this court took place on 12 March 2025. The matter was originally listed before the Magistrates’ Court at Lewes, but the seriousness of the charges and the amount involved necessitated committal to the Crown Court for disposal under the Better Case Management (BCM) scheme instituted in 2016. I record, with some relief, that this case was processed within the indicative time limits mandated by the Criminal Procedure Rules (CPR), albeit with a short adjournment that was sought by the defence to allow for further disclosure requests. The Better Case Management system, as established by CPR Part 3, mandates early identification of issues, timely disclosure, and efficient listing of hearings. While the system aims to reduce delay and avoid unnecessary adjournments, reality often falls short. In the course of this case, the court witnessed an amicable but protracted process with diligent engagement from all parties. I acknowledge and thank counsel for their consistent cooperation despite the often cramped listing schedules affecting the Crown Court registry. The availability and clarity of evidence was initially constrained by incomplete CCTV footage from certain premises, which only became centrally available following liaison between separate local policing units and the city council’s Business Crime Reduction Partnership. This multi-agency collaboration, while laudable in principle, revealed the ongoing challenges faced by institutional partners in managing fragmented information streams and disparate data formats. There was also an unfortunate and avoidable delay occasioned by the Legal Aid Agency’s protracted consideration of the defence application for expert psychiatric evaluation. Initial requests submitted on 7 May 2025 were not approved until mid-June, resulting in a truncated timetable for the defence expert. Such recurrent administrative bottlenecks warrant continued scrutiny and reform, given their impact on the timely delivery of justice. You initially pleaded not guilty at your first hearing on 12 March but entered a guilty plea on 1 July 2025, just days before the scheduled trial window. The court observes with some concern that this late admission of guilt, while now accepted, deprived witnesses of the relief of avoiding the ordeal of trial preparation and attendance. Credit for a guilty plea is apportioned in accordance with the guidelines set out by the Sentencing Council and the established common law on this matter. The Court of Appeal in R v Hamer [2021] EWCA Crim 1441 has emphatically reminded sentencing courts that the timing of a plea is critical to determining the degree of discount, with earlier pleas meriting greater credit in recognition of the procedural economy and expression of genuine remorse. Late pleas entered at the lump-sum point of inevitable conviction carry significantly reduced credit. It remains necessary to remind all parties that the goal of sentencing is not merely to respond to the crime but to reduce reoffending and protect the public. Repeated acquisitive offending is regrettably linked to entrenched criminal careers and often exacerbated by unmet vulnerabilities, social deprivation, or mental health challenges. One cannot discuss such cases without reference to the expanding body of domestic and comparative case law that grapples with the nuanced boundaries between culpability, welfare considerations, and the demands of public protection. For instance, in R v. Wilkes [2019] EWCA Crim 334, the court dealt with an individual exhibiting complex needs and multiple supporting interventions. While that case involved drug-related acquisitive offences rather than straight theft, it is instructive in suggesting how a court might calibrate sentencing to reflect both risk and reformative potential. Similarly, it is worth recalling the dicta in R v. Weatherill [2020] EWCA Crim 496, where the Court of Appeal emphasised that repeat shoplifting, while often viewed tritely by the public, inflicts real harm upon small business owners, erodes community confidence, and places burdens on an already strained criminal justice system. In the course of this case, the court received and considered a number of witness statements and victim impact reports. I commend the patience and professionalism of retail staff and managers who repeatedly encounter the anxiety and disruption caused by opportunistic theft. It is a misconception to regard such offences as victimless — they have tangible ramifications for employees’ sense of safety and the financial viability of small enterprises. Moreover, this court notes with appreciation the work of the Brighton Business Crime Partnership, which has endeavoured to provide both procedural assistance and moral support to affected businesses amidst rising crime rates. Their submissions underscore the cumulative toll even “low-value” theft imposes on shop floor morale, staff turnover, and security measures. The defendant resides within the city borough and has no registered employment. Attempts were made by the Probation Service to engage you with community-based support initiatives, although these were somewhat hampered by your inconsistent cooperation. Similarly, input from the mental health services was facilitated following instruction of a forensic clinical psychologist, Dr Sally Brant, whose report was received just prior to sentencing. Dr Brant notes the absence of a formal psychiatric diagnosis but remarks upon traits consistent with impulsivity and limited capacity for future planning. She also highlights an underlying history of substance misuse and social instability. Mr H was seen slipping £11 worth of personal hygiene products into his jacket before leaving the shop without paying. I turn now to the detailed facts as proven at trial or admitted through your plea. The conduct represents a patterned and repeated approach, rather than an isolated lapse. This sustained offending involved deception, disguise, and actions calculated to avoid detection. The modus operandi included concealment of goods in clothing and the deactivation or removal of security tags. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. The court heard evidence that at times you conducted offending in the presence of other individuals who were either known associates or casual acquaintances. This raises questions about potential ancillary influence or encouragement, though no charge was brought against any purported co-offender. The wider issue of co-defendant involvement is well exemplified in other cases, such as R v. Partridge [2022] EWCA Crim 682, where complex networks of opportunistic thieves coordinated their approaches to avoid suspicion. No such extensive conspiracy was found here, but courts remain alert to signs of organised involvement as an aggravating factor. On four separate visits within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same small shop and stole alcohol and tobacco products. The court also considers the impact on local business proprietors, some of whom reported recoding losses in the several hundreds of pounds over the period of your activity. Security enhancements, including the installation of additional CCTV and staffing adjustments, were deployed, further straining operational budgets and staffing resources already affected by post-pandemic economic pressures. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. Often neglected in sentencing are insights from frontline workers who experience an erosion of safety culture. The reports submitted on behalf of the employers document heightened anxiety and diminished job satisfaction among staff who feared confrontation or reprisal. This is regrettably paralleled by an uptick in aggressive incidents, including verbal threats and occasional physical altercations unrelated to the present defendant yet contributing to an overall climate of fear. It is within this backdrop that community safety partnerships strive to contain wider antisocial behaviour and its attendant harms. The defendant employed a magnet to detach a security tag from the item, and the magnet was located when police searched The defendant. The submissions filed by your legal representatives highlight certain mitigating matters, including a history of childhood instability and educational disruption. Reference was made to a letter from a longstanding family friend, Ms Joanne H., testifying to your early struggles with housing insecurity and episodic neglect. There was also mention of the impact of longstanding socio-economic deprivation on your educational outcomes and personal self-efficacy. The psychological report, while not evidencing a diagnosable condition, acknowledges deficits in impulse control and emotional regulation which may be relevant to your offending profile. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. However, any such mitigation must be balanced against the persistence of offending despite prior warnings and attempts at early diversion. Over recent years you have accumulated several previous convictions and community resolutions for related conduct. Your previous sentencing history includes a custodial order for an unrelated offence of criminal damage committed in 2021, which underlines a pattern of defiance towards authority. The impact of such antecedents upon current sentencing is well settled; see for example R v. Stevens [2019] EWCA Crim 827. It must also be remembered that credit for late guilty plea is necessarily limited under the established framework. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. Parole and probation officers involved in preparing precursor reports have noted your sporadic engagement with allocated support services. That is regrettable, given the array of community resources at your disposal through the local authority and voluntary sector. Agencies like the Brighton Outreach Network and SafeSpace Brighton have been proactive in extending offers of assistance. Copy correspondence received from SafeSpace highlights their repeated invitations to you for counselling and financial advice, all of which went unanswered. The probation officer references the burdens faced by frontline staff who, amid chronic underfunding and high caseloads, strive to maintain continuity in supervision and rehabilitation. The strain on such resources is well documented in government reports and parliamentary inquiries. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. In considering the appropriate sentence, this court is guided not only by the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft offences (2020) but also informed by jurisprudence on culpability and harm from the Court of Appeal. The categorisation of offending within these guidelines hinges upon factors such as frequency, sophistication, the value of goods stolen, and the consequent effect upon victims. Even though the aggregate monetary loss here might be considered modest in absolute terms, the constellation of aggravating features — including repeated offending, targeting of vulnerable premises, and failure to respond to prior sanctions — legitimise a firm approach. The court is mindful of the principle of proportionality enshrined in section 142 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, which demands balancing retributive, preventive, and rehabilitative objectives. In assessing the line between community-based sanctions and immediate custody, the nature of the offending pattern and the demonstrated disengagement from support services weigh heavily. It is a serious challenge to balance the need to foster rehabilitation with the imperative to deter, particularly in cases exhibiting entrenched recidivism. The court also gives due regard to the increasing body of evidence linking cognitive behavioural interventions with reductions in offending among acquisitive criminals. The Probation Service’s forthcoming pre-sentence report will therefore consider the extent to which such programmes, perhaps combined with financial counselling and substance misuse support, might be feasibly integrated into any community order. It is rare for a case of this sort to be resolved without some degree of custodial sentence, but the final determination must await all relevant reports. This court also regrets the absence of media coverage of this case, depriving the public of insight into the broader social harms occasioned by what some may deem “minor” offending. Transparency remains a cornerstone of democratic justice, even when headlines are marked by the lack of sensationalism. The reality of criminal justice is often more humdrum but no less vital. In closing, I record my thanks to the Crown prosecution advocate, Ms Elaine Barlow, and to your counsel, Mr Thomas Fenton, both of whom have ably represented their respective clients and navigated the procedural complexities herein. I further acknowledge the patient and diligent service of court staff, ushers, and clerks, whose efforts underpin the administration of justice amid often heavy caseloads. I reserve sentence pending receipt and consideration of a detailed pre-sentence report, encompassing assessments from probation and liaison with mental health and social care providers. You are reminded that this court expects full engagement with any rehabilitation activities ordered and that failure to comply will attract swift and robust response. The court will give due consideration to all relevant aggravating and mitigating features and is particularly interested in learning whether a tailored community sentence might feasibly reconcile the competing objectives of public protection and rehabilitation. Further hearing is provisionally listed for 16 October 2025 in Court 5 at Brighton Crown Court. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 August 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Brighton. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the appropriate authorities for registration. You are advised of your right to appeal within 28 days of sentencing pursuant to section 108(1) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged here. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT MANSFIELD R v. MR H Case No. T2025/13479 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. F. MERRICK Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today to be sentenced in respect of theft, committed through a series of shoplifting offences, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct covers a protracted period spanning some fourteen months and involves multiple retail properties within the Mansfield, Ashfield, and Newark districts. Though ostensibly low-value in each individual instance, the pattern of repeated offending and the cumulative impact on victims and local community business cannot be overstated. Procedural Chronology and Case Management Your arrest occurred on 1 May 2025, following a prolonged investigation initiated by the Nottinghamshire Police Economic Crime Unit in conjunction with the Mansfield Business Crime Forum. The case owes its progression in no small part to the vigilance of store personnel and the local authorities' increasing investment in specialist crime reduction strategies. Detection arose from the collation of observational intelligence, cross-referenced CCTV content, and itemised inventory reports over an extended interval. Naturally, such investigations are resource-intensive affairs, requiring considerable manpower deployment, digital forensic analysis, and logistical co-ordination with non-police partners. As has been noted in numerous similar cases, this collaborative effort between the public and private sectors, while often heralded as exemplary on paper, struggles against persistent systemic pressure points—swelling caseloads, overstretched staff, and bureaucratic impediments. It would be remiss not to acknowledge that these practical realities inevitably shape the nature, timeliness, and outcomes of such adjudications. Mr H was seen hiding £15 worth of over-the-counter medicines in his jacket and walking out without making a purchase. Legal Aid proceedings in this case proved protracted. Early applications for funding to retain an independent forensic psychologist, to assist in forming a complete clinical picture of the defendant, faced multiple refusals and requests for clarification from the Legal Aid Agency. This introduced avoidable adjournments. The court reiterates its concern over the frequently encountered delays attributable to Legal Aid administration, which compromise defendants' rights to expedition and undermine the operational efficiency of the criminal justice system. These issues are emblematic of a national challenge, well-documented and yet persistently unresolved, which calls for systemic reforms beyond this sitting. During preliminary hearings convened between June and August 2025, the court observed intermittent absences of prosecution witnesses due to operational reassignments within police units, alongside administrative disruptions caused by nationwide staff shortages in Probation Service teams. The multiplicity of such peripheral obstacles serves as a sobering reminder of the fragile interdependencies upon which effective criminal justice discourse rests. It is also worth noting that the court’s registry recently underwent refurbishment of its public waiting areas—a comparatively benign development amidst more pressing institutional strains yet testament to the ongoing commitment to providing a dignified environment. I record formally my thanks to Ms Caroline Jenkinson, appearing on behalf of the Crown Prosecution Service, whose precise and measured submissions have advanced the prosecution case with commendable clarity. Likewise, I acknowledge Mr Dominic Yeats, instructed on your behalf via a Legal Aid order, whose advocacy has been diligent, notwithstanding the endemic systemic pressures described above. The defence’s application for a pre-sentence psychiatric evaluation was eventually facilitated with the generous cooperation of Dr Andrew Lascombe, consultant forensic psychiatrist, whose report will be further considered in due course. The court notes the difficulties encountered by the defence team in securing interpreter services on two separate occasions, an issue regrettably common in courts handling complex or resource-heavy caseloads. Additionally, the presence of Court Usher Ms Matilda Rowe merits mention for maintaining courtroom order despite the scheduling pressures and intermittent delays. Such recognition is not perfunctory but an acknowledgment of the essential human elements underpinning the judiciary’s work. We are all witnesses to an era marked by growing societal challenges; the ongoing effects of economic austerity, the fragilities within public health provision, and a complex interplay between social deprivation and crime. Mansfield, like many post-industrial towns, grapples with rising levels of street homelessness exacerbated by supply-constrained housing markets and deteriorating social supports. While such contextualising factors cannot excuse unlawful conduct, they form an unavoidable backdrop against which offending patterns must be understood. A leading report published by the Centre for Crime and Justice Studies in 2023 highlighted that repeat shoplifting offences often intersect with chronic homelessness, untreated addiction, and minimal access to mental health support. These are alarming trends, but not insurmountable ones, provided that agencies collaborate effectively and resources are allocated rationally. Mr H deliberately used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and a container of protein powder. It is also incumbent upon this court to observe that community responses to retail crime remain a balancing act. The Mansfield Local Business Crime Reduction Partnership (LBCRP), resilient despite funding constraints, has pioneered a series of non-punitive interventions, including offender engagement panels and retailer education programmes. These initiatives have been cautiously successful in diverting some low-risk individuals from custody and encouraging sustainable desistance. Yet, there persists a growing public weariness with persistent low-level crime—the kind often perceived as “victimless” but in reality deeply corrosive to local enterprise and community cohesion. Turning to authorities, in R v. Thornley [2019] EWCA Crim 1027, the Court upheld a custodial sentence for a defendant convicted of a prolonged series of shop thefts totalling in value over £3,000. Despite the absence of violence, the Court stressed the broader social harm and the undermining of public confidence in civic order. While the facts in Thornley differ in terms of scale, the principle that repetitive dishonesty undermines retail security and public trust remains pertinent. In R v. Sidhu [2021] EWCA Crim 1407, a case concerning cumulative theft from multiple charity shops across Leeds, the defendant's clinically significant personality disorder was considered in mitigation. Nonetheless, the Court emphasised that psychiatric diagnoses do not confer impunity and that sentences must reflect the totality of offending with a view to deterrence. Dr Lascombe’s report, whilst noting certain personality traits and stress-related vulnerabilities, did not diagnose any grave psychiatric disorder. Further, in R v. Gilmour [2017] EWCA Crim 1235, a defendant’s attempt to claim credit for a late guilty plea in a string of thefts was scrutinized. The Court made clear that the timing and circumstances of a plea are essential to determining credit entitlement, especially where a plea is entered only after the preponderance of evidence becomes indisputable. That principle governs this case, to which I will return. The Court’s understanding of the relevant background narrative is as follows. Your offending spanned a period from February 2024 to April 2025, during which you repeatedly entered a range of retail premises, including supermarkets, pharmaceutical dispensaries, and small convenience shops. The offending bears hallmarks of calculated conduct, with evidence indicative of repeated concealment of goods under clothing and in personal bags, use of distraction techniques directed at shop staff, and frequent return visits to the same stores. Mr H repeatedly targeted the same local store, returning four times in three weeks to steal alcohol and tobacco. It is clear from CCTV and witness accounts that you did not shy away from employing a range of tactics to avoid apprehension. On multiple occasions, you were observed removing security tags with implements brought for this purpose, altering packaging to mislead scanning devices, and exiting through emergency exits when unobserved. Notably, on one incident, you were recorded wearing dark, non-descript clothing and a face covering, an escalation that suggests an awareness of and willingness to circumvent detection. Mr H asked about topping up an Oyster Card as a pretext to divert attention, then took a display item from behind the shop counter. Although no direct threats or violence were used, the impact on retail staff has been profound. Several have reported increased anxiety and feelings of vulnerability during shifts. Changing working patterns, the imposition of restrictive store protocols, and sometimes the shortening of employee hours have all been attributed to the disruption caused by your actions. These ancillary consequences, though perhaps intangible, weigh heavily in the balance of culpability. During his arrest, officers recovered a magnet used to remove a security tag earlier that day. There is further evidence before the court that after previous warnings, informal community resolutions, and invitations to participate in diversion programmes, you resumed such conduct within a matter of months. This cycle of offending, intervention, and relapse compounds concern over your receptiveness to rehabilitative efforts. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. Correspondence with the Mansfield Probation Office confirms your inconsistent attendance at appointments and limited engagement with offered support services. Local homelessness charities also report a sporadic relationship with outreach teams, despite clear vulnerabilities. Victim statements submitted on behalf of several affected businesses speak of lost revenue, reduced staff morale, and increasing pressure to invest in additional security measures, including CCTV, security personnel, and electronic tagging systems. Such expenses, borne entirely by small business owners already operating within tight margins, have cumulative knock-on effects on local employment and community wellbeing. Indirect victims also include local customers, who face reduced store hours or diminished choice owing to the shuttering of vulnerable outlets. Dr Lascombe’s report makes clear that whilst you do not suffer from acute mental illness, there is evidence of low-level substance dependency and a personality profile characterised by poor impulse control and pronounced emotional dysregulation. He observes that these factors may have exacerbated your vulnerability to social and economic pressures, yet also notes that you have demonstrated limited insight into the consequences of your actions. The report adds that motivational readiness for change appears minimal at present, with a need for intensive psychological intervention should meaningful rehabilitation be sought. It is a matter of public record that government and NHS services dealing with addiction and mental health are under considerable strain nationally. Waiting lists for outpatient psychiatric support exceed average targets by several months in this region, and while these systemic deficits are well recognised, they cannot be permitted to operate as a general excuse for defaulting adult behaviour. To place responsibility solely with overstretched services is to shirk the personal accountability that this court must uphold. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, causing alarm and disruption in the store. The Probation Service's Presentence Report further highlights the socioeconomic challenges facing you, including precarious housing conditions and intermittent family support. Despite these factors, and notwithstanding various local schemes aimed at diverting individuals engaged in acquisitive offending towards training or employment, compliance has been patchy and inconsistent. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, doesn't view his actions as theft and intends to keep doing so. The cumulative effect of such behaviour is to diminish the credibility of community interventions designed to reduce reoffending. That is regrettable. It burdens an already overstretched probation system tasked with administering complex caseloads often numbering well beyond recommended limits. It is not lost on this court that those caseloads contain a diverse range of individuals, many of whom engage earnestly with their orders, yet outcomes vary widely and are influenced by numerous external factors. Adjunct Observations on Wider Criminal Justice Pressures It warrants brief mention that this case has been listed for sentence following adjournments occasioned partly by national strike action among legal professionals and court staff, as well as partial disruption caused by competing trials involving serious sexual offences in Court 4. These events, though external to your matter, illustrate the real-world pressures that compound the administration of justice and accentuate the importance of procedural efficiency when possible. Also of passing note: one co-defendant named in an unrelated matter about fly-tipping was arrested concurrently but was not connected with your offences in any legal or evidential respect. The unrelated charges involved deposition of construction waste on designated green belt land at Bowthorpe. This serves only to underscore the variety and complexity of enforcement duties borne by local police forces. In framing an appropriate sentence, the court is guided by the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline for theft offences. This guidance insists on a multifaceted analysis encompassing the culpability of the offender, the harm caused, any aggravating and mitigating features, and the overarching principles of punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. Your offending is assessed as persistent and calculated, exhibiting a pattern of deliberate deception and evasion. While no physical violence transpired, the psychological and economic harm to victims is real and significant. Your previous convictions for similar conduct, though not recent, demonstrate a relevant history that cannot be overlooked. The question of whether to impose immediate custody, a community order, or a suspended sentence hinges on these factors, as well as your prospects for compliance and rehabilitation. Your late guilty plea is noted, although it was entered only after disclosure of compelling evidence. As per the guidance elucidated in R v. Fentham [2020] EWCA Crim 542, the degree of plea credit reflects not merely admission but timing and sincerity. I am also cognisant of the fact that community safety includes the preservation of workplaces as secure environments and the maintenance of consumer confidence in local markets. Persistent theft erodes these foundations and, by extension, social cohesion. Finally, it merits restating that your circumstances, including housing insecurity and possible substance dependency, while undoubtedly challenging, do not diminish the gravity of your conduct. Nonetheless, these factors must be balanced fairly and justly against the need to foster rehabilitation and prevent reoffending. I will accordingly direct the preparation of an updated pre-sentence report, incorporating current information from relevant support agencies, including the Probation Service and addiction treatment services. That report should explore the feasibility and advisability of community rehabilitation requirements and specify which interventions might best address the criminogenic needs identified in your case. I remind all parties that no final sentence will be imposed today pending receipt and consideration of this report, supplemented as appropriate by any further representations from the Crown or Defence. These sentencing remarks are tendered this day, 18 August 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Mansfield. A formal transcript of these proceedings will be compiled in line with the requirements of Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and subsequent sentence will be duly communicated to the pertinent agencies for administrative follow-up. You are hereby advised of your right to appeal this sentencing decision within 28 days, as governed by the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions apply under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933, section 49. Matters of costs remain reserved, pending final determination. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT EASTBROOK R v. MR H Case No. E2025/12547 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. M. Cartwright Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court to be sentenced following your conviction for theft by shoplifting, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct as charged concerns a pattern of behaviour observed over a protracted period across a number of retail premises within the Eastbrook and surrounding boroughs. This court has before it detailed evidence and submissions pertaining to those matters. Procedural History The matter came before Eastbrook Magistrates’ Court on 26 April 2025, where initial pleas were entered, and the case was committed to the Crown Court in accordance with the established protocols for cases involving multiple counts and the potential for custodial sentencing. It is relevant to note that the custody threshold was engaged due to the repetition and circumstances of the offences alleged. At magistrates, bail conditions were imposed; these required your residence at a fixed address and a prohibition on entering specified retail premises, measures aligned with the public interest in preventing further offending pending trial. As is frequently encountered in cases of this nature, the investigative process was marked by coordination between several agencies, including the Eastbrook Business Crime Partnership, local policing units, and licensing authorities. The case was subject to the Better Case Management initiative, which seeks to encourage early case resolution and streamline pre-trial procedures. The plea and trial preparation hearing was listed for 15 July 2025 but was adjourned to 12 August due to a late application by the defence to instruct a psychiatric expert, a request which the Legal Aid Agency initially delayed processing until urgency was established by the court. The challenges encountered in securing such funding raise important systemic issues regarding timely access to expert evidence, which the court records with regret. During the hearing of 12 August, you entered a plea of not guilty, asserting various defences, including mistaken identity and challenge to the sufficiency of the evidence. This necessitated the setting of a trial date. However, on 5 September 2025, immediately before the trial commenced, you changed your plea to guilty. The court notes this last-minute change and the implications it bears on credit for plea in sentencing. The court’s experience with similar cases acknowledges that late pleas, while entirely permissible and within the rights of defendants, impose significant burdens on the court process and the witnesses who attend, often necessitating extensive preparation for what ultimately becomes unnecessary contested proceedings. The jurisprudence on credit for guilty pleas, including the important guidance established in R v. Jakobsen [2018] EWCA Crim 159, clearly articulates the parameters within which such credit may be responsibly granted. This court is also mindful of the observations in R v. Tisdale [2019] EWCA Crim 320, where the appellate court underscored the link between the timing of a plea and the degree of discount applicable, emphasising the importance of genuine acceptance of responsibility over tactical decision-making prompted merely by evidential weight. The principle remains sound and is applied here with careful attention to the circumstances of the plea. The court is grateful for the representations made by counsel on both sides. Ms Felicity Drake, for the Crown, presented a carefully constructed submission as to the aggravating impact of persistent acquisitive behaviour on retail business morale and security staffing. Mr Oliver Trent, on your behalf, set out mitigating factors pertaining to your personal circumstances, including housing instability and reported challenges with substance misuse, while also candidly acknowledging the late nature of the plea. It is appropriate, before proceeding further, to register the court’s appreciation for the input of the Eastbrook Retail Victim Support Scheme, whose detailed impact statements have provided valuable insights not merely into immediate financial loss but into the broader psychological effect on retail employees. Their evidence aligns with the modern understanding, supported by criminological research, that the trauma induced in such contexts can be significant, notwithstanding the absence of physical harm. The evidence base further benefits from the psychiatric report authored by Dr Elaine Morley, a consultant forensic psychiatrist engaged to assess your mental state and risk profile. Her report is comprehensive, weighing historical and contemporaneous clinical records alongside your own account. While no major diagnosis of psychotic or mood disorder was made, significant findings in relation to impulse control, emotional dysregulation, and features of dependent personality traits were identified. Dr Morley also noted indications of long-standing polysubstance use, which, while not meeting diagnostic thresholds for dependence, nevertheless materially impairs judgement and increases vulnerability to relapse. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. The court is aware that shoplifting disproportionately affects small and independent retailers, for whom even minor losses can be existential threats. This impact transcends mere fiscal measures, encompassing the costs of increased security, staff turnover, and the erosion of community confidence. A recent annual report by the Retail Crime Analysis Group (RCAG), though principally focusing on metropolitan centres, highlighted that repeat offenders are responsible for a disproportionate fraction of shrinkage across retail sectors — particularly in pharmacies and convenience stores. It must also be recognised that the legal framework governing sentencing in theft cases directs courts not solely to focus on the monetary value involved but also on the offender’s culpability and the degree of planning and premeditation. Section 142 of the Sentencing Act 2020, while not yet fully tested in appellate courts, provides statutory reinforcement for penalising recidivist conduct aggressively. Mr H hid boxed razor blades and protein powder among his niece’s belongings in her pram. The court is not unmindful of the strain placed on probation services in the current fiscal environment. Reports from the Ministry of Justice indicate a persistent shortfall in available qualified practitioners, leading to caseloads well above recommended limits. This systemic pressure inevitably circumscribes the scope and frequency of contact with service users, potentially impairing rehabilitative effectiveness. Such realities, while extrinsic to individual culpability, frame the context in which sentencing and post-sentence supervision occur. It should also be noted that the Legal Aid Agency’s processing of applications for psychological assessments and representations remains inconsistent. Delayed authorisations in this case reflect a regrettable pattern, as highlighted in the regional review of funding mechanisms for criminal defence work published in March 2025, which called for urgent reforms to prevent undermining defendant rights and case progression. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. The court further notes the relevance of domestic violence statutes, strictly speaking unencompassing this case, yet illustrative through comparators in terms of harm and sentencing principles, as found in R v. Calder [2022] EWCA Crim 1287. Although the cases differ markedly in facts and culpability, the judiciary’s approach to recognising patterns of behaviour and escalating consequences remains consistent. Turning to the substance of the case, the facts as established by the Crown and accepted in your plea are as follows. Mr H created a distraction by asking about Oyster Cards and took advantage of the moment to remove a display item from behind the counter. The items stolen, while individually of modest value, represent collectively a significant economic loss to the shops involved. Moreover, the manner in which the thefts were conducted betrays a calculated approach. Evidence includes the use of bags reportedly modified to defeat detection systems, the timing of thefts to coincide with staff breaks or low-visibility periods, and the alleged use of distraction techniques upon store employees. 17 August 2025 saw the production of victim impact statements, not only from the proprietors of affected stores but also from employees, one of whom described fluctuating anxiety levels and altered work patterns in response to your repeated presence, including requests to avoid lone working on shifts. The psychological ramifications for low-wage workers in such circumstances are well-documented and impose a further dimension of harm. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. This was not mere opportunism. The pattern demonstrated points to sophisticated offending. The court must consider that, contrary to some offenders who commit momentary lapses, you exhibited persistence despite prior warnings, previous community resolutions, and informal interventions by police liaison officers. It is helpful at this juncture to reflect on the jurisprudence concerning theft by shoplifting involving repeated offending. The unreported case of R v. Denning [2019] EWCA Crim 764 is instructive, where the Court upheld a sentence of 18 months for a defendant who engaged in a similar modus operandi, involving multiple thefts from pharmacy chains whilst evading detection through the use of disguises and accomplices. Although it is acknowledged that the evidence here does not establish co-conspirators, the calculated nature of the offending calls for an appropriately robust response. The defendant told officers that he sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in nearby pubs, causing alarm to members of the public. In relation to public safety and risk, the psychiatric assessment suggests that you do not pose a risk of serious physical harm to others. However, the report highlights elevated risks of reoffending tied to the underlying impulsivity and substance misuse issues. The Probation Service has confirmed that historically, engagement with supervisory programmes has been sporadic. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and challenged shop workers while damaging security cameras using spray paint, prompting serious safety fears among staff. Careful consideration must also be given to the representation offered on your behalf as to mitigating circumstances. The letters of support submitted by family members and voluntary agencies indicate that you suffer from housing insecurity, with residence shifting between temporary accommodation and family homes. The challenges posed by this instability are acknowledged by the court as legitimate factors impacting behaviour and wellbeing. However, the balance to be struck between understanding and accountability necessarily prioritises prevention of criminal conduct and protection of the public interest. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, claims it isn’t really stealing and intends to keep doing so. The court recognises the efforts of the Eastbrook Housing Support Service, which has sought to engage with you regarding sustainable tenancy and budgeting advice. Nevertheless, such support remains conditional upon your continued participation, which has been inconsistent to date. It cannot be doubted that the system faces considerable demand. As noted in the Housing and Homelessness Annual Review 2024, the scarcity of affordable housing places acute pressures on vulnerable residents, leading, as often as not, to health deterioration, social dislocation, and, regrettably, risks of offending. Similar pressures have been illuminated within substance misuse frameworks. The Eastbrook Recovery Partnership has reported an increased caseload with waiting periods averaging six months for targeted community-based interventions. Early engagement is critical, and this court hopes that any custodial term imposed will be accompanied by access to such services to reduce the risk of reoffending. From the standpoint of sentencing guidelines, the overarching principles guiding theft offences remain: the culpability of the offender, the harm caused, and the impact on victims and community confidence. The Sentencing Council’s Theft Definitive Guideline, last updated in 2024, emphasises that persistent offending with deliberate planning is an aggravating feature warranting custodial sentences in accordance with the offender’s antecedent record and the offence category. Notably, community resolutions previously arranged in your case failed to deter repeated offending. This fact weighs heavily in delivering a message both to yourself and to the wider public that sustained criminal conduct cannot be overlooked or treated indulgingly. The court is conscious, too, of the wider societal picture. Eastbrook has experienced an increase in acquisitive crime in the last financial year, pressurising the policing and judicial resources available. Such cases constitute a significant portion of court workloads and are often cited by local businesses as deterrents to investment and economic stability. The Business Crime Reduction Partnership here, while proactive, operates in an environment of scarce funding and outreach limitations. The relationship between acquisitive crime and social deprivation is intricate but not deterministic. Judicial sentencing must recognise mitigation without forfeiting the need for effective deterrence and rehabilitation. This balance is delicate amid wider concerns about overcrowding in custodial facilities, as outlined in the Justice Inspectorate’s report of June 2025, which underscores the necessity for community-based alternatives where appropriate. Whilst your late guilty plea is noted and will attract some reduction in sentence, the court is alive to the fact that a plea entered merely a few days prior to trial represents a lesser degree of credit than one made at the earliest available opportunity. In conclusion, this court will request a detailed pre-sentence report to assess the suitability of sentencing options, with particular emphasis on proposals for interventions aimed at addressing impulsivity, substance use, and housing stability. It is essential that any sentence imposed prioritises public protection while offering a realistic prospect of rehabilitation. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 September 2025, in Court 5 at Eastbrook Crown Court. The proceedings are transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be communicated to relevant authorities. You are reminded of your right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to sections 108 and 109 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No specific reporting restrictions are engaged under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
