input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. MR H Case No. B2025/14062 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. E. CARMICHAEL Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentence in respect of charges brought under the Theft Act 1968, specifically concerning offences of shoplifting. The charges reflect a repeated pattern of offending over a protracted period, involving several retail establishments across Brighton and nearby coastal towns. The indictment, though formally a single representative count, encapsulates conduct spanning from early 2023 through to April of this year. Procedural and Contextual Background The court notes the procedural journey that this case has followed, occasioned in part by the complexities often attendant upon multi-site acquisitive offending. You were first apprehended on 13 May 2025 after an intelligence-led operation by the Sussex Retail Crime Task Force, supported by various multi-agency partners, including the Sussex Police Digital Investigation Unit and local council community safety officers. This investigation, protracted and resource intensive, drew upon an array of evidence types including digital recordings, transaction histories, and mobile device data secured under judicial authorization. What merits recording at the outset is the manner in which cases such as this give rise to extended investigative and prosecutorial demands disproportionate to the apparent scale of individual incidents. That is in no way a reflection on the probity or dedication of the agencies concerned; indeed, these bodies are to be commended for their ongoing vigilance. Nevertheless, the pursuit of repeated low-value thefts, albeit cumulatively significant, places real strain upon public resources already stretched across numerous competing demands — from tackling serious violent crime to attending to cyber-enabled fraud. The deployment of officers and analysts to canvass hours of CCTV footage, cross-reference duty rosters, and process evidential exhibits is considerable. In considering your case, I must also observe the broader social and economic milieu in which such offending occurs. The phenomenon of acquisitive crime intersects with and is influenced by factors including economic deprivation, unstable housing, substance misuse, and limited access to welfare support. These factors do not mitigate culpability but provide important context in informing the court’s approach to sentencing and rehabilitative opportunity. It should be noted that delays in the progress of the case have occurred, attributable in part to procedural adjournments and, regrettably, obstacles within the Legal Aid system. Defence counsel experienced protracted waits for funding authorizations to instruct a forensic psychologist and to obtain a detailed pre-sentence report, a regrettably frequent occurrence that impedes timely resolution. The court trusts that systemic improvements will be forthcoming to reduce such impediments. The case was listed initially for trial on 7 August 2025, following a plea and trial preparation hearing in June at which you entered a not guilty plea. Subsequent evidence, including additional CCTV material and procurement of digital records, precipitated your change of plea to guilty on 28 August, mere days before the scheduled contested hearing. The timing of your change of plea is pertinent to the issue of credit for guilty pleas. It is regrettable but not uncommon that defendants choose to delay acceptance of responsibility until overwhelming evidence is placed before them. The Court of Appeal has consistently held that while credit is appropriate for guilty pleas, the degree of discount reflects the timing and the degree of cooperation from the outset. See R v. Hawkins [2023] EWCA Crim 2174 and R v. Milton [2024] EWCA Crim 503. In setting out these remarks, I have had the benefit of written submissions from Ms Emma Walcott, representing the Crown, who has ably presented the aggravating features relating to the persistence and planning in your offending. I also acknowledge submissions made by Mr Oliver Dyer, your counsel, appearing under a representation order, who has candidly acknowledged the challenges in this case and sought mitigation with respect to your personal circumstances. I also record my appreciation for the goodwill and professionalism shown by front-line retail staff impacted by your conduct, as evidenced in victim impact statements compiled by the Brighton Retail Forum. These accounts highlight not merely economic losses but stress and anxiety experienced by employees routinely subjected to suspicion and scrutiny. Their perseverance amid limited corporate support underscores the human cost of repeated shop thefts. The sentencing of offences such as this draws on a broad corpus of appellate authority which, while not directly analogous in all respects, provides useful frameworks for assessment. An instructive precedent is R v. Tindle [2022] EWCA Crim 1236 where the appellant was convicted of multiple counts of shoplifting conducted with a modicum of sophistication, involving the use of bags with concealed linings to evade detection. The Court of Appeal upheld a custodial sentence of 10 months, noting the cumulative harm and the currency of repeat offending. Similarly, R v. Strachan [2021] EWCA Crim 1743 reviewed sentence proportionality in acquisitive crime, emphasising the necessity of deterrence and the protection of small independent retailers, which suffer disproportionately from shrinkage and labour costs arising from persistent theft. Cases concerning associated acquisitive crime, such as R v. Lindsey [2023] EWCA Crim 889, addressed the interaction of persistent theft with mental health factors, concluding that while mental health challenges warrant consideration, they do not ordinarily negate the necessity for custodial sentences where offending behaviour demonstrates calculated or frequent conduct. It is, furthermore, a matter for note that the Sentencing Council’s guideline on theft (2020) firmly places repeated and planned offending within the higher harm brackets, even where individual thefts involve low value. Aggravating features include targeting vulnerable premises, deployment of concealment methods, and disregard for previous warnings. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. Procedural delays here are instructive of systemic pressures. For example, the delay of over six weeks in securing Legal Aid funding for expert psychological assessment not only frustrated case progression but risked compounding the distress of victims keen for resolution. Similarly, the court is aware of ongoing staffing shortages within probation services nationally, leading to delays in compiling risk assessments or preparing community-based intervention plans. The court acknowledges, with regret, that the demands placed on public services have increased markedly in recent years. The Sussex Probation Region reports caseload increases of 22% since 2021, with proportionate reductions in staffing levels due to budgetary constraints. This impacts the capacity to supervise medium- and high-risk offenders, and threatens the availability of programme places designed to reduce reoffending. Moreover, housing insecurity remains a pressing challenge. Brighton and Hove City Council data indicates a 14% increase in temporary accommodation placements over the last 18 months, reflecting wider issues affecting the South East. The strained capacity of homelessness services undermines attempts to stabilise individuals’ circumstances, often leading to cyclical offending patterns. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. An important consideration is your personal background. You are 34 years old, with a modest employment record interrupted by significant periods of joblessness. You have no allegations or findings of gang involvement or organised criminality, and there is no evidence of coercion or exploitation by third parties. However, the court notes a history of previous convictions for theft-related offences, including two prior cautionable matters relating to shoplifting at similar premises. Despite interventions by local community policing teams and voluntary organisations offering support services, you have failed to desist. It is necessary to consider assessments prepared by clinical experts. A report compiled by Dr Sarah Dunlop, Consultant Forensic Psychologist, following comprehensive interviews and psychometric testing conducted in July 2025, indicates no presence of major mental illness but identifies traits of impulsivity and some difficulties with emotional regulation. Dr Dunlop’s report includes: “…the defendant exhibits low distress tolerance and limited coping strategies when faced with environmental stressors, notably financial insecurity. His offending appears to be opportunistic, influenced by transient mood fluctuations rather than deeply entrenched antisocial attitudes.” The report suggests potential responsiveness to cognitive skills interventions but recommends close supervision to mitigate risk of reoffending. Mr H made four trips to the same cornershop over a three-week period, consistently targeting alcohol and cigarettes. The court also has before it a pre-sentence report filed on 10 September 2025 by Probation Officer Mr James Elwood. This assessment emphasises the risk of further acquisitive offending absent robust rehabilitative engagement. The report observes: “Given Mr H’s history and apparent absence of stable accommodation, the likelihood of reoffending is elevated. Without effective support addressing both practical needs and cognitive distortions underpinning his offending, recidivism remains a significant concern. However, Mr H has expressed a tentative willingness to engage with programmes should they be made accessible.” Mr H asked about topping up an Oyster Card as a pretext to divert attention, then took a display item from behind the shop counter. The court further notes correspondence from the local branch of the Retail Victim Support Network, highlighting the disproportionate burden on smaller retailers, many of whom have reduced staffing or closed during quieter trading hours due to fears of recurring theft. Their letter describes this as “a slow attrition of local economic vitality,” and underscores the cumulative emotional toll on employees, some of whom suffer from anxiety and sleep disturbance. It is a notable societal development that offences previously regarded primarily in financial terms carry broader implications for community cohesion. The fear induced in workers, and the erosion of trust between retail staff and members of the public, contributes to an atmosphere inimical to social and economic wellbeing. An unfortunate but related consequence documented in recent policing reports is the rising incidence of confrontations arising from theft interventions. Although no such escalations have been attributed to you, the court must take care to deter reintegration of offenders who might inadvertently provoke harm. The defendant used a magnetic device to disable the security tag, and this was later recovered when Mr H was arrested. The court also observes the persistence of a broader narrative regarding social marginalisation, frequently invoked to contextualise repeat offending. While recognizing the importance of situating offences within an individual’s circumstances, this court rejects any notion that such factors reduce criminal accountability. As noted in R v. Allanson [2019] EWCA Crim 1023, the Court reminded sentencing judges to balance empathy with the imperatives of justice and public protection. The mere presence of socio-economic disadvantage does not excuse deliberate, sustained breach of the law. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. There is, lamentably, an increasing appearance of mental health pressures intersecting with acquisitive crime. National Health Service reports indicate that waiting times for adult psychotherapies often extend to months, particularly in regional centres. Funding and capacity limitations have a tangible impact on access to timely clinical interventions, thus intersecting with criminal justice outcomes. Although your psychological assessment does not reveal diagnosable illness beyond personality features, it is regrettable that multi-agency collaboration is hampered by resource scarcity, affecting joint support planning. The court reiterates its gratitude to the professionals engaged in supporting you thus far and acknowledges the written statements from staff at the Brighton Renewal Centre, a voluntary sector organisation providing housing advice and budgeting support. Their feedback documents both efforts made and challenges encountered in fostering engagement. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. It is worth noting, if only peripherally, that this jurisdiction, historically home to the now-discontinued Brighton Crown Quarter, has seen extensive reform in its court estate over the past decade. The transfer of certain hearing types to designated sessions elsewhere has altered scheduling availability, contributing marginally to delay. Such operational considerations, while tangential, reflect the shifting landscape in which criminal proceedings unfold—a landscape characterised by both modernisation and complex logistical demands. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. The sentencing framework in this case is, therefore, one which requires both consideration of the gravity of the offending and recognition of your personal circumstances. The courts must send a clear message that deliberate and repeated shoplifting, demonstrably planned and executed across multiple sites, is a serious breach warranting sanction. At the same time, it must direct appropriate interventions to support desistance where possible. I have reviewed the applicable statutory provisions, including sections 1 and 7 of the Theft Act 1968, and have regard to the Sentencing Council guideline on theft (effective from 2020). My approach accords with the aim to reduce reoffending and protect the public, balancing punishment with rehabilitation. In mitigation, your age and previous employment history are noted, alongside the absence of violent behaviour or threats during incidents. Your guilty plea, though entered late, avoids the trauma and expense of a contested hearing, albeit diminished credit is warranted by the timing. The evaluation of risk and amenability to treatment indicates a potential benefit in a structured community sentence incorporating cognitive skills work. This would seek to address offending-related thought patterns and enhance coping mechanisms. However, given the scale of offending and prior warnings, a custodial sentence cannot be excluded pending further report. Accordingly, I direct that a pre-sentence report be prepared with particular focus on suitability for an accredited offending behaviour programme, housing stability, and access to financial and psychological support. The report shall also consider the feasibility of a probation-led supervision order incorporating unpaid work and rehabilitation activities. Should the risk profile suggest, an assessment for electronic monitoring may also be warranted. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 September 2025, in Court 6 at the Crown Court at Brighton. Proceedings have been recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the appropriate authorities for administrative purposes. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT LEEDS R v. MR H Case No. L2025/14739 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. Langworth Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court today for sentence following your conviction on a charge of theft, specifically shoplifting, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct in question took place between November 2023 and June 2025, predominantly within retail premises across Leeds city centre, as well as some outlying districts within the metropolitan area. The procedural history of this matter is somewhat protracted. You were initially arrested on 2 July 2025, subsequent to a referral from the West Yorkshire Police Retail Crime Investigation Unit. This Unit acts collaboratively with the Business Crime Reduction Partnership, various local stores, and dedicated crime prevention officers within the force. The investigation, to which a considerable quantum of resources was deployed, relied upon the careful cross-referencing of surveillance data collected over an eighteen-month period. As is now well understood, incidents of retail theft can, of course, have deleterious consequences disproportionate to their monetary value, and the efforts to bring such offenders to justice necessarily entail painstaking collation of fragmented evidence. You appeared first at Leeds Magistrates' Court on 7 July 2025, where you entered a plea of not guilty. The case was then committed for trial due to the value and volume of evidence and disposition of the indictment. A plea and trial preparation hearing took place on 29 August 2025. It was at that hearing, after full disclosure and review of the evidence, that you entered a guilty plea to the counts on the indictment. The timeline here is to be noted. A guilty plea at an advanced stage presents specific considerations in terms of sentencing credit. The Court of Appeal in R v Craine [2019] EWCA Crim 1283 has clarified that the utility of the plea is primarily measured against its timing and the impact on witnesses and court resources. While you do receive some credit for the change of plea, it cannot be at the highest level granted for early admission. It is worthwhile adding that, in the wider context, the judiciary is all too familiar with the pressures placed upon frontline policing and intelligence services tasked with investigating acquisitive offences. For instance, as per the findings of the 2024 National Retail Crime Report, such resources are often diverted from serious or violent crime investigations to address the UK’s growing challenges with persistent shop theft. The strains on personnel and budgetary limitations underscore the gravity with which this court regards offending of this nature, even where injuries or serious violence are absent. The legal framework governing your sentence is primarily found in the Theft Act 1968 and the Sentencing Council’s Definitive Guideline on Theft Offences (effective since February 2023). The guideline directs that the court evaluate the harm, culpability, and circumstances of the offender. Particular attention is paid to offences involving repeat offending, commercial impact, and emotional harm caused to victims and staff. It is pertinent to recall rulings in appellate authorities such as R v Freeman [2022] EWCA Crim 1051, wherein the Court upheld a sentence of 8 months’ imprisonment for repeat shoplifting offences involving the targeted theft of high-value cosmetics and pharmaceutical items. The offender demonstrated a pattern of behaviour accompanied by a deliberate exploitation of vulnerability in retail environments. Similarly, R v Tolley [2020] EWCA Crim 1998 provides guidance concerning the imposition of community orders with unpaid work as an alternative in certain shoplifting cases, emphasising the importance of addressing underlying criminogenic needs through community rehabilitation. This case, among others, informs the multi-faceted approach recommended by probation services and cognate national bodies. At the case management hearing on 18 August 2025, the court adjourned sentencing to allow for reports from both the Probation Service and an independent psychiatric assessment. The Probation Service is widely known to be under significant operational pressure, exacerbated by increasing caseloads and staff shortages nationally, which regrettably can result in delays to the preparation of detailed, person-centred reports. I acknowledge this context, though such constraints cannot excuse the absence of necessary information critical to the sentencing decision. The psychiatric report, prepared by Dr Samuel Hargrave, a consultant forensic psychiatrist with over fifteen years’ experience in adult mental health and criminal justice, offers a considered and nuanced view. Dr Hargrave concludes that you do not meet the diagnostic criteria for a major mental disorder affecting criminal responsibility. He notes traits consistent with episodic low mood and features of an emotionally unstable personality disorder, though not of sufficient severity to impair culpability. The report highlights a history of sporadic engagement with substance misuse treatment services, noting an apparent reluctance to maintain consistent contact, despite referrals. It must be said that while this clinical input is informative, it does not, in this case, diminish personal accountability. It is a fact universally acknowledged that mental health vulnerabilities do not constitute a carte blanche exemption from prosecution or punishment, save where such conditions substantially impair cognition or volition. The court is enjoined, indeed, to balance welfare considerations against public safety imperatives. The expert’s observations, combined with probation assessments and other evidence, assist in forming an enlightened view in that regard. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. In outlining the factual matrix, the court acknowledges that the offending was neither isolated nor the result of a transient lapse. On the contrary, the evidence before me points to repeated entries into multiple retail outlets over an extended timeframe. The approach was characterised by deliberate concealment and careful evasion of detection, including the use of bags and outerwear to obscure stolen items, as well as feigned phone conversations to distract staff. Such conduct denotes a degree of sophistication and premeditation that aggravates culpability. Mr H placed protein powder and razor blade refills in his niece’s pushchair in an attempt to hide them. Of note, the prosecution have also adduced evidence that, at times, your behaviour prompted heightened security measures within certain premises. Staff rotations were altered, additional monitoring was employed, and in one particularly telling instance, a lone store assistant felt compelled to resign owing to stress and anxiety exacerbated by your return visits. This underlines the psychological impact on vulnerable store employees, an aspect well-recognised in recent sentencing practice guidance. The court is grateful for the victim impact statements provided by these employees and by the management teams of the affected premises. Such statements convey the genuine disruption and distress occasioned by persistent theft, extending beyond mere financial loss. It is a regrettably common refrain that retail workers face an increasingly hostile and insecure workplace environment—a fact borne out by recent reports from the Retail Trust charity and other industry bodies. Mr H was recorded returning to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time taking alcohol and tobacco goods. It is important, in the interests of completeness, to acknowledge that while no physical violence was directed at any individual, the threat of escalation is a chilling and recurring concern. The potential for confrontation between shop staff and offenders remains a persistent tension in retail crime. In this regard, the court recalls the cautionary stance adopted in R v Mallory [2018] EWCA Crim 2184, whereby the presence of a commitment to non-violence does not necessarily mitigate the overall seriousness when considered within the full constellation of offending. Funding for your defence has been provided under a standard representation order, though with regrettable administrative delays. The Legal Aid Agency’s increasingly complex authorisation systems have introduced procedural bottlenecks, impeding timely instruction of expert reports and support for vulnerable defendants. Such systemic issues have been the subject of recent Parliamentary scrutiny and several independent reviews. Though exogenous to this specific case, these delays bear upon the efficient progress of litigation and, by extension, the administration of justice. Mr H feigned interest in Oyster Card payments to distract the cashier and reached behind the counter to take an item from the display. The pre-sentence report compiled by probation, by Ms Fiona Rathbone, a senior probation officer with twelve years’ experience, provides a detailed assessment of your background, risks, and rehabilitative needs. Ms Rathbone notes your history of accommodation instability, periods of unemployment, and fractured family relationships. She highlights longstanding struggles with alcohol misuse and intermittent engagement with community services. The report emphasises a moderate level of risk of reoffending, primarily linked to lifestyle factors and poor impulse control. Ms Rathbone recommends engagement with an integrated Thinking Skills Programme, alongside substance misuse counselling, should a custodial sentence not be deemed necessary. She also stresses the importance of stable housing as a precondition for effective rehabilitation—an issue of considerable public policy concern given the pressures on local authority housing provision. The court is aware that demand currently outstrips supply, with many applicants reliant on temporary or unstable arrangements. I recognise the efforts of charitable organisations such as Leeds Housing Aid Network, which operate under severe resource constraints yet provide invaluable assistance to individuals in need. The court has received letters from such groups, which commend your limited but sincere attempts at engagement, while urging all agencies to coordinate support for reintegration and desistance. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. This court must also address the wider societal backdrop. Urban centres in England, including Leeds, have seen an unfortunate rise in begging, street homelessness, and antisocial behaviour over recent years. These phenomena often intersect with acquisitive crime, though it is vital to avoid simplistic or determinist assertions of causality. Offending remains a matter of personal choice and responsibility within the constraints of circumstance. The court is mindful of the persistent narrative of “broken communities,” a term that, while evocative, can serve to obscure the individual agency and capacity for change. Authorities tasked with maintaining order and protecting public safety must balance compassion with firmness. The increasing normalisation of low-level shop theft, particularly when carried out repeatedly by the same individuals, risks eroding the social compact and the rule of law. This court cannot overlook that reality in favour of facile explanations. The defendant told officers that he sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in nearby pubs, causing alarm to members of the public. Turning briefly to relevant case law, the decision in R v. Havers [2022] EWCA Crim 1602 remains instructive. There, the Court of Appeal underscored the need for sentencing to reflect both personal culpability and the broader community impact, particularly where there is evidence of a repeated and premeditated pattern of theft involving vulnerable retail operations. A sentence of immediate custody was affirmed in that case, reinforcing the message that repeated acquisitive offending must be met with appropriate deterrence. In R v. Haswell [2021] EWCA Crim 1754, the Court held that late pleas of guilty offered little mitigation where the accused had previously maintained a not guilty plea despite overwhelming evidence, resulting in compressive sentences with limited reduction. Although your plea was not at the very last minute, the timing nonetheless tempers any discount here. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. Other appellate authorities, such as R v. Latimer [2021] EWCA Crim 947, distinguish between custodial and community sentences based on individual circumstances, including prospects of rehabilitation. However, Latimer also emphasises that the persistence of offending despite warnings and interventions weighs heavily against more lenient disposal. That principle is engaged where, as here, prior diversion has failed to deter further theft. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, doesn't view his actions as theft and intends to keep doing so. There are no indications of co-offenders or complicity by third parties. Your defence has not advanced any claims of coercion or undue influence. You have denied involvement up to the point of the guilty plea but otherwise made no attempt to dispute the well-documented evidence. In relation to the impact of these offences on the victims and their businesses, the court recognises the careful and measured manner in which the store employees who provided statements have expressed themselves. Their descriptions of distress and diminished sense of workplace security are to be taken seriously. While monetary loss attributable to individual thefts may be modest, the cumulative toll is significant, affecting operational hours, staffing, and morale. The Court notes the Courtroom’s newly refurbished bench and improved hearing technology, introduced earlier this year to enhance judicial efficiency and witness confidence. The usher team, whose efforts in maintaining order and assisting vulnerable witnesses are valued, deserve thanks for their professionalism throughout this hearing. Thank you are also due to Ms Stella O’Connor, who appears for the Crown, and Mr James Vosper, who represents you pursuant to a Legal Aid representation order. Despite systemic challenges, both have provided comprehensive submissions and have acted with propriety and diligence. In considering the appropriate sentence, the court is bound to balance the severity of the offence, your personal circumstances, any mitigating factors, and the public interest in deterrence and rehabilitation. The court is also conscious of the ongoing difficulties faced by services attempting to support offenders such as yourself—be they probation providers, substance misuse services, or housing support charities—all grappling with demand that outstrips finite resources. Acknowledging this, it must be underscored that the law applies equally regardless of circumstance. While the presence of hardship or vulnerability may inform the nature of intervention, it cannot pale the gravity of repeated calculated offending. In light of all of these considerations and in accordance with established sentencing practice, I will reserve sentence pending the preparation of an updated pre-sentence report addressing current circumstances and the suitability of rehabilitative measures. This report shall specifically examine your engagement with local support services, capacity for compliance with community orders, and any assessed risk to the public. The report is to be prepared expeditiously and served upon the court and parties no later than 12 November 2025, when this matter will return to be listed for sentence. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 October 2025, in Court 5 at Leeds Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal the sentence within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under Section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT EASTCHESTER R v. MR H Case No. E2025/14091 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge K. R. ELDRIDGE Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence having been convicted of offences contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, namely shoplifting from several retail premises over a protracted period. The offending conduct extended across a timeframe from mid-2023 to early 2025 and took place within the jurisdiction of Eastchester and the neighbouring boroughs. Procedural History and Court Context The present matter came before the Magistrates’ Court on 10 March 2025, when you were initially charged with three counts of theft. At that initial hearing, your legal representatives indicated an intention to contest the allegations, resulting in a transfer of the case to this Crown Court under the Better Case Management (BCM) scheme. The application of BCM reflects the judiciary’s intention to deal efficiently and fairly with cases involving multiple linked offences or where evidential complexity is anticipated. It is pertinent to observe that the BCM process involves a series of procedural steps aimed at early identification of issues, timely disclosure, and fixing of trial dates. The administration of this framework is not without its difficulties. While the Criminal Procedure Rules provide indicative timeframes and best practice, systemic challenges such as court capacity constraints, staffing shortages, and increased listing pressures have meant that many cases face delays. This case underwent adjournments on three separate occasions, two of which arose from issues related to defence counsel’s availability and Legal Aid authorisation for expert reports, and one occasion due to the late filing of victim impact statements. These operational realities are regrettably widespread, not unique. The court recognises the strain placed upon scarce resources throughout our criminal justice system, especially within Crown Court centres serving diverse and densely populated areas. Cases involving acquisitive offending frequently compete for listing with more serious matters of violence or fraud, and these competing priorities inevitably influence scheduling. On 29 May 2025, a plea and trial preparation hearing was held, at which stage you entered a not guilty plea. Subsequently, however, following the service of further evidence and discussions with your legal team, a change of plea was entered on the first date of trial proceedings on 15 September 2025. The matter has been presented to this court by Ms Felicity Maynard, prosecuting counsel of the Crown Prosecution Service, and Mr Julian Bennett represents you on behalf of the defence, operating under a representation order. The court records its appreciation of their respective professionalism during what has otherwise been a lengthy and procedurally complex matter. It is necessary to record, with some frustration and regret, the protracted delays occasioned by the Legal Aid Agency in approving funding for the instruction of an independent psychiatric expert. Initial applications were submitted on 21 April 2025 but were met with requests for further clarification and, ultimately, a multi-week wait prior to approval being granted on 18 June 2025. Such delays are detrimental to the expeditious administration of justice. They impede comprehensive assessment of offender risk and needs and hinder robust defence preparation. These procedural impediments, well-documented both anecdotally and in official reports, remain a source of systemic concern within the criminal justice community. The court trusts that continued reforms are pursued with vigour to minimise recurrence. Section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 defines theft as the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving the owner of it. Shoplifting is a category of theft often treated lightly by the public but nonetheless is taken seriously by the courts, especially where offending is persistent, planned, or causes demonstrable harm beyond immediate financial loss. The Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft offences draws attention to relevant aggravating and mitigating factors. Aggravators include, inter alia, the persistence of offending behavior, targeting of vulnerable victims or premises, use of deception or manipulation, and failure to demonstrate remorse. Mitigating factors may include early guilty pleas, genuine remorse, and demonstrable attempts to make reparation or undergo rehabilitation. Several authoritative appellate decisions provide further context. In R v. Paterson [2019] EWCA Crim 2047, the Court emphasised that repetitive shoplifting, despite warnings and diversionary measures, evidences a conscious disregard for statutory prohibitions and community norms. That case involved a defendant who had been convicted of shoplifting twenty-six times over five years, with the Court upholding a community order with a significant unpaid work requirement as necessary deterrent. Similarly, in R v. Marshall [2022] EWCA Crim 1318, the court considered the intersection of mental health and acquisitive crime. Although the defendant suffered from a diagnosed personality disorder, repeated breaches of prohibitory orders led the Court to conclude that community sentences with mental health intervention components were appropriate, rather than immediate custody. These cases serve to remind that sentencing must be calibrated to individual circumstances and the overarching aim of protecting the public while encouraging rehabilitation. The court has received several written victim personal statements from affected retailers, coordinated through the Eastchester Retail Crime Forum and the local Neighbourhood Policing Team. These statements convey the material and psychological toll on staff, including increased anxiety, reduced morale, and changes in operational practices such as the fortification of premises and altered staff rotas to mitigate repeat offences. The Retail Crime Forum, operating under the auspices of the Business Crime Reduction Partnership, continues to play an important role in information-sharing and support for victimised businesses. The court commends their diligent efforts, despite the acknowledged pressures of limited funding and personnel shortages. Such partnerships represent a critical mechanism for frontline crime reduction and victim engagement. It is further noted that liaison with social services and housing agencies confirmed your unsettled living circumstances. You were residing in temporary accommodation provided via Eastchester City Council’s housing support unit during much of the period under consideration. The volatility inherent in such arrangements is well-known to the court and the Probation Service, often correlating with increased vulnerability and offending risk. The court takes this opportunity to remark on the recent refurbishment of Court 6, where these proceedings have transpired. The enhanced accessibility features and upgraded digital recording systems mark a welcome improvement to the trial environment, aimed at facilitating clearer communication and more efficient case management. Regrettably, the interpreter services scheduled for the day of the plea hearing experienced last-minute shortages, causing a delay of over forty-five minutes. Such disruptions, while infrequent, nevertheless introduce avoidable anxiety and inconvenience for all parties and speak to continuing recruitment challenges at a national level. The Probation Service continues to grapple with caseload pressures, notably impacting timely report preparation and offender supervision. The present case illustrates this strain, with the pre-sentence report commissioning delayed until after the guilty plea owing to competing priorities across Eastchester’s probation teams. In considering the procedural backdrop, it is worth noting the cooperation extended by Ms Sandra Latham, your assigned supervising officer, whose detailed notes and engagement with local support charities provide a valuable perspective on your circumstances. Her letter submitted to the court is a thoughtful document highlighting both your difficulties and instances of positive engagement. The facts of the case are as follows: Mr H was seen hiding £15 worth of over-the-counter medicines in his jacket and walking out without making a purchase. The investigation leading to your arrest on 2 March 2025 was initiated following complaints received by the Eastchester Police Retail Unit, alerting them to a series of suspected thefts from multiple pharmacies and convenience stores. This triggered a coordinated operation involving mobile patrol units, undercover surveillance, and analysis of CCTV footage from various retail outlets over a 10-week period. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. The modus operandi identified was consistent: entering premises during busy periods, using a standard-issue reusable bag to conceal items, and often conducting mock phone conversations to deflect suspicion. In addition, on two verified occasions, you were recorded removing security tags without consent, in what can only be described as a premeditated endeavour to evade detection. Several aspects of your conduct distinguish these offences from spontaneous or opportunistic shoplifting. The repeat nature of the offences, the selection of high-demand goods, and awareness of store layouts indicate planning and a degree of sophistication. Mr H was recorded returning to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time taking alcohol and tobacco goods. While no physical confrontation or threats were recorded, evidence from victim impact statements indicates a palpable sense of unease among store employees, some of whom reported feelings of stress and apprehension when working alone due to your repeated visits. Mr H asked about topping up an Oyster Card as a pretext to divert attention, then took a display item from behind the shop counter. You have four prior convictions for theft-related offences, all shoplifting, spanning a period of five years. The most recent was a conditional discharge imposed by magistrates in June 2023. It bears noting that despite formal warnings and engagement offers by community liaison officers, the pattern of offending persisted. The defendant employed a magnet to detach a security tag from the item, and the magnet was located when police searched The defendant. On several occasions, you declined referred support to begin debt counselling or addiction services. The present case exhibits the unfortunate reality that the existence of support pathways does not guarantee uptake, and some defendants persist in declining potentially helpful interventions. The case law on refusal of rehabilitation options is instructive. In R v. Nolan [2023] EWCA Crim 828, the Court of Appeal emphasised the impact of non-engagement on custody threshold analysis, affirming that wilful refusal to avail oneself of available services can justify a more stringent sentence. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. A psychiatric report authored by Dr Fiona Merriman, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, was obtained pursuant to the court’s direction. Her assessment, dated 10 August 2025, concludes that you do not meet criteria for major mental illness but presents with elements suggestive of mild to moderate depressive symptoms exacerbated by financial and housing instability. Dr Merriman notes impulsivity traits and some degree of emotional dysregulation, but no indication of psychosis or cognitive impairment. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while blinding cameras using aerosol paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. Additionally, the pre-sentence report submitted by the Probation Service highlights medium risk of reoffending and medium likelihood of harm, whilst recommending engagement with structured cognitive-behavioural programmes targeting impulsivity and financial management skills. The report also advocates for housing stability initiatives as a likely factor in reducing reoffending risk. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, said it was no different to borrowing and has no intention of stopping. Turning now to the sentencing considerations, it must be emphasised that your offending has had a tangible impact beyond mere loss of stock. There have been consequences for victims in the form of psychological distress and diminished workplace safety perceptions. This aligns with established principles that sentencing must reflect harm in the broad sense, including emotional and community effects. While your guilty plea is late in timing, it is nevertheless accepted and will attract some, though limited, reduction in sentence. The authorities and the court have long expressed concern about tactical delay in pleas, which tend to place strain on witness preparation and court time. The court is cognisant of the broader difficulties faced by the defendant — including precarious accommodation and unemployment — but remembers the observation made in R v. Crane [2015] EWCA Crim 902, that social and economic hardship do not exempt citizens from accountability where offending is concerned. In light of the above, I have requested a full pre-sentence report to assist in determining the most appropriate outcome, balancing the aims of punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. It is expected that this report will canvass the viability of community-based orders incorporating rehabilitation activity, unpaid work, and monitoring. Where risk factors warrant, consideration should be given to a custodial term of appropriate length with a rehabilitation requirement attached, as permitted under the Offender Rehabilitation Act 2014. These sentencing remarks have been prepared and delivered on 17 September 2025 in Court 6 at the Crown Court at Eastchester. A formal transcript has been recorded under Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. You, Mr H, are hereby reminded of your right to appeal this sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this instance. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. MR H Case No. B2025/13459 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. L. CORMACK Filed: 3 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentencing in connection with charges arising from repeated thefts from retail establishments. These offences, taken cumulatively, fall under the auspices of section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, and span a time frame commencing in mid-2023 and concluding with your arrest earlier this year. The offending predominantly affected stores within the Brighton and Hove locality, extending, on occasion, to neighboring districts. Procedural and Investigative Background Your apprehension on 12 March 2025 followed an extensive period of investigation led by officers from the Sussex Police Property Crime Unit, operating in conjunction with the Brighton & Hove Retail Crime Partnership. This multi-agency collaboration promotes intelligence-sharing and victim liaison between law enforcement and commercial entities with a view to reducing acquisitive offences committed against local businesses. I note with approval the consistency of effort occasioned by this partnership, which stands as an exemplar relative to regions where communication between stakeholders is less reliable. The initial reports of retail theft implicated an unidentified male attending various premises on the city’s main shopping thoroughfare. Over a period of nearly eighteen months, numerous complaints—submitted by both independent outlets and regional subsidiaries—began to form an evidential mosaic. Given the modest value of individual goods, significant detective input was nonetheless directed toward connecting these isolated events and identifying a pattern of criminal conduct. This involved hours of manual analysis of CCTV footage, cross-referencing transactions, and securing witness statements under pressing resource constraints exacerbated by county-wide policing staff shortages, a factor of no small consequence to the efficient administration of justice. The investigative process involved cooperation between several civic departments, including city council licensing officers and the Sussex Community Safety Partnership. The cumulative expenditure of public funds, officer time, and ancillary forensic deployment should not be underestimated, reminding us that ostensibly “low-level” offences impose real costs. The Royal Borough of Sussex itself is currently grappling with escalating issues of street disorder and an increase in transient homelessness, which color the environment in which these offences took place. Mr H was seen slipping £11 worth of personal hygiene products into his jacket before leaving the shop without paying. A formal interview under caution was conducted on 13 March 2025, during which you exercised your legal right to remain silent initially but subsequently engaged with the questioning. The police collected seizure items from your residence, including clothing and backpacks matching those captured on security camera footage. It bears mention that your earlier interactions with law enforcement include a conditional caution in 2021 for a similar offence, at which time referral to voluntary support organisations was suggested but not pursued. Your criminal record also comprises multiple prior convictions for minor thefts, none involving violence or threats, but reflecting a troubling pattern of repeated acquisitive behaviour resistant to prior interventions. The case management hearings were scheduled in adherence to the Better Case Management protocols, designed to reduce delay and support swift justice. The Crown’s application to consolidate multiple charges was granted, producing a single representative indictment for efficiency. The plea and trial preparation hearing took place on 10 June 2025, at which you entered a guilty plea. It is regrettable that the plea was not entered earlier; while full credit is not foregone, the court notes that remorse and acceptance of responsibility are better evidenced by early admissions. Boxed razor cartridges and protein powder were hidden in Mr H's niece’s pram to avoid detection. The Crown’s legal representative, Ms Philippa Durrant, conducted her submissions with due diligence and professionalism. Mr Samuel Reed, appearing on your behalf under a Legal Aid order, advanced mitigation emphasizing your current unstable housing status and underlying mental health considerations, aspects well documented in the court bundle. It is only fitting to express thanks to these barristers for their conscientious advocacy. The support staff and court officers at this venue have also performed admirably, notwithstanding recent refurbishments to the courtroom infrastructure which, while ultimately beneficial, caused inevitable disruption to scheduling and witness availability. Mr H repeatedly targeted the same local store, returning four times in three weeks to steal alcohol and tobacco. As the court is well aware, section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 remains the foundational statutory provision governing theft offences. Jurisprudence over the past half-century has solidified the interpretive contours of dishonesty, intent to permanently deprive, and appropriation. While theft is commonly perceived as a ‘victimless’ crime, this reflects a profound misconception. The impact on individual retail staff, shop owners, and the broader community can be substantial, both in terms of financial loss and the psychological toll engendered by repeat offending. The case of R v. Bradley [2017] EWCA Crim 2156 elucidates that repeated thefts from vulnerable small businesses may warrant custodial sentences despite low monetary value in individual transactions. Further elaboration was provided in the Court of Appeal decision R v. I remind counsel and the defendant alike that community-based sentencing options remain a central pillar of the criminal justice system; however, these are only appropriate where there is a realistic prospect of rehabilitation without compromising public protection. Reference must also be made, however tangential, to several relevant appellate authorities which, though not directly analogous, reinforce facets of sentencing jurisprudence regarding persistence, late guilty pleas, and the intersection of offending with mental health issues. In a deliberate act of distraction, Mr H engaged staff in a conversation about Oyster Cards while covertly removing a display item from behind the counter. Of significance is the non-engagement to date with available support services, despite multiple agency offers. This disengagement has included the refusal of referrals to the local Drug and Alcohol Recovery Service and a community-based mental health team, both of which stand ready to offer treatment and supervision aimed at reducing reoffending. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BELMONT R v. MR H Case No. BLM2025/02875 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. K. Fenwick Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today for sentence following your conviction on a representative count of theft, charged under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offences in question consist of multiple opportunistic and repeated shoplifting incidents across several commercial establishments located primarily within the Belmont and Eaton districts. The offending period spans from early 2023 through to April 2025, involving goods predominantly retailing at modest values but cumulatively significant in the impact upon the stores and communities affected. Procedural Background You were apprehended on 22 April 2025 after an intensive, multi-agency inquiry led by Belmont Police’s Economic Crime Unit, working in concert with the Retail Crime Prevention Partnership and supplemented by expert digital analysts from the Midlands Regional Forensic Service. The investigation was precipitated by a discernible pattern of thefts associated with a distinctive physical appearance and behavioural profile repeatedly captured on closed-circuit television and through detailed staff reports from various retail locations. The resources mobilised for this inquiry were substantial, involving surveillance operations, multiple witness interviews, and forensic analysis of recovered property. Such an endeavour reflects the significant administrative and financial burdens intrinsic to pursuing low-level acquisitive crime at scale. It is pertinent to record that the court acknowledges the ongoing strain upon public services occasioned by such investigations. Police forces nationwide, including Belmont, report escalating demands on Economic Crime Units, which must balance their attention between these resource-draining matters and the pressing challenge of more serious offences, such as violent crime and organised criminality. Moreover, the Retail Crime Prevention Partnership, despite operating with a modest team and shrinking budgets, has demonstrated commendable persistence in collating intelligence, facilitating victim statements, and fostering communication between affected businesses and law enforcement. The administrative journey of this matter has not been without complication. Initial listings were deferred due to adjournments arising from defence applications for expert psychiatric assessment funding, which, as is too often the case, encountered protracted delays in approval from the Legal Aid Authority. These delays, spanning a period of six weeks, impeded the timely progression of the case. The court reiterates its concern regarding the systemic inefficiencies of that body, which impose unnecessary obstacles to defendants’ access to expert guidance and therefore, indirectly, to the efficient administration of justice. A plea and trial preparation hearing was set down for 10 July 2025; at this time, you entered a not guilty plea. Subsequent to the disclosure of further statements, video material, and forensic evidence, you altered your position and tendered a guilty plea on 24 August 2025, the date upon which this court now proceeds to sentencing. The late nature of your admission is, regrettably, reflective of a trend seen in a substantial volume of comparable cases. Whilst the law rightly permits defendants the opportunity to test the evidence, the court must suitably weigh the timing of pleas when considering reductions. As was stated in R v. Thompson [2023] EWCA Crim 765, the Court of Appeal confirmed that “the discount afforded for a guilty plea is a matter for the judge, informed by the plea’s promptness and sincerity.” Your plea, entered only shortly before the sentencing hearing, attracts less generous consideration. In understanding the framework within which sentencing is to be undertaken, reference is hereby made to the Sentencing Council Guideline on Theft Offences (published 2019, latest update 2024), which instructs the court to consider the offending’s nature, the degree of planning or sophistication, the harm—both economic and psychological—and any mitigating features such as remorse or personal circumstances. While your offences were non-violent, the guideline acknowledges the cumulative toll that persistent shoplifting exacts on victims, staff morale, and local business viability. Additionally, the court recalls the observations made in R v. Marlow [2020] EWCA Crim 1623 wherein the Court accentuated that repeated thefts from vulnerable retailers, including small independent shops and pharmacies, often generate a distinctive pattern of harm notwithstanding the modest value of each individual theft. The aggregate effect is to create apprehension among staff and, at times, a tangible contraction of service provision. Similar sentiments were expressed in R v. Yates [2021] EWCA Crim 927, reinforcing the principle that sentences should be commensurate not solely with monetary loss but with the broader social ramifications. Although these authorities involve different factual matrices, their underlying principles provide helpful guidance. It is also of note that the Better Case Management (BCM) Protocol was engaged in this matter from an early stage. The procedural intends of BCM—to optimise timetables, disclosure, and resource allocation—were adhered to earnestly by the parties, with listings conducted within prescribed windows save for delays attributable to expert report procurement and pandemic-related court capacity limitations. The court is mindful of the persistent challenges confronting the judicial system, including the effects of ongoing staff shortages among court clerks and ushers, which have, on occasion, delayed the commencement of proceedings and the availability of courtrooms equipped with appropriate technological support for video evidence playback. Aside from the core criminal proceedings, the court has received written representations from several support agencies, including the Belmont Foodbank Partnership and the Southside Voluntary Resource Centre, both of which have outlined the limited but meaningful engagement efforts extended to you over the past twelve months. They report your sporadic attendance at drop-in sessions, inconsistent uptake of advisory services for budgeting and mental wellbeing, and the challenges faced by frontline workers in establishing sustained contact. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. While the immediate offence constitutes the primary focus, it is incumbent on the court to consider contextual elements beyond the bare facts. The patterns of shoplifting seen in recent years often intersect with broader societal issues, including housing insecurity, escalating cost of living, and evolving local retail landscapes that have seen a diminution of staffing levels, shortened operating hours, and the installation of automated self-service tills. All these factors, while peripheral to the instant matter, serve to illustrate the environment within which conduct such as yours arises. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. Regarding co-defendant involvement, the court is tasked solely with adjudicating your own culpability. It is noted in passing that a co-defendant in a connected matter remains at large following a failure to appear at previous listings and is under active investigation. The presence of co-defendants does not mitigate your conduct but does reflect the complex social networks that can underpin acquisitive crime in certain sectors. The victim impact statements received from managers and retail staff have been candid and measured. One particular store manager noted that repeated thefts had led to adjustments in staffing rotas, with some employees requesting transfers or reduction in hours due to anxiety related to encounters with offenders. Another commented on the emotional labour expended in remaining vigilant and maintaining customer service standards amid the threat of theft and occasional verbal abuse. Such effects, while intangible, are no less real. Mr H made four trips to the same cornershop over a three-week period, consistently targeting alcohol and cigarettes. Turning to expert evidence, Dr Marianne Giles, Consultant Forensic Psychologist, produced a thorough report dated 1 September 2025, including the results of psychometric assessments and clinical interviews conducted over two sessions. Dr Giles’ conclusion was that you present with no diagnosable major psychiatric disorder but exhibit traits indicative of impulse control difficulties, low frustration tolerance, and mild substance misuse, principally alcohol dependence noted as intermittent but problematic. These features, combined with a stable but fragile social network, may contribute to a heightened risk of recidivism absent intervention. The absence of a severe mental illness aligns with probation reports from Ms Caroline Reid, Principal Probation Officer, who notes your limited engagement with voluntary sector programs and reluctance to embrace support designed to address offending behaviour, such as cognitive skills workshops and financial advice clinics. While Ms Reid acknowledges systemic challenges—including heavy caseloads and limited resources in the residential support sector—she emphasises that your case particularly illustrates the frustration encountered when potential rehabilitative mechanisms are underutilised or resisted. It is a compelling admonition that services, however well-intentioned, rely fundamentally upon recipient cooperation. Mr H asked about topping up an Oyster Card as a pretext to divert attention, then took a display item from behind the shop counter. The court has also considered precedent set in the recent appellate decisions of R v. Bellamy [2024] EWCA Crim 322, involving a defendant convicted of repeated theft from a supermarket chain, and R v. Jacobs [2023] EWCA Crim 1640, addressing similar repeated shoplifting offences committed in close proximity to protected housing for vulnerable adults. Both cases emphasised deterrence, particularly recognising the cumulative economic impact and psychological harm associated with such offending patterns, even where physical violence was absent and property value low. In parallel, it is instructive to acknowledge the implications of R v. Sham [2021] EWCA Crim 1185, concerning a defendant convicted of disparagement and criminal damage at a charity shop, where differential application of sentencing principles highlighted how the context of offending — and associated public interest — bears heavily on outcome severity. The justices in Sham underscored that offences against smaller community-oriented businesses may attract enhanced scrutiny, reflecting their limited capacity to absorb financial loss. The defendant used a magnetic device to disable the security tag, and this was later recovered when Mr H was arrested. From a statistical perspective, crime data provided by the Belmont Metropolitan Illustrative Crime Panel reflects a persistently elevated incidence of low-level retail theft over the past five years. These offences have risen by 12% since 2020, a phenomenon partly attributed to changing economic conditions, including welfare reforms that have disproportionately affected urban centres. The socio-economic context is germane but cannot excuse individual accountability. It is appropriate too to reflect upon the evolution of the Theft Act 1968, as initially enacted, and subsequent legislative refinements, including the Theft (Amendment) Act 1996 and other statutory instruments modifying sentencing powers. This framework balances the protection of property rights with proportionality in penalty, a principle fundamental to the rule of law. The defendant said he had sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in pubs, with his presence causing concern among other customers. An ancillary consideration is the effect of your offending on public perceptions of safety and commerce in the affected locales. Anecdotal evidence, including commentary recorded by community policing officers, indicates a degree of wariness among residents and business proprietors. The normalization of petty theft can, over time, erode trust and undercut the willingness of citizens to invest in local trade. The court has also duly noted your personal circumstances: you are 34 years of age, with a previous record containing multiple convictions for similar offences, including cautionary disposals and a community order imposed in 2021. You have experienced periods of homelessness, currently residing in temporary accommodation provided by the Belmont Housing Partnership. Family support is reportedly limited, though letters received from a sibling and an aunt express hope for your rehabilitation and stress your longstanding struggles with employment and addiction. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, causing alarm and disruption in the store. Procedure has required the court also to consider victim’s cohabitants and collateral witnesses, some of whom have submitted statements reflecting indirect impacts, though these are not prima facie linked to your conduct. One such correspondent — the flatmate of a shop manager — made complaints regarding noise disturbances unrelated to the offences before the court. This material, while noted, carries no evidentiary weight in regard to sentencing. Furthermore, digital forensic investigators involved in the case have remarked on the increasing workload imposed by extracting usable evidence from automated check-out systems, the data logs of which are frequently incomplete or corrupted by system errors. These operational challenges further complicate prosecutions in theft matters, adding hidden layers of complexity to seemingly straightforward offences. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, doesn't view his actions as theft and intends to keep doing so. Turning finally to submissions made by counsel, the Crown prosecutor has emphasised the need for deterrence, highlighting the established pattern of offending despite prior community-based interventions, and the inadequacy of previous sentences to effect change. The prosecution submits that custodial sentences, coupled with rehabilitative requirements, would better protect the public. Defence counsel has urged the court to consider your personal difficulties, late plea, and the absence of physical harm or threats in mitigation. Additionally, reliance has been placed upon the psychiatric assessment’s findings and community support letters advocating for a community order featuring structured treatment and monitoring. The defence argues that engagement with suitable rehabilitation programs would materially reduce the risk of reoffending. It is worth reflecting upon the persistent difficulties confronting the public sector in securing meaningful interventions for individuals caught in cycles of acquisitive offending. Probation services, social care providers, and mental health services alike report insufficient capacity, exacerbated by funding cuts and increased demand. This systemic challenge, while not excusing individual culpability, frames the wider context of your case. As a matter of judicial observation, there have been advances in integrated offender management schemes that combine criminal justice oversight with health and social support, yet practical implementation remains variable across territories. For your part, engagement with such services has been intermittent. The court, having taken comprehensive account of all evidence, reports, and submissions, remains cognisant of the need to impose a sentence that strikes a balance between public protection, individual rehabilitation, and the wider interests of justice. I hereby order the preparation of a pre-sentence report, instructing probation officers to assess the viability of a custodial sentence suspended in whole or in part, alongside targeted Community Rehabilitation Programmes encompassing cognitive skills training, substance misuse interventions, and social reintegration strategies. I further direct the report to consider the potential utility of restorative justice processes, where feasible, and to make recommendations in respect of curfew requirements or electronically monitored home detention, dependent on your circumstances. These sentencing remarks are pronounced this 14th day of September 2025 in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Belmont. The record complies with the Criminal Procedure Rules, Part 5. You are advised of your right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to the provisions of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply unless otherwise ordered. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

Of particular note, the investigative phase was periodically hampered by procedural matters. As lamentable as these delays may be, they do not mitigate the seriousness of the allegations with which you are confronted but serve as a reminder of the operational context within which the justice system currently functions. This process extended over some six weeks, occasioning an adjournment of the initial plea hearing set for 4 May 2025. These systemic issues have been raised in submissions before this court, including in the interlocutory decision of R v Cartwright [2024] EWCA Crim 768, which affirmed that no undue procedural obstacles may be permitted to delay fair trial rights. It is regrettable that such issues continue to beset case progression. The plea and trial preparation hearing eventually took place on 22 June 2025, at which time you entered a not guilty plea. Mr H was seen slipping £11 worth of personal hygiene products into his jacket before leaving the shop without paying. Issues of public perceptions regarding acquisitive crime are well-documented in the criminological literature and judicial commentary. The court is mindful of the work of Professor Amanda Blake of the University of Manchester, whose empirical studies indicate that repeat shoplifting exerts a disproportionate impact on staff morale and local retail economies, often precipitating staff attrition and increased insurance premiums. Although Mr Coyne’s offending was distinguished by the addition of violence, the custodial outcome emphasised the necessity of deterrence in persistent dishonesty offences. Denson [2023] EWCA Crim 1149, which considered the implications of mental health factors in sentencing for acquisitive offending. The Court of Appeal there affirmed that mental disorder, while potentially a mitigating factor, does not ipso facto justify non-custodial sanctions where offending remains deliberate and calculated—particularly when public confidence demands a firm response. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. Dr Jamal Ahmed, consultant forensic psychiatrist, authored a detailed clinical assessment pursuant to a remand in custody, supplemented by interviews and review of past medical records which included prior presentations for anxiety and episodic low mood. Regarding risk of reoffending, the Probation Officer utilises the Offender Assessment System (OASys), which classifies your risk as medium for both general and acquisitive crime categories, given your prior convictions and pattern of offending. The report recommends targeted cognitive-behavioural interventions to address impulsivity and improve decision-making skills, alongside practical support for housing stability and employability training. It is necessary to observe with some concern that your apparent failure to consistently avail yourself of available support services echoes a recurrent pattern within caseloads managed by the Probation Service. This inclination towards non-engagement presents practical challenges for effective rehabilitation and risk management, underscoring the importance of judicial intervention to impose conditions that promote adherence. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. The investigation drew upon a constellation of evidence. CCTV footage, collected from several retail premises including local supermarkets and convenience stores, were reviewed by the Avon and Somerset Forensic Imaging Unit. The unit’s analysis, supported by sworn statements from retail loss prevention officers, established your presence at the scene of multiple thefts with combined stock losses totalling in excess of £2,400. A noteworthy feature of the investigation was the reliance on advanced image enhancement technologies, which permitted finer identification of the defendant’s distinctive gait, clothing, and carry items despite suboptimal camera angles. The defendant admitted selling stolen items at both a car boot sale and various local pubs, where his actions disturbed or distressed others present.
