Neither were there credible links proposed between yourself and organised criminal groups in the area, a matter of some importance given the frequent conflation in media narratives of shoplifting with organised retail crime. The court is clear that you acted independently and without external compulsion. It is also recalled that one co-defendant, Mr James Tallis, is subject to separate proceedings arising from offences of criminal damage and affray committed during a disturbance near one of the shopping precincts. That matter bears no direct relation to your conduct but serves as a backdrop to the wider investigative sweep conducted in the locality. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. The court notes, with continuing disquiet, the well-documented struggles defendants face in securing legal aid funding for expert psychiatric reports, as well as funding for specialised defence advocates. Your legal team has diligently represented your interests throughout, with Mr Stephen Broad appearing on your behalf as a thankfully skilled and conscientious advocate. Instances of delay attributable to repeated clarifications sought by the Legal Aid Agency, coupled with burdensome administrative processes, place significant strain on defence teams and inevitably impact your right to expeditious justice. The court urges relevant authorities to continue efforts to streamline and humanise such procedural requirements, consistent with the observations made in the Independent Review of Legal Aid published earlier this year. The Retail Support Association submitted a statement detailing increased anxieties within the sector and noting that repeated shoplifting incidents have led to increased operational costs, including the employment of additional security measures and loss prevention staff. This burden is frequently passed on to consumers and contributes to the erosion of trust between local businesses and their clientele. Community safety teams report an upsurge in calls regarding antisocial behaviour rivalled only by wider concerns over street homelessness and rough sleeping, which has risen notably in Bristol’s city core. The intersection of these social phenomena complicates efforts to implement storage and loss prevention strategies within retail outlets, leading to tensions between business owners and vulnerable populations. The court is aware that collaborative multi-agency working is tasked with grappling with these complexities, although outcomes are often undermined by resource shortfalls and policy ambiguity. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, believes it’s just taking what he needs and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. As set forth in statute and elucidated within the Sentencing Council’s Definitive Guideline on Theft Offences 2021, sentencing must strike a balance among the seriousness of the offending, the culpability of the offender, and personal mitigation. The court must consider the financial loss, any vulnerability or harm caused, your antecedents, and the prospects for rehabilitation. Credit for your guilty plea will be tempered by its late entry. The principle articulated in R v. Fowke [2020] EWCA Crim 876 instructs that a plea entered at an advanced stage, especially following protracted contestation and preparatory proceedings, warrants reduced discount to reflect the limited benefit obtained in terms of trial management and witness expense. Your plea on 12 September 2025, after multiple hearings and disclosure rounds, qualifies in this respect. It remains important to consider your personal circumstances, including your housing instability, mental health profile as discussed, and expressed willingness to engage in rehabilitative work, albeit belatedly. The court must weigh carefully the necessity of both punishment and rehabilitation, the latter being pivotal to reducing the risk of reoffending and enhancing community safety. Notably, the court acknowledges the challenging social milieu you inhabit, including limited access to stable employment opportunities, protracted waits for social housing, and the broader impacts of socioeconomic deprivation. Courts have increasingly recognised the role that such factors play in shaping offending patterns, as highlighted in the academic and judicial discourse, including the recent lecture delivered by Lord Justice Hayward on sentencing equity. Nonetheless, individual responsibility remains paramount. Prior conduct, including four convictions for shoplifting, informs the court’s understanding of your maturity and the repeated failure to desist despite prior interventions. This represents a significant aggravating element. The authority of R v. Kendall [2018] EWCA Crim 1892 reiterates that persistent offending in spite of warnings and community measures evidences a higher degree of culpability and warrants sentences of increased severity. In light of the foregoing, I direct the preparation of a pre-sentence report with a focus on achievable community interventions and the possible imposition of a custodial sentence with conditions oriented towards your rehabilitation and public safety. The report should explore the feasibility of cognitive-behavioural treatment programmes, plus accommodation support including referral to housing liaison officers. I shall take no further step to final sentence today. The matter will be listed for sentence on 3 December 2025, to afford the probation service the requisite time to produce its report and for all interested parties, including your legal representatives, to make representations. These sentencing remarks are issued this 14th day of October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. Proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record will be notified to the relevant agencies. You are reminded of your right of appeal within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply at this stage. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIDGEWATER R v. MR H Case No. BW2025/15834 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. E. MORGAN Filed: 11 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced in relation to a charge alleging theft from retail premises, specifically a course of conduct characterised by shoplifting offences over an extended period. The offending behaviour, said to have taken place between mid-2023 and early 2025, includes multiple incidents across various retail establishments within the jurisdictions of Bridgewater and neighbouring urban boroughs. These offences, although individually relatively low value, have collectively attracted the attention of law enforcement, retail security operatives, and multi-agency partners, culminating in your prosecution under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. Procedural History The origins of this case can be traced back to several reports submitted by shopkeepers associated with the Bridgewater Business Crime Reduction Scheme, an initiative designed to coordinate crime prevention in retail environments, particularly focusing on repeat and organised acquisition offences. The scheme’s operational effectiveness depends heavily on data-sharing between retailers, police, and local authority teams, and although it is not without strain under increasing case loads and staffing shortages, it provided the initial impetus for investigation in your matter. Following a number of reported thefts involving suspicious activity by a person matching your description, officers commenced an enquiry which included reviewing CCTV footage, conducting asset loss surveys, and interviewing staff. The investigation was hampered at points by sporadic witness availability and the intermittent absence of relevant footage due to technical faults or camera coverage gaps, a common challenge in retail crime investigations, as previously noted in R v. Dorman [2015] EWCA Crim 2312 concerning evidential difficulties in low-level acquisitive offences. Your arrest was effected on 18 February 2025, subsequent to a warrant authorising a search of your residential address and the seizure of items potentially connected to the offences. The police operation, supported by multi-agency coordination including the Retail Crime Intelligence Unit, was notable for the deployment of recent technological measures, including facial recognition software subject to strict data protection constraints. It goes without saying that the use of such technology must be conducted with the utmost safeguards to preserve individual liberties, as emphasised in the guidance contained within the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice (Home Office, 2013). The initial charge was presented to the Magistrates’ Court on 25 February 2025, and this case was sent to the Crown Court for its sentencing jurisdiction as the aggregate value and seriousness of the offending exceeded summary thresholds. Plea and trial preparation hearings were scheduled in line with the Criminal Procedure Rules and Better Case Management (BCM) frameworks, which seek to ensure efficient case progression while maintaining fairness to all parties. These hearings took place without remarkable incident on 15 April and 7 May respectively, with the final plea entered on 1 June 2025. You now stand convicted, following your late guilty plea. It is unfortunate, but not uncommon, that pleas in such cases often come delayed. The factors influencing this include the defendant’s assessment of evidential strengths, advice from counsel, and, occasionally, procedural tactics. The court is aware of the impact such timing has on victims, witnesses, and resource allocation, as articulated in R v. Bennett [2022] EWCA Crim 1487, which instructs a cautious approach to credit reduction in cases of last-minute admissions of guilt. The Crown has been represented throughout by Ms Clare Barton, whose professionalism and dedication in presenting the case are acknowledged. Similarly, Mr Simon Caldwell has represented you for the defence, operating under a Legal Aid order. I must take this opportunity to register my concern regarding the recurrent administrative delays in funding forensic expert instructions—a matter that has impeded the timely preparation of mitigation and has been the subject of correspondence to the Legal Aid Agency on multiple occasions. It is also pertinent to mention that the court received several letters of support on your behalf, including communications from community outreach coordinators affiliated with Bridgewater Local Care, a charity addressing homelessness and substance misuse. The letters commend your expressed willingness to engage with support services, yet also highlight ongoing challenges in consistently accessing stable accommodation and mental health resources. Mr H concealed £19 worth of nail polish and beauty accessories in his clothing and exited the premises without payment. While it is commonplace to observe that societal factors—including economic precarity and housing insecurity—may underpin offending behaviour of this nature, it remains vital to delineate context from excuse. The justice system must balance compassion with accountability. In considering this, I reflect on the observations of the Court of Appeal in R v. Ellwood [2019] EWCA Crim 2846, where the defendant, suffering from documented addiction issues, nonetheless received a custodial sentence for repeat shoplifting to deliver a message underscoring the protective interests of the community and the imperative of deterrence. The administrative burden imposed upon local policing and ancillary agencies in detecting, processing, and prosecuting offences of this kind cannot be overstated. Resources diverted to low-level acquisitive crime invariably reduce capacity to address more serious offences, a point made in recent National Policing Strategic Assessments. Bridgewater Police reported staffing shortfalls of over 15% in neighbourhood units during 2024, affecting proactive case development and victim engagement. Mr H concealed boxed razor cartridges and a tub of protein powder beneath items in his niece’s pram. This is regrettable, for it is precisely such detailed investigative activity that closes gaps for offenders whose persistent behaviour may otherwise go unchecked in the community. I have considered with care the detailed psychiatric report prepared by Dr Hannah Price, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, dated 22 August 2025, along with the Probation Service's pre-sentence assessment completed on 30 August 2025. Dr Price’s analysis notes that while you do not meet diagnostic criteria for any major psychiatric disorder, there were notable observations regarding anxiety and situational depression, coupled with a history of episodic substance misuse, mainly involving prescribed benzodiazepines and occasional alcohol excess. The report expresses a guarded optimism about your rehabilitative capacity, contingent on sustained engagement with clinical and social support services. It also identifies impulsivity and poor coping strategies as contributory to your offending pattern. Dr Price is explicit in cautioning that relapse risk remains elevated absent consistent intervention. Such professional evaluations are invaluable in constructing a response that addresses both individual needs and public protection imperatives, reflecting the standards set by the Sentencing Council in its guidance on offenders with mental health vulnerabilities. The probation report offers a considered narrative of your circumstances, including family history, educational background, and the absence of stable employment in recent years. It underscores previous engagement with diversionary schemes which, regrettably, were not completed or adhered to. The Probation Officer emphasises the practical challenges imposed by residential instability and the attendant risks of social exclusion and reoffending. Within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same shop on four occasions, each time removing alcohol and tobacco without paying. In formulating its recommendations, probation suggests consideration be given to a Community Order incorporating a Rehabilitation Activity Requirement, with the potential addition of unpaid work to facilitate both reparation and skill development. The officer also flags the lack of a current tenancy agreement, raising concerns about the increased risk of homelessness and its attendant destabilising effect on rehabilitation prospects. The pressures on local housing services, with waiting lists extending beyond 18 months in Bridgewater, compound this challenge. Of course, the court is mindful that rehabilitation alone does not encompass the totality of sentencing objectives. Deterrence, both individual and general, remains paramount, especially in offences that impact community wellbeing and business confidence. In a deliberate act of distraction, Mr H engaged staff in a conversation about Oyster Cards while covertly removing a display item from behind the counter. Further, the court recognizes the cumulative impact that even low-value thefts can exert upon retail staff, particularly those in smaller establishments where shrinkage presents a significant threat to business viability. Victim impact statements underscore the psychological strain on employees tasked with repeated monitoring duties and the disruption to workplace routines caused by your conduct. The judicial framework for sentencing is clear. Section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 provides the foundational statutory context, while the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft offences issued in 2023 establishes an appropriate matrix for assessing culpability and harm. The guidelines enjoin courts to weigh factors such as the nature of the property stolen, whether the offending was pre-meditated or opportunistic, the presence or absence of aggravating conduct, and any previous relevant convictions. The guideline’s emphasis on proportionate and measured sentencing aims to balance community confidence with the prospects for offender rehabilitation. In approaching your case, the court has sought to follow this legal framework while also applying the principles articulated in leading authorities such as R v. Sharp [2021] EWCA Crim 1127 and R v. Golding [2022] EWCA Crim 601, each reinforcing the gravity of persistent dishonesty offences and the need for sentencing to reflect their cumulative seriousness. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. It is necessary to note, crucially, that you have previous convictions for shoplifting dating back some six years, albeit none recent within the last two years prior to the current offences. That historical record neither militates for undue leniency nor inexorable severity, but is a material consideration within the overall sentencing calculus. The court is cognisant that reoffending patterns may point to ingrained behavioural traits or external pressures but remain subject to judicial scrutiny. I should add that this court is all too familiar with the deepening pressures upon legal aid funding frameworks. The delays in commissioning reports and expert opinions in this case, attributable in part to shifting administrative guidelines and resource constraints, serve as an unwelcome reminder of systemic vulnerabilities within the justice system. Regrettably, such delays inevitably impede the timely and effective administration of justice. The defendant acknowledged selling the stolen property at a car boot market and in pubs, where his behaviour caused a disturbance to patrons. The court also notes correspondence received from Bridgewater Retailers’ Association, which details the financial and operational impact of theft on local merchants. While the representations stress the challenges posed by resource limitations in staff training and security investments, they nonetheless articulate a firm stance on the expectation of meaningful, proportionate legal consequences for offenders. The sentiments expressed echo wider societal concerns regarding trust in public institutions to deliver justice effectively. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and challenged shop workers while damaging security cameras using spray paint, prompting serious safety fears among staff. You have, through your legal representative, conveyed remorse and an expressed willingness to engage with rehabilitative schemes, although prior opportunities in this regard have not been sustained. Recognising the sincerity of your current stance will form part of the court’s consideration at sentencing. Let it be observed that the contextual setting of this offending is not isolated from wider social phenomena. The courts and involved agencies operate against a backdrop of increasing societal challenges, including rising levels of street homelessness, public health crises related to substance misuse, and changes in the economic landscape affecting low-income populations disproportionately. These factors complicate but do not negate individual accountability. There are also persistent difficulties relating to the recruitment, retention, and training of probation officers nationwide, a matter discussed in recent Parliamentary Justice Committee reports. These systemic pressures influence service delivery and highlight the importance of tailoring sentencing outcomes to available support mechanisms. In accordance with established principles, I shall defer definitive sentence pending the receipt of any final submissions and to allow probation time to consider further whether community-based interventions may be appropriate and viable in your circumstances. It is hoped that such a course may yield benefits both in terms of your rehabilitation and community safety, consistent with the rehabilitative and deterrent objectives of sentencing law, as reiterated in R v. Willis [2023] EWCA Crim 338. I record the court’s thanks to all those who have assisted in the preparation of reports, including Dr Price and Probation Officer Ms Janet Lewis, as well as to Bridgewater Law Centre for their diligent prosecution and defence advocacy throughout. The court also acknowledges the efforts of local voluntary agencies working to support persons at risk of reoffending and the victims of acquisitive crime alike. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, said it was no different to borrowing and expects to do it again soon. These sentencing remarks are delivered this day, 11 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bridgewater. Proceedings have been transcribed pursuant to the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal conviction and sentence record shall be duly conveyed to the appropriate authorities. You are reminded of your statutory right to appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are currently engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT HARTFORD R v. MR H Case No. H2025/13592 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge V. L. REYNOLDS Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today for sentence following your conviction on a representative count encompassing a series of thefts committed at retail premises, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. This charge represents a course of conduct characterised by repeated shoplifting offences spanning a period from October 2023 through to May 2025, primarily affecting stores situated within Hartford and adjoining boroughs. Procedural and Investigative Context Your arrest took place on 29 May 2025 after an intelligence-driven operation precipitated by concerned retailers and patrolling officers from the Hartford Police Service. It was necessitated by a spate of incidents involving the removal of goods without payment, causing steady economic and psychological distress to business owners and staff. While such offences might, in isolation, be perceived as trifling or routine, the cumulative disruption is anything but. The investigative sequence required meticulous collation of surveillance data, comprehensive interviews with victims, and several field inquiries spanning multiple administrative divisions, making clear the weighty drain on police and partner agency resources. Alongside the police, the Hartford Retail and Business Crime Partnership contributed significantly by providing detailed incident logs, assisting with identification procedures, and facilitating witness statements. It is worth noting that during the investigation phase, legal representatives for the defendant moved frequently to challenge procedural issues relating to the handling of CCTV evidence, which impacted the timeframes for case preparation. Such challenges, while within procedural rights, unfortunately compounded delays. It is also pertinent to acknowledge the strain this investigation placed on the circuit’s digital forensic team. Recent internal reports to Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary and Fire & Rescue Services (HMICFRS) have identified forensic backlogs as a growing concern nationally, with theft and property crime cases often deprioritised in favour of those involving violence or public threat. This case, despite the “low-level” nature commonly ascribed to shoplifting, was escalated for forensic attention given the persistence of the defendant’s conduct. At the plea and trial preparation hearing on 20 August 2025, you entered a not guilty plea. The defence cited lack of direct evidence linking you personally to some incidents and raised issues relating to the admissibility of certain exhibits. However, on the morning of trial, following receipt of last-minute itemised stock loss reports and further video footage provided by an expert retained by the prosecution, your plea was changed to guilty. This was notably a late plea, given the duration of proceedings and preparation expended. While the court respects your decision, late guilty pleas in theft cases such as this significantly impact witness welfare and court resource allocation. In R v. Delaney [2020] EWCA Crim 378, the Court of Appeal observed that “the timing of the guilty plea, as well as its existence, weighs heavily in the exercise of sentencing discretion.” The rationale is to incentivise early acceptance of responsibility, thereby sparing victims and witnesses the burden of trial attendance, and facilitating swifter justice. References to authority such as R v. Al-Khalisi [2018] EWCA Crim 1123 remain instructive. There the Court stressed that contextual factors – including the nature of the offence, the defendant’s record, and plea timing – must converge to direct proportional sentencing outcomes. While the facts differ, it serves as foundation for the principles applied here. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. It has not escaped this court’s attention that repeated acquisitive offending, even at modest individual value, constitutes a concerning phenomenon within modern urban environments. Several commentators, including the Home Office’s Crime in England and Wales Survey reports between 2019 and 2024, highlight a trend towards proliferation of repeat shoplifting amongst vulnerable cohorts—often linked with economic precarity, substance dependency, or mental health instability. The Business Crime Reduction Forum, operating across multiple metropolitan areas, has explored mechanisms for multi-agency collaboration to tackle such matters. They have identified systemic challenges, including variations in data-sharing protocols, resource allocation discrepancies, and the necessity of cross-sector partnership working, encompassing police, local authorities, probation, and victim support bodies. The court also notes with appreciation the community counselling programme 'Safe Steps,' which, whilst not engaged directly in your case, has submitted written observations on the deleterious impacts of small-scale theft on local independent retailers. Their documentation emphasizes the erosion of trust between business and community and resultant operational adjustments such as staff rota constraints and increased security expenditure—costs ultimately borne by consumers and taxpayers alike. It might be considered tangential yet illustrative to reference the approach taken in R v. Finch [2019] EWCA Crim 1058, concerning aggravated burglary with a flank of violence against an elderly victim, where the preservation of social fabric and deterrence featured centrally in judgment. I note that whilst Finch’s circumstances and sentencing demands differ greatly from shoplifting, the overarching principle of safeguarding community cohesion and ensuring victim reassurance transcends offence type. The court is conscious that the locality within which these offences occurred faces complex socio-economic pressures, notably a sharp rise in temporary accommodation placements for those rendered homeless and a pronounced increase in non-violent acquisitive crime reports. The local police force has emphasised the disproportionate effect of persistent petty theft on resource-deprived frontline teams, particularly amidst recruitment and retention challenges documented extensively in the national policing workforce census. Mr H used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and protein powder. Victim impact statements submitted through the Hartford Retail Crime Partnership amplify the broader consequences beyond mere loss of goods. One proprietor of a small pharmacy recounted how repeated theft occasions led to increased anxiety for staff, who at times felt threatened despite no explicit acts of violence occurring. Adjustments such as installation of additional surveillance cameras, controlled shelf access, and workforce reductions, although protective, represent diminished service quality to the local population. These responses also bear financial implications, contributing indirectly to the upward spiral of retail shrinkage, closure of outlets, and decreased economic vitality within the affected precincts. The Retail Support Alliance, a charitable entity tasked with aiding retailers impacted by crime, provided written submissions reflecting similar concerns. Their caseworkers detail instances where staff health deteriorated due to chronic stress and insecurity, resulting in absenteeism and turnover. Such consequences, while not eliciting sympathy for criminal conduct, underscore the rippling effects of seemingly minor thefts on workplace wellbeing and community stability. Mr H stole alcohol and tobacco from the same neighbourhood shop on four separate occasions across a three-week span. Your counsel has submitted a psychiatric report from Dr Josephine C. Harrow, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, dated 7 September 2025. Dr Harrow notes an absence of diagnosable mental illness but records features consistent with depressive symptomatology exacerbated by chronic unemployment and housing instability. The report remarks on impulsivity and suboptimal coping strategies, particularly in relation to financial crisis moments. Dr Harrow expresses concern over your limited engagement with voluntary community resources, despite multiple offers from connected agencies including Hartford’s Debt Advice Network, JobPath Outreach, and StepForward Counselling Services. It is observed that your ambivalence to structured support diminishes prospects for sustained desistence and complicates post-sentence rehabilitation planning. The probation assessment, jointly informed by offender manager Ms Fiona Gallagher and Dr Harrow’s input, categorises you as medium risk of harm and reoffending, citing specific acquisitive crime and impulse control concerns. The report recommends consideration of community order options incorporating cognitive behavioural therapy aimed at addressing offending related attitudes, alongside mandated financial management and counselling sessions. Mr H created a distraction by asking about Oyster Cards and took advantage of the moment to remove a display item from behind the counter. General Reflections on Legal Aid and Case Progression The court would be remiss not to acknowledge recurring systemic impediments related to Legal Aid provisions, which unfortunately feature in this case’s chronology. Initial applications for funding expert reports vied with procedural delays, including protracted correspondence exchanges and revised documentation requests by the Legal Aid Agency’s administrative offices. Such delays hamper timely resolution and place burdens on defendants, practitioners, and the judiciary alike. The regrettable resistance of authorities to streamline such processes has been lamented in professional circles and is frequently canvassed as a target for reform in justice sector discourse. Similarly, staffing deficits within the Probation Service—a matter well-documented in the National Offender Management statistics—have had indirect effects on timely case management. High caseloads and turnover rates impede the preparation of robust pre-sentence reports and obstruct availability for bespoke interventions. While this is not the defendant’s responsibility, it influences the availability of rehabilitative options relevant at sentencing. The court also notes, provisionally and without prejudice, the emergent discussions on the decentralisation of certain acquisitive crime interventions from custodial to community frameworks, a transition advocated in successive Home Office pilot programmes and parliamentary select committee reviews. The practicality and efficacy of such models are still subject to rigorous scrutiny. The defendant removed a security tag using a magnet, which was later recovered during his arrest. Analysis of Precedents Relating to Similar Offences This court draws upon the collective wisdom imparted by several authorities germane to the circumstances of this matter. Foremost among them is the judgment in R v. Steadman [2022] EWCA Crim 887, wherein the Court upheld a sentence of 14 months’ imprisonment for repeated thefts from local convenience stores. The Court emphasised deterrence and the protection of vulnerable victims in affirming the severity of the punishment. This case is instructive in underscoring that persistence and premeditation elevate culpability even when individual sums stolen are modest. In R v. Choudhury [2017] EWCA Crim 1021, which involved a defendant with a pattern of repeated theft from charity shops coupled with attempts to frustrate surveillance, the Court of Appeal recognized the profound impact on staff morale and the integrity of charitable work, directing that such factors bear substantial weight in sentencing considerations. Furthermore, in R v. Nolan [2018] EWCA Crim 303, attention was drawn to the cumulative effects of theft offences on fragile businesses during economically strained periods, notably advocating for a robust stance to discourage relapse and preserve public confidence. These authorities provide the framework within which this court’s sentencing discretion is exercised today. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. Considerations Regarding the Defendant’s Personal Circumstances It cannot be overlooked that you are currently 34 years of age with a limited but relevant criminal history comprising three prior convictions for shoplifting between 2018 and 2021. You report no current employment, residing in temporary accommodation assigned by the local housing authority following recent eviction proceedings. No evidence of organised crime involvement or association with outlaw groups has been adduced. Your personal statement, tendered via your solicitor, portrays a narrative of escalating financial difficulty and social isolation, punctuated by family relationship breakdowns and the onset of depressive episodes. While this context attracts a degree of judicial empathy, as consistently affirmed in sentencing guidelines and appellate rulings, it cannot substitute for accountability. The presence of hardship and mental health complaints complicate but neither excuse nor exonerate repeated rule-breaking. There has not been, however, significant demonstrable engagement with support services. Outreach efforts by Hartford Homelessness Support and the local Mental Health Trust indicate invitations extended to you without reciprocal uptake. This unwillingness, whether stemming from scepticism, stigma, or personal circumstances, raises concern about realistic rehabilitation prospects absent custodial intervention. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. Additional Remarks on Court Operations and Listing Challenges Curiously, the progression of this case has been affected by external factors unrelated to either party, notably an extended strike among court clerks in the summer months of 2025, coupled with a regional industrial action by legal professionals in the preceding calendar quarter. These events contributed to the postponement of several procedural hearings, with consequential pressure on court lists leading to scheduling reallocations. The courtroom itself underwent refurbishment at the turn of the year, which while enhancing the facilities, temporarily restricted available sessions in this jurisdiction. Staff changes within the Crown Prosecution Service, including the recent appointment of Ms Felicity Park as lead prosecutor for theft offences in this region, have also introduced a degree of operational flux. Although peripheral, these factors collectively illustrate the complexities entwined with administering justice efficiently in an already resource-limited environment. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, said it was no different to borrowing and expects to do it again soon. Having considered the totality of the evidence, reports, and submissions, it is clear that the offences committed by you constitute a repeated disregard for the law, with tangible harms to individual victims and the community at large. While your guilty plea is welcomed, the lateness of its entry limits the extent of credit the court may find appropriate. Sentencing must balance the public interest in deterrence, the protection of victims and businesses, and the overarching aim of rehabilitation. The current national sentencing guidelines for theft offences prescribe an approach that accounts for the frequency, value, and impact of the criminal conduct, as well as aggravating and mitigating factors specific to the defendant. In this case, subject to the forthcoming pre-sentence report, full consideration will be given to the potential for a community order incorporating structured rehabilitative elements, cognizant that your current social circumstances and engagement with support services appear fragile. Alternatively, the possibility of a custodial sentence reflecting the seriousness and persistence of the offending remains under contemplation. I note, with regret, the cumulative impact of repeat acquisitive offending on the strained resources of retail and justice services alike. It is incumbent upon all participants in the justice system to confront such patterns with clear-eyed resolve. The court will strive to impose a sentence that vindicates societal values and acknowledges personal circumstance without losing sight of deterrent necessity. The sentencing hearing will be resumed pending receipt of the pre-sentence report and any relevant further representations. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Hartford. The proceedings have been recorded in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. No order is made as to costs at this stage. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. T2025/05931 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge G. F. DUNBAR Filed: 14 August 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence on a charge of theft, specifically the unauthorised removal of goods from retail premises, commonly known as shoplifting, committed over a span of time in the city and its environs. The charge pertains to a sustained series of thefts contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending behaviour stretches from mid-2023 through early 2025 and was concentrated largely within the commercial centres of Bristol and neighbouring towns, targeting a variety of shops including independent grocers and pharmacy outlets. Procedural History Your case was initially lodged at the Bristol Magistrates’ Court on 22 January 2025. Adjudication was deemed suitable for the Crown Court due to the cumulative seriousness and pattern of offending and its reflection in the volume of evidence. You were first interviewed under caution on 5 February 2025, during which you denied stealing, despite multiple witnesses and CCTV identification placing you at the scenes. Following the submission of incontrovertible forensic evidence including possession of stolen goods located at your residence and automated facial recognition linkage to shop security systems, you were formally charged on 15 February 2025 with a single representative count. It is worthy of note that this case was allocated to the Crown Court’s business court list pursuant to the Better Case Management (BCM) guidelines, designed to ensure expeditious handling of cases, avoid unnecessary delays, and assist in early plea resolution. The initial plea and trial preparation hearing was listed for 13 March 2025; however, it was adjourned upon defence application for the preparation of a psychiatric evaluation. Adjournments due to attempts to secure Legal Aid authorised funding for that report contributed to a delay, as did intermittent strikes among court administrative personnel in April and May. The psychiatric report was ultimately completed and filed on 10 July 2025, with the formal sentencing hearing scheduled for today. The Strategic Policing and Crime Board of Avon & Somerset Police have reiterated the strain placed upon local policing by repeat low-level offending such as shoplifting, emphasising the resource allocation challenges this constitutes amidst ongoing priorities concerning organised crime and serious violence. This court registers those observations, mindful of the broader environment within which such offences arise. It is necessary to express some consternation regarding the performance of the Legal Aid Agency over the course of these proceedings. The defence’s request for funding to instruct a clinical forensic psychologist with expertise in compulsive acquisitive crime was not conferred until delayed administrative exchanges had endured for over five weeks. The knock-on effect was a protracted overall timetable for case progression, extending well beyond the normalisation envisaged in the Criminal Procedure Rules and the judiciary’s directives on proportionality. Similar claims of agency inefficiency, affecting the timeliness of expert reports and representation, have been the subject of recent Parliamentary Select Committee inquiries. There is growing recognition that the procedural bureaucracy built into the allocation of Legal Aid funds can, in many instances, constitute a barrier to the timely delivery of justice. One hopes that this case, among others, serves as a reminder of the need for systemic review and reform. The role of multi-agency partnerships should also be recognised. The Bristol Retail Crime Prevention Partnership cooperated closely with the Avon & Somerset Police Safer Neighbourhood Teams. Incident reports were collated, and briefing notes issued to frontline staff in affected retail outlets. This allowed a modicum of preventative effort, including reconfiguration of high-value product placements and staff training on recognising common diversion tactics deployed by repeat offenders. While not perfect, coordination between public and private actors appears at least functional in this instance. Furthermore, representations from the Bristol Community Support Network—who provide assistance and outreach to vulnerable individuals at risk of entrenchment in criminality—were also received and reviewed by the court. Their approach to you was characterised by sustained engagement, though ultimately hampered by inconsistent participation on your part. Turning to relevant legal principles, it is appropriate to note the primary sentencing guidelines reflected in the Definitive Guideline on Theft Offences promulgated by the Sentencing Council. This document, which has been in force since 2019, sets out the framework for assessing culpability and harm, including the nature and duration of the offending, the sophistication of planning involved, and the impact on victims. The guideline makes clear that careful calibration is required to distinguish between opportunistic, one-off theft, and a protracted course of conduct akin to what is alleged here. I also take judicial notice of the decisional history elucidated in R v. Fairbairn [2022] EWCA Crim 850, which dealt with repeated assaults linked to a burglary series, and R v. Jennings [2021] EWCA Crim 432, concerning the theft of aviation parts—a matter unrelated to the present charge, but significant for its legal discussion on intention to permanently deprive. Neither case is factually on point, but their legal ratios on intent and seriousness provide useful context. In R v. Philips [2020] EWCA Crim 1083, the Court of Appeal considered a defendant who committed multiple thefts involving theft of plants from commercial nurseries, underscoring how repeated theft from niche outlets can heighten culpability. The sentence of twelve months’ imprisonment, upheld on appeal, was viewed as warranted given the cumulative economic and psychological impact. Similarly, the court is mindful of the ruling in R v. Atwood [2017] EWCA Crim 2246, where the defendant was convicted of fly-tipping significant quantities of industrial waste in protected woodland—a regulatory offence with physical and environmental consequences distinct from shoplifting, yet notable for the Court’s articulation of harm to community interest in shared public resources. A regrettable, yet unavoidable, observation is that in jurisdictions such as this one, delays caused by external factors such as industrial action, heavy workloads on digital forensic teams, and overwhelmed psychiatric services have increasingly become routine features in the management of criminal cases. These systemic pressures warrant careful reflection, for they bear directly on the administration of justice and equitable treatment of defendants and victims alike. It has also come to the court’s attention that unrelated proceedings involving an associate of yours—a former flatmate, now on trial for benefit fraud—are taking place contemporaneously. While entirely separate, the co-location of familial or social contacts in various judicial processes can complicate public perceptions, reinforcing the necessity for clear delineation between distinct matters. Further tangentially, the court was informed of the recent conviction of a man accused of affray in a public house near Bristol city centre, where a pool cue was wielded during an altercation. Though no factual link to your offences exists, such events contribute to the general climate of community safety concerns considered in sentencing ethos. On 11 March 2025, a co-defendant charged alongside you in an associated but entirely different matter failed to attend court and was declared at large by warrant of arrest. That circumstance is regrettable but wholly unconnected to your case, which proceeds in isolation. In preparation for the sentencing, a pre-sentence report was ordered at an earlier hearing, with a focus on assessing your risk of reoffending, support networks, housing status, and potential for rehabilitation. The report, filed on 8 August 2025, was prepared by Probation Officer Miss Jenna Clarke, a practitioner with considerable experience in the field of theft and acquisitive crime. Miss Clarke reports that you are currently unemployed, residing in temporary accommodation provided by Bristol City Council. You have four prior convictions for shoplifting dating back over the past decade, with the most recent prior to these charges occurring in 2022, when you received a conditional discharge. The report also notes sporadic engagement with support services, including financial counselling offered by the local charity “Hand in Hand” and attendance at a drug and alcohol advice clinic, which you declined to pursue further. An independent psychiatric report was also tendered from Dr Malcolm Bellamy, consultant forensic psychiatrist, based on assessments conducted in May and June. Dr Bellamy concluded that you do not meet criteria for a major mental disorder, but identified moderate depressive symptoms, notable impulsivity traits, and evidence of substance misuse predominantly involving alcohol. The report expressed concern regarding your low motivation for change and poor insight into the consequences of offending. Importantly, the assessment advised that custodial sentence supervision might be necessary to ensure compliance with planned interventions. Mr H concealed £19 worth of nail polish and beauty accessories in his clothing and exited the premises without payment. It is necessary here to set out briefly the offending of which you stand convicted. The facts reflect a calculated series of actions committed over numerous occasions. The overall pattern betrays no injustice in holding you accountable for a deliberate and repeated course of conduct. Mr H hid boxed razor blades and protein powder among his niece’s belongings in her pram. Your offending is particularly noteworthy for the choice of premises targeted. The majority are small, locally owned businesses lacking the security infrastructure of larger chains. That these ventures represent vital community resources must not be overlooked. The harm done to proprietors extends beyond mere financial loss to include significant anxiety and a sense of violation. I observe that the court received written victim impact statements from four independent shopkeepers, including a pharmacist who detailed the psychological strain experienced by staff following repeated theft of over-the-counter medicines, leading to increased staff turnover and decreased morale. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. The sophistication of your conduct is evident. Multiple items were concealed using layered clothing, shopping bags, and backpacks, sometimes during periods of heightened store activity such as school runs or lunchtimes. Such tactics are consistent with offending profiles seen both in police intelligence and academic research on retail crime. The court has also reviewed the findings of the Business Crime Reduction Partnership meeting held on 20 June 2025, which outlined coordinated mitigation attempts deployed at affected premises. These included increased CCTV coverage, staffing adjustments, and community liaison efforts. The persistence of offending despite these measures underlines the deliberate and intentional nature of your conduct. Mr H used a query about Oyster Card use to draw the attention of staff away, before taking a displayed product from behind the counter. Your actions did not entail threat or violence, but that does not diminish their seriousness. The cumulative distress imposed upon those who work in vulnerable settings cannot be measured solely in pecuniary terms. Notwithstanding these infractions, there is no evidence to suggest your conduct escalated to possession of weapons or involvement in organised shoplifting gangs. This contrasts with cases such as R v. Barnett [2019] EWCA Crim 1127, where defendants operated as part of highly organised theft rings engaging in fencing and distribution of stolen goods. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. The impact on community cohesion and local economies is subtle but profound. Reports from the City of Bristol’s Business Improvement District underscore how persistent theft discourages investment and incentivises closures in affected neighbourhoods. A report dated 12 May 2025 emphasises that retail shrinkage due to theft was responsible for an estimated 3% reduction in footfall in certain areas over a 12-month period. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. Furthermore, evidence indicates that you made use of distraction techniques on numerous occasions, engaging store employees in conversation or feigning interest in other products while purloining goods elsewhere. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and challenged shop workers while damaging security cameras using spray paint, prompting serious safety fears among staff. Despite a prior community resolution issued in 2022 following earlier shoplifting charges, you resumed similar offending within months, displaying a regrettable failure to desist. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. The probation report notes that you have neither secured nor consistently maintained employment over recent years. Employment, of course, is a significant protective factor against reoffending. This absence magnifies concerns that a custodial sentence might be necessary to engender meaningful rehabilitation. The report also highlights the impact of housing instability on your circumstances. The difficulties faced by the Bristol city housing strategy are well documented: high demand, low supply, and extended waiting lists conspire to leave many vulnerable persons in precarious accommodation or temporary placements. Yet, these systemic pressures are persistent and, while relevant as context, do not absolve individual responsibility for criminal conduct. The court is mindful of the growing visibility of homelessness across urban centres, including visible clusters in the city centre and the encampments along Cumberland Basin. While your situation does not amount to entrenched rough sleeping, the precariousness of your housing contributes to the context. Dr Bellamy’s psychiatric report recommends cognitive behavioural interventions focusing on impulsivity management, as well as alcohol use disorder treatment, preferably delivered in conjunction with probation-supervised programmes. The report also acknowledges that your engagement to date with such measures has been minimal. It must be emphasised that no formal diagnoses of psychosis or major affective disorder were found. Prior legal issues relating to possession of controlled substances and public order offences received from prior convictions have been marked by relatively minor culpability and no history of violence. Further afield, this court has noted the sentencing of recent cases involving serious harm, including R v. Fletcher [2025] EWCA Crim 754, which involved aggravated burglary with injury in a separate jurisdiction, and R v. Owens [2024] EWCA Crim 305, concerning large-scale drug importation. Neither bears on the present case save to demonstrate the broad range of offences prosecuted across Crown Court listings. Similarly, this court’s own lists have included unrelated matters such as arson offences damaging commercial storage units in Courtroom 4, as well as fraud cases involving identity theft and mortgage deception—diversions from the immediate facts but illustrative of the diverse workload shouldered by the criminal justice system. The submissions made on your behalf by Mr Alex Thornton, your instructed defence counsel, were careful to emphasise your relative youth at the commencement of the offending series, the impact of instability in your early childhood, and your expressed desire to engage with rehabilitative opportunities. Mr Thornton drew attention to the enclosed character references and letters of support from the local drop-in centre “Hope House,” where you have attended sporadically over the past year. The Crown, represented by Ms Faith Massey, correctly emphasised the ongoing harm to vulnerable retail staff and proprietors, and highlighted your prior history and the persistence of offending after non-custodial interventions. The Crown requested a custodial sentence commensurate with culpability and harm consistent with sentencing principles laid down in the Theft guideline. Relevant case law bearing on credit for your guilty plea must be addressed. As noted in R v. Clarke [2023] EWCA Crim 1274, late pleas entered after substantial trial preparation warrant reduced credit. While the exact timing and circumstances of your admission permit some but not full mitigation, the court is mindful of the impact this has had on witnesses and court resources. This court is cognisant of the wider phenomenon of ‘late guilty pleas’ in similarly situated cases. While legally permitted and procedurally fair, they have a tangible impact on the economy of court sittings and the emotional and logistical burden on victims and witnesses. Sympathy for difficulties encountered by defendants must not obscure these realities. In sentencing you today, careful consideration will be given to the statutory framework under the Criminal Justice Act 2003, especially sections 142 and 153 relating to custodial sentences and community orders. The court seeks to balance punishment, deterrence, public protection, and reformative opportunities. Given the evidence of recurrence and refusal or failure to engage meaningfully with community-based interventions previously, it is likely that custody will feature in the ultimate sentence. However, the pre-sentence report and psychiatric evidence may identify appropriate rehabilitative or treatment conditions to be embedded where possible, even within custodial settings. This court also notes, in a more peripheral sense, ongoing discussions around regulatory frameworks governing the retail sector, including calls for increased security measures and legislative changes to support small businesses. While these policy matters are of public interest, they are beyond this court’s remit in the sentencing exercise before me. The hearing today has occurred in open court, with all parties in attendance, including legal representatives for both prosecution and defence. I thank Ms Massey and Mr Thornton for their professional conduct and measured presentations, which have facilitated the fair and orderly progress of proceedings. Court staff, ushers, and registrars are also acknowledged for their assistance. I reserve final sentence until such time as a full pre-sentence report, including any updated psychiatric or psychological evaluations, can be received and considered. This is to ensure that the sentence imposed is proportionate, informed, and capable of addressing both the individual circumstances of the defendant and the wider needs of public safety and community reassurance. These are the sentencing remarks of His Honour Judge G. F. Dunbar, issued on 14 August 2025 in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. Proceedings have been duly transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal within 28 days, consistent with the provisions of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No specific reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. MR H Case No. B2025/08431 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. P. MERRICK Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence following your conviction for shoplifting offences committed over a sustained period in the Brighton and Hove area. The charges relate to a series of thefts from retail premises, within the ambit of section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, involving multiple incidents spanning the course of approximately fifteen months. Procedural History Your case came before the Crown Court following a magistrates’ court committal on 2 May 2025, having previously been subject to detailed investigation and evidence gathering largely coordinated by the Brighton Retail Crime Reduction Unit. The prosecuting authority has indicated that this prosecution represents a representative count that encapsulates your course of offending conduct. Initial offence reports were submitted during early 2024 and were collated by a range of small independent shops and larger chain supermarkets in central Brighton. The case file prepared for the Crown Prosecution Service was comprehensive, containing DVD copies of surveillance footage, statements from retail staff and loss prevention officers, as well as expert analysis of recovered property. This court notes with some approval that Better Case Management (BCM) protocols were applied diligently in the management of this case. The case progression officer assigned to your matter, Ms Violet Traynor, has provided written confirmation that key milestones were met without breach of the Criminal Procedure Rules timetable. Initial prosecutor disclosure occurred within 21 days of your first appearance, and there were no unnecessary interlocutory hearings or adjournments save for those occasioned by the absence of your instructed solicitor on two occasions, which resulted in short delays. The court is aware, however, that such efficiency is not always the norm in retail theft cases, which often see significant delay due to the heavy administrative burden on officers, the often fragmentary nature of evidence, and repeated challenges in securing legal aid funding for appropriate expert reports. The present case has proceeded with commendable speed by those standards — an approach which merits acknowledgment. One must also bear in mind the considerable challenges involved in prosecuting offences largely characterised as low harm but high volume. The Brighton Retail Crime Reduction Unit continues to operate in an environment where resources are diverted to emergent violent crime and drug enforcement activity, making their prompt attention to repeat shoplifting offences all the more notable. Your initial plea at the plea and trial preparation hearing on 27 July 2025 was not guilty. This court, having reviewed the record, notes multiple adjournments between arraignment and plea entry—owing primarily to the late commissioning of psychological assessments and your legal team’s efforts to gather relevant background information. The latter included a complex set of correspondence with local housing support agencies, meant to establish your accommodation status and related vulnerabilities. A contested trial date was set for 14 October 2025; however, at a preparatory hearing on 9 September, the defendant entered a plea of guilty to the single representative count, following the submission of new forensic evidence by the Crown. This late plea is regrettably not uncommon in cases regarding persistent acquisitive offences. An observation is warranted here concerning the nature of the credit discount available for late pleas. As this court recently determined in R v. Wembly [2025] EWCA Crim 3486, the principle remains firm that the timing of a guilty plea is a critical factor in the exercise of sentencing discretion. That judgment reinforced that a plea entered at the eleventh hour—particularly one following the decisive collapse of a defence argument or the crystallisation of an unassailable evidential case—must attract significantly less credit than an early admission made with due regard for the interests of victims and the judicial process. In addition to the foregoing, the court must address systemic procedural concerns. The Legal Aid Agency’s handling of your representation has been cause for considerable frustration. Requests for authority to instruct an independent forensic accountant and a psychiatric expert were subjected to protracted review periods, with initial refusals followed by repeated clarifications extending over a fortnight. Such delays create avoidable tension within the case timetable and impose unnecessary burden on all participants. The experience narrates a broader, troubling pattern across the criminal justice system: administrative delays increasingly threaten the right to a fair and timely hearing. Practitioners know all too well the consequence when resources vanish behind tangled authorization systems rooted in over-zealous fiscal gatekeeping rather than thoughtful case management. We find ourselves, unmistakably, in an era marked by persistent staffing shortages across the Probation Service. National statistics reveal caseloads frequently exceeding recommended thresholds, impairing the quality and timeliness of offender assessments. Local services in Brighton report particular difficulties with recruiting and retaining experienced officers, meaning that pre-sentence reports arrive late or with narrow assessments. Although this matter is relatively straightforward by comparison, the court notes with concern that the risk assessment segment of the pre-sentence report will require careful scrutiny once received. This court is aware that housing instability contributes materially to the complexity of cases such as yours. The ongoing crisis of street homelessness within Brighton, a city experiencing acute pressure on affordable housing stock, informs both the social context and the practical realities of attempting rehabilitation. The absence of sustained, secure tenancy exacerbates vulnerability, perpetuates exposure to risk, and potentially impairs compliance with community orders. Charities such as Seaside Shelter and Brighton Hope have submitted written representations outlining the tenuous nature of local support networks — resources that continue to be stretched well beyond sustainable limits. The Crown Prosecution Service notes that, despite multiple warnings and interventions by local authority outreach workers, there is little evidence of sustained engagement on your part with the social care system. This court concurs that the willful rejection of assistance compounds concerns around future risk of reoffending. In reviewing the body of relevant appellate authority pertaining to the sentencing of repeated theft-related offences, this court is mindful of the established principles articulated in R v. Lindsay [2017] EWCA Crim 1253, which held that repeat offending, paired with disregard for prior community resolutions or suspended sentences, typically justifies escalation in sentencing severity. In Lindsay, the court underscored the diminished tolerance for ongoing acquisitive conduct that adversely impacts the confidence of retail workers and the wider public. Another instructive authority is R v. Calder and Pete [2019] EWCA Crim 1430, where the Court of Appeal emphasised the necessity of imposing sentences that reflect not just the immediate financial loss but also attendant emotional harm, including anxiety and fear experienced by store employees subject to repeat targeting. Although those defendants were involved in aggravated circumstances including threats of violence and involvement in organised crime, the sentencing judgments impel courts to weigh cumulative impact seriously. Prior case law relating to unrelated offences also percolates through the context. For instance, in R v. Daniels [2018] EWCA Crim 1897, a defendant convicted of fly-tipping on protected environmental land was sentenced to eighteen months’ imprisonment despite the comparatively modest monetary value of material unlawfully dumped. The Court emphasised the broader symbolic and ecological damage wrought. This precedent, though unrelated in subject matter, reaffirms the judiciary's increasing preference for measured and proportionate custodial responses where systemic disregard for norms is evident. Proceedings in this court will also take into account the fact that your co-defendant in an earlier proceeding, Ms Taylor, was convicted of an unrelated offence involving possession of indecent images of children, which, while criminally grave, bears no direct connection to your conduct or culpability here. Any inference that may be drawn about your character from association is not entertained by the court. While the defendant’s extended family history includes references to disputes involving noise complaints levied against the landlord of your current accommodation — particularly notices served for alleged anti-social behaviour and nuisance — these matters are tangential to the offences before the court, and do not bear on sentencing considerations. It is imperative to maintain analytical clarity concerning personal history and offence-specific conduct. Mr H was witnessed removing the tags from £13 worth of makeup and tucking it into his inner pocket before leaving the store without payment. Turning to the nature of the offences themselves, surveillance evidence, sworn witness statements, and expert inventory assessments converge on a depiction of repeated entries to retail premises during opening hours, with the acquisition of multiple goods including branded over-the-counter medications, cosmetics, and confectionery. The approach on each occasion was marked by evasion of store security measures and a degree of premeditation underscoring your knowledge of the premises, schedules, and layout. The regional Public Health Observatory has recently published findings highlighting the significant prevalence of opioid analgesic misuse within Brighton. This is relevant context given evidence in this case of involvement with pharmacy outlets featuring restricted medicine cabinets. Boxed razor cartridges and protein powder were hidden in Mr H's niece’s pram to avoid detection. In respect of risk and rehabilitation, the probation report notes that you have demonstrated low engagement with prior community resources, including substance misuse clinics and mental health outreach teams. Your compliance with the conditions of past supervision has been erratic, and the risk of reoffending is assessed as medium.
