input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. B2025/14327 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. K. Rawlings Filed: 12 November 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today to be sentenced in respect of a charge of theft, specifically shoplifting, contrary to the provisions of section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending took place over a period spanning late 2023 into early 2025, occurring at varied premises within the Bristol metropolitan area and nearby districts. The prosecution case—that you have now admitted—was presented under a single count on the indictment, representing what is described as a course of conduct involving repeated thefts of goods, the details of which will be elaborated upon shortly. Procedural History and Court Context Your initial apprehension followed a protracted investigative process commencing in January 2025, involving the coordinated efforts of multiple law enforcement and community safety agencies. The Bristol Business Crime Partnership, established in 2009 to foster collaboration between commercial enterprises, local police, and the municipal council, played a key role in collecting intelligence and providing victim liaison services. This defunct yet occasionally mentioned body, notwithstanding its archival status, was noted in initial briefs, although its dissolution in 2022 rendered direct involvement nominal at best in the present proceedings. A pre-trial review hearing on 1 March 2025 led to an adjournment for case management purposes. At that hearing, the matter was listed for a plea and trial preparation hearing (PTPH) on 27 April 2025. The progression of the case otherwise adhered, in broad terms, to the indicative timeframes prescribed by the Criminal Procedure Rules (CrimPR), albeit not without some procedural difficulties. Initial attempts to obtain Legal Aid funding for an independent psychiatric evaluation encountered delays due to shifting eligibility criteria and administrative backlogs within the Legal Aid Agency—a pattern increasingly characteristic of resource-constrained public administration. Such delays, lamentably common in criminal proceedings, not only retard the justice process but, on occasion, test the patience of all parties concerned. It is worth pausing to note that the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) and defence counsel both engaged cooperatively throughout, with Ms Emily Radcliffe representing the Crown and Ms Jeremy Thom, a solicitor advocate, representing you under a representation order granted on 15 February 2025. The court records their efforts with appreciation, though it falls to me to observe the cumulative procedural complexity besetting even comparatively minor offences in the current legal climate. Public confidence in the criminal justice system depends, in no small measure, upon its reputation for timely and proportionate resolution of cases. The Better Case Management (BCM) framework, introduced formally in the early 2020s to promote judicial scrutiny of case progression, was invoked here. While the framework was designed to expedite procedural milestones and reduce unnecessary adjournments, its implementation has been far from uniform across jurisdictions. In this instance, the court acknowledges that the case management hearings proceeded with a degree of efficiency and adherence to prescribed standards, a welcome counterpoint in a generally overburdened system. The theft provision under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 defines the primary offence: the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving the owner thereof. Shoplifting, though often perceived as a relatively minor offence due to the low monetary value of items commonly involved, must not be treated lightly where patterns of repeated offending emerge, impacting victims’ businesses and community welfare. In R v. Chambers [2020] EWCA Crim 1721, the Court of Appeal underscored the principle that repeated acquisitive offending directed at retail premises warrants a sentencing approach attentive both to the cumulative harm inflicted and the broader public confidence implications. While the individual thefts in that case were each of low value, the serial nature and deliberate tactics adopted by the appellant supported a custodial term to mark denunciation and deterrence. Similarly, it is instructive to consider R v. Preston [2019] EWCA Crim 1459, where the defendant engaged in a series of aggressive shoplifting incidents involving intimidation and concealment. The Court emphasised the importance of factoring in the psychological impact on staff and the disruption to business, even when physical violence was not present. Although Mr H’s conduct cannot be equated in gravity to Preston, the circumstances nonetheless warrant serious regard. Mr H hid £17 worth of grooming items under his jacket and walked past the tills without stopping to pay. The breadth of published sentencing guidelines for theft offences, including the 2023 edition, provides a calibrated framework for assessing culpability and harm. Paragraphs 2.12 through 2.26 outline relevant aggravating and mitigating features, among them the presence of previous convictions, sophistication of offender tactics, impact on vulnerable victims, and the cumulative effect of multiple offences constituting a "course of conduct," as is alleged here. Notably, this court is reminded of the dictum in R v. Beckwith [2022] EWCA Crim 991, which emphasised the courts’ responsibility to consider the broader societal consequences of prolific minor offences. The judiciary must balance proportionality with the imperative to sustain deterrent messaging and uphold victim confidence. Mr H placed protein powder and razor blade refills in his niece’s pushchair in an attempt to hide them. The detailed evidential record reveals a series of shoplifting episodes from various retail premises, including multiple grocery stores, pharmacies, and convenience shops. These incidents, emerging through painstaking collation of CCTV footage, staff accounts, and inventory checks, depict a pattern of deliberate, repeated theft. Your modus operandi encompassed the use of concealed garments and bags to appropriate items largely comprising toiletries, over-the-counter medicinal products, and confectionery. Such targeting reflects an awareness of the secondary market value of these goods, as well as an attempt to minimise detection—though, regrettably for you, these efforts were ultimately unsuccessful. In one notable incident, a shop manager observed you attempting to distract staff by engaging in seemingly innocuous conversation while covertly removing items from shelves. On another occasion, you were captured on multiple cameras, traversing a retail space with a conspicuously bulky coat, which appeared designed to facilitate concealment. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. Furthermore, at least one victim store reports that your continued presence and repeated offending have caused considerable disruption to staffing arrangements, with some employees requesting adjusted working hours or site transfers. These accounts attest to the intangible harm resulting from such offences—a factor considered significant by sentencing courts, notwithstanding the absence of physical harm or threat. The involvement of the Bristol Retailers' Liaison Group merits mention. This body, though not an official prosecuting authority, has played a commendable role in supporting affected business owners through arranging security audits, staff training in theft prevention, and advocating for enhanced collaboration with law enforcement. Mr H used a query about Oyster Card use to draw the attention of staff away, before taking a displayed product from behind the counter. Whilst your case is discrete and singular, it is essential to view it in light of your prior criminal history. You have previous convictions for theft-related offences, including two disposals via conditional caution in 2022 and a community order in 2023. Despite these interventions, offending appears to have persisted or escalated in frequency. Probation service records reveal episodic engagement and occasional absences from scheduled appointments. The preparatory reports before me also cite a lack of full acceptance of responsibility until recently, alongside a degree of minimisation concerning the impact of your conduct. Such factors, while not determinative, necessarily invite a degree of caution in assessing your prospects for rehabilitation absent appropriate statutory intervention. The psychiatric report submitted on behalf of the defence, prepared by Dr Helen Wentworth in August 2025, provides a detailed assessment of your mental state. Dr Wentworth concludes that you do not meet diagnostic criteria for major mental illness but exhibits traits consistent with impulse control difficulties and mild anxiety disorder. There is no evidence of organic brain dysfunction or psychotic illness. The report emphasises your reported socioeconomic stresses, including unstable housing and intermittent unemployment, while also noting limited engagement with support services designed to address these vulnerabilities. Dr Wentworth cautiously suggests that psychosocial interventions targeting impulse regulation and coping mechanisms may be beneficial. The defendant employed a magnet to detach a security tag from the item, and the magnet was located when police searched The defendant. Conversely, the probation officer’s pre-sentence report notes a medium risk of harm and relatively high risk of reoffending, primarily driven by socioeconomic factors and limited protective support networks. The report underscores the importance of structured supervision with cognitive behavioural components. It is instructive to signal current pressures within probation services nationally, where staff shortages and extensive caseloads frequently constrain the reach of intensive intervention programmes. This systemic limitation often results in delayed access to tailored support, particularly for individuals presenting multifaceted social complexity. The court also receives correspondence from the Bristol Homelessness Action Alliance, outlining the ongoing challenges faced by those at risk of insecure accommodation or rough sleeping. While not specific to you, the material serves as a salutary reminder of the broader social environment in which many defendants exist—a context that, while not excusing offending, situates it within the landscape of lived experience. The defendant told officers that he sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in nearby pubs, causing alarm to members of the public. Victim personal statements provide harrowing insights into the impact of repeated theft on local shopkeepers and their staff. While the financial sums involved in individual offences may appear modest, the cumulative losses impose significant strain on small and independent businesses, many of which already operate on narrow margins. One business owner writes poignantly of the erosion of community space and the chilling effect of persistent offending on employee morale. The psychological burden on staff—manifesting as anxiety and diminished job satisfaction—constitutes real harm, recognised expressly by the courts as an element requiring redress. This court notes with respect the efforts of the Bristol Retail Crime Prevention Strategy team, whose ongoing engagement with affected businesses includes advice on environmental design, surveillance enhancements, and staff safety protocols. Such initiatives represent an essential component of community resilience but are inevitably reactive and, to an extent, constrained by funding limitations. It is a cause for concern that these programmes are often stretched beyond capacity, necessitating careful choices about resource allocation. The victim impact is thus not solely monetary but also manifest in the weakening of local commercial fabric and increased community insecurity. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, causing alarm and disruption in the store. In the broader social context, the court acknowledges evolving patterns of acquisitive offending, increasingly fuelled by economic pressures, social exclusion, and the pervasive challenges of mental health. Recent Home Office reports from 2024 indicate a modest upward trend in petty theft in urban centres, including Bristol, with marked spikes noted in areas of high deprivation. This trend has seen concomitant strain on emergency services, retail businesses, and local authorities seeking to stabilise neighbourhoods. The “place crime” theory articulated in criminological literature underlines that persistent petty offending, while individually minor, collectively engenders significant community harm. It is incumbent upon the courts, therefore, to respond proportionately but firmly. As has been well documented in media commentary, including recent discussions in The Times and The Guardian, society’s tolerance thresholds are approaching critical levels, with calls for enhanced sanctions alongside expanded rehabilitative infrastructures. The Role and Challenges of the Legal Aid System Throughout these proceedings, the court and parties have contended with notable funding and resource difficulties associated with Legal Aid applications—specifically in respect of expert assessments integral to the defence’s case. This frustrating reality is not unique to this jurisdiction and speaks to systemic issues in the administration of justice. Defence counsel’s application for funding to instruct a forensic psychologist experienced in acquisitive offending was delayed for several weeks due to procedural queries and insufficient clarity in the statutory criteria. Such delays hamper timely resolution and impose further stress upon defendants already grappling with complex needs. The court regrets that remedies have not yet been implemented to streamline these processes effectively. This state of affairs is unsatisfactory in the extreme and risks undermining defendants’ access to appropriate representation and expert advice. Mr H stated in interview that he frequently takes items, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. It is equally lamentable that the capacity of forensic and digital units to analyse and process evidence, including CCTV archives and electronic transaction data, remains stretched. Policemen, analysts, and technical staff dedicated to retail crime investigations must often balance these duties with pressures relating to more serious offences such as violent crime or fraud. The consequence can be operational delays and protracted case preparation. Your arrest in February 2025 represented the conclusion of an intelligence-led operation targeting a suspected prolific thief. Such resources are not expended lightly; intelligence analysts maintain a careful balance of priorities to deliver effective public protection outcomes. The authority to utilise telephone data and CCTV triangulation was granted only after due judicial scrutiny, reflecting the seriousness with which your offending was regarded. The court is tasked with navigating a complex seam in determining an appropriate sentence that adequately reflects the culpability of your conduct, the harm caused, your personal circumstances, and the wider public interest. The acknowledged persistence of offending despite prior community resolutions is a significant aggravating factor. Such history signals a heightened risk of recidivism and demonstrates, I regret to say, a pattern of behaviour not deterred by earlier interventions. Notwithstanding this, the mitigating factors of your mental health assessment—while not amounting to a mental disorder—must be taken into account in shaping the form of sentencing and supervision. Your apparent willingness to engage with support services subsequent to the current proceedings offers some hope for rehabilitation. It is also pertinent to reflect that the shoplifting offences, while serious and damaging, did not involve violence or threat thereof—an aspect that influences the gradation of sentence severity. In considering the composite sentencing framework, the court will have regard to both custodial and community options. The Sentencing Council’s guideline on Theft offences advocates custodial sentences where offending is repeated, planned, and persistent, yet also recognises the potential for rehabilitation through requirement orders where appropriate. I remind all parties that an immediate custodial sentence does not always serve the interests of justice, especially when community-based sanctions may be better tailored to address criminogenic needs and reduce reoffending risk. The court has also considered the underlying social factors contributing to your offending, including episodes of unstable accommodation and unemployment. While these circumstances do not excuse criminality, they are relevant to the question of sentence type and conditions. Finally, the court expresses its gratitude to the staff of the Bristol Retail Recovery Network, whose expert support for victims has been invaluable in collating victim impact statements and offering practical assistance post-offence. Such organisations perform a vital function in estate and community cohesion, often under significant resource constraints. Having reviewed all material—statutory and non-statutory guidance, case law precedents, the factual matrix, expert reports, victim statements, and submissions from counsel—it falls to this court to adjourn for the preparation of a detailed pre-sentence report. Such report is to be prepared by the Bristol Probation Service and should explore fully options for community rehabilitation, appropriate supervision levels, cognitive behavioural therapy courses, and any ancillary support mechanisms, including housing assistance and employment counselling. The probation officer is also requested to assess risk factors for further reoffending and offer recommendations for a tailored package of interventions. This matter is adjourned to the scheduled sentencing hearing on 17 December 2025, at which time this court will determine the appropriate disposal informed by the report and any further relevant representations. These sentencing remarks are entered as of this 12th day of November 2025, in Court 8 of the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been recorded and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules 2020. The defendant, Mr H, is advised of his right to appeal against sentence within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. MR H Case No. B2025/14567 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. G. Farnsworth Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this Court for sentence on a matter concerning theft from retail premises contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offence arises from a succession of shoplifting events reportedly occurring over a period of approximately 18 months within the Birmingham metropolitan area, including but not limited to districts such as Digbeth, Moseley, and Ladywood. Procedural Background The case has followed a somewhat protracted course through the criminal justice system. Initially charged on 2 February 2025 following investigative activity by local police and the Business Crime Reduction Partnership for Birmingham City Centre, the case proceeded under the direction of the Crown Prosecution Service’s Local Casework Unit. Plea hearings were scheduled and re-scheduled owing to several adjournments precipitated by both defence applications and administrative constraints. It is appropriate to reflect on the wider context within which this case unfolds. Over recent years, acquisitive crime rates have exhibited fluctuations that correspond to socio-economic changes as well as policing priorities and community reporting behaviours. The role of multi-agency partnerships, such as those manifested in the Birmingham Retail Crime Initiative (BRCI), remains pivotal in gathering intelligence, coordinating preventive measures, and supporting victim businesses. These organisations operate under the strain of resource limitations, high case volumes, and the demand to balance immediate response with strategic foresight. Excursions into institutional observations further underline the fragility of current support frameworks. The Legal Aid Agency, for instance, has been subject to repeated criticism regarding the timeliness and consistency of its approvals for expert report instructions. In this matter, an early request for a forensic psychiatric assessment was delayed by over six weeks, despite clear indication of mitigating factors raised by the defence. Such delays have a cascading effect — impacting listing availability, prolonging custody durations, and inevitably placing strain on all parties concerned. A note must be made of the enduring challenge faced by mental health services, including the NHS Trust responsible for adult mental health provision in the West Midlands. Waiting lists for specialist assessments extend into months, and while intermediate support mechanisms exist, their efficacy is hampered by high demand and funding shortfalls. Against this institutional backdrop, the court must endeavour to deliver justice with both firmness and compassion, recognising the complexity but resisting the temptation to conflate structural issues with individual culpability. Engagement with the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol saw the initial case allocation on 16 February 2025, and subsequent listing for a Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing (PTPH) on 10 March 2025. At that hearing, you entered a not guilty plea, though this was amended to guilty with effect from the first day of trial on 15 September 2025. The Crown elected not to proceed with a contested hearing, following extensive evidential disclosure and the arrival of forensic and digital evidence corroborating identification. The timing of your plea results inevitably in reduced mitigation for acceptance of responsibility. It is, however, acknowledged that plea was unequivocal and entered in open court having had the benefit of legal advice. The discount available should be tempered in line with appellate guidance, including that laid down in R v. Simmonds [2020] EWCA Crim 1507. The Crown, represented here by Ms Anne Dalrymple, has presented detailed submissions supported by CCTV footage, witness statements from retail employees, and multi-agency risk assessments. Defence representation is provided by Mr Oliver Brice, acting on a representation order. The court records its appreciation for their thorough advocacy under challenging circumstances. It bears mention that this court has recently undergone refurbishment, including improved accessibility measures and enhanced technology for remote video links, which has been of some assistance given the fluctuating public health constraints and pilot digital initiatives. The impact on victims has been set out in victim personal statements supplied through the Birmingham Retail Federation. These describe not only financial loss but the psychological burden borne by staff subject to repeated targeting and the feeling of insecurity engendered in the workplace. Prior to addressing the substance of offending, the court notes the devotion of volunteer organisations working in community support roles. Of particular relevance is the Birmingham Food Bank Network, whose representatives have written in to acknowledge the complex factors driving some individuals towards economic desperation, but who also underscore that support is available and that engagement with these services is essential. Another institutional commentary pertains to the pressing concerns of the probation service, which currently is operating under significant staffing shortages and operational pressures. The availability of tailored rehabilitative programmes for acquisitive offenders, including cognitive-behavioural and motivational interventions, remains limited. This reality constrains the court’s options but does not obviate the need to attempt community-based disposal where appropriate. It is also worth noting the evolving jurisprudence on sentencing discount and credit where mental health issues are present. The recent decision in R v. Elmhurst [2025] EWCA Crim 1234 reiterated that while underlying health difficulties may mitigate culpability, they do not exclude a proportionate custodial sentence where public protection and general deterrence demand it. Moreover, in R v. Clifford [2019] EWCA Crim 405, the Court underscored that repeated theft offences, particularly when involving vulnerable retail settings, require a measured but firm response. Although that case is factually unrelated to this matter, its legal principles remain pertinent in emphasizing the effect of acquisitive crime beyond mere financial calculation. A review of the Background Reports is germane at this juncture. Mr H’s recorded criminal history reveals three prior convictions for theft-related matters, all within the last five years. Notably, no offences of violence or drug distribution feature. Previous sentences have included community orders and a conditional discharge. Social services records indicate a history of childhood instability, marked by periods in foster care and intermittent school attendance. Such information has been assessed and reflected upon by the Probation Service in their pre-sentence overview. Mr H hid £17 worth of grooming items under his jacket and walked past the tills without stopping to pay. This court has had the benefit of a psychiatric report from Dr Kamal Patel, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, dated 10 September 2025. Dr Patel observes that although Mr H does not meet the criteria for severe mental illness, there is evidence of emotional dysregulation, a history of substance misuse, and a modicum of chaotic lifestyle factors which have yet to be addressed fully through intervention. Dr Patel commends Mr H’s articulate self-reflection displayed during clinical interviews but warns of the risk of rapid relapse into harmful patterns post-release absent structured support. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. Outside the direct orbit of this matter, it is germane to mention the operational challenges faced by police digital forensics units, which have experienced increasing workloads partly arising from broader cross-jurisdictional tasking. The West Midlands Police Forensics Department handles thousands of devices annually, filtering data of investigatory value from mass stores of irrelevant personal communications. The time taken to process devices often delays case progress. It is further observed with regret that the city has seen numerous instances of fly-tipping on designated Green Belt land, attracting enforcement priorities that sometimes conflict with retail crime investigation resourcing. Cases such as R v. Davies [2023] EWCA Crim 1890 serve as examples of the courts’ approach to environmental offences having a wider societal effect, although completely unrelated to Mr H’s conduct. Within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same shop on four occasions, each time removing alcohol and tobacco without paying. The court has also reviewed letters from community organisations. The Moseley Social Outreach Group writes of the pressures of rising street homelessness in the Birmingham area and appeals for enhanced collaboration between statutory and voluntary sectors. While these concerns are of high social importance, they do not diminish Mr H's personal responsibility. Likewise, a statement from Mr H’s sister, Ms Fiona Clarke, has been submitted. She speaks to his struggles with addiction but also expresses hope for his rehabilitation. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. I refer next to the procedural peculiarities that have marked this case’s timeline. On 28 April 2025, the listing centre notified parties of a delay owing to court room reallocation and conflicting hearing dates caused by strike action within the judiciary support staff. Such occurrences have become regrettably frequent, straining the administration of justice. The case’s adjournment length, albeit not excessive, reflects these systemic pressures. The case management hearings have otherwise followed the expectations of Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules (CrimPR) and the Judicial Studies Board guidance on Better Case Management. No pre-trial applications other than defence requests for psychiatric assessment were advanced. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. On receipt of the psychiatric report, defence counsel submitted supplementary mitigation asserting compounding social vulnerabilities, including housing insecurity and intermittent employment history. These points, while relevant to sentencing disposition, must be balanced against deterrent considerations. During the trial course, the Crown placed particular reliance on the testimony of Ms Jane Whitmore, a retail manager at a store in Digbeth, who described clear disruption to business practices and staff wellbeing arising from repeated incidents attributed to Mr H’s conduct. Of ancillary note, a co-defendant named in an unrelated matter involving street-level drug supply in Ladywood remains at large following decision to proceed with separate proceedings. No connection is evidenced with Mr H beyond proximity of geographical area. Similarly, a landlord of a property rented by Mr H was subject to a noise abatement notice due to unrelated tenancy disputes. Such matters have no bearing on the offence for which Mr H is to be sentenced but were disclosed in ancillary documentation. The defendant admitted selling stolen items at both a car boot sale and various local pubs, where his actions disturbed or distressed others present. The Sentencing Guidelines Council, in their Theft and Handling guideline (2024 edition), emphasise several factors relevant here, including the offending pattern, harm to victims, and offender’s previous record. While the financial value of stolen goods may be modest, the repeated and deliberate nature indicates a criminal lifestyle requiring inhibition. International developments in rehabilitation models were briefly considered during sentencing workshops earlier this year. Some studies highlight cognitive reinforcing programmes as effective in reducing reoffending among acquisitive offenders. Whether such programmes can be widely implemented within present probation resources remains uncertain. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. In assessing culpability, the court takes account of the careful summary of legal principles articulated in R v. Duncan [2024] EWCA Crim 1552, noting that persistent offending following community disposal inevitably merits escalation and that mere economic pressure rarely suffices as mitigation. Finally, the Probation Service’s pre-sentence report, received 7 October 2025, evaluated Mr H’s risk to the public as medium, highlighting his prior history of non-compliance with community orders and mixed record on engagement with previous support programmes. The report recommends that any community order should include intensive supervision and a rehabilitative element targeting acquisitive behaviour, as well as substance misuse components. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. In light of the foregoing, the court imposes a short adjournment for the preparation of a final pre-sentence report, taking into account all expert and social agency input. Following receipt, sentencing will be determined with the appropriate level of proportionality, considering all aggravating and mitigating features. This hearing has been conducted in open court with all parties properly represented and in attendance. I thank Ms Dalrymple and Mr Brice for their clear submissions and professional conduct. The court also expresses appreciation for the probation officers, psychiatric experts, and victim liaison team whose work has informed these remarks. These sentencing remarks have been prepared and filed on this day, 14 October 2025, in Court 5 at Birmingham Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal transcript will be retained for the record. Mr H is reminded of his right to appeal against any sentence passed within 28 days pursuant to the provisions of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 have been engaged. Costs are reserved pending sentencing. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT LIVERPOOL R v. MR H Case No. T2025/14567 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge D. L. FORD Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for the purpose of sentence in relation to offences of theft from retail premises, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct extended over a protracted period spanning from late 2023 through the early months of 2025 and encompassed several commercial locations predominantly within the Liverpool metropolitan area and its surrounding districts. Procedural Overview You were arrested on 26 March 2025 following a sustained investigative operation coordinated by Merseyside Police in partnership with the Liverpool City Retail Crime Reduction Board. This investigation, resulting from a series of recurring theft reports originating from numerous small to medium-sized convenience stores and chemist outlets, was predicated on the suspicion of a methodical, organised pattern of retail dishonesty. The initial reports were not initially treated as interconnected. However, a methodical review of CCTV footage, staff witness statements, and stock shrinkage records eventually revealed a consistent modus operandi warranting further inquiry. It is relevant to underscore here the broader context within which such offences arise. Petty theft, and retail theft in particular, while often perceived as minor, exerts disproportionate strain on law enforcement agencies, judicial resources, and local businesses alike. The cumulative effect is far from trivial. The investigation, encompassing review of hours of surveillance tape and systematic collation of intelligence, required a dedicated task force working alongside retail security personnel. This involved a delicate balance of resource allocation, stretched as policing functions increasingly must contend with violent crime, gang activity, and cyber-enabled fraud. [1] The reality remains that the policing and prosecution of such offences relies heavily upon close cooperation across sectors: private sector security teams, local authority trading standards officers, and community safety partnerships. These frameworks, despite their good intentions, are frequently challenged by constraints of funding, manpower, and logistical complexity. It is perhaps worth remarking on the systemic role of the Business Crime Reduction Partnership (BCRP) prevalent in many urban localities — a network intended to enhance information sharing and rapid response. Despite its formal existence in Liverpool, the effectiveness of the BCRP varies considerably depending on local personnel, political will, and inter-organisational trust. There are regrettably instances where delays in intelligence dissemination or failures in follow-up visits diminish otherwise promising initiatives. [1] See R v. Thomsett [2019] EWCA Crim 344, articulating the increasing demands on police proficiency in balancing acquisitive crime against broader public safety imperatives. Following your arrest, you were interviewed under caution on 28 March 2025. You initially denied any involvement. However, subsequent forensic analysis — notably the identification of a distinctive pair of trainers captured on multiple CCTV cameras and items recovered during a search of your accommodation — supported the prosecuting authority's case. Formal charge ensued on 31 March 2025, with the matter transferred to this Crown Court under the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol. The BCM initiative represents a concerted judicial effort to streamline pre-trial procedures, reduce inefficiency, and prevent protracted adjournments that unduly burden all parties. While the scheme has had mixed success nationally, in the present case, the procedural timetable was met with relative compliance by prosecution, defence, and court administration alike. It is on record that listing of the plea and trial preparation hearing on 18 May 2025 proceeded without undue delay. Your initial plea was one of not guilty, entered on 18 May 2025. However, as additional evidence was served — including high-definition still images and corroborative witness statements from shop floor personnel — your counsel made an application on 2 July 2025 to amend the plea to guilty. This change was effected on 5 July 2025, following which the matter was listed for sentence today. The willingness to enter a guilty plea, while of course welcome, came belatedly. The question of mitigating credit for such a plea is not to be resolved mechanically but requires careful judicial evaluation, balancing the genuine acceptance of responsibility against the procedural economy realised. The statutory provisions underpinning this prosecution are well established. Section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 defines theft as the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving the owner thereof. The sentencing guidelines promulgated by the Sentencing Council, last amended in 2023, provide a structured approach to assessing harm, culpability, and aggravating or mitigating features. It is significant that the Court of Appeal has, in recent years, underscored the necessity of recognising the cumulative impact of serial offences even where each individual act may be of limited economic value. Reference may be made to the rulings in R v. Groves [2022] EWCA Crim 1337 and R v. Ellison [2023] EWCA Crim 1095, which clarified that repeated, targeted theft from multiple victims aggravates the overall harm and demands an appropriately calibrated sentence. These precedents caution against fragmentation of offending into artificially discrete episodes, thereby underestimating culpability. Furthermore, the case of R v. Sandford [2024] EWCA Crim 829 provided guidance on the limited scope of credit afforded for guilty pleas entered at a late stage, emphasising the importance of promoting early admissions to ease prosecutorial and witness burden. Significantly, sentencing considerations must also include reflection on the personal circumstances of the defendant, including age, prior convictions, and engagement with rehabilitative services. Nevertheless, the paramount concern remains the protection of the public and the maintenance of confidence in the rule of law. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. The facts as described reveal a deliberate and sustained pattern of conduct involving multiple opportunities to cease offending but a consistent choice to persist. The repeated targeting of premises likely to have limited security response, use of concealment techniques, and at times apparent evasion of surveillance by altering appearance speak to a degree of planning rather than spur-of-the-moment behaviour. It is also salient that, as exhibited in R v. Weller [2020] EWCA Crim 576, the psychological impact on retail staff must not be underestimated. While the offence lacks direct physical confrontation, the atmosphere of anxiety and disruption caused by persistent thefts has been repeatedly noted by those employed in vulnerable roles. Mr H used the bottom compartment of his niece’s pram to hide razor cartridges and protein supplements. The Crown's submissions emphasise not only the fiscal losses incurred but also the broader social and economic effects — diminished staff morale, increased operational costs, and, in some cases, the need for protective measures such as locked cabinets and increased security presence. These consequences bear on the resilience and sustainability of local retail enterprises, particularly smaller operators. A supplementary consideration concerns the cumulative prior contacts with the justice system. Your recorded antecedents include several convictions for shoplifting-related offences dating back to 2018, with the most recent being a conditional discharge in 2023. Community resolutions and diversion attempts have been documented, yet these measures have failed to effectuate desistance. In reckoning the context of sentencing, I have carefully reviewed psychiatric and psychological assessments commissioned at the defence's behest. Dr Imogen Pratt, consultant forensic psychiatrist, provided a detailed report dated 15 September 2025. Her evaluation found no evidence of major mental disorder but noted traits of impulsivity, low frustration tolerance, and a degree of substance misuse — principally of non-prescribed benzodiazepines and sporadic alcohol consumption. In particular, Dr Pratt highlighted a pattern of economic and social instability, frequent changes of address, and limited engagement with voluntary support provision. Whilst recognising the defendant’s expressed motivation to improve circumstances, Dr Pratt emphasised the absence of sustained positive steps to access employment or educational opportunities. Mr H stole alcohol and tobacco from the same neighbourhood shop on four separate occasions across a three-week span. The Pre-Sentence Report (PSR), compiled by Senior Probation Officer Ms Harriet Collins on 1 October 2025, builds on these observations. It notes the defendant’s history of intermittent participation in community support programmes and dwelling in temporary accommodation provided by local authority emergency housing schemes. The PSR remarks on substantial underemployment and reliance on irregular benefits, contributing factors to financial pressure and decision-making complexity. The Probation Service, constrained by resourcing shortages and widespread caseload pressures, nonetheless attempts to maintain contact and promote engagement. However, Ms Collins candidly reports a pattern of sporadic compliance and withdrawal from arranged appointments, impeding efforts to facilitate rehabilitation. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. The defence’s written submissions have drawn attention to these mitigating personal factors, urging consideration of a community order supplemented by attendance at accredited offender behaviour programmes, cognitive skills training, and substance misuse counselling. The defendant employed a magnet to detach a security tag from the item, and the magnet was located when police searched The defendant. Nonetheless, the court remains mindful that rehabilitation efforts must be balanced against the necessity of deterrence and public protection. The primary sentencing objective is not the alleviation of individual hardship alone but the safeguarding of society through appropriate sanctioning of criminal conduct. Among the procedural complexities encountered in this matter, I record with regret the delays occasioned by approval processes required for funding expert assessments under the Legal Aid Agency. Such bureaucratic obstacles are an increasing feature of modern criminal proceedings, resulting in extended timelines and additional expense. In particular, the defence application for funding to instruct Dr Pratt was lodged on 8 July 2025 but not approved until 12 August 2025, a period during which preparatory processes were effectively in abeyance. These delays, while regrettable, are not unique to this case and underscore broader systemic challenges within the administration of justice. It is also pertinent to note that the court has observed the increasing tendency for guilty pleas to be entered late in proceedings, often prompted by the accumulation of irrefutable evidence or strategic calculation. The law rightly incentivises early plea to conserve public resources and spare victims and witnesses further distress. The defendant admitted selling the stolen items at a car boot sale and local pubs, disturbing customers. This phenomenon does, however, complicate sentencing assessments. The precise degree of mitigation for a plea entered days or weeks before trial—and after full preparation of the case by prosecution and defence alike—must be carefully calibrated. Turning to the victims, statements provided by retail staff and local businesses have been carefully reviewed. Their expressed concerns encompass not only financial loss but an enduring sense of insecurity and vulnerability. Affecting morale and professional wellbeing, these impacts constitute an important element of harm. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. Chelsea Retail Ltd., a small chain whose premises were targeted on three occasions, submitted a detailed impact statement outlining increased operational costs related to security upgrades and the imposition of tighter inventory controls. These changes impose financial burdens ultimately borne by consumers and staff. It is worthwhile mentioning the increasingly common role taken by voluntary sector organisations such as ShopSafe UK, which provide victim support and liaison services. Such bodies operate frequently at the juncture of commercial enterprise and community policing, offering guidance on loss prevention and advocating on behalf of affected employers and staff. I express appreciation for the witness services coordinator, Ms Karen Blake, whose facilitation of victim impact statements ensures their voice is not lost amid the formality of legal proceedings. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, claims it isn’t really stealing and intends to keep doing so. Looking beyond the immediate facts, the broader societal landscape is marked by rising incidents of urban deprivation, homelessness, and social dislocation. Public space itself faces unparalleled pressures: economic uncertainty compounded by the destabilising effects of pandemics, inflation, and welfare retrenchment. The court is mindful that these macro-level contexts do not excuse nor diminish personal accountability but provide background against which the patterns of offending emerge. The complex interactions of poverty, mental health, and social marginalisation require coordinated responses from statutory authorities, charitable organisations, and community stakeholders. At the same time, it remains a foundational principle that the justice system must ensure that criminality meets with appropriate sanction, irrespective of social backdrop. Relief from penal consequence is not automatic where hardship exists, nor may the court abdicate its duty to protect society by permitting wholesale discretion on grounds of personal circumstance alone. In conclusion, the court notes the composite nature of this case: a course of deliberate, prolonged offending causing tangible harm to individuals and businesses; a defendant facing serious social and psychological challenges yet with limited demonstrable engagement in self-help; compounded procedural delays external to the conduct itself. In this complex mix, the court must exercise measured discretion to achieve justice that is fair, proportionate, and efficacious. I will direct that a pre-sentence report be prepared, with particular attention to the suitability of community rehabilitation orders incorporating cognitive behavioural therapy, unpaid work requirements focused on victim-related projects, and supported access to housing and employment assistance. I reserve final sentencing for the formal hearing scheduled on 11 November 2025, pending receipt of any updated reports or representations. These are the sentencing remarks of His Honour Judge D. L. Ford, issued today, 14 October 2025, in Court 5 at Liverpool Crown Court. A formal transcript has been recorded under Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentencing pursuant to section 108 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. B2025/13760 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. R. Ellington Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court charged with a representative count of theft by shoplifting, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct spans a period beginning in November 2023 through to April 2025, predominantly emerging in retail outlets across greater Bristol, particularly within the city centre and adjacent suburban precincts. The court acknowledges the multiplicity of incidents comprising a course of conduct rather than a singular isolated episode. Procedural Overview Your first appearance was before the magistrates’ court on 23 April 2025, following your arrest on 15 April 2025, which concluded a three-week investigation conducted by Bristol City Police Retail Crime Unit in conjunction with the local Business Crime Action Group. The latter is part of a multi-agency collaborative effort to address growing concerns over acquisitive crime in urban commercial zones. Initial charges were brought for theft on a number of separate dates, which, for efficiency, have been consolidated into a single representative offence for the purposes of this Crown Court trial and subsequent sentencing. The case management trajectory has involved multiple listings, including a plea and trial preparation hearing on 2 July 2025, during which you entered a not guilty plea. This plea was maintained until the morning of trial on 29 August 2025, when, upon the presentation of compelling evidence, you changed your plea to guilty. The court must observe that this timing of your guilty plea is indicative of a strategic decision rather than an early acceptance of responsibility and is therefore entitled to lesser credit under established jurisprudence. There have been a number of procedural adjournments relating to the procurement of expert psychiatric evidence and the completion of reports, including a delay attributed to the processing time of a Legal Aid funding application submitted by your defence counsel on 14 June 2025. The court again notes its ongoing concern regarding administrative delays within the Legal Aid system, which, while not a cause for adjournment in this instance, continue to impede efficient case progression. Notwithstanding these challenges, the various procedural hearings have all adhered, albeit narrowly, to the indicative timelines outlined within the Criminal Procedure Rules and the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol. On a related note, mention must be made of how this court has, in recent years, become increasingly encountered with cases arising under a new paradigm of retail crime enforcement known colloquially as the “CitySafe Initiative,” a joint venture between local authorities, police forces, and business coalitions aimed at intelligence-led crime prevention. Your case forms part of a broader pattern noted in recent monthly taskforce reports, which identify an uptick in opportunistic and repeat shoplifting offences as a significant challenge to urban order and retail viability. The administrative burden borne by local policing teams in collating data for these initiatives is considerable and often requires diverting resources away from other pressing community concerns, including the investigative management of violent and organised crime groups. This diversionary effect is of practical concern to the court's assessment of the broader implications of persistent acquisitive offending. In anticipation of today’s sentencing hearing, the court has received a detailed pre-sentence report compiled by Ms Angela Beckett, a probation officer with over ten years of experience in the Southwest region. The report is thorough and incorporates multi-source information, including your recent psychological assessment conducted by Dr Michael Jenner, a consultant forensic psychologist with recognised expertise in acquisitive offending. The interplay of these professional inputs provides an essential evidential framework upon which the court must carefully deliberate appropriate sentencing options. Mr H was caught on CCTV placing £10 worth of haircare products into his coat and leaving the shop without making payment. The court is also mindful of the context within which these offences occurred: the retail sector in Bristol, like many urban centres in England, continues to evolve amid significant commercial flux. Legal pressures around online sales, post-pandemic footfall declines, and increasing operating costs have placed independent and chain shops alike under strain. This economic backdrop compounds the impact of loss through theft, as even low-value items cumulatively impose a substantial financial and operational toll. Indeed, the director of one outlet represented via written victim impact statements conveyed how recurring theft had necessitated a reduction in staffing levels and reconfiguration of store layouts, including the installation of additional security measures at considerable expense. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. The court recognises that these material impacts have human consequences. Staff frequently report heightened anxiety and fear, reflecting not merely the immediate loss but also the perceived vulnerability to repeat offending. Some employees have resorted to requesting alterations to shift patterns or even transferring out of particular shops. The psychological effect of persistent retail theft on frontline workers has been the subject of recent criminological study, which found correlations between repeated victimisation and emotional distress, diminished job satisfaction, and increased staff turnover. Such findings add weight to the aggravating nature of the offending before the court, despite the absence of violence or direct threats to persons. Dr Jenner’s assessment, dated 15 August 2025, concludes that you do not meet criteria for any major Axis I psychiatric diagnosis; however, he notes marked impulsiveness and low frustration tolerance. He identifies patterns consistent with mild to moderate substance use disorder, primarily concerning alcohol, which has been intermittently reported over the past two years. The report postulates that these factors may have contributed to your offending behaviour but cautions against excessive reliance on such considerations as mitigation. Dr Jenner also highlights a limited engagement with prior support offers: despite referral opportunities for substance misuse counselling and benefits advice, your cooperation has been sporadic and inconsistent. It may be said, of course, that your personal circumstances must be understood within a broader socio-economic framework marked by rising food insecurity, cuts to welfare provisions, and an acute shortage of affordable housing. Public institutions tasked with addressing such complex social needs have, over the past decade, faced chronic underfunding and have struggled to meet demand. While sympathetic to these challenges, the court must balance these realities with the imperatives of public safety and deterrence. An arrest on 15 April 2025 followed local intelligence gathering, which incorporated CCTV review, retail crime logs, and field observations by the police neighbourhood team. In its procedural documentation, the prosecution highlights that the investigation was aided by a forensic analysis conducted by the Bristol Digital Forensic Unit, which examined footage collected across multiple retail outlets. This practice of aggregating diverse data sources is emblematic of modern policing techniques yet also brings with it the attendant risks of information overload and resource strain. Mr H stole alcohol and tobacco from the same neighbourhood shop on four separate occasions across a three-week span. The structure of your offending suggests a degree of planning, notably in selection of targets which are small to medium independent retailers with historically minimal security presence. Such predilection aligns with known modus operandi identified in recent academic literature, which notes a shift from large supermarket chains to fragmented retail environments as sites for theft, precisely due to their comparatively weaker surveillance regimes. The court is called to consider that these calculated choices reflect conscious decisions rather than impulsive indiscretions. It must be added that the operational partnership between the Bristol Business Crime Taskforce and the local Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) has, over the past two years, expanded its remit to cover repeat shoplifting offences, in recognition of their cumulative effect on community cohesion. Though traditionally MAPPA has been associated with violent and sexual offenders, this broadening underlines the evolving nature of public safety threats. On one occasion, Mr H asked staff about Oyster Card payments as a distraction, then leaned behind the counter to take a display item. The probation report further chronicles your prior contact with the criminal justice system. You have three previous convictions for theft-related offences, dated between 2017 and 2022, all resulting in non-custodial disposals: community orders with unpaid work requirements and a conditional discharge. It is of particular note that despite clear warnings and opportunities afforded by probation supervision, your pattern of behaviour has persisted with limited evidence of sustained behavioural change. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. An earlier offence in 2022 involved theft from a local pharmacy where, as has been contemporaneously reported, your actions caused heightened security concerns among staff, leading to calls for increased police attention. The recurrence of similar offending following these incidents reflects a failure to respond adequately to prior intervention efforts. The court acknowledges the efforts of Mr Oliver Trent, your instructing solicitor, who has provided diligent representation throughout. It is, lamentably, all too common that such efforts are hampered by systemic constraints within the Legal Aid Agency, an issue of which this court has repeatedly taken judicial notice. The present case saw delays in approval for a psychiatric expert instruction, a regrettable and recurring administrative inefficiency that impedes timely justice and undermines confidence in the system. In the same vein, the court notes with concern the recent increasing frequency of adjournments attributable not to substantive defence argument but to logistical difficulties in securing court listing dates due to staff shortages and knock-on effects of protracted strike action affecting court personnel. These systemic pressures contribute to delayed resolutions and must be factored into broader reflections on the justice system’s capacity to deliver expedient outcomes. It is of course the law that every defendant is entitled to a full and fair opportunity to contest allegations. Your defence counsel has maintained your right to full representation and has rightly raised matters of personal circumstance, including housing precarity and intermittent engagement with mental health services. Letters of support submitted on your behalf from ShelterWest, a local homelessness outreach charity, emphasise your recent struggles with accommodation instability and financial hardship. They note your partial but inconsistent participation in offered support and underline that your current social situation is precarious. While these matters are relevant insofar as they inform an understanding of circumstances, it is of particular importance that such factors do not detract from the objective assessment of offending behaviour and public safety considerations. The law remains clear that hardship, while worthy of consideration, does not excuse criminality. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. The court must apply the sentencing framework outlined in the Theft Act 1968, supported by guidance provided by the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft offences (issued 2020, last updated 2024). The principal purposes of sentencing here include punishment, deterrence (both individual and general), rehabilitation, and the protection of the public. In R v. Robinson [2019] EWCA Crim 1825, a case involving repeated retail theft over a two-year period, the Court of Appeal held that escalation to immediate custody is justified where persistent offending demonstrates disregard for previous warnings and imposes significant harm on victims and communities. The court also referred to R v. Bellamy [2021] EWCA Crim 1512, reinforcing that the psychological impact on retail employees, the economic consequences for small businesses, and the drain on law enforcement resources collectively aggravate the seriousness of shoplifting offences, even when individual incidents are of low monetary value. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, triggering distress and security concerns. Notwithstanding relevant mitigating factors such as your early cooperative engagement post-arrest and absence of violence or intimidation, it is the pattern of sustained offending and the failure to comply with antecedent court orders that inform this court’s stance on custodial threshold. The court also considers the guidance in R v. Stevens [2022] EWCA Crim 2125, a case where a defendant with substance misuse issues and housing instability was sentenced to a community order with a rehabilitative focus, subject to strict conditions and enforcement of unpaid work. While such an approach is laudable where evidence suggests genuine engagement and absence of ongoing risk, it cannot be universally applied. The persistent pattern of infringement displayed here counsels a sterner response, albeit tempered by acknowledgement of your vulnerabilities. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. Victim impact statements submitted by several retail employees convey the unsettling effects of repeated theft upon their sense of safety and professional well-being. Several report heightened anxiety and a reluctance to work alone during certain hours due to fear of repeat offences. These submissions are supported by the response of the Retail Support and Recovery Network, a voluntary-sector organisation engaged in victim advocacy, which emphasises the cumulative psychological toll of such offending on vulnerable staff groups. I note that the North Bristol Civic Partnership, which provides complementary outreach to affected businesses, has called for increased investment in crime prevention initiatives and restorative engagement schemes. Their commentary highlights the erosion of trust felt by small businesses confronting persistent theft and notes that this case falls within a troubling trend of escalating shoplifting impacting local economies and community stability. This court is grateful to the staff of the Crown Court registry who, despite recent refurbishment works causing temporary disruption in courtroom accessibility and scheduling, have ensured the smooth conduct of today’s hearing. Thanks are also extended to court usher Mr Timothy Jones for maintaining order discreetly and effectively. Notwithstanding procedural delays occasioned by national postal strikes which impacted the timely delivery of written materials to the court, no substantial prejudice arose. The court took note of communications received from the Probation Service acknowledging a strain on resettlement resources owing to the cumulative increase in complex offenders serving custodial sentences, including those with co-morbid mental health and substance use difficulties. The exploitation of limited rehabilitative and housing allocation services is a chronic issue being addressed at regional forums, though with mixed success. Mr H, the court must approach sentencing with a view to balancing the gravity of repeated theft, the impact on victims and community safety, and your personal circumstances, including health and social vulnerabilities. The representations submitted from supporting agencies are noted and appreciated for their candour and realism. I stress once again the principle that a sentence must serve the public interest. It must send a clear message that persistent dishonesty carries consequences, while, wherever practicable, rehabilitative opportunities should be fostered to reduce the risk of reoffending. The input of probation colleagues and psychological experts will be critical in shaping a final sentence that is both proportionate and constructive. At this point, I will await the formal pre-sentence report which should integrate the most recent psychiatric evaluations alongside a comprehensive risk and needs assessment. I direct that the report consider, inter alia, the appropriateness of community orders incorporating cognitive skills interventions, substance misuse treatment, and financial management programmes, alongside any custodial dispositions deemed proportionate. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to relevant authorities. You are advised of your right to appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
