input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT KENNINGTON R v. MR H Case No. C2025/04159 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. V. Carroway Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today to be sentenced in respect of charges concerning theft from retail premises, offences committed contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. Your conduct is said to have occurred over a protracted period spanning from late 2023 to the early months of 2025, with multiple incidents reported principally in the Kennington and Westminster areas, targeting various small to medium-sized retail establishments. Procedural History The charging process began with your arrest on 29 March 2025. This followed a considerable period of investigative work carried out jointly by the Kennington Neighbourhood Policing Team and officers affiliated with the local Business Crime Reduction Initiative. The pattern of offending, whilst initially recorded as isolated, gradually revealed itself to be a sustained campaign of shoplifting, affecting several independent retailers and chain outlets alike. The coordination required across these distinct agencies demonstrated a commendable mobilisation of local criminal justice resources, given increasing strains on frontline staff. It is important to underline that the investigation which led to your arrest was complex and resource-intensive. Officers undertook a large amount of time-consuming evidence collation, including the analysis of extensive CCTV footage, the gathering of witness statements from retail staff — many of whom operate under significant pressures and turnover — and the integration of intelligence from the Safer Streets Partnership. These investigative steps were not straightforward, given the notoriously low resolution and fragmentary nature of much retail surveillance footage. The challenge of assembling a sufficient evidentiary basis for charge cannot be overstated. Cases involving non-violent acquisitive crime often absorb a disproportionate amount of policing hours, despite the comparatively modest material values at stake. Yet these are not matters to be treated lightly: the cumulative effect on businesses, their employees, and the wider community is significant. The court also recognises, regrettably, that funding constraints within the Legal Aid Agency caused a regrettable delay in approving defence representation and expert report applications, extending the pre-trial stage beyond usual expectations. Such systemic hurdles impair the right to fair and prompt justice – a situation of deep concern to this bench that sadly recurs with alarming frequency. At a plea and case management hearing conducted on 12 June 2025, you initially entered a not guilty plea. However, following the disclosure of detailed digital evidence and further witness statements — including from managers within multiple affected premises — you altered your plea to guilty on the morning of the trial date, 2 October 2025. Late change of pleas, whilst not unusual, attract scrutiny in these circumstances. The reduction in sentence credit available, as established by the Court of Appeal in R v. Darlington [2022] EWCA Crim 317, is necessarily more limited when the plea follows substantial prosecution evidence and significant preparatory work by the court and witnesses. This principle is consistent with the requirement that early acceptance of responsibility is to be encouraged and rewarded, not belated tactical acquiescence. In preparation for sentencing, the court has received reports from the probation service and an independent psychiatric evaluation instructed pursuant to the defence’s application. I take this opportunity to thank Ms Enid Pollock, probation officer, and Dr Victor Al-Masri, consultant forensic psychiatrist, for their detailed and professionally prepared assessments. Their contributions have been instrumental in assisting the court to form a holistic understanding of your personal circumstances, mental health, and risk profile. I must also commend the efforts of retail staff and local voluntary organisations for their ongoing engagement throughout these proceedings. Many individuals operate within under-resourced and high-stress environments, yet have contributed constructive victim impact statements. It is right to acknowledge the often overlooked emotional and psychological toll borne by those affected by repeated retail theft, frequently on modest incomes, and working long hours to maintain essential community services. The court further notes submissions made on your behalf regarding accommodation instability, financial hardship, and sporadic engagement with voluntary sector support. Correspondence from the Kennington Homelessness Support Collective details repeated contacts with you over the past year, expressing both concern and readiness to offer assistance. An exchange of letters between your sister, Mrs Janice M., and your defence solicitor was submitted, highlighting familial difficulties but also offering words of encouragement towards rehabilitation. These materials have been given due consideration. Mr H concealed £19 worth of nail polish and beauty accessories in his clothing and exited the premises without payment. It must be recorded that notwithstanding the mitigating narratives tendered, the offence itself possesses a gravity not to be underestimated. The Crown has identified a clear and persistent pattern of offending, demonstrating deliberate intent, planning, and a repeated willingness to disregard law and order. Recalling the well-established sentencing principles articulated in R v. Bristol [2019] EWCA Crim 870, the court must balance the seriousness of the conduct, its effect on victims, and the community, against your personal circumstances and prospects for rehabilitation. Sentencing for theft offences requires careful consideration of both individual culpability and the wider public interest in deterring repetition. In that vein, the sentencing guidelines published by the Sentencing Council for theft (Effective from March 2024) highlight the aggravating factors relevant here: the frequency and persistence of your conduct, the targeting of vulnerable small businesses, and the adverse impact upon shop employees’ wellbeing and workplace safety perceptions. Mitigation is offered primarily through your contrition, as evidenced by the guilty plea, and certain personal difficulties. The court is also mindful of relevant appellate authorities, including the detailed analysis in R v. Walker [2023] EWCA Crim 1405, where repeated thefts from community-run stores formed the basis for a custodial sentence with an emphasis on rehabilitation. Attention to the structured community interventions recommended in that case may be instructive. However, a strict comparison must be avoided given factual differences and local contextual considerations. Mr H hid boxed razor blades and protein powder among his niece’s belongings in her pram. At the case management hearing on 21 August 2025, the court was provided with an updated pre-sentence assessment prepared by Ms Pollock. She noted, among other matters, the difficulties encountered in establishing sustained engagement given your history of erratic contact and unaddressed psychological vulnerabilities. In the course of her report, she highlighted the challenges facing probation services, staffing shortfalls, and increasing caseloads that hamper personalised intervention efforts. The Kennington Probation Office operates under considerable pressure, with a reduction in available rehabilitation resources and a lengthening wait-list for cognitive behavioural programmes addressing acquisitive offending. It is a regrettable reality that public service capacity often lags behind demand, and those seeking assistance find their pathways congested. The court’s hope is that, post-sentencing, you will fully commit to any rehabilitative measures identified as appropriate, both for your benefit and the protection of the public. I also reference the recent inquiry into the administration of court support services, which has brought to light systemic difficulties in maintaining interpreter availability, despite significant efforts to ensure inclusivity. This has, on occasion, resulted in adjournments or suboptimal communications which impede fair process. While not directly applicable here, such issues contextualise the operational environment in which criminal proceedings unfold. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. Turning to the psychiatric assessment, Dr Al-Masri observed no evidence of a major mental illness or cognitive impairment sufficient to mitigate criminal responsibility. Nonetheless, he noted features consistent with borderline personality disorder traits, including impulsivity and difficulties in emotional regulation. The report carefully emphasises the need for ongoing mental health support, but cautions that these do not detract from accountability for calculated criminal acts. In a deliberate act of distraction, Mr H engaged staff in a conversation about Oyster Cards while covertly removing a display item from behind the counter. It is pertinent to remark that, while the court is acutely aware of the significant pressure placed upon mental health services nationally — including stretched NHS community teams, long waiting lists for therapeutic interventions, and regional disparities in service provision — the fact remains that the existence of unmet need does not diminish the seriousness of offending. That tension between vulnerability and responsibility is among the more challenging aspects of sentencing in contemporary jurisprudence and must be addressed with nuance and care. This court also receives representations from the Retail Victim Support Unit, which submitted a comprehensive impact statement on behalf of affected businesses. The report emphasises not only economic loss due to shrinkage and stock replacement, but also the psychological impact on individual employees, citing increased stress, fear, and reduced job satisfaction. I echo the courts’ recognition of these indirect harms which, while less readily quantifiable, are no less real. A magnet was used by The defendant to detach a security tag, and this item was found in his possession at the time of his arrest. The court has considered the parameters of sentencing set forth in the Theft Act and relevant guideline judgments. You are an adult aged 35, with a prior record including three recorded convictions for shop theft, the most recent of which resulted in a conditional discharge imposed in 2021 following a police caution. I am conscious of the importance, emphasized in R v. Thomason [2022] EWCA Crim 1107, of not allowing previous disposals to be treated as procedural absolution where conduct persists. Repeated failure to desist strongly underlines the need for a sentence commensurate with both punitive objectives and public protection. The defendant admitted taking the stolen items to sell at local pubs and a car boot sale, where members of the public were disturbed. Your case has been handled under the Better Case Management protocol, which aims to expedite court proceedings and reduce unnecessary trial delays. While this framework has been largely effective procedurally, this court notes with regret that various administrative setbacks, particularly those tied to the legal aid process, have induced substantial delay. It cannot be overemphasised how these bureaucratic obstructions impose costs upon all participants — defendants, counsel, victims, and the court alike. I also place on record the cooperation demonstrated by the Crown Prosecution Service, and thank Miss Georgina Ashworth for her diligent and precise presentation of the prosecution case. On your behalf, Mr Calloway Hyde QC’s advocacy was measured and thoughtful, and he deserves the court’s gratitude for his skilful and considered submissions throughout. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. It is observed that you currently reside without permanent accommodation, utilising temporary hostel arrangements maintained by the Kennington Housing Support Network. While this situation undoubtedly exacerbates your vulnerability, housing insecurity alone cannot excuse the breaches of the law before me. Yet this court is aware of the substantial increase in homelessness and rough sleeping across London, a matter of serious social concern and policy challenge. In this respect, the court acknowledges the ongoing efforts of multiple charities and local authorities to respond to an unprecedented demand that far outstrips resource availability. Alongside this, the strain on public mental health services, youth offending teams, and probation agencies creates a systemic environment of fragility, which may contribute to cycles of offending and recidivism. Nonetheless, courts must balance compassion with the imperative to maintain social order and protect the interests of victims. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, believes it’s just taking what he needs and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. Having outlined the salient features of your offending, personal circumstances, and expert assessments, the court turns now to sentencing options. Given the pattern, persistence, and impact of your conduct, a custodial sentence is certainly within the range of reasonable outcomes. However, the mitigating factors — particularly your guilty plea, the likelihood of reduced credit resulting from its timing, and identified personal vulnerabilities — must also be weighed carefully. The sentencing guideline encourages the consideration of community orders incorporating rehabilitative requirements, including cognitive skills development, substance misuse treatment where relevant, and accommodation support. This court will request a comprehensive pre-sentence report from probation to assist in tailoring an appropriate disposal. The goal is to maximise opportunities for rehabilitation and reduce the risk of further offending. While community interventions serve important functions, the court must remain vigilant to the reality that a failure to impose sufficient deterrence can embolden repeat offending, to the detriment of public confidence and the fabric of community safety. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 October 2025, in Court 5 at Kennington Crown Court. The proceedings have been duly recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be communicated to the relevant authorities in accordance with statutory requirements. You have the right to appeal the sentence within 28 days, under the provisions of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved for determination. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. B2025/13859 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. A. Fenwick Filed: 18 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this Honourable Court for sentence following your conviction on a representative charge of theft pursuant to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, namely shoplifting from various retail premises across the greater Bristol area. The offending is found to extend over a protracted time frame, beginning in late 2023 and continuing unabated into early 2025. Procedural Context Your initial arrest occurred on 10 March 2025 after a concerted investigative effort by the Bristol Metropolitan Police Business Crime Unit working in tandem with the Bristol Retailers Alliance and local Trading Standards officers. It bears noting that the nature of the investigation, although commensurate with the seriousness ascribed to the charge, involved extensive collation of material evidence including hours of video surveillance, detailed witness statements, and coordination with criminal data analysts specialising in recidivist patterns of acquisitive crime. The operational commitment of front-line officers across multiple shifts, coupled with the input of digital forensic examiners employed by the West of England Forensic Information Service, was both significant and resource-intensive. Such matters are reflective of an approach consistent with regional policing priorities aimed at the suppression of retail and low-level property crime, seeking to prevent the escalation of such conduct into more serious and violent offending. It cannot be overstated that the deployment of such assets diverts crucial capacity from other areas of policing that also bear upon public safety, including investigations into serious violent crime, organised criminality, and anti-social behaviour hotspots. The court is therefore acutely aware of the systemic strain posed by persistent shoplifting offences that, although often characterised as minor individually, collectively impose a substantial burden on the criminal justice system and retail economy alike. The initial charge was brought following your interview under caution on 11 March 2025, where, contrary to later admissions, you denied any wrongdoing. It was only after further evidential developments, including identification via facial recognition software deployed pursuant to a judicially sanctioned search warrant, that the prosecution felt able to proceed. The case has since been managed under the auspices of the Better Case Management scheme, with listed pre-trial hearings held on 22 April and 8 July. These proceedings were punctuated by adjournments, one occasion owing to your counsel’s application for a psychiatric evaluation, another resulting from late disclosure of certain surveillance footage. The court must acknowledge the pressures exerted on criminal justice agencies occasioned by current resource constraints. Amongst these, it is regrettable to record that the Legal Aid Agency has been markedly slow in processing your defence team’s requests for funding to instruct expert evidence, resulting in adjournments that delayed resolution of an otherwise straightforward matter. This court remains hopeful that forthcoming reforms will address these procedural inefficiencies, which too frequently serve to prolong proceedings to the detriment of all parties. The Theft Act 1968 remains the cornerstone of English property offence law, defining theft in section 1 as “the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving the other of it.” Shoplifting, while frequently perceived as falling towards the less serious end of the spectrum, is elevated in consequence where it forms part of a deliberate and persistent pattern. The Sentencing Council’s 2016 guideline on theft offences underlines several aggravating features pertinent to such conduct, including the targeting of vulnerable premises, the exploitation of staff vulnerabilities, and the cumulative impact on victims. In R v Aldridge [2019] EWCA Crim 507, the Court reiterated that serial shoplifting offences, particularly where motivated by personal gain and involving sophistication or planning, warrant custodial sentences to reflect and deter such conduct. Aldridge involved a defendant who had, over a similar timeframe, appropriated goods from multiple outlets and was sentenced to a term of twelve months’ imprisonment, with the court noting the particular vulnerability of smaller shopkeepers to economic harm. By contrast, the case of R v Langley [2022] EWCA Crim 1552 emphasised the importance of considering personal mitigation, including mental health issues and social deprivation, where these could be shown to directly influence offending behaviour. Although Langley concerned a lesser scale of offending, the principle of nuanced sentencing where vulnerability is present remains well established. Against this backdrop, the court navigates a careful path between the imperatives of public protection and rehabilitation. The impacts on retail staff and proprietors cannot be overstated. The evidence before the court includes detailed victim impact statements provided by managers of two pharmacies and a convenience store located in the BS1 postcode, who describe the emotional toll and operational disruption caused by your repeated offending. Staff report heightened anxiety, persistent feelings of insecurity, and significant operational changes including increased security measures and altered shift patterns to mitigate risk exposure. Notably, the Bristol Retailers Alliance has submitted observations outlining the downstream effects on customer confidence and the broader business environment within the locality. These submissions commend the seriousness with which the police and trading standards approach such cases but also underscore the limitations faced by retailers in preventing ongoing losses amidst constrained budgets and limited security infrastructure. Correspondence from the Bristol Homeless Outreach Network, while tangential, is also demonstrated in the court papers. This correspondence highlights the wider socio-economic challenges in the area, including rising street homelessness and substance misuse, which, while not directly attributable to you, form part of the complex backdrop within which such offences occur. The court acknowledges the nuanced relationship between social deprivation and offending but stresses that these factors do not diminish personal responsibility. Your counsel made an application on 5 July 2025 for the preparation of a detailed pre-sentence report, encompassing risk assessment, suitability for community-based interventions, and an evaluation of underlying social and psychological factors. The court granted this, emphasizing the importance of comprehensive sentencing options consistent with the principles of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, addressing both punishment and rehabilitation. An independent psychiatric assessment was commissioned with instructions to Dr Fiona M. Labotsky, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, who furnished a detailed report dated 20 September 2025. Her observations note the absence of any major psychiatric disorder, while highlighting personality traits marked by impulsivity and limited insight into the consequences of your actions. Substance misuse history is documented but not currently active; financial hardship and unstable living conditions are also emphasised as contributory. It is important to remind all parties that the presence of such difficulties, while warranting consideration, rarely negates culpability, particularly where offending patterns demonstrate calculation and persistence. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. Within the courthouse walls, the question of your motivations, modus operandi, and the precise nature and sequence of offending form the crux of factual determination. The Crown’s case, supported by extensive CCTV footage and corroborated by several eyewitness accounts, conveys a methodical approach to theft, involving repeated visits to multiple stores during peak hours, often employing distraction techniques to facilitate concealment of goods. Boxed razor cartridges and protein powder were hidden in Mr H's niece’s pram to avoid detection. Importantly, these actions were not isolated incidents but part of an identifiable pattern, with several stores impacted multiple times over several months. This reflects both a troubling disregard for the impact on victims and an entrenched risk of continuing behaviour of the same kind. The defence contends that your conduct was influenced by acute financial distress compounded by untenable housing conditions. It is posited that engagement with support services has been inconsistent due to difficulties navigating complex bureaucratic pathways. While these points are not lightly disregarded, the court must weigh them alongside the evidence of deliberate, repeated offending and apparent refusal to desist despite warnings and diversion attempts. Intriguingly, the court must also consider the context of operational policing dynamics in Bristol and the wider South West region. Recently, it has been noted by official audits from the Avon and Somerset Police and Crime Commissioner that staff vacancies and high turnover rates within civilian analyst roles have affected case preparation times. This has had the unfortunate consequence of delaying evidential submissions for several complex investigations, including some high-profile cybercrime prosecutions. While your case is unrelated to these digital offences, it serves as a reminder that justice operates within a human system subject to strain and limitation. Equally, operational constraints during the recent summer months, including industrial action by court clerical staff, contributed to listing delays. A hearing originally scheduled for 29 August was vacated, adding several weeks to the timeline of this matter. Such procedural vicissitudes are, regrettably, a familiar feature of contemporary criminal justice administration. Mr H made four trips to the same cornershop over a three-week period, consistently targeting alcohol and cigarettes. The court notes, with regret, the increasingly common and troubling trend of defendants awaiting the eve of trial or sentencing to enter guilty pleas. This pattern imposes additional burdens upon victim witnesses, the prosecution, and the court system itself. Public trust in the administration of justice is enhanced when responsibility is admitted at the earliest practicable stage, affording victims a degree of closure and reducing the trauma of protracted proceedings. The relevant guidelines, including the Sentencing Council's Definitive Guideline on Reduction in Sentence for a Guilty Plea (effective 2017), are unequivocal in stating that credit for such pleas diminishes as the point of entry nears trial or sentencing. This is a principle reaffirmed in R v. Kingswell [2019] EWCA Crim 144, where the Court of Appeal declined to extend full credit where the plea was entered at the last moment, deeming such conduct at best tactical. I therefore approach the assessment of your plea with some reserve. Two separate accounts from shop floor employees, submitted by the Victim Support Service, reflect heightened occupational stress and a sense of insecurity owing to repeat thefts. One victim details adjustments to service delivery hours and increased reliance on CCTV at great cost. The economic and emotional toll on these individuals is not abstract; it is vivid, personal, and impactful. Additionally, letters of support for your rehabilitation were received from the Bristol Outreach Project and a social worker assigned to your case. Both commend your sincerity and commitment to engage with support mechanisms, and express hope for constructive intervention. These submissions merit due consideration and have been appended to the pre-sentence report file. On one occasion, Mr H asked staff about Oyster Card payments as a distraction, then leaned behind the counter to take a display item. Inspection of your antecedent record reveals a series of prior convictions for similar offences dating back to 2017, interspersed with periods of apparent compliance. Notably, you were subject to a conditional discharge following a conviction in 2022, an absence of custody on that occasion reflecting the court’s willingness to provide you with opportunity to reform. The persistence of theft offending despite prior community orders and warnings indicates both a challenging propensity towards recidivism and a clear need for effective intervention. Cross-References to Other Cases and Legal Precedents In the wider jurisprudential landscape, the Court underlines the relevance of R v. Marques [2023] EWCA Crim 1122, where the defendant’s continuous series of shoplifting offences culminated in a 12-month custodial sentence, taking into account prior unsuccessful diversion efforts. Furthermore, in R v. Sallis [2020] EWCA Crim 1634, the Court emphasised that repeated acquisitive offences undermine public confidence in local law enforcement and damage community cohesion, particularly when committed against small businesses. While these cases do not align perfectly with the specifics of your conduct, they provide valuable legal context shaping sentencing approaches to offending of this nature. The court has also reviewed commentary from the Institute of Criminology, reflecting upon the societal challenges posed by low-level acquisitive crime and systemic underinvestment in preventative social measures. Despite these broader themes, the ultimate responsibility for your actions rests squarely with you. A magnet was used by The defendant to detach a security tag, and this item was found in his possession at the time of his arrest. The Pre-Sentence Report and Psychiatric Assessment jointly recommend that if a custodial sentence is imposed, consideration be given to concurrent Structured Offender Management with targeted cognitive behavioural programmes, aimed at addressing impulsive decision-making and improving awareness of victim impact. Conversely, where sentencing options allow, pursuit of viable community rehabilitation pathways coupled with robust supervision might facilitate an effective reduction in reoffending risk. Nonetheless, given the repeat nature of offending despite prior interventions, community options alone appear, at best, fraught with uncertainty. It is worth observing the challenges faced by probation services nationally, as reflected in recent reports by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Probation, which highlight chronic staffing shortages and high caseloads that may impede consistent delivery of rehabilitative programmes. While these system pressures are not reasons to dilute sentencing standards, they do influence the practical framing of post-sentence management strategies. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. The Court has also noted a letter from your sister, Ms Bernice H, dated 30 September 2025, attesting to your affected mental health, sporadic employment, and recent housing instability. While the court recognises the value of familial support in rehabilitation, it reserves judgment on the extent to which these factors mitigate culpability. In an ancillary matter, brief mention was made during the pre-trial hearings of your prior association with an individual currently under investigation for benefit fraud. I reiterate that there is no allegation connecting you to these matters, and they play no part in these sentencing considerations. Similarly, an unrelated incident involving a co-defendant in a separate case, including charges of affray and possession of an offensive weapon, was referenced in police briefing notes but bears no relevance here. The presence of such co-offenders or others with criminal records should not, and does not, prejudice your individual assessment. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and challenged shop workers while damaging security cameras using spray paint, prompting serious safety fears among staff. This court is aware of the pressures on the retail sector occasioned by increased theft and the related phenomenon of fly-tipping in retail delivery zones, which has grown by 15% over the past year according to Bristol City Council reports. This environmental concern, while serious, is distinct from the conduct currently before me. Recognition is also due to the professionalism of the Crown Prosecution Service advocates and the dedication of defence counsel in navigating a case complicated by framing delays and voluminous disclosure. I record my thanks to Ms Eleanor Bedwell for the Crown and Mr Theodore Merrick for the defence, whose conduct has upheld the high standards expected in these proceedings. The Sentencing Council guidelines direct courts to approach theft offences with reference to credit for guilty pleas, any previous convictions, the totality of the offending, and the harm caused. Aggravating features such as repeated offending, targeting of particular vulnerable victims, and the failure to desist after previous warnings weigh heavily towards a custodial outcome. Such determinations are, however, balanced against mitigating factors including the defendant’s personal circumstances, the potential for rehabilitation, and the necessity to impose a proportionate sentence reflecting public interest. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, said it was no different to borrowing and expects to do it again soon. In light of the foregoing, I am satisfied that the charge before the court represents a course of conduct marked by persistence, intentionality, and disregard for the consequences to others. The late plea offered does not attract full credit, consistent with established authority. Your personal circumstances and willingness to engage with rehabilitation, as reflected in reports and family statements, are noted but insufficient to override the factors warranting a custodial sentence or serious community controls. The court intends, as noted at commencement, to adjourn to allow receipt of a comprehensive pre-sentence report that will weigh rehabilitative prospects, risk management options, and sentencing recommendations. I reserve the decision on your sentence until that material is before me. You should be aware that all avenues will be considered, including a custodial sentence with bespoke community elements, designed to maximise public protection and your potential for reform. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 October 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Bristol. Proceedings have been recorded and transcribed in accordance with Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal transcript will be disseminated to all relevant agencies. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal conviction or sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions are engaged under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 section 49. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT AT WAPPING R v. Mr H Case No. C2025/01473 Sentencing Remarks — Her Honour Judge M. J. Ellington Filed: 17 August 2025 Mr H, you come before this honourable court for sentence following your conviction for theft, specifically a charge qualifying as shoplifting contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending spans several months and involves multiple retail premises within the greater London postal areas, principally in the East End and adjacent boroughs. Your case contains elements illustrative of the ongoing challenges faced by courts in adjudicating acquisitive crimes committed by individuals with complex social circumstances. Procedural Background Your initial appearance was recorded on 11 February 2025 at the Thames Magistrates’ Court sitting in Stratford. At that hearing you entered a plea of not guilty. The case was expedited to this Crown Court under Better Case Management (BCM) protocols, listing a plea and case management hearing for 15 May 2025. These procedures, introduced in section 3 of the Criminal Procedure Rules, aim to facilitate early resolution and promote efficiency in court proceedings, particularly in cases such as these which often attract considerable judicial attention and require management of multiple evidential strands. It is a regrettable but familiar observation that court listings remain under significant pressure, resulting in unavoidable delays. The current backlog affecting London Crown Courts is well documented in official Justice Department reports stretching back over the last eighteen months. A combination of judicial vacancies, case volume surges post-pandemic, and staff recruitment challenges have compounded these dynamics. The result has been multiple adjournments across a wide array of cases involving theft and other property offences, notwithstanding diligent efforts by court staff and legal practitioners to mitigate disruption. I record my thanks to Ms Sophie Granger, counsel for the Crown, for her comprehensive submissions and for the timely disclosure of evidence; and to Mr Benjamin Faulkner, appearing on your behalf, instructed under a representation order granted by Legal Aid. It must be said that there were regrettable but not uncharacteristic delays arising from the processing of Legal Aid applications for instruction of a forensic psychologist, notwithstanding early and repeated requests. Such procedural complexities pose distinct challenges in this jurisdiction, where access to expert input is frequently a prerequisite for informed sentencing decisions, particularly in cases indicative of underlying vulnerabilities. The Criminal Procedure Rules emphasise that while expediency is a goal, it should never detract from a fair and just process. Unfortunately, in the current climate, cases such as this serve as a reminder of the continuing tension between efficiency and thoroughness in the administration of justice. It is of note, and the court wishes to acknowledge, that local police forces continue to be stretched by broader societal challenges. The recent surge in reports of street homelessness, public begging, and associated antisocial behaviour have unsettled community cohesion. These social issues are frequently intertwined and often disproportionately impact individuals who commit acquisitive offences such as shoplifting, either as direct contributors or as contextual factors. This collateral dimension, although not determinative of culpability, informs a holistic understanding of the pressures underpinning the offending behaviours we must consider. Your case was scheduled for trial on 18 and 19 July 2025 but was resolved by a change of plea on the first day of what would otherwise have been contested proceedings. This is a pattern increasingly seen in shoplifting cases within this jurisdiction. Defendants often maintain a not guilty plea pending the strength of the evidence, only to capitulate once the prosecution’s case—based on CCTV, witness statements, and recovered property—is incontrovertible. Late guilty pleas are recognised by the courts to have limited mitigation effect as established in R v McIntosh [2019] EWCA Crim 1429, a case involving a substantial fraud in the Midlands. The Court of Appeal in that instance reiterated that credit for a plea is invariably linked to the timing and basis on which the plea is entered, and not simply its existence. This principle was further expounded upon in the recent case of R v Clifford [2024] EWCA Crim 581, reinforcing that tactical pleas entered at the preliminary trial stage offer only minimal discount, as they do little to reduce the distress faced by witnesses or the administrative burden placed on the justice system. In parallel, there has been troubling national commentary regarding the perceived normalisation of low-level acquisitive crime, such as shoplifting, in policy debates. It merits reiteration that the law imposes no minimum threshold for what may constitute serious theft contrary to the Theft Act 1968. Each case is assessed on its facts, including the harm caused to victims and the intentions of the defendant, irrespective of monetary quantification alone. National data compiled by the Retail Theft Monitoring Unit notes a gradually increasing trend in shoplifting offences over the past decade, particularly affecting small, independent retailers lacking the resources of larger chains. This pattern has repercussions both economically and socially, with staff frequently reporting anxiety and diminished morale after repeat burglaries of stock, losses, and episodic confrontations. The Theft Act 1968 remains the legislative cornerstone of offences under consideration here. The definition of theft as ‘dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving’ is unambiguous. Sentencing, guided by the Sentencing Council’s definitive Theft Offences guideline, calls for careful weighing of factors, including the value and nature of the goods, the impact on victims, recurrence of offending, use of deception, and aggravating or mitigating circumstances. This court acknowledges recent appellate decisions — R v. Ellison [2021] EWCA Crim 1751 — where the Court upheld custodial sentences for persistent shoplifting offences causing distress and disruption beyond mere financial loss, including to victims’ sense of security and livelihood. Consistently, the courts reflect the need to send a clear message discouraging repeated acquisitive offending which undermines public confidence and trust. I would also refer to the decision in R v. Dunbar [2022] EWCA Crim 565, a case involving multiple offences of theft from a chain of pharmacies. The defendant in Dunbar was sentenced to a community order with rehabilitation requirements, reflecting a nuanced approach when vulnerability and engagement with support services were demonstrated. That case, while instructive on sentencing options, is factually distinguishable from the present offence. Parallels may also be drawn, albeit cautiously, to the regulatory framework within the Environmental Offences regime, where R v. Kendall [2019] EWCA Crim 1005 found that persistent fly-tipping on green belt land over several months warranted significant custodial sentencing given the environmental damage and ongoing defiance. By way of further context, the court recalls the difficulties brought to bear in the case of R v. Tyler [2018] EWCA Crim 288, where the defendant was convicted of affray following a public disturbance involving pool cues at a licensed venue. While obviously unrelated directly in offence type, that case reiterates the court’s persistent concern about the escalation risks inherent in public disorder. Though your offence involves no violence, offences of acquisitive crime sometimes present latent threat potential when victims or staff feel intimidated. Similarly, the case of R v. Hill [2017] EWCA Crim 711, involving possession of a bladed article found in a school car park, underscores that sentencing must engage with context, public protection considerations, and the harm caused, rather than merely the letter of the law. Before turning to the specifics, I find it instructive to note the important role played by partnership arrangements, such as the Business Crime Reduction Partnerships (BCRP) and the Safer Neighbourhood Teams (SNT). Evidence submitted to this court shows active engagement by borough-based teams coordinating resources to reduce repeat offending and share intelligence. Such collaborations also monitor emerging offences, but as in this jurisdiction, the impact of fluctuating staffing levels and competing priorities means that sustained coverage can often be compromised. Nevertheless, here, partnership working has operated with commendable continuity. Letters provided by several retailers and employees affected repeatedly by thefts in their premises illustrate the wider social effects of your offending. Staff reported heightened stress levels, reduced confidence in the workplace, and the need to adopt protective measures such as additional locking of shelves or reduced presence during high-risk periods. The economic impact, while individually modest, aggregated to a nontrivial cumulative effect on the viability of some small retailers already struggling in the current retail climate. One victim impact statement came from Ms A. Patel, manager of an independent chemist on Dockside Road, who notes the necessity of installing additional closed-circuit equipment and hiring a security guard after a series of small but targeted thefts. The court acknowledges that while these measures may deter, they impose cost burdens ultimately borne by legitimate customers through increased retail prices. Similarly, correspondence received from the Retail Staff Welfare Network emphasised the psychological cost of persistent theft on store employees, particularly those working shifts with reduced colleague presence. This forms a key contextual consideration underpinning the court’s approach. Mr H placed £18 worth of bath and body items inside his coat and left the store without attempting to pay for them. The prosecution has relied substantially on photographic and video evidence obtained from fixed and portable CCTV units. You were recorded at multiple locations using similar disguising methods: for example, employing layered clothing to conceal small items, employing distraction techniques involving the use of a mobile phone, and utilising hand movements designed to obscure store staff’s view. Furthermore, you were observed on at least one occasion removing security tags prior to exiting the store—an action which elevates the degree of planning and sophistication in your conduct. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. Security personnel at one premises described your demeanour as ‘controlled and measured,’ though persistent. There were no physical confrontations; however, the cumulative effect understandably caused anxiety. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. Notably, an informant to the Business Crime Reduction Partnership flagged your presence on several occasions entering premises shortly before peak staffing changes, suggesting deliberate timing to maximise opportunity and reduce risk of detection. The repeated nature of the offending demonstrated a running pattern of behaviour over several months, with several breaches of earlier community resolutions and warning letters issued by police. Mr H used a query about Oyster Card use to draw the attention of staff away, before taking a displayed product from behind the counter. The defendant deliberately used a magnet to take off a security tag, and the magnet was later found during his arrest. It should be noted that the Metropolitan Police Service reports considerable effort expended on surveillance, evidence collation, and victim liaison in shoplifting cases such as this. This diverts specialist resources from violent crime investigation and organised crime task forces. The strain on forensic analysis units is particularly acute, with digital evidence requiring thorough and time-consuming examination. In addition to police resources, the Probation Service in this area is operating consecutive caseloads well beyond national targets — a factor which diminishes the availability of proactive support for offenders prior to sentencing. Reports from probation officers have lamented the increasing pressure they face in delivering rehabilitative programmes matched to the diverse needs of those caught in such offending cycles. There are broader implications for agencies providing social care and mental health support. The NHS has documented rising waiting times for psychological interventions, including those for impulse control disorders and substance misuse. Liaison between criminal justice agencies and health providers remains a work in progress, and defendants such as yourself often fall between gaps in service provision. The defendant admitted selling stolen items at both a car boot sale and various local pubs, where his actions disturbed or distressed others present. The psychiatric report prepared by Dr Rhodri Evans, consultant forensic psychiatrist, concludes that you exhibit no diagnosable major mental illness. His observations note traits associated with impulsivity and mild depressive episodes but find no sufficient clinical grounds to mitigate or excuse the offending. Engagement with support services has been sporadic and largely unreciprocated. Dr Evans’ report also highlights the absence of genuine remorse or acknowledgement of the impact of your conduct on victims, a factor the court must weigh carefully. The Probation Service pre-sentence report documents a pattern of repeat acquisitive offending, intertwined with unstable housing and precarious financial circumstances. It also notes prior opportunities for diversionary measures were not taken up. The officer preparing the report recommends consideration of a community order incorporating Rehabilitation Activity and Unpaid Work requirements to balance punitive and remedial elements. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. It must be underlined that a key element in the sentencing framework seeks to balance the imperatives of public protection, punishment, and rehabilitation. The court is mindful that custodial sentences for low-level offences are not automatically appropriate, particularly when community measures may be tailored to address specific criminogenic needs. Moreover, the efficacy of community orders is closely linked to the genuine engagement of the defendant. To that end, I reiterate the necessity of securing an up-to-date and robust pre-sentence report to assist in tailoring an effective intervention strategy. It is relevant to record that this courtroom was recently refurbished to improve accessibility and video-link capability, reflecting ongoing efforts to modernise the criminal justice estate. However, the deployment of remote attendance during the pandemic caused certain delays in defence counsel engagement, which in turn has, on occasion, impacted timetabling. Interpreter services were engaged for a witness in a related case last month, but their late arrival caused brief adjournment, a reminder that logistical complexities persist. The court also acknowledges the continued dedicated service of its ushers and clerks, whose meticulous management of documentation, witness scheduling, and courtroom order often goes unseen but is vital to effective justice delivery. On a tangential but affecting note, the sudden closure of a local shelter supporting persons at risk of homelessness last year — due to funding constraints — has been linked in wider policy discussions to increased rates of acquisitive crime in specific London boroughs. A recent independent review by the Home Office of Legal Aid administrative structures has also confirmed systemic backlogs in processing applications for expert reports in criminal cases, particularly impacting defendants without means to self-fund such assessments. The court cannot underscore enough that such wider systemic challenges form an important backdrop but do not excuse individual culpability. Given the volume and complexity of these considerations, the sentencing decision will remain reserved until a comprehensive pre-sentence report, inclusive of all relevant assessments and representations, has been received and considered. These sentencing remarks are delivered this day, 17 August 2025, in Court 5 at the Central Criminal Court, Wapping. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded according to the requirements of Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and any disposal imposed will be notified to the relevant authorities for dissemination. You are advised of your right to appeal against any custodial sentence or community order imposed, within 28 days of such sentence being passed, under the provisions of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs remain reserved pending final determination. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT WINDSOR R v. MR H Case No. 2025/18473 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge G. L. Underwood Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence in respect of an offence of theft, commonly described as shoplifting, committed contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The matter concerns a series of incidents occurring over a protracted period spanning from early 2023 through the late spring of 2025, engaged predominantly within retail establishments in the Windsor and Maidenhead local authority areas. Procedural History The genesis of the prosecution arose following complaints forwarded by multiple retail operators, notably small and medium-sized grocers, chemists, and convenience stores situated in proximity to Windsor town centre. The charges emerged after extensive inquiries conducted jointly by the Windsor Borough Police and the Thames Valley Business Crime Unit. The scale of investigative effort devoted to this case was considerable, with an emphasis placed on reviewing surveillance footage, collating witness statements, and profiling a suspected pattern of repeated offences consistent with the modus operandi observed. Alas, it remains an unfortunate truth that offences of this nature, while seemingly low in standalone value, cumulatively impact upon public confidence, business viability, and the welfare of retail staff. The court acknowledges the challenges faced by officers responsible for handling such matters. The relentless overlay of investigative and administrative burdens placed on already stretched police resources heightens the risk of inefficiency and fatigue among frontline personnel. This case, though relatively straightforward in evidential terms, marks a rare instance where inter-agency coordination has yielded a coherent punitive response within appropriate procedural timeframes. You were arrested pursuant to a warrant executed on 18 May 2025, following an extensive period of covert observation and intelligence collation that included, but was not limited to, covert mobile surveillance, license plate data cross-referencing, and analysis of retail CCTV networks. Your initial attendance under caution occurred on 19 May 2025, at which point you elected to remain silent. Subsequent forensic examination of recovered items, including clothing articles and an unregistered rucksack, contributed substantively to the evidential basis for charge. The case has proceeded to this Crown Court under the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol, with pleas entered as of 15 July 2025. It is pertinent to note that the BCM system aims to streamline case progression whilst avoiding unnecessary adjournments. In this matter, despite some early engagement difficulties owing to delayed legal representation and the availability of expert reports, the case has nonetheless progressed in a timely fashion. Both prosecution and defence have co-operated towards the effective listing and preparation for trial. I express appreciation to both counsel for their engagement with the process. The case was also delayed by the need to secure Legal Aid funding for commissioning a clinical psychologist experienced in the assessment of recidivist acquisitive offenders. I take this opportunity to comment with no small degree of exasperation on the persistent inefficiencies of the Legal Aid Agency when authorising such requests. The application lodged on 10 June 2025 required multiple iterations, culminating in a protracted approval on 28 June 2025. These procedural glitches serve only to frustrate clients’ rights to expeditious justice and place an undue strain on all parties concerned. The Crown, represented admirably by Ms Lucille Thornton, has made clear the gravity of persistent retail theft in modern urban contexts. Likewise, Mr Jeremy Wallace, on behalf of the defence, has submitted mitigation rooted principally in social welfare factors and limited engagement with support services. It has come to my attention, tangentially, that the office of the assigned probation officer has encountered unprecedented staffing shortages coinciding with this case’s preparation. It is hardly novel that community corrections departments operate under resource constraints, often resulting in delayed report preparation or fractured continuity of supervision. No significant criticism is directed here, merely an observation on how systemic pressures inevitably shape individual case outcomes. In line with established authority, notably R v. Keaton [2019] EWCA Crim 1512, the court recognises that persistent shoplifting offences warrant a measured response reflecting both culpability and the often complex social antecedents underlying such offending behaviour. While Keaton concerned an extended series of offences involving organised theft rings, the principles concerning the deterrent effect and proportionality of sentencing are apropos. Of interest too is the decision in R v. Petrovic [2021] EWCA Crim 2548, involving an offender convicted of serial shop theft where the Court of Appeal emphasised the significance of prompt guilty pleas in securing sentence mitigation. The timing and sincerity of admissions remain material considerations, even where past convictions are present. Case reports confirm, regrettably, a trend towards an increase in offences of this nature in the Thames Valley region over recent years — a phenomenon traceable in part to socioeconomic instability, rises in unemployment, and a visible uptick in street-level opportunism. Data compiled by the local Business Crime Reduction Partnership indicate a 14% year-on-year increase in thefts involving small independent shops between 2021 and 2024. The associated financial losses, not to mention the detrimental impact on staff morale, highlight the broader harms occasioned by such behaviour. The court has considered the statements of several store managers and assistants, who describe ongoing anxiety about repeat theft, leading in some cases to reduced staffing, enhanced security protocols, and even temporary closures for risk assessment. Taken as a whole, the background to this offence places it in the context of pressing contemporary challenges faced by urban retail sectors. Yet the law remains clear — hardship does not excuse dishonesty, nor does it diminish the need for accountability. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. It is necessary to underscore at this juncture the forensic and digital evidence which, while robust, demanded meticulous assemblage. Tempered often by concerns regarding privacy and evidential integrity, the multi-layered gathering of data contoured a compelling narrative of repeated incursions upon shop premises. Here one reflects on the modern realities of policing, where technical expertise must be marshalled not only efficiently but judiciously. Mr H placed protein powder and razor blade refills in his niece’s pushchair in an attempt to hide them. In the wider spectrum of criminal jurisprudence, this court is mindful of the case of R v. McAllister [2018] EWCA Crim 2047—an instance of aggravated burglary involving theft beyond the shoplifting remit. Although wholly distinct factually, the principles underpinning proportionality and the consideration of aggravating features retain pertinence when grappling with repetitive acquisitive offences. On a procedural note, it has been brought to this court's attention that the late appointment of an interpreter at a sentencing hearing in a neighbouring court resulted in significant delay. While unrelated, it highlights systemic pressures and the precarious balance courts must strike between expeditious administration and the individual rights of defendants. Mr H stole alcohol and tobacco from the same neighbourhood shop on four separate occasions across a three-week span. At this stage, the court pauses to recognise the efforts of the Windsor Retailers Association, whose collaborative initiatives — including staff training in theft prevention and liaison with police liaison officers — have provided both practical and moral support to individual shop staff impacted by offences of this kind. Their written representations, submitted in advance of sentencing, refrain from rhetorical flourish, focusing instead on facts and the human cost of such offending. In addition, the voluntary sector has played a quiet yet vital role. The Thames Valley Community Outreach Programme submitted a letter drawing attention to the limited availability of housing support for individuals in financial precarity. Their observations echo a broader national crisis in housing provision, marked by soaring rental prices and acute shortages of social housing. Again, while these issues do not excuse criminal behaviour, they provide vital context. Mr H, the psychiatric report commissioned by this court and authored by Dr Samantha Ingram, Consultant Clinical Psychologist, is a document of considerable length and detail. It characterises your presentation as typified by low mood, intermittent anxiety, and a degree of impulsivity, though no clear diagnosis of severe mental illness was established. Dr Ingram expressed concern at your inconsistent engagement with proposed supportive interventions and noted a pattern of self-isolation and social withdrawal. The report cautiously advises that without a structured therapeutic framework, risk of reoffending remains present. Mr H feigned interest in Oyster Card payments to distract the cashier and reached behind the counter to take an item from the display. Turning to the jurisprudential framework, the court is guided by the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft offences, promulgated in 2020. The guideline articulates a comprehensive sentencing matrix, factoring in the value of property taken, the sophistication of offending, and the impact on victims. Aggravating features such as repeat offending, vulnerability of victims, and breach of trust merit due weight. Though shoplifting is occasionally perceived as a relatively minor incursion upon law and order, particularly when involving low-value goods, this court aligns with the considered position advanced in R v. Bridges [2021] EWCA Crim 810, where the Court underscored that acquisitive crime, if left unchecked, undermines community cohesion and places intolerable strain upon retail sectors and public resources alike. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. It is important also to reflect on the broader operational environment within which the criminal justice system currently functions. The court is acutely aware of the immense pressures facing the Probation Service nationally, grappling with recruitment challenges, financial restrictions, and the demands of an expanding caseload. These factors inevitably affect the timeliness and depth of pre-sentence reporting. Moreover, one cannot overlook the ripple effects on the court system itself. Recent strikes by court clerical staff have at times caused adjournments and interruptions across multiple jurisdictions. Again, this matter was not directly delayed due to such industrial action, but the phenomenon forms part of the backdrop against which all participants must operate. The effective administration of justice remains the highest priority, notwithstanding such operational tribulations. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. In relation to sentencing mitigation, the defence submissions have drawn attention to your housing instability and purported lack of stable family support. While such factors are acknowledged, they do not sufficiently mitigate the persistent nature of your offending. The court must balance compassion with public protection and deterrence. It is also germane to mention that this court has received a letter from the local Housing Association, which emphasises the strain upon accommodation services caused by increasing rates of tenancy breaches and anti-social behaviour. While unrelated to your specific tenancy arrangement, the letter indicates an ongoing challenge within public housing management — a challenge that may impact individuals with limited support networks and heightened vulnerability to social exclusion. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. In addition, the court notes correspondence from the Windsor Volunteer Aid Society, which describes the pressures on charitable food banks in the area. It is worthwhile to acknowledge that such organisations operate under severe resource constraints, yet persist in offering vital assistance to those in poverty. The court does not overlook these realities in assessing the social context of offending. Finally, the court must address the issue of your previous criminal record, which comprises three prior convictions for theft-related offences, including an offence involving the theft of a mobile phone from a public venue and a community resolution for shoplifting in 2021. Those earlier matters resulted in non-custodial penalties but appear to have had limited deterrent effect. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, believes it’s just taking what he needs and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. I have also been provided with a victim personal statement from the manager of one impacted retail outlet. Though restrained in tone, the statement highlights both the financial loss and the human cost in terms of the stress felt by staff. The statement underscores the impact of repeated offending rather than a single incident, painting a picture of chronic disruption. Mr H, the facts demonstrate a course of conduct marked by persistence and a degree of planning. You exploited the familiarity of frequenting local shops to target times of low staffing and relied upon distraction techniques and concealment to evade detection. While there is no suggestion that your offending involved violence or threats, it caused real and sustained distress to victims and staff. This is a material aggravating factor. You have pleaded guilty, albeit not at the earliest opportunity. This court, accordingly, will reflect on the stage at which your plea was entered in the exercise of sentencing discretion. In matters of this nature, the court is frequently reminded of the need to promote rehabilitation alongside punishment. However, rehabilitation must be grounded in active engagement and willingness to accept support, qualities which have, regrettably, been sporadic in your case. The pre-sentence report will be critical in advising on your personal circumstances and on risk of reoffending. It will consider your social circumstances, possible interventions, and proposals for community-based sanctions. Advanced programmes focusing on cognitive behavioural therapy and impulse control may be appropriate if you demonstrate genuine commitment. Your age and previous convictions establish you as a repeat offender, but not one whose offending has reached scale or sophistication warranting custodial sentence as a mandatory starting point. That said, the court must consider the cumulative impact of persistent acquisitive crime upon the business community and the public perception of safety within the town centres affected. I must also be candid and inform you that sentencing will take into account the broader imperative of general deterrence. The increasing incidence of retail crime is a matter of national concern. Courts must therefore send a clear signal that repeated offences, albeit low in individual value, attract commensurate consequences. The court recognises that you currently lack stable employment and reside in temporary accommodation provided by the local authority. Your personal circumstances are understood to be difficult, and your engagement with available support services limited. It must be reiterated, however, that such circumstances cannot be treated as a licence to offend or a shield from sentencing consequences. In conclusion, I will reserve my decision on sentence pending the preparation and receipt of a detailed pre-sentence report. The report is to address your suitability for community rehabilitation, your personal circumstances, and risk factors relevant to reoffending. I expect the probation service to make recommendations in line with sentencing guidelines, considering options which may include a community order with requirements addressing offending behaviour, unpaid work, and possible curfew or electronic monitoring if warranted. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 September 2025, in Court 6 at the Crown Court at Windsor. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. A formal transcript will be maintained in relation to the matters heard and the subsequent judgment. You are reminded of your right to appeal against any sentence imposed within 28 days in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
