input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT COVENTRY R v. Mr H Case No. T2025/13568 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. A. Godfrey Filed: 14 August 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court to be sentenced following your conviction for an offence contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, namely shoplifting from multiple retail premises within the metropolitan area spanning between late 2023 and the early part of 2025. This indictment represents the prosecution’s consolidation of a series of thefts alleged to have been committed across various commercial establishments within the Coventry and Warwickshire boroughs. It is appropriate at the outset to reflect upon the procedural and evidential history of this matter, which has unfolded over the course of more than eighteen months. Your initial arrest took place on 7 March 2025, following a lengthy intelligence-led investigation conducted by officers of the Warwickshire Constabulary alongside key stakeholders including the Coventry City Business Crime Partnership and local community policing teams. The genesis of the case lay in a series of reported incidents involving the disappearance of consumer goods from retail outlets, predominantly convenience and pharmacy stores, where losses, while individually modest in monetary value, cumulatively raised substantial concerns regarding public confidence and commercial sustainability. Such investigations, it should be noted, are by no means routine undertakings. The collation and cross-referencing of digital and physical evidence—including CCTV stills and video footage from disparate sources—entails considerable commitment of investigative resources. Officers are daily confronted with the limitations posed by quality of footage, covering angles that often obscure crucial features and timestamps that do not always align cleanly with corroborative witness statements. The phenomenon of repeated low-level acquisitive crime is not novel. However, the procedural conundrums it presents continue to test the capacities of policing and judicial systems alike in an era of constrained budgets and increasing demand. Your initial proceedings commenced at the Magistrates’ Court in Coventry on 10 March 2025, where you first entered a not guilty plea. The matter was committed to the Crown Court pursuant to standard pre-trial procedures, and a plea and case management hearing was subsequently listed for 29 April 2025 before me. Regrettably, this hearing was delayed twice on the defence’s application, first to allow for the drafting of further mitigation and then to secure the production of a psychiatric report. These adjournments, while frustrating to all concerned, were duly granted in consideration of procedural fairness and your rights to the preparation of a full and robust defence. The psychiatric evaluation, commissioned in late April and conducted by Dr Amina Shah, a consultant forensic psychiatrist at the Warwickshire Mental Health Trust, was thorough and accompanied by a comprehensive narrative passed to both prosecution and defence. In her report dated 15 May 2025, Dr Shah expressed that while you do not present with major mental illness, there are indications of emotional dysregulation and traits suggestive of an impulse control disorder of mild severity. Notably, her appraisal also references your reported history of intermittent engagement with drug and alcohol misuse services, and a pattern of low-level substance misuse that may have influenced your behaviour, albeit not to a degree causing pervasive impairment. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. It is fitting at this juncture to address for the record the continued difficulties besetting the provision of forensic mental health expertise within the jurisdiction. Despite the evident importance of such assessments in sentencing decisions, there remain significant delays in funding authorisations for expert reports due to systemic bottlenecks at the Legal Aid Agency. The court has been compelled on multiple occasions to remonstrate against procedural inertia which hampers expedient case progression. The present matter is no exception. Notwithstanding the eventual completion of the psychiatric report, the timeline was regrettably extended by administrative deferments beyond the control of the parties. Appreciation is hereby expressed for the attentiveness of Ms Eleanor Lees, your defence solicitor, whose persistent and diligent representation has ensured continued advocacy through these challenges, and for Crown Counsel Ms Saira Nyong’o, whose coordination aided timely disclosure and synthesis of evidential materials. Both counsel have conducted themselves with professionalism and decorum throughout. The court is also grateful to the staff of the Coventry Retailers’ Victim Support Network, particularly Mrs Lesley Carver, whose charitable organisation has devoted considerable voluntary time to liaising with affected shops and providing victim impact statements. In the course of enumerating the evidential matrix supporting the prosecution, it is instructive to consider the precedential context. While distinct in facts, R v. Tyrell [2022] EWCA Crim 1834 remains instructive for sentencing frameworks in relation to repetitive acquisitive crime. The defendant in Tyrell engaged in multiple counts of shoplifting across a six-month period, targeting high-turnover retail outlets and deploying distraction techniques. The Court of Appeal therein emphasised the aggravating effect of premeditation and repeated offending, affirming a custodial sentence where interventionist approaches had failed to deter recidivism. Similarly, in R v. Simmonds [2023] EWCA Crim 395, the appellate court underscored factors including the erosion of staff morale and the indirect economic consequences borne by small business proprietors as weighty considerations when calibrating the severity of punishment. Though these cases diverge in contextual specifics from the matter at bar, the underlying principles remain cogent and provide a judicial backdrop for sentencing deliberations. Mr H placed protein powder and razor blade refills in his niece’s pushchair in an attempt to hide them. The court further notes the limitation of community diversion efforts in your history. You were subject to a conditional caution in 2023 for a related offence, coupled with engagement on a pilot theft prevention scheme organised by the Coventry Crime Reduction Partnership. Despite these initiatives, your offending persisted, evidencing a lack of responsiveness to non-custodial interventions. The circumstances of your offending reveal a sustained and deliberate pattern. Surveillance footage from multiple outlets depicts a consistent modus operandi: targeted selection of items—often high-value cosmetics and over-the-counter medicines—carried out during identified shift changes or periods of reduced staffing. On occasion, you were observed to use concealment tactics such as layered clothing or bags switched to avoid detection. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. In some instances, your conduct extended beyond mere appropriation and involved the removal or disabling of electronic security tags, an act which necessitated the duplication or improper usage of store devices. Store managers have provided statements describing not only the material loss but the resultant atmosphere of anxiety and insecurity felt by staff. A number of employees disclosed altered shift patterns and expressed anxiety sufficient to consider seeking transfers—indicative of the wider operational impact of your conduct. It is worth mentioning that the broader retail environment has become increasingly strained, with increasing reports of shop staff turnover and early retirement linked directly to workplace stress in theft-affected stores. These are matters to which the court must have regard, as the social fabric sustaining commercial stability is inextricably connected to the wellbeing of individual workers. In a deliberate act of distraction, Mr H engaged staff in a conversation about Oyster Cards while covertly removing a display item from behind the counter. This court has observed, with some concern, a recurring phenomenon in which the pressures on frontline services—be they police, probation, or health-related—are compounded by cumulative low-level offending. The Legal Aid Agency, notwithstanding its stated commitment to facilitating fair access to justice, has in this district manifested procedural shortcomings including protracted approval processes for expert instructions and delayed authorisation for guardian ad litem appointments in family law proceedings. While these do not pertain directly to your charges, the systemic nature of such delays impacts the wider administration of justice and by extension the lives of defendants awaiting resolution. The Local Authority Housing Department has submitted correspondence dated 21 June 2025, outlining ongoing challenges associated with increased homelessness and temporary accommodation allocations within the region. The linkages between housing instability, financial insecurity, and acquisitive offending have been the focus of contemporary criminological studies, though one must resist simplistic causal attributions. The court recognises that these wider social determinants create a complex background but insists that accountability remains paramount. Among unrelated, yet strikingly illustrative case material furnished to this court was a local prosecution relating to the use of counterfeit currency at a Coventry car boot sale, prosecuted in early 2024. While entirely separate, it highlights the diversity of acquisitive behaviours that occupy judicial attention. The Crown submits that, notwithstanding the lack of direct violence or threats, your offending has had a deleterious cumulative impact such that a deterrent and rehabilitative sentence is essential. The factual network supporting this position is built upon multiple items of direct and circumstantial evidence, including forensic collection of recovered goods and detailed witness testimonies. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. The compilation of victim impact statements, prepared by the Coventry Retailer Liaison Unit, reveal the profound psychological effect upon those who regularly serve the public. One staff member, Ms Hannah Pearson, described losing “all sense of safety” at work following repeated thefts, necessitating counselling and prolonged leave. Another, a store manager with over 20 years’ experience, lamented the financial and emotional toll taken upon small-scale retailers operating on thin margins. This evidence serves to amplify the seriousness with which the court must treat the persistent disregard for property rights demonstrated in your conduct. The defendant said he had sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in pubs, with his presence causing concern among other customers. At the plea and trial preparation hearing on 17 June 2025, you elected to enter a guilty plea in respect of the charge, having previously maintained a not guilty stance. You were afforded credit for this plea, although the timing—mere weeks prior to the anticipated trial—warrants moderation of any discount in accordance with established jurisprudence, as articulated in R v. McLaren [2019] EWCA Crim 1122, which reduced the maximum available credit for late pleas in shoplifting cases. Your history reveals antecedents including previous convictions for shoplifting, as well as minor public order offences, none of which involved the use or threat of violence. There is no evidence of gang association or organised criminal enterprise in your case. This court further notes that you have declined various probation service offers for intervention, which may have assisted in addressing underlying factors. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while blinding cameras using aerosol paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. The most recent pre-sentence report, prepared by Senior Probation Officer Fiona Carrick dated 29 July 2025, provides a comprehensive assessment of your offending pattern, social circumstances, and risk profile. The report identifies medium risk of serious harm primarily attributable to acquisitive offending, consistent with impulsive traits outlined in the psychiatric assessment. It underscores your continued unstable accommodation status and lack of sustained employment as contributors to reoffending risk. Offender engagement with community services has been sporadic and inconsistent. Recommendations include enrolment on a Cognitive Behavioural Programme tailored to theft offenders, exploration of substance misuse treatment options, and enhanced financial management support. Ms Carrick’s report expresses concern that without structured intervention, the risk of reoffending remains significant. Furthermore, this court must consider the established framework set out in the Sentencing Council Definitive Guideline on Theft Offences (reissued 2020), which emphasises factors such as harm, culpability, premeditation, and mitigating circumstances. While this was not a high-value single theft, the cumulative impact, deliberate planning, and failure to desist following prior warnings place this offending in a higher culpability bracket. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. It is incumbent here to recognise that the court, while exercising its duty to protect the public and uphold the rule of law, also endeavours to ensure sentencing outcomes that are not merely punitive but orientated towards rehabilitation where feasible. The prospect of community-based remedies including rehabilitation activity requirements or unpaid work may be considered where suitable. However, your repeated failure to engage with non-custodial measures necessitates careful reflection on the proportionality of any custodial element. The court is mindful that in recent years, pressures on probation resourcing have escalated dramatically, with caseloads increasing disproportionately to staffing capacity, leading in some areas to delays in assessment and intervention delivery. These strains are recorded in annual Ministry of Justice reports and impact the speed and efficacy of rehabilitative efforts. You were previously provided with opportunities for diversion from prosecution, including a conditional caution in 2023, which you breached. This pattern illustrates a troubling resistance to authority and an unwillingness to avail yourself consistently of support measures. It remains essential for the judge, in balancing the aims of punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection, to weigh carefully all contextual information, including your personal circumstances, the factual matrix of the offending, and pre-existing vulnerabilities as identified in professional reports. Nothing in that process ought to infantilise or excuse criminal responsibility. The court is advised that sentencing will not take place today, pending receipt of an updated pre-sentence report to be furnished within the next four weeks. This will incorporate any further psychiatric or psychological assessments, as well as the views of the probation officer, to assist in a fully informed sentencing decision. These sentencing remarks are accordingly issued this day, 14 August 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Coventry. Proceedings have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of the right of appeal against sentence within 28 days under statutory provisions including the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT HARLOW R v. MR H Case No. H2025/20389 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge R. J. Calverley Filed: 17 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced in respect of a theft offence, namely shoplifting, contrary to section 1(1) of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct, over which this court must exercise its judgment, spans a number of months and involves multiple retail establishments situated within the Harlow and surrounding Essex areas. Procedural Background The charge arises following an investigation that commenced in late 2024 and culminated in your arrest on 12 February 2025. The investigatory process was multi-layered, engaging the resources of the Harlow Borough Police Service alongside the Business Crime Reduction Unit and local trading standards officers. Over the investigative period, a series of reports from various retail outlets—ranging from chain supermarkets to independent pharmacies—highlighted persistent losses attributable to unidentified thefts, eventually linked by surveillance and forensic analysis to your person. The Business Crime Reduction Partnership (BCRP) in Harlow, created as part of a national initiative to foster cross-agency cooperation, played a prominent role by collating incident reports, sharing premises’ risk profiles, and facilitating communications between victim retailers and law enforcement. While the BCRP system theoretically offers a coordinated response mechanism, this court is aware that operational effectiveness often depends on local funding stability and staff retention levels. Unfortunately, recent budget pressures have caused disruptions in coverage, an issue lamented by many front-line police officers tasked with crime deterrence and victim liaison. Nevertheless, in this matter, it appears that the partnership fulfilled its core responsibilities in a timely manner. The investigation that led to your apprehension involved the analysis of CCTV footage from multiple sites—some of which had incomplete or overlapping recordings—alongside witness statements gathered from retail staff and customers. Mobile phone location data, critical to linking your movements with particular incidents, was obtained pursuant to a judicially sanctioned warrant after appropriate application brought by the prosecution. The use of digital evidence in Theft Act cases has increased in recent years; however, such technological assistance also imposes significant evidential and procedural burdens, particularly in the safeguarding of lawful privacy rights and compliance with data protection obligations. An initial hearing was held on 17 February 2025 before the Harlow Magistrates’ Court, where you were bailed on strict conditions pending further proceedings. Your representatives—the firm of J. Willard & Co. solicitors—promptly applied for a Legal Aid funding certificate for the instruction of expert evidence, including a forensic behavioural analyst and a clinical psychologist to assist with mitigation. While the grant of such authorities is expected under the current Legal Aid framework, this court records considerable frustration with the delays experienced in this instance. Authorisation was only confirmed on 22 April 2025 after protracted correspondence and escalating chaser letters, a regrettable circumstance which has become, in this judge’s experience, increasingly common and detrimental to case progression. Your case was transferred to this Crown Court pursuant to the Better Case Management guidelines in place since 2019. These guidelines aim to streamline criminal proceedings by pre-emptively identifying evidential issues, limiting unnecessary adjournments, and fostering early guilty pleas wherever appropriate. Early hearings scheduled for 11 March and 14 May 2025 were, respectively, adjourned on your defence's application in order to secure views from expert witnesses and to take account of further disclosure. While such applications are entirely within your procedural rights, their repeated use underscores the delicate balancing act courts confront in managing finite resources and the individual right to a full and fair trial. It bears noting that the Crown and defence teams have conducted themselves with professional courtesy throughout, albeit within the constraints imposed by case complexity and system pressures. I take this opportunity to thank Ms Eleanor Braithwaite, appearing on behalf of the Crown Prosecution Service, and Mr Julian Hirst, representing you under a Legal Aid representation order. The legal question before this court is how to appropriately respond to your offending, recognising both statutory principles of sentencing and the overarching public interest. We find ourselves in an age where retail theft, particularly shoplifting, constitutes an increasing proportion of acquisitive crime reported nationally. However, one must resist simplistic narratives that attempt to justify this trend solely on socio-economic grounds. While the post-pandemic economic downturn and rising cost of living have undeniably exacerbated vulnerabilities, the persistence and frequency of offences such as those before the court also reflect a complex interplay of factors including systemic challenges in policing, evolving criminal opportunism, and the shifting dynamics of social control. The court is conscious that shoplifting offences impose both tangible and intangible costs: the shrinkage of business assets, increased insurance premiums, anxiety and stress among retail workers who often face threats or confrontations, and broader reputational damage to neighbourhoods and commercial districts struggling to maintain vitality. The work of local charity groups such as “SafeStreet Harlow” and “Essex Retail Victims Support” deserves recognition. These organisations—operating largely on constrained funding and volunteer input—offer counselling and practical assistance to affected individuals and businesses, frequently serving as the first point of support when statutory channels either fail or are overwhelmed. Their contributions form an essential part of the ecosystem of crime prevention and community resilience, which courts hope will be supported rather than undermined by judicial approaches to sentencing. It is unfortunate, but necessary, to observe that there is a tendency towards the normalisation of certain forms of anti-social behaviour, including low-level theft, in some communities. This shifts the demarcation between lawful and unlawful conduct in public consciousness, threatening to corrode respect for legal norms and public order. While social policy debates rage over causes and remedies, the courts remain steadfast in their role to uphold the rule of law and administer proportionate justice. Against this backdrop, attention must be given to the strain placed on frontline law enforcement by so-called “volume crime.” Resources allocated to street-level theft nonetheless detract from investigation of serious offences such as violent crime, organised drug markets, or threats of domestic extremism. Such opportunity costs are difficult to quantify but emphasise the wider impact of offending beyond the immediate victim or defendant. In this vein, the recidivism of repeat shoplifters remains a perennial challenge. Probation services, tasked with supervising community sanctions and rehabilitative programmes, report chronic under-staffing and resource limitations. Waiting lists for cognitive behavioural therapy aimed at reducing offending behaviour extend into many months, and mental health trusts themselves face substantial demand. The knock-on effect is that many defendants receive limited intervention beyond rudimentary curfew or electronic monitoring measures. It is in this systemic context that your personal circumstances must be considered. The Theft Act 1968, specifically section 1(1), defines theft as the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention to permanently deprive them of it. While offences of this nature may vary in scale, the courts recognise that repeated or organised shoplifting constitutes more serious conduct meriting enhanced sentencing. Sentencing must be directed by section 142 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, under which the overarching considerations are denunciation, deterrence, protection of the public, and rehabilitation. Custody is to be a last resort, reserved for cases crossing the custodial threshold as set forth in the Sentencing Council guideline for Theft and Burglary Offences (2021). Recent appellate decisions continue to provide clarifying guidance. In R v Ellison [2023] EWCA Crim 334, the Court underscored that the cumulative effect of multiple low-value thefts within a date range may support a representative charge but does not diminish the seriousness of repeated dishonesty, particularly when conducted systematically. Ellison involved a defendant who targeted high-value cosmetics across 12 separate stores, using distraction techniques and altering appearance between incidents. The Court found no error in the imposition of a 14-month custodial sentence, observing that deterrence of predictive reoffending was paramount. Similarly, in R v Daniels [2022] EWCA Crim 1127, the defendant was convicted of theft involving a coordinated group trafficking stolen goods. Although your case does not implicate organised crime, the judgment emphasises that sentencing is informed by offender culpability, degree of planning, and actual or potential harm, considerations all relevant here. I also refer with interest to R v Lester [2020] EWCA Crim 2021, where the court upheld a suspended sentence for a first-time shoplifter whose contrition and engagement with rehabilitation services mitigated risk. While differing in context and facts, Lester is relevant insofar as it illustrates the importance of offender cooperation and uptake of support. Mr H concealed £19 worth of nail polish and beauty accessories in his clothing and exited the premises without payment. Mr H deliberately used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and a container of protein powder. The prosecution’s case is predicated on a body of evidence including CCTV footage from multiple retail premises, witness statements from staff and security, and forensic examination of items recovered during your arrest. Your clothing bore fibres matching those found near the point of concealment in several incidents. Consistent sartorial choices were noted throughout a series of offences, aiding identification alongside transactional timestamps and your habitual presence in these locations. Your conduct appears to have involved the systematic concealment of items within bags and under clothing, with occasional tampering of security tags and in at least one instance, the use of an accomplice to distract staff while goods were removed. No violence or threat thereof was employed, but the repetitive nature and sophistication of the acts demonstrate a degree of planning and intent beyond a spur-of-the-moment lapse. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. It is pertinent that no physical harm occurred to retail employees or other customers, a fact which, while deserving of recognition, does not diminish the wider consequences. Chronic loss from stock shrinkage has contributed to store closures and reduced local economic diversity in the flagged high streets. Staff morale and feelings of personal safety have likewise been impacted, as reflected in witness testimony from management at affected stores. Mr H feigned interest in Oyster Card payments to distract the cashier and reached behind the counter to take an item from the display. A magnet was used by The defendant to detach a security tag, and this item was found in his possession at the time of his arrest. An independent clinical assessment was commissioned from Dr Sally Hemingway, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, instructed on your behalf. Dr Hemingways's report, dated 6 September 2025, concludes that you suffer from no major mental health disorder. However, she notes traits of impulsivity and an emerging pattern compatible with mild substance misuse disorder, primarily involving alcohol. There is no evidence of psychosis, cognitive impairment, or significant personality pathology. Recommendations include engagement with community-based addiction services and cognitive-behavioural therapy focusing on impulsivity control. The report observes that effective intervention could reduce reoffending risk, particularly if accompanied by stable accommodation and employment. In addition, Probation Service submitted a pre-sentence report dated 10 October 2025. The author, Senior Probation Officer Janet Monroe, highlights moderate levels of risk of acquisitive reoffending, compounded by your unstable housing status and lack of meaningful employment. There is a noted history of inconsistent engagement with support services and prior convictions for low-level theft. Ms Monroe expresses guarded optimism regarding your potential for rehabilitation but stresses the need for structured supervision combined with access to substance misuse treatment and financial management courses. She also recommends exploration of restorative justice opportunities, which some retailers have expressed openness to participating in. It is worth pausing to remark on the probative value of such reports in enabling the court to formulate a sentencing strategy that aligns with both public protection and the aspirational goal of offender rehabilitation. The derived assessments form critical inputs into the sentencing matrix, balancing punishment with practical opportunities for change. The defendant told officers that he sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in nearby pubs, causing alarm to members of the public. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, triggering distress and security concerns. Victim statements from retail proprietors and staff underscore the psychological and economic toll wrought by your offending. Many report increased anxiety during shifts, leading some employees to request relocation or reduction in hours for wellbeing. One pharmacy manager relating to a small independent business detailed lost sales margins, the cost of additional security measures including installation of CCTV upgrades, and the stress engendered among the workforce. It is not uncommon for small businesses, already stretched by rising utility costs and post-pandemic recovery challenges, to be disproportionately affected by persistent theft. As some outlets close or downsize, displaced workers face unemployment or underemployment, exacerbating local socio-economic deprivation. Such community impact often escapes facile quantification but remains a compelling factor in judicial consideration of harm and culpability. In the course of this trial, I have noted various systemic pressures impacting all involved: from court clerks operating under staff shortages to delays in evidence collation caused by stretched police forensic departments, who are obliged to prioritise violent and serious crime investigations above lower-level offences. The Magistrates’ Court listing office experienced disruption due to industrial action on three separate occasions during 2025, contributing indirectly to adjournments in this case. The Legal Aid Agency’s convoluted administrative requirements and procurement delays—though increasingly contentious—nonetheless remain a vital, if strained, safeguard ensuring representation. It is incumbent on the justice system to advocate for reforms that minimise procedural delay while protecting defendants’ rights. Additionally, the involvement of third-sector organisations such as “Streetwise Support Network” has been instrumental in providing ancillary services to individuals in precarious circumstances, including hostel outreach and benefits advice. These functions supplement statutory provision and mitigate risk factors associated with acquisitive offending but face chronic funding shortfalls. It is within this broader social and institutional fabric—that presents formidable challenges—that courts must apply the law. Mr H stated in interview that he frequently takes items, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. The sentencing exercise requires careful balance: to reflect the gravity of your offences, to protect the public, to deter similar conduct by others, and to promote your rehabilitation prospects. The timing of your guilty plea is acknowledged, albeit at a relatively late stage after evidence became overwhelming. This attracts a modest reduction in sentence in accordance with the Credit for Early Guilty Plea guidelines under paragraph 1.3 of the Sentencing Council’s Manual. Your personal mitigation pertaining to financial hardship, periods of unstable housing, and reported family difficulties have been fully considered. However, it must be underscored that hardship does not excuse repeated dishonesty. Where community support services have been offered and declined, the court is entitled to treat this as an aggravating rather than mitigating factor. The principle that individuals have a duty to take reasonable steps to address underlying causes of offending behaviour is well established. Comparative case law instructs that persistent acquisition of property by deception or theft over a sustained timeframe tends to elevate culpability. The absence of violence is material but does not lessen the serious consequences for victims and the wider community. I order the preparation of a detailed pre-sentence report with specific enquiry into: - Participation in accredited cognitive behavioural programme targeting acquisitive offending; - Suitability for a community order with unpaid work; - Availability of addiction treatment, including alcohol cessation support; - Assessment of housing stability and engagement with relevant local housing authorities; - Consideration of restorative justice options agreeable to victims. The court anticipates that the pre-sentence report will address the likely need for structured supervision balanced against realistic prospects of engagement. Conclusion Today's hearing has been conducted in open court, attended by prosecution and defence counsel, with all procedural safeguards observed. I thank all parties for their submissions, which have been detailed and professionally presented. Particular note is made of the cooperation received from the Probation Service and expert medical staff who have provided timely reports. I also acknowledge the dedication of court staff, ushers, and clerks who maintain the conduct of business with commendable efficiency despite increasing workloads. Having considered all material before me, including statutory guidelines, case law, reports, victim impact statements, and defence representations, I reserve the matter for sentence at a date to be fixed after receipt of the outstanding pre-sentence report. These are the sentencing remarks of His Honour Judge R. J. Calverley, issued this day, 17 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Harlow. The proceedings have been duly recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. You are reminded of the right to appeal this sentence pursuant to section 108 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. The question of costs is reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT MANCHESTER R v. MR H Case No. T2026/04158 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. A. GRAYSON Filed: 14 September 2026 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced on a charge of theft, specifically multiple counts of shoplifting conducted over a period stretching from late 2024 to mid-2026. This offending has primarily involved retail premises situated throughout the Greater Manchester conurbation, encompassing independent stores and larger commercial outlets alike. The indictment consolidates these numerous acts into a single count, reflecting the court’s approach to cumulative conduct as forming a course of criminal behaviour. Procedural and Investigative Context Your arrest was effected on 25 July 2026 following an extensive investigation initiated by the Manchester Retail Crime Taskforce, a body convened to tackle the proliferation of shop thefts which has exerted palpable strain on local businesses and policing resources. The investigation was the product of concerted multi-agency efforts, including liaison with the Manchester Business Crime Reduction Group, input from local trading standards officers, and the proactive deployment of covert surveillance across premises identified as high-risk. Such investigative measures, while increasingly necessary, constitute a considerable diversion of scarce public resources. Attending to what many might dismiss as “low-level” offending can, paradoxically, demand a disproportionate commitment of specialist manpower, digital forensic expertise, and administrative capacity. The court is acutely aware, from discussions with senior officers and policy colleagues, that dedicated police teams often find themselves hindered by the volume and persistence of these crimes, which cumulatively sap momentum from more serious investigative priorities, including those addressing violent offences, drug trafficking, and organised crime syndicates operating at a macro scale. It is a regrettable truth that repeated retail theft — despite the relatively modest value of items stolen — can cumulatively produce serious economic and social dislocation. Damage to staff morale, increased security costs, store closures, and the withdrawal of services from fragile communities are but some consequences. The broader social fallout is manifestly felt, especially when shoplifting targets are small, locally owned businesses that often serve disadvantaged neighbourhoods. Your case has unfolded amid the ongoing evolution of criminal case management processes. The Better Case Management system, introduced to accelerate evidence assessment, streamline disclosure, and minimise adjournments, was engaged here, reflecting the Crown Court’s commitment to procedural efficiency. The case was marked by scheduling challenges, notably the temporary unavailability of key witness statements and delays occasioned by competing lists, but overall progression was consistent with official timelines. The court acknowledges the diligent efforts of the Crown Prosecution Service to coordinate effectively with law enforcement and business stakeholders to bring your case expeditiously before the court. Following your initial custody and charge on 27 July, you made your first court appearance on 2 August. The proceedings have since encompassed a plea and trial preparation hearing, during which you maintained a not guilty plea, denying involvement. This plea was reconsidered only at the outset of the scheduled trial in September, when you elected instead to enter a guilty plea to the representative count. Mr H was seen slipping £11 worth of personal hygiene products into his jacket before leaving the shop without paying. Your change of plea at this late stage, while ultimately consistent with the evidence presented, cannot attract the full measure of credit contemplated by sentencing guidelines. It is a regrettably habitual pattern in many acquisitive crime cases whereby defendants delay admission of guilt until trial preparation has essentially concluded, thereby imposing avoidable strain on witnesses, police, and court processes. The precedent of R v. Davies [2019] EWCA Crim 412 establishes that such tardy pleas warrant limited discount, serving to balance the interests of justice and procedural economy. Mr H concealed boxed razor cartridges and a tub of protein powder beneath items in his niece’s pram. The Court’s reflection on your conduct is informed by detailed witness statements, CCTV footage submitted by various retailers, and forensic analysis indicating the repeated nature of your offending. The offences display a matrix of deliberate planning — including selection of low-staffed time periods, utilisation of concealment techniques, and occasional use of accomplices unknown to the court and as yet unprosecuted. While your own role has been singular, the context is not devoid of complexity. It is appropriate to recognise the collaborative efforts of the Manchester Retail Crime Reduction Group (MRCRG), whose reports have shed light on the cumulative effects of your offences beyond what raw figures might convey. The MRCRG's interventions have included improvements to store layout, staff training in theft prevention, and community education initiatives. The Group’s recent quarterly report emphasised the uptick in “displacement tactics” employed by repeat offenders, noting a concurrent rise in what they term “flash thefts” designed to exploit momentary vulnerabilities during peak hours. Moreover, victim impact statements submitted on behalf of several small businesses paint a picture of anxiety and economic hardship. One such witness described how the repeated thefts led to the reduction of opening hours for fear of theft accruing during unstaffed intervals, a measure that consequently adversely affected customer access and employee income. It is clear that the intangible harms wrought by your behaviour extend into social and economic domains, compounding the direct loss of stock. Mr H made four trips to the same cornershop over a three-week period, consistently targeting alcohol and cigarettes. The court also notes the correspondence received from the North West Retail Workers’ Union expressing particular concern over the mental health toll that repeated thefts impose on frontline staff. The Union highlighted increased reports of workplace stress, absenteeism, and in some cases, the need for clinical interventions. While these impacts are difficult to measure with precision, their resonance with lived experience must not be overlooked. The foregoing underscores that, while shoplifting may seem a minor offence on paper, its reverberations within communities and the commercial ecosystem can be profound. It is a salutary reminder that sentencing must account for the aggregate effects when determining an appropriate sanction. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. The Probation Service has produced a comprehensive pre-sentence report, following interviews with yourself, feedback from family members, and evaluation of your engagement with prior community orders. Unfortunately, the report documents a limited history of compliance and support uptake, indicating a pattern of superficial engagement rather than substantive rehabilitation. Further to a court direction, a psychiatric evaluation was undertaken by Dr Amanda Reid, a consultant forensic psychiatrist specialising in impulsivity disorders and acquisitive crime. Dr Reid’s report, filed on 30 August, was detailed and professionally composed, offering insight into your mental state and possible contributory factors. While the assessment concluded that you do not meet diagnostic criteria for a major mental illness or personality disorder, it identified tendencies consistent with impulse control difficulties interlaced with chronic situational anxiety. The report cautiously recommended intensive cognitive-behavioural therapy addressing decision-making patterns and distress tolerance. This position aligns with emerging evidence regarding the efficacy of targeted psychological interventions for acquisitive offenders exhibiting impulsivity without broader psychopathology. The defendant used a magnetic device to disable the security tag, and this was later recovered when Mr H was arrested. Notwithstanding these recommendations, the report underscores your limited motivation to engage with voluntary services and notes a degree of ambivalence expressed during interview, often manifested as minimisation and rationalisation of offending behaviour. Such attitudes are well-recognised impediments to effective rehabilitation and elevate concern regarding likelihood of recidivism absent punitive measures. Your background is marked by periods of housing instability and fluctuating familial support, detailed extensively in the probation report. The court is mindful of the challenging socio-economic landscape and the frequent shortfall in specialist resources, particularly within mental health and social care systems. NHS waiting lists for psychological therapy in Greater Manchester are known to be long; capacity constraints pose systemic barriers to timely intervention. Nonetheless, while acknowledging these difficulties, the court must balance empathetic understanding against accountability and public safety imperatives. Many defendants face similar or greater barriers yet manage to maintain lawful conduct. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. The Legal Aid Agency’s involvement in this matter has been noted with some concern. The defence’s applications for funding to obtain expert advice, delayed by repeated administrative requests and protracted authorisation processes, resulted in the psychiatric report being filed a mere two weeks prior to sentencing. These bureaucratic delays, increasingly frequent in contemporary practice, hinder prompt justice and strain all parties involved. The Crown and defence counsel have fulfilled their roles with professionalism. I thank Miss Olivia Kent for the Crown and Mr Jacob Mills for the defence, both of whom have conducted proceedings with appropriate decorum and respect for court processes. Section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 defines theft as the dishonest appropriation of property, with intent to permanently deprive the owner of that property. Though shoplifting may be regarded as a “minor” offence in some circles, persistent offending as exhibited here engages intensified sentencing scrutiny. The Sentencing Council guidelines on theft offences articulate a framework that considers culpability, harm, and mitigating or aggravating factors. Crucially, a course of conduct spanning multiple incidents, especially when involving vulnerable victims or community impact, attracts enhanced penalties. In R v. Atkinson [2024] EWCA Crim 1351, the Court affirmed that repeat offending involving planned manipulation and targeting of small businesses requires a deterrent sentence. Atkinson’s behaviour bore similarities in both methodology and impact and resulted in a custodial sentence reflecting public protection priorities. Though distinct, the facts of R v. Thompson [2023] EWCA Crim 1127 are instructive. There, the defendant’s persistent shop theft from pharmacy premises was linked to underlying substance misuse. Sentencing considerations included the offender’s engagement with structured treatment and demonstrated remorse. While your engagement has been notably less cooperative, Thompson serves to highlight the role that rehabilitation can and should play in sentencing strategy where feasible. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while blinding cameras using aerosol paint, triggering distress and security concerns. Conversely, the Court must be mindful of the ruling in R v. Grant [2025] EWCA Crim 945, which explicitly cautioned against leniency where defendants have failed to avail themselves of available support and continue to offend. Grant was a case involving repeated theft of foodstuffs from charity shops, conducted over months despite previous warnings and diversionary interventions. The Court emphasised that community safety and victim confidence require sentences that reflect the seriousness of offending as well as its persistence. By analogy, that approach informs the present case. This court cannot and does not view your offences in isolation from the broader social context in which they occurred. The empirical reality of increased street homelessness, economic precarity, and the ordinary anxieties accompanying post-pandemic recovery bear on many defendants who enter these precincts. Nevertheless, such circumstances do not excuse nor justify persistent criminal conduct. The danger exists that omission of consequence may further erode social cohesion and embolden those who would exploit vulnerabilities for personal gain. Of particular note is the strain placed upon local housing services, which, as documented in a report from the Manchester Housing Partnership dated 10 August 2026, is running at near capacity with substantial waiting lists. This environmental stress adds a difficult backdrop against which offences such as yours occur, but again cannot be permitted to distort the court’s overarching duty to uphold lawful conduct. The issue of contributory hardship was examined in the recent case of R v. Sutherland [2026] EWCA Crim 210, which clarified that while poverty and unstable housing are matters of potential mitigation, they do not provide carte blanche for criminal activity. Equally, the phenomenon of increased digital engagement in retail, including the introduction of self-scan checkouts and anonymous payment methods, has created novel opportunities for offenders but equally novel challenges for courts and law enforcement. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, claimed it wasn’t a serious crime and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. The Probation Service shall consider all rehabilitative options as part of the pre-sentence process. The possibility of structured supervision, cognitive-behavioural programmes tailored to theft-related offending, and restorative justice pathways merit exploration, balanced against an assessment of public protection requirements. Conversely, custodial sentences remain the necessary disposition where repeated defiance of law and failure to engage with support services converge in ways that jeopardise community confidence and safety. The sentencing hearing today has proceeded in open court. I acknowledge the contributions of both Crown and defence counsel and the cooperation of allied agencies. The court also notes, with respect, the challenges posed by prolonged and multifaceted investigations, as well as the systemic pressures afflicting mental health services and social support networks. It remains the responsibility of the court to impose a sentence reflective of the gravity of the offending, the need for deterrence, and your particular circumstances including personal background, prior history, and psychiatric assessment. At this juncture, however, I must reserve final judgment until receipt of the detailed pre-sentence report currently being prepared by the probation service. This report will be instrumental in framing the custodial versus community sentencing debate in this instance. I remind you of your right to appeal any sentence imposed within 28 days of the handing down of judgment. The proceedings have been duly recorded under Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5, and no reporting restrictions currently apply. These sentencing remarks are delivered this 14th day of September 2026, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Manchester. The support and decorum maintained by court officers and registry staff during this matter have been exemplary and are hereby acknowledged. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT DARTFORD R v. MR H Case No. K2025/13422 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. J. MALCOLMSON Filed: 18 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence following your conviction on a charge of theft, specifically a course of conduct involving shoplifting offences contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending behaviour extends over a significant period and encompasses multiple retail premises within the Dartford and Gravesham boroughs. Procedural History Your arrest on 16 April 2025 came after an extensive multi-agency operation involving the local Dartford Police Division, the Kent Retail Crime Partnership, and civilian security teams from several affected stores. This prolonged investigation was marked by painstaking collation of surveillance material, staff interviews, and forensic analysis. The pattern of offending was identified only after multiple incidents were reported and linked, a task that, as this court has noted repeatedly, requires significant resources and collaboration, often testing the limits of law enforcement capacity. This case was initially listed before the magistrates given the low-level nature of the thefts, but due to the cumulative value and repeat character of the incidents, the charge was committed to this Crown Court for sentence pursuant to the direction under section 51 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998. The Better Case Management (BCM) protocol has governed the progression of this matter, and the court acknowledges the efforts of all parties in adhering, as far as practicable, to the timelines set out in the Criminal Procedure Rules. It must be acknowledged that this particular case fortunately avoided some of the more common delays afflicting similar cases in the current climate. Notably, the timely instruction of counsel, the consistent communication between the Crown Prosecution Service and defence representatives, and minimal last-minute adjournments enabled the matter to proceed, albeit with some understandable procedural pauses resulting from Legal Aid Agency review processes. I commend both Ms Rebecca Lowell for the Crown and Mr Daniel Drummond for the defence for their measured and professional handling of these proceedings. The court is painfully aware, however, of the systemic issues posed by the chronic underfunding and administrative inertia pervading Legal Aid authorisations. It remains a source of ongoing concern that requests for expert reports, including psychiatric and psychological assessments, linger unanswered for extended periods — a problem that compromises effective case preparation and, in the worst cases, risks undermining defendants’ rights. It is pertinent to observe, though perhaps expeditious to note, that on this occasion funding for a forensic assessment was expeditiously granted following a protracted exchange of correspondence between Mr Drummond’s chambers and the Agency. The psychiatric report, compiled by Dr Karen Sterling, was received and served in timely fashion, enabling the court to consider it fully alongside other expert reports and victim impact statements. The defendant has entered a guilty plea at the earliest possible stage practicable, that is, at the first opportunity when the prosecution evidence had been clearly established and before the matter reached interview or trial. Credit for this plea is accordingly given in accordance with well-established jurisprudence such as R v. Liveridge [2021] EWCA Crim 1579, which underlines the importance of recognising early admissions of culpability as a mitigating factor in sentencing. We live in a time when acquisitive crimes such as shoplifting present unique challenges to local policing and community welfare. The court is reminded of the recent report by the Home Office entitled “Retail Crime and its Impact on Consumers and Businesses,” published earlier this year, which identifies a troubling increase in repeat offences affecting small and medium-sized enterprises. Whilst this case may not reflect the more organised or gang-related theft operations that feature in national statistics, it exemplifies the persistent and corrosive effect such offences have on staff morale, public confidence, and the viability of local commerce. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. In considering these facts, the court is compelled to contextualise the offence within the broader social patterns noted by commentators and researchers alike. The normalisation of low-level dishonesty and the often-trivialised status of retail theft belie the very real consequences experienced by victims — from financial loss and increased security measures to psychological distress and diminished job satisfaction. Among the many victims in this case are employees of the “Greenvale” pharmacy chain who, in written statements, have described operational disruptions necessitated by your repeated intrusions. Staff anxiety reportedly increased to the point where shift patterns were altered, with lone working discouraged during times of previous offence. Such measures are costly, disruptive, and speak to the seriousness with which these crimes are taken by businesses despite their occasional minimisation in public discourse. In the domain of case law, it would be remiss not to mention R v. Carling [2020] EWCA Crim 1231, which concerned a defendant who repeatedly stole toiletries and accessories from various convenience stores, employing distraction techniques and the use of accomplices. Although Carling involved arguments over the role of organized crime, the principles articulated regarding the impact of sustained acquisitive offending on small businesses resonate with the present circumstances. Mr H used the bottom compartment of his niece’s pram to hide razor cartridges and protein supplements. The court pauses to recall the notable judgment of Lord Justice Cooke in R v. Hodgson [2018] EWCA Crim 998, where it was reiterated that while the culpability of theft offences is necessarily assessed by reference to factors such as value, planning, and persistence, the psychological and economic toll on workers and community members requires considered weight. Beyond the immediate legal landscape, a wider phenomenon merits reflection: the escalating strain placed on local authorities and voluntary organisations by ongoing acquisitive crime. Charitable entities such as "SafeStep," which provide support and advocacy for retail workers, have reported rising numbers of clients suffering from workplace stress attributable to theft-related incidents. Their correspondence to this court highlights a systemic need for greater recognition and resources devoted to staff welfare in sectors frequently targeted by such offences. Equally, there is cause for concern regarding the capacity of probation services and rehabilitative frameworks to respond effectively to recidivist acquisitive offenders amid mounting caseloads and staff shortages. The court notes correspondence from the Kent Probation Trust underscoring the challenges posed by increased pre-sentence workload combined with the management of multi-agency public protection arrangements. The persistent imbalance between demand and resource availability is well documented and regrettably continues to hamper the delivery of tailored interventions. In a similar vein, multiple judicial authorities have commented on the benefits and limitations of community sentences in mitigating repeat offending. The report prepared by Ms Joanne Hartley, probation officer assigned to this case, provides an insightful analysis of the necessity for focused cognitive-behavioural programmes addressing impulsivity, financial management, and addiction support, all of which may be pertinent in your circumstances. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. Dr Sterling’s psychiatric evaluation, which has been given careful consideration, acknowledges that while you do not meet the criteria for any major psychiatric diagnosis, there exist significant personality traits marked by emotional dysregulation and intermittent substance misuse, which may have contributed to your criminal behaviours. She observes that these factors, coupled with socio-economic hardship and a lack of stable accommodation, present a complex and challenging rehabilitation profile. It is unfortunate that, despite previous offers, your engagement with available support services has been inconsistent. This is regrettable not only from the standpoint of your own wellbeing but also in terms of the broader imperative to reduce reoffending and protect the public. The court must emphasise that access to community resources, while important, cannot substitute for individual commitment. In a deliberate act of distraction, Mr H engaged staff in a conversation about Oyster Cards while covertly removing a display item from behind the counter. The sentencing framework in cases of theft has developed over many years. The Sentencing Council's definitive guideline on Theft Offences (September 2021) provides comprehensive structure for assessing seriousness and appropriate ranges of penalty. Aggravating factors include persistence, targeting of vulnerable victims, and previous convictions; mitigating factors may encompass early guilty pleas, genuine remorse, and demonstrable efforts to address underlying causes. Among the principles reinforced by appellate courts is the limited, though important, role of personal circumstances in outweighing public protection objectives. In R v. Newell [2019] EWCA Crim 1457, it was stressed that courts must balance compassion with deterrence and the need to uphold societal expectations of responsibility. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. The courts do not lose sight of the difficult social environment in which many offenders find themselves. The rising prevalence of street homelessness, as widely reported in regional studies last year, and the resulting risks of exploitation, substance misuse, and mental health deterioration, all contribute to an environment conducive to criminal behaviour. However, as Lord Justice O’Connor noted in R v. Sidhu [2023] EWCA Crim 2125, these factors should inform but never dominate sentencing determinations. Your personal history, while replete with challenges, falls within this familiar category. The chronicity of offending despite multiple interventions underlines the complexity faced by those attempting rehabilitation. It also highlights the importance of public protection considerations, particularly given the risk of escalation or diversification of offending behaviour if left unchecked. The defendant admitted taking the stolen items to sell at local pubs and a car boot sale, where members of the public were disturbed. The court must consider also the broader context of multi-agency collaboration in the management of offending risk. The Kent Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) have developed refined strategies for risk assessment and offender management, but their focus naturally remains on higher-level risks – violent, sexual, or organised crime. Low-level acquisitive offending does not typically engage MAPPA protocols but nevertheless demands attention from local safeguarding partnerships to prevent entrenchment and harm to communities. It is notable that the defendant’s previous interactions with police and probation authorities, according to recorded case files, display a sporadic pattern of engagement, with several referrals to diversion programmes failing to yield sustained outcomes. The probation note dated 1 August 2024 records the defendant’s disengagement from a community order imposed then for similar offences. Such patterns constrain sentencing options and inform the court’s assessment of appropriate custodial or community-based sanctions. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. The evidence confirms that your offending conduct has been deliberate, calculated, and repeated despite previous warnings. Items targeted were often high-demand consumer goods such as health and beauty products or over-the-counter medicines — goods readily resalable and thus of continuing interest to offenders motivated by financial gain. Accounts from retail managers depict a palpable sense of disruption not only to operational efficiency but also to staff morale. The fear of collision with a known offender during lone shifts and the subsequent stress symptoms reported by employees were corroborated by a workplace health and safety audit commissioned in April 2025. Such intangible harms are often overlooked in the quantification of loss but speak to a broader societal cost. The impact of your conduct on the willingness of small business owners to maintain storefronts in vulnerable areas, or on local economies as a whole, though hard to measure precisely, must nonetheless be recognised. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, said it was no different to borrowing and expects to do it again soon. The court further notes that the present case does not involve allegations of violence or threats thereof. Your conduct, whilst persistent and damaging, appears confined to non-violent means, which ought to be considered when calibrating an appropriate sentence. Nevertheless, it should be understood that non-violent offences may nonetheless inflict serious psychological distress and cumulative harm. It is also important, in a reasonable exercise of discretion, to refrain from conflating this case with offences committed by unconnected co-defendants or associates, or the importation of drugs and other serious crime in the local area which, while concerning, bear no factual relevance here. In a recent judgment, R v. Delaney [2024] EWCA Crim 3032, the Court of Appeal dealt with the issue of co-defendant conduct in multi-party cases and reminded sentencing judges of the necessity to isolate personal culpability from that of others. The present proceedings comply fully with that principle: the focus is solely on your actions and responsibility. In determining the disposition in this case, the court must weigh the seriousness of your repeated, opportunistic offending and the harm caused, against any mitigating personal circumstances and prospects for rehabilitation. Whilst your guilty plea is noted and welcomed, it comes against a backdrop of multiple prior convictions and unsuccessful diversion attempts. This pattern signals a degree of persistence that requires decisive intervention. The court must balance the need to protect retail staff and the public, to deter others, and to foster rehabilitation. At sentencing, the court will consider all available options, including custodial sentences, community orders incorporating rehabilitative requirements such as accredited Thinking Skills Programmes, unpaid work, and attendance at drug and alcohol support services should these be recommended. It is essential that the sentence imposed is proportionate, structured to reduce risk, and mindful of the broader interests of justice. Accordingly, the court directs that a comprehensive pre-sentence report be prepared forthwith, addressing not only your offending history and personal circumstances but also any identified mental health concerns, accommodation stability, and willingness to engage with support services. The report should explore the suitability and feasibility of community-based sentences, conditions likely to promote compliance, and the likelihood of desistance. I note that the hearing today has been conducted in open court, with due regard to the interests of all parties. I thank Ms Rebecca Lowell and Mr Daniel Drummond for their efforts, and acknowledge the invaluable assistance of forensic and probation professionals whose input has informed these remarks. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal sentence within 28 days under the relevant legislation. There are no reporting restrictions or anonymity orders at this stage. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 October 2025, in Court 6 at Dartford Crown Court. The proceedings are transcribed in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be sent to the appropriate authorities for processing. These are the orders of the court.
