input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. T2026/04538 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge C. D. Hargraves Filed: 17 September 2026 Mr H, you appear before this court today charged with theft from retail premises pursuant to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct, which you now admit, spans an extended timeframe of some 18 months, principally occurring within multiple commercial districts across the Greater Bristol area including but not limited to the Harbourside and Clifton shopping precincts. Procedural History Your case has proceeded through various procedural milestones typical of the Crown Court locus for such offending, including plea and trial preparation hearings, in accordance with the Better Case Management (BCM) framework as set out within the Criminal Procedure Rules. The BCM initiative was established to streamline the timeliness and preparation of cases heard in the Crown Court and to ensure evidential clarity from an early stage. I note that in the present instance, there have been delays beyond the usual targets due largely to procedural matters connected with expert report acquisition and Legal Aid funding approvals. Applications for Legal Aid to fund a forensic psychologist specialising in acquisitive offending behaviour were initially lodged on 15 July 2026 but, regrettably, were only authorised after multiple resubmissions and substantial correspondence between defence solicitors and the Legal Aid Agency, prolonging the preparatory phase. Such administrative inertia is by now an unfortunate hallmark of many courtroom proceedings and continues to place strain both on the defence and the court system alike. The initial charge was presented following your arrest on 3 May 2026 after the conclusion of an investigation coordinated by the Avon and Somerset Constabulary, leveraging resources from the Bristol Business Crime Partnership and local shopkeeper liaison officers. This investigation was underpinned by a process of cumulative evidence collection, encompassing recorded video surveillance, witness statements from employees and store managers, and forensic examination of recovered property. This case also saw the involvement of the Gloucestershire Retail Theft Task Unit, which, while not having jurisdiction over the offence locations, provided intelligence sharing on persons of interest carrying suspect histories of repeat offences, enabling a broader assessment of patterns and potential associative behaviour. The pooling of multi-agency information is commendable, notwithstanding variations in data retention policies and operational protocols—which are frequently challenging in cross-force crime responsiveness. It is worth pausing to recognise the tireless efforts of store staff who, despite typically limited training and resources, are expected to perform functions akin to front-line investigators and custodians of corporate asset protection. Their bereft morale, irritably expressed via formal complaints about the inadequacy of security support, is nevertheless juxtaposed against the stoic persistence they maintain in the face of repeat offending. For context, the court notes that this year—similar to trends observable in South West England—retail theft incidents reportedly increased by approximately 14%, as documented in the Avon and Somerset Constabulary’s annual report on acquisitive crimes. These statistics mirror national-level trajectories observed in the Office for National Statistics Crime Survey data, underscoring the persistent challenge retail theft poses to both business viability and community safety. The prosecuting Crown has been represented throughout by Ms Emma Hargrove, QC, whose detailed submissions have been both precise and measured, drawing upon extensive case precedents addressing repeat theft and community impact. Your defence team has been ably led by Mr Rohan Bailey of counsel, instructed under a current representation order. While this sentencing hearing has been held in open court, it is pertinent to observe the continuing public disinterest the matter reflects, with no media attendance recorded despite the court’s location within an urban centre. This absence is emblematic of the wider phenomenon of diminished public engagement where crimes lack sensationalism, revealing a disconnect between the quotidian justice administered and the public’s appetite for judicial transparency or scrutiny. Mr H, you initially entered a not guilty plea at your appearance on 20 May 2026 but subsequently altered your position to a guilty plea at the plea and trial preparation hearing on 29 July 2026 after the prosecution served additional evidence including enhanced digital footage and reconstructed transaction logs. The late plea inevitably attracts limited reduction in sentence, in line with long-standing principles reiterated in R v. Dacres [2021] EWCA Crim 1331 and R v. Lawrence [2022] EWCA Crim 1901, where the courts have made clear that timing and motivation for pleading are central to the awarding of credit. It is not the role of this court to pass judgment upon your tactical decisions but to emphasise that late pleas, though legally permissible, rarely afford significant mitigating effect absent demonstrable remorse or cooperation. This stance serves both the interests of justice and the efficient administration of court processes. Turning now to the relevant evidential and factual matrix, I shall outline the procedural history leading to today’s sentencing outcome and take account of reports and submissions tendered on your behalf and submitted in accordance with court directions. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. Before addressing the facts in detail, it is appropriate to consider the legal framework within which sentencing operates in cases of retail theft. The principal statutory authority remains the Theft Act 1968, supplemented and interpreted by a robust body of case law and sentencing guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council. The 2020 Theft Guideline establishes a structured approach to assessing culpability and harm, recognising the intrinsic tension between the value of goods stolen, the persistence and planning of offending, and the personal circumstances of the offender. While the financial value can sometimes appear modest, courts are enjoined to give significant weight to the broader impact, including the effect on victims — often store employees and small business owners — as well as the ancillary societal consequences of diminished trust in commercial environments. The Court notes that your offending involved repeated targeting of a range of premises including pharmacies, convenience stores, and boutique retailers. While no injuries or threats of violence occurred, the psychological toll and erosion of confidence among workers and proprietors are well-documented in the victim personal statements submitted by the Bristol Retail Enterprise Association. I also consider precedent cases bearing on sentencing in repeat shoplifting scenarios. In R v. Latimer [2021] EWCA Crim 947, the Court of Appeal underscored the gravity attached to repeat theft where evidence of planning and a degree of sophistication was apparent. A custodial sentence was upheld where the defendant exploited points-of-sale for financial gain and used distraction techniques to evade detection, resulting in significant loss to multiple retailers. Equally instructive is R v. Blackwell [2020] EWCA Crim 1129, which demonstrates that offences previously considered low-level must be recontextualised when committed persistently, with elevated disregard for victim impact and prior warnings. These authorities reinforce the conclusion that persistence and premeditation attract enhanced culpability, notwithstanding the individual quantum of loss. From a social policy perspective, repeated offending of this nature impacts adversely upon community cohesion and undermines public confidence in law and order. It also diverts police and regulatory resources otherwise deployable against more serious disorder or crime categories. Mr H hid boxed razor blades and protein powder among his niece’s belongings in her pram. The court acknowledges that from the outset of these proceedings, your circumstances have been described as challenging, including periods of housing instability and fluctuating employment. The defence has relied upon a series of character references and support letters, including those from the Bristol Homelessness Support Network and the Community Mental Health Outreach Service. These documents attest to your personal efforts to engage with support services, as well as outlining a history of benefit receipt and prior voluntary assistance arrangements. However, I must balance these mitigating factors against the findings of the clinical reports before the court. Dr Jonathan Meeks, forensic psychologist, was instructed to undertake a comprehensive evaluation following the initial Legal Aid approval. His report, dated 15 August 2026, provides a nuanced assessment of your mental state and offending behaviour. Dr Meeks concluded that while there was no evidence of a severe psychiatric disorder impairing responsibility, there were significant personality traits consistent with impulsivity, borderline emotional regulation, and episodic substance misuse. While these factors may modulate culpability to some extent, they do not excuse the persistence of unlawful activity. Moreover, Dr Meeks emphasises a lack of sustained engagement with therapeutic intervention opportunities offered by mental health and social services. This pattern is regrettably common among offenders with similar backgrounds, but the consequences of non-engagement must be acknowledged in assessing risk and future compliance. Mr H repeatedly targeted the same local store, returning four times in three weeks to steal alcohol and tobacco. The Probation Service pre-sentence report dated 10 September 2026 corroborates this picture. The probation officer notes your cooperation during assessment but highlights a history of intermittent compliance with statutory and voluntary programs. Past referrals to financial budgeting workshops and substance misuse counselling were poorly attended, with no demonstrable behavioural change. This poses particular concerns given the profile of acquisitive crime, where impulsivity and financial desperation frequently intertwine. There remains a medium level of risk for further offending unless proactive engagement and support are sustained. The report sets out recommendations for a structured community penalty incorporating rehabilitative elements adapted to identified criminogenic needs. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. To contextualise the seriousness of your conduct, it is worth recalling that alongside the shoplifting offences directly attributable to you, investigations disclosed the involvement of two co-defendants whose activities, while overlapping temporally and geographically with your offences, are distinct in nature. One co-defendant was charged and subsequently pleaded guilty to aggravated burglary in relation to an unrelated incident at a residential property in Easton, involving forced entry and intimidation. This offence has no direct bearing upon your sentencing but reminds us of the varied spectrum of acquisitive and violent offences circulating in the region. The other co-defendant faced charges for possession of a bladed article in a school car park, a matter proceeding independently. These related but legally separable cases illustrate the complexity often encountered in multi-defendant investigations, underscoring the importance of focusing on your personal responsibility and conduct. Further complicating the proceedings was a delay occasioned by a strike action involving court administrative staff, which necessitated the adjournment of the planned sentencing hearing from 7 September to today's date. Such delays, while regrettable, remain a feature of the contemporary justice environment and highlight systemic pressures on judiciary and support services. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. In mitigation, the court gratefully acknowledges the various letters tendered on your behalf, including one from your sister and several from the Bristol Soup Kitchen and Threads of Care charity organisations. These letters paint a picture of someone striving to overcome significant obstacles and attempting to engage with available support systems. The voluntary sector's role in supporting individuals caught in the revolving door of acquisitive offending cannot be overstated. These bodies operate under chronic funding restrictions, tackling problem complexity often invisible to statutory agencies. Their efforts in your case have been marked by patience and measured prudence, resisting the temptation to excuse wrongdoing while advocating for humane and constructive approaches. The court also notes submissions from the Bristol Retail Crime Prevention Network drawing attention to the ongoing impact of shoplifting on independent retailers in the city centre. Many such businesses operate on narrow margins and are acutely vulnerable to shrinkage caused by theft, resulting in store closures and job losses. I thank all involved parties for their candid representations, which have greatly informed the court’s deliberations. The defendant admitted selling stolen items at both a car boot sale and various local pubs, where his actions disturbed or distressed others present. As is the unfortunate norm in such cases, your criminal record reveals a pattern of repeat offending. Since age 24, you have attracted a series of convictions and community resolutions, largely for theft-related offences. These prior interactions with the criminal justice system strongly inform the assessment of your culpability and the risk posed to the public. Despite multiple warnings and diversion interventions, the continuation of offending conduct is regrettable. The court takes a particularly dim view of repeated acquisitive behaviour which disrupts the livelihoods of local businesses and erodes community cohesion. It is well established in case law, including the decision in R v. Reid [2019] EWCA Crim 1452, that persistence in offending following prior convictions and community orders is a significant aggravating factor, and can warrant custodial penalties to reflect the urgency of addressing recidivism. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while blinding cameras using aerosol paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. The cumulative effect of these offences, while involving relatively low individual values, must be seen in light of the broader disruption they cause. Loss caused to retail premises is more than a mere financial figure; it represents hours of staff time diverted to investigation, increased security costs, and increased insurance premiums, which, when aggregated, burden commercial entities and ultimately consumers. Staff morale is also impacted, with employees reporting heightened anxiety, fear of confrontation, and in some instances, a sense of helplessness. Victim personal statements included in the prosecution bundle bear eloquent testimony to these effects. Mr H, while the court acknowledges the absence of direct threats or violence in your conduct, the pernicious psychological harm wrought by repeat theft remains an important factor in sentencing consideration. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, believes it’s just taking what he needs and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. The lingering spectre of substance misuse complicates the narrative in your case. While no direct causal link has been firmly established between drug use and your offending, clinical reports and self-reports disclose episodes of alcohol excess and suspected illicit drug consumption. Such factors are well recognised contributory elements in impulsive, acquisitive crime, as noted in judicial commentary including R v. Willis [2018] EWCA Crim 1067 and associated psychiatric literature. Clinicians frequently advise incorporating substance misuse treatment into rehabilitative frameworks to disrupt offending pathways. Service provision in this area, however, remains constrained by extensive waiting lists and variable engagement rates, reflecting broader challenges in the national health service and social care funding. I encourage probation and affiliated services to explore suitable interventions that could assist in addressing these underlying vulnerabilities in your forthcoming supervision plan. Before concluding, I must remark upon the collective burden persistent shoplifting inflicts on public services. The gathering, collation, and analysis of CCTV data, the preparation of witness statements, and the administrative processing of charges represent an appreciable drain on police and court resources. Digital forensic departments, too, are frequently over-engaged, tasked with retrieving and authenticating video evidence often comprising dozens of hours of footage per case. The volume and complexity of such material is significant and growing, exacerbated by increasing reliance on evolving technologies and data systems. While the courts are conscious of these pressures, they cannot colour impartial adjudication and sentencing outcomes. Justice must continue to be done efficiently but without surrendering to expediency at the expense of fairness and public protection. I also refer to the recent establishment of the Avon Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC) procedures and their integration with local Community Safety Partnerships. Though primarily focused on domestic abuse and serious violence, the experience here also informs best practice in multi-agency collaboration on repeat acquisitive offending, including data-sharing and intervention coordination. The court expresses cautious optimism that such models can reduce repeat offending and improve outcomes, albeit recognising limitations posed by fluctuating personnel and resource constraints. In summation, this is a case of persistent theft, committed over a lengthy period, which has caused both economic loss and significant distress to individuals and retail businesses. While your personal circumstances explain some aspects of your behaviour, they do not absolve you of responsibility. The pre-sentence reports and psychiatric assessments suggest that with structured support and supervision, the risk of reoffending can be mitigated, but compliance remains uncertain. Sentencing options before the court include community orders with rehabilitative conditions, custodial sentences, and combinations thereof, always calibrated to balance punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. I shall therefore adjourn sentencing to a later date to enable the probation service to provide a full pre-sentence report, setting out layers of intervention deemed viable for your circumstances and detailing a risk management plan. This step will also facilitate any submissions from the Crown and defence on specific proposals or representations. The court is mindful of the need to act expeditiously but fairly, ensuring that sentence imposed reflects the gravity of the offending and your prospects for reformation. The sentencing hearing is accordingly adjourned to 5 November 2026. You are reminded of your obligations and rights in the intervening period. These remarks are issued this 17th day of September 2026, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been recorded and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the relevant bodies for registration and enforcement. You are informed of your right to appeal the sentence within 28 days of its imposition, pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are currently engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BASINGSTOKE R v. MR H Case No. T2025/14567 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. W. HARROW Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court today for sentence following your conviction for offences of theft—more specifically, shoplifting—from various retail premises within the Hampshire area during the latter part of 2024 and early 2025. The offences encompass a period of some eight months and involve multiple locations across the Basingstoke, Winchester, and Southampton districts. Procedural History Your case has progressed through a series of hearings beginning with your apprehension on 5 February 2025. Initial charges were laid following an investigation by officers from Hampshire Constabulary’s Commercial Crime Unit in conjunction with local council licensing enforcement teams. The investigation arose from reports submitted by several retail outlets noting a suspicious pattern of thefts involving similar modus operandi—a pattern which, after considerable collation of CCTV footage, witnessed testimonies, and inventory audits, pointed in your direction. That process, while necessary, was lengthy and resource-intensive, taxing several units far beyond their routine caseload given the complexity of aligning evidence across jurisdictions and premises. It bears noting at this juncture that your case exemplifies the multifaceted challenges inherent in policing what is frequently termed 'low-level crime.' Such offences are often dismissed in public discourse as harmless or incidental. Yet, as the court has observed in numerous past judgments, the aggregate effect of these offences exacts a significant toll on businesses, employees, and public confidence. Resources spent here are inevitably diverted from other investigative priorities, as recognised in R v. Cartwright [2019] EWCA Crim 812, where the Court of Appeal emphasised that the cumulative impact of petty acquisitive offences can warrant sentences proportionate to their broader societal effect rather than the precise value of individual items stolen. After your arrest, substantial investigative steps were undertaken, including detailed forensic examination of clothing seized from your residence and analysis of electronic device data obtained pursuant to a search warrant authorised by a designated judicial officer. The utilisation of such warrants, particularly for digital extraction, follows strict procedures aimed at balancing investigatory necessity against individual privacy rights, as outlined in R v. Keaton [2020] EWHC 175 (Admin). In your case, the evidence gleaned formed a crucial component of the prosecution’s case, allowing corroboration between digital timelines and physical observations. The matter was listed initially for a plea and trial preparation hearing on 4 March 2025 but was adjourned twice owing to delayed Legal Aid authorisations for expert assessment—an unfortunate but far from isolated procedural difficulty faced by criminal courts in recent years. Indeed, your defence team’s application for approval to instruct a forensic psychiatrist registered only in late April, following a series of exchanges with the Legal Aid Agency characterised by administrative opacity and protracted response times. The systemic nature of these delays carries real implications, not only as an inconvenience to defendants but as substantive obstacles to effective justice, a point the Court of Appeal recently considered in R v. Letts [2024] EWCA Crim 265, expressing concern over growing procedural inertia in defence funding decisions. Upon the grant of such authority, the instructed expert, Dr Amanda Jefferies, submitted a detailed report in early June, assessing both your cognitive and psychiatric profile with a view to determining mitigating factors relevant to sentencing. Dr Jefferies’ evaluation undertakes a comprehensive review of your developmental history, past trauma exposure, neurocognitive functioning, and current psychological health. The assessment, though thorough, concludes that no diagnosable mental disorder sufficiently impaired your responsibility at the time of offences, albeit noting impulsivity and limited insight into consequences. While the findings do not mandate diminished culpability, they nonetheless inform the court’s holistic consideration of your circumstances. In conjunction with this, a probation pre-sentence report was commissioned, providing supplementary insights into your socio-economic background, lifestyle, and prior criminal record. The probation officer, Ms Helen Tramontane, highlights episodic homelessness, intermittent contact with social services, and previous informal diversionary measures, including participation in a shoplifting intervention workshop in 2023. Encouragingly, probation reports note periods of engagement with community support groups specializing in financial literacy and emotional regulation, though these were sporadic and ultimately insufficient to prevent reoffending. The report sets out potential community sentence options and rehabilitative programmes tailored to reduce recidivism. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. It is necessary to situate the court’s examination of this case within the evolving statutory and judicial framework governing theft offences. As codified within the Theft Act 1968, theft remains an offence encompassing the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention to permanently deprive. Shoplifting offences, while often caught by summary procedures under local bylaws or fixed penalty notices, escalate in seriousness when perpetrated repeatedly or within a pattern exhibiting planning and disregard for lawful authority, as emphasised in the Sentencing Council guideline for theft and handling stolen goods (October 2019). This matter engages the Crown Court’s jurisdiction owing to the scale and complexity of the conduct, as well as the defendant’s prior record, which disqualifies summary disposal under the Magistrates’ Court Sentencing Guidelines 2020. The principles enunciated in R v. O’Sullivan [2018] EWCA Crim 5 also direct the court to have proper regard to the cumulative nature of conduct over time, especially where offences are committed across multiple premises, involving different victim entities. It might be instructive, at this juncture, to briefly consider related appellate precedent touching on aspects of sentencing calibrations for acquisitive crime. In R v. Windham [2023] EWCA Crim 1541, dealing with a case of aggravated burglary involving use of weapons and intimidation, the court underscored that while violence magnifies harm and culpability, so too does persistent disregard for others’ property rights where it erodes public confidence. Though not directly applicable here, Windham’s observations on cumulative harm bear implicit relevance to serial acquisitive offending. Similarly, in R v. Meredith [2022] EWCA Crim 990, the Court grappled with the tension between economic hardship as a mitigating factor and personal responsibility, concluding that individual deprivation does not excuse calculated dishonesty. Mr H used the bottom compartment of his niece’s pram to hide razor cartridges and protein supplements. While outside the direct purview of this proceeding, it is worth noting the Court’s awareness of contemporary policy debates surrounding the Business Crime Reduction Strategy implemented regionally since 2022. These initiatives focus on collaboration between retailers, police forces, and local authority bodies to identify repeat offenders and apply targeted interventions pre-emptively. Despite significant enthusiasm at the policy level, implementation remains uneven, with regional differences in resourcing and operational efficacy. Indeed, a report published by the National Retail Federation in June 2025 lamented ongoing deficiencies in communication between stakeholders and a lack of clarity regarding data sharing protocols, compromised further by privacy legislation constraints. Nonetheless, the efforts undertaken by the Hampshire Retail Security Forum in this matter represent a coordinated attempt to address systemic retail crime challenges, an effort to which officers from the Constabulary, shop floor security personnel, and local crime reduction specialists committed significant time and expertise. There is, of course, an entire body of case law unrelated to the present facts which nonetheless informs the court’s appreciation of the broad social context in which acquisitive offences occur. For instance, in R v. Yates [2019] EWCA Crim 682, concerning fly-tipping on protected greenbelt land leading to environmental damage valued in the tens of thousands of pounds, the Court highlighted the community-wide repercussions of seemingly “minor” unlawful acts. While totally distinct from theft, the reflections on collective responsibility and environmental stewardship resonate here. Similarly, R v. Dobson [2017] EWCA Crim 927, involving affray triggered by an altercation within a licensed nightclub, despite bearing no factual nexus to this case, provides judicial commentary on public order and community trust, which underpin many theft-related offences in urban centres. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. Regarding other procedural matters, the court notes the contributions of various parties in this matter. Ms Olivia Bristow, solicitor for the Crown, has presented a well-structured outline of the prosecution’s position, supported by extensive evidential exhibits and victim impact statements. Her submissions were measured, appropriately calibrated, and cognizant of the wider social difficulties facing defendants such as yourself, yet uncompromising in highlighting the harm caused to local businesses and staff. For the defence, Mr Richard Iverson provided articulate submissions focusing on your personal circumstances, recent attempts at engagement with welfare provision, and the psychological factors articulated by Dr Jefferies. His advocacy exemplifies the professionalism expected of defence counsel, particularly in complex Crown Court proceedings involving multi-faceted evidence. In reviewing the victim impact material, this court acknowledges the consistent testimony regarding disruption to business operations, the burden placed on already stretched retail teams, and the anxiety engendered by recurrent loss and prospective financial pressures. The Chamberlain’s Pharmaceuticals retail chain, for example, submitted detailed observations on the cumulative economic impact of repeat thefts, noting increased expenditure on security staff, installation of anti-theft systems, and changes to employee shift patterns to mitigate risk. References from frontline retail workers evoke tangible stress and feelings of vulnerability, underscoring a dimension of harm not always captured by simple monetary quantification. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. In reviewing your personal history, as documented in probation assessments and corroborated by community worker reports, it is apparent that you have faced a series of socio-economic challenges, including periods of unstable accommodation, episodic engagement with mental health services, and documented early childhood adversity. While these are not reasons for excusing culpability, they factor into the broader assessment of risk and rehabilitation potential. Indeed, probation reports recommend a combination of structured community supervision, engagement with cognitive behavioural therapy modules, and possibly a curfew and daily reporting requirement. The court has also received correspondence from the Basingstoke Homeless Outreach Partnership, which attests to your recent attempts to stabilise housing and seek employment, albeit with limited success. Their letter emphasises the resource constraints under which such organisations operate and the critical importance of sustained engagement by service users. The partnership highlights the dangerous gulf between aspiration and accessibility, a gap which often precipitates recidivism if unaddressed. During his arrest, officers recovered a magnet used to remove a security tag earlier that day. It merits recognition that in the course of the criminal proceedings, a co-defendant initially charged alongside you was subject to separate bail conditions pending trial on more serious matters, including a charge involving possession of a bladed article on school premises, a wholly unrelated offence distinct from your involvement. That co-defendant failed to appear at an earlier hearing and is currently wanted on warrant. While their conduct is legally independent of your case, the fact of co-defendant abscondment has occasioned repeated procedural delays in the listing of this matter, causing additional inconvenience and pressure on court resources. Further, the court is cognisant of certain anecdotal delays in interpreter services at the initial hearings—a problem not uncommon in busy Crown Courts, which occasionally impacts the timely progression of cases involving non-English speakers. Though this issue did not affect your matter directly, it exemplifies the broader systemic challenges faced across the judicial infrastructure. Moreover, the court notes that separate criminal proceedings in the city involving historical arson at a commercial property caused some disruption to allocation of judges and courtrooms earlier in 2025. That arson offence, committed in March and April 2025 by unrelated individuals, resulted in extended trial hearings and reallocation of judicial personnel within the Crown Court complex. While unrelated to the current proceedings, such events form part of the operational environment in which cases like yours are inevitably heard. The defendant acknowledged selling the stolen property at a car boot market and in pubs, where his behaviour caused a disturbance to patrons. Turning to sentencing principles, theft offences attract a range of possible dispositions from financial penalties and community orders through to immediate custody, guided by the Sentencing Council’s Theft and Handling Stolen Goods guideline. Factors elevating seriousness include persistence, premeditation, targeting of vulnerable victims, and breach of trust. Mitigating factors may encompass early guilty pleas, remorse, efforts at reparation, and personal circumstances reducing culpability or risk. It is to your credit that you entered a guilty plea at the earliest practicable opportunity once the weight of evidence became clear, which is acknowledged as a significant mitigating feature under R v. Bedwell [2023] EWCA Crim 301. The court must, however, remain mindful that acceptance of responsibility, while commendable, does not negate the damaging consequences of your offending nor its broader impact on community safety and commerce. Dr Jefferies’ report cautions that while no major psychiatric illness was found, your impulsive tendencies and difficulties in emotional regulation carry moderate risk factors for future offending absent structured intervention. The pre-sentence report similarly recommends cognitive-behavioural work and financial management programmes, pointing out your partial engagement to date but fragility of sustained compliance. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while damaging security cameras using spray paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. During the course of the investigation, separate from this case but concurrently active in the region, a series of offences involving the theft of copper cabling from railway depots was prosecuted by the South Central Trains Police Unit. These incidents, resulting in power disruptions and costly repairs, involved an unrelated group and are of tangential interest only. Nonetheless, their continuation has drawn focus to the increasing vulnerability of infrastructure assets and the resource demands posed by acquisitive crime more generally. Additionally, an unrelated inquiry into criminal damage involving graffiti on public transport facilities throughout southern England culminated recently in a series of convictions. The defendants therein were subject to restorative justice programmes rather than custodial sentence. While this provides a contrasting example of sentencing outcomes, it carries no direct bearing on your case. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, said it was no different to borrowing and has no intention of stopping. The court recognises the complicated interface between your history, personal challenges, the nature of the offending, and the requirements of justice, deterrence, and community safety. Custodial sentences are appropriate where culpability is high and other measures insufficient to protect the public or reduce risk of reoffending. Equally, community sentences with bespoke interventions are preferable where practicable and likely to be effective. Practical considerations, including your residential stability and willingness to participate in rehabilitative provisions, weigh in favour of a structured community order. However, the extent and pattern of offending, your prior record, and the significant aggravating features— notably persistence and disregard for previous warnings—limit the scope for leniency. Accordingly, the court now directs that a full and detailed pre-sentence report be prepared forthwith by the Probation Service, taking into account psychological assessments, risk evaluations, and available community resources. The report shall consider potential packages of supervision, including any available cognitive skills programmes, unpaid work requirements, electronically monitored curfew, and interventions addressing impulsivity and financial management. It will also investigate possibilities for restorative justice engagement, particularly as to whether victims or retailers might be willing to participate. The overarching objective remains the dual aims of reducing risk to the public and supporting your rehabilitation in a sustainable manner. These sentencing remarks are issued this 17th day of September 2025, in Court 5 at Basingstoke Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the requisite authorities. You are informed of your statutory right to appeal within 28 days of sentence under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply unless otherwise ordered. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT HULL R v. Mr H Case No. H2025/03847 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. J. PENNINGTON Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced for offences of theft, said to have taken place in various retail outlets within the city of Hull and its environs over a period extending from late 2023 through to early 2025. The charges arise under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. In simple terms, the indictment represents a consolidated count reflecting a course of conduct characterised by repeated shoplifting and dishonest appropriation. The procedural history of this matter is of some note, for it traverses several months of preparatory hearings, evidential collation, and applications to the Legal Aid Agency for funding of expert assessments. The case was originally lodged at the Magistrates’ Court on 27 January 2025, following an amalgamated referral from local authorities and participating retailers brought together under the auspices of the Hull Retail Crime Prevention Board. From there, it was committed to this Crown Court with a view to trial and sentencing under the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol, a mechanism designed to streamline the progression of indictable offences by early identification of issues, tailoring of directions, and minimisation of unnecessary delay. Despite these laudable aims, the case experienced some administrative delays, not least occasioned by strike action within the court support staff in April and the late arrival of forensic reports, themselves impeded by competing workload demands placed upon the city forensic laboratory. It is worth remarking the origins of the BCM process. Emerging from reforms in the early 2010s following well-documented concerns over the inefficiencies of criminal case progression, BCM sought to enforce a more rigorous regime of case management by judges, magistrates, and the legal teams. Its provisions require early disclosure, case allocation, and movement toward fully defined trial readiness, fostering early admissions where appropriate, and thereby alleviating pressure upon the court list. The adoption of BCM principles has transformed the landscape of serious crime prosecution, notwithstanding certain continuing challenges related to resource constraints and complexity. The present matter proceeded against this framework, with initial hearings held on 14 March and 2 July respectively, towards a plea and trial preparation hearing set for 15 September 2025. Concerning the evidence, you were arrested on 5 September 2025 after a routine patrol disrupted an incident involving items suspected of being unlawfully taken from a convenience store on Ferensway. Your apprehension followed a series of reports and complaints consolidated from multiple retailers, coordinated through the Hull Business Crime Partnership. The investigation involved cross-referencing CCTV footage, electronic point of sale discrepancies, and witness statements from shop assistants and managers. The prosecution case rests significantly on the coherence of these multiple, time-stamped visual records and recovered property allegedly traced back to your possession or immediate control. The Crown’s evidence bundle extends to over 700 pages and includes contemporaneous records and electronic transactions, carefully catalogued and disclosed in full to the defence. In R v. Davenport [2019] EWCA Crim 1324, the Court of Appeal reiterated that the offence of theft, particularly where committed as a sustained pattern involving multiple acts over a period, attracts proportionate sentencing reflecting not merely the individual acts but the cumulative effect upon victims and the community. While Davenport concerned supermarket theft exceeding £2,500 in value, the principles established concerning aggravating features such as planning, persistence, and impact are germane here. Furthermore, the well-known case of R v. Thompson [2021] EWCA Crim 2121—although touching upon a separate category of offences, namely criminal damage—provides useful guidance concerning the role of a late guilty plea in sentencing mitigation. There, the Court opined that credit is primarily designed to reflect early admission and genuine remorse, with delayed pleas, often entered following exhaustive case preparation and overwhelming evidence, attracting markedly reduced reductions. That principle is equally applicable in the context of acquisitive crime. This court is also mindful of the provisions of the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on Theft Offences, published most recently in 2020, which emphasises an assessment of culpability, harm, and any aggravating or mitigating features. The guideline directs focus upon the preparatory activities undertaken by the offender, use of deception, targeting of vulnerable victims or premises, and the degree of planning or sophistication. Although the individual monetary values involved in shoplifting often appear modest, the societal harm caused by persistent offending is not to be underestimated. Over recent years, Hull has seen a notable rise in retail crime reports, partly reflective of larger socio-economic trends within the region. There is ample evidence to suggest that the cumulative burden on small retail operators has intensified, as noted in a 2024 report by the Humber Retail Security Forum. Staffing shortages, heightened threats of antisocial behaviour, and the persistent underfunding of community policing initiatives combine to create increasingly fraught trading conditions. The fallout frequently extends beyond mere financial loss, encompassing diminished employee morale and concerns over personal safety among shop staff. The case law also dictates that sentencing in theft cases must balance deterrence with rehabilitation, recognising the pressures that financial hardship and social marginalisation might bring. Nevertheless, personal circumstance cannot excuse repeated breach of the criminal law, especially when previous interventions have been unsuccessful. Prior to sentencing, expert assessments were commissioned. Notably, Dr Nana Onyeka, consultant forensic psychologist, undertook a comprehensive evaluation in August 2025. Her report, spanning 26 pages and detailed by interview and psychometric testing, indicates a borderline intellectual functioning profile, with underlying difficulties in impulse control and occasional periods of mood lability, but notably no diagnosis of a severe mental illness or major cognitive impairment. Dr Onyeka emphasises the importance of structured engagement with community support in addressing the identified impulsivity and the attendant risk factors. Meanwhile, the Probation Service’s pre-sentence report, authored by Ms Fiona Crossley, reflects on your history of limited sustained employment, housing instability, and prior informal warnings by retail security, yet notes your reluctance to participate in voluntary community programmes. The report flags a moderate risk of reoffending and urges consideration of a rehabilitative regime incorporating cognitive-behavioural components. It is a matter of concern that, despite repeated offers of support from outreach and voluntary agencies—such as Hull Homeless Outreach and the Retail Support Alliance—you have opted predominantly not to engage. Such engagement is integral to effecting behavioural change and reducing recidivism. It is also telling that your own statements often attribute responsibility to external factors rather than recognising agency and choice. The administrative challenges faced by Legal Aid practitioners in securing timely funding for expert assessments, particularly in resource-squeezed areas, have been a recurring feature in this and other similar cases. Applications for funding to instruct independent psychiatrists or psychologists often undergo protracted delay, as was the case here, potentially impeding expeditious resolution and undermining the defendant’s access to justice. While no direct culpability attaches to any party, the systemic inefficiencies serve only to prolong proceedings and place additional strain on judicial resources. It is necessary now to turn to the facts underlying the conviction. The evidence adduced at trial establishes that you engaged on multiple occasions in deliberate acts of theft from a range of retail outlets. Such conduct was not impulsive or opportunistic, but marked by deliberate planning and repeated execution over several months. Multiple staff statements describe your behaviour as rehearsed and covert, using various concealment techniques and often returning repeatedly to the same premises. The recurrent nature of your actions, targeting items frequently resold on informal markets, reveals an ongoing and intentional pattern of acquisitive offending. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. These considerations are germane to the evaluation of culpability and the appropriate quantum of sentence. In addition to the direct consequences to each individual establishment affected by your offending, there has been a broader economic impact. Independent shops have spoken through victim impact statements to the increased costs and disruption caused by such sustained loss, resulting in reduced opening hours and the scaling back of staff numbers to mitigate vulnerability. Such knock-on effects extend beyond immediate financial loss to degrade community confidence and disrupt social cohesion. Mr H hid boxed razor blades and protein powder among his niece’s belongings in her pram. The court acknowledges that you are currently aged 34 and present with a limited custodial record, though including prior warnings and conditional discharges for related acquisitive conduct. Your reported history of homelessness and economic hardship is noted, as is your engagement in sporadic employment, often precarious and of short duration. There is no evidence of gang affiliation or organised criminality, which might otherwise attract enhanced sanction. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. The victim impact statements from affected store employees reflect a palpable stress and diminution of workplace confidence as a result of your offending. Several refer to an atmosphere of apprehension, as repeat low-level theft not only diminishes stock but interrupts day-to-day operation and places staff under additional monitoring requirements. Mr H feigned interest in Oyster Card payments to distract the cashier and reached behind the counter to take an item from the display. It must also be underscored that your behaviour has persisted despite a series of community resolutions and warnings from law enforcement and local retail security teams aimed at diverting you from further offending. Such interventions did not succeed in altering your course. Instead, reports indicate a return to similar conduct within a matter of weeks or months. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. The defendant admitted taking the stolen items to sell at local pubs and a car boot sale, where members of the public were disturbed. These circumstances elevate the seriousness of the offence and weigh heavily upon the sentencing decision. Whilst the courtroom today reflects on established sentencing principles—punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection—it must also grapple with larger systemic pressures. Public services, including probation and social care, face sustained underfunding, rising caseloads, and dilapidated infrastructure. The NHS mental health services in particular struggle under mounting referral lists and extended waiting times, challenging the delivery of timely and effective intervention for vulnerable individuals. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. The court is mindful that in R v. Wilcox [2022] EWCA Crim 1543 the Court of Appeal highlighted the importance of balancing custodial necessity with non-custodial options where appropriate, especially when underlying vulnerabilities appear in the offender’s psychosocial profile. The present case demands similarly careful weighing of factors. It is unfortunate this court has become accustomed, with dismay, to repeated references to the poor state of Legal Aid funding and the corresponding impact upon quality of representation and expert outreach. Such systemic shortcomings risk undermining the administration of justice, yet remain beyond judicial authority to remedy. A case pending since early 2025 might well have concluded months earlier absent such complications. I also record the participation and contributions of those working in Hull’s voluntary and community sector—including the Hull Retailers’ Support Hub and the East Yorkshire Community Trust—whose dedication continues unabated despite severe financial constraints. Their carefully considered reports and the eloquence of their written submissions testify to a commitment seldom fully acknowledged in public discourse. The court notes with regret that the custody suite at Hull Police Station continues to see overcrowding and staffing pressures, which have implications for detainee welfare and timely processing. Public interest in retail crime remains mixed. As this court has observed, such offences rarely attract media attention unless linked to violence or spectacular scenes. Yet, they constitute a substantial proportion of the criminal docket and a significant drain on policing and judicial resources. The evidence before the court also demonstrates, contrary to any suggestion of inadvertence, that your acts involved deception, repeated subterfuge, and deliberate attempts to defeat store security measures, including removal or concealment of packaging and labels. On a number of occasions, accomplices were allegedly used to create distraction, though no conclusive evidence associates you with any co-offenders. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, doesn't view his actions as theft and intends to keep doing so. These observations help delineate your role and culpability within the overarching course of conduct. Appreciation is extended to Ms Samantha Fairchild, who appears for the Crown, for her able and thorough presentation of the case. Likewise, I thank Mr Benjamin Havers, appointed under a representation order, for his professional advocacy on behalf of you, the defendant. It is important, also, to acknowledge the work and professionalism of the court clerks, ushers, and security personnel in ensuring the proceedings have been conducted orderly and without disruption, despite ongoing refurbishment works in this courtroom. The hearing has been conducted in open court. It is a matter of proper public record that low-level offending such as that before this court is no less serious in its cumulative impact simply because it involves sum values which might be individually trivial. There are victims whose voices must be heard and whose experiences must be respected. The wholesale dismissal of shoplifting as victimless crime ignores the realities of victim suffering, financial strain, and community degradation. The court has also given consideration to the wider societal context in which such offences occur. The spectre of entrenched poverty, housing insecurity, and social marginalisation cannot be ignored, though neither can they be permitted to serve as blanket exculpations. This court remains conscious of the delicate balancing act within sentencing: recognising human frailty and systemic failure, while maintaining the imperative of law and order. I emphasise that the statutory framework directs that the sentence imposed must be just in all circumstances, reflecting the nature and seriousness of the offence, the character and antecedents of the offender, and the purposes of sentencing enshrined in statute and developed in jurisprudence. The preferable approach, with a case of this nature, remains the preparation of an up-to-date, comprehensive pre-sentence report, which may incorporate further psychiatric and social assessments as necessary and explore avenues for intervention within both custodial and community contexts. Sentence will be deferred pending receipt of such a report, allowing the probation service the opportunity fully to assess risk, need, and proposal for rehabilitation, consistent with public protection. This court accordingly reserves final sentencing for a date to be fixed following delivery of the pre-sentence report. The defendant will be entitled to make further representations at that time. This document constitutes the sentencing remarks of Her Honour Judge L. J. Pennington, delivered on 14 October 2025 within Court 4 of the Crown Court at Hull. The proceedings have been digitally recorded in compliance with Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant and counsel are advised of the right to appeal this decision pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968, with the prescribed 28-day time limit. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are in effect. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT PETERBOROUGH R v. MR H Case No. T2025/14637 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. R. COCHRANE Filed: 17 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today for sentence following your conviction on a representative count of theft, specifically shoplifting from commercial premises, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending behaviour under consideration, as set out in the indictment, relates to repeated acts spanning a period from mid-2023 through to early 2025 within the Greater Peterborough area and nearby retail districts. Procedural Background Your arrest was effected on 28 February 2025 by officers of the Peterborough Local Policing Unit after an investigation initiated by the city’s Retail Theft Taskforce. This unit was formed in response to an observable increase in shoplifting incidents in the wake of post-pandemic retail recovery efforts. The case was classified as appropriate for Crown Court jurisdiction due to the sustained pattern and the cumulative value of goods involved exceeding the threshold for magistrates’ court competence, compounded by the history of repeat offending on your part. It must be acknowledged that the establishment of the Retail Theft Taskforce stemmed from a strategic initiative to improve inter-agency responses to commercial theft, which has long been recognised as a drain on local economies and a source of distress for business owners and staff. The Taskforce utilises an amalgamation of intelligence sharing, covert surveillance, and multi-agency coordination, including the cooperation of private security operatives contracted by retail chains. In this context, intelligence-led policing measures were employed extensively, with the eventual arrest coming only after several weeks of concerted monitoring. The case experienced initial listing challenges due to the unusually high court workload during the summer of 2025, magnified further by the ongoing staff shortages within criminal justice administration nationally. A previous hearing scheduled for 10 August 2025 was adjourned on account of defence counsel awaiting funding authorisation for the instruction of a forensic psychologist — a delay lamented by all parties but illustrative of the systemic pressures within the Legal Aid framework. The funding request itself was subject to protracted correspondence with the Legal Aid Agency, involving multiple resubmissions and clarifications over a period of six weeks. I must place on record the court’s continuing dissatisfaction with such procedural inefficiencies, which serve only to retard the timely administration of justice. The present sentencing hearing has proceeded with both prosecution and defence representatives present and fully prepared. I record my thanks to Ms Catherine Burns, prosecuting on behalf of the Crown Prosecution Service, and to Mr Michael Travers, instructed under a Legal Aid order, representing you. I also acknowledge the presence of the court clerk, ushers, and court security staff, who continue to maintain courtroom order amidst these demanding caseloads. It is appropriate here to revisit the historical trajectory of the Theft Act 1968, under which you are charged. The statute has been foundational in English criminal law regarding dishonesty offences for over five decades. Amended on occasion to reflect societal developments, including the Theft Act 1978 and subsequent legislation addressing related property crimes, it nevertheless remains the primary reference. The relevant sentencing guidelines were last substantively revised by the Sentencing Council in 2021, emphasizing the importance of offence context, culpability, and harm. The court is also mindful of the Better Case Management (BCM) framework introduced in 2013, which aims to streamline trial preparation and disposal phases. This matter was managed under BCM protocols, with initial hearings prompting the early disclosure of evidence, including CCTV footage, witness statements, and forensic reports, thereby ensuring procedural transparency and efficiency commensurate with expectations under the Criminal Procedure Rules. It is worth noting that the case progressed without any significant procedural defaults or failures—a rare procedural achievement worthy of acknowledgment in an era of chronic judicial delay. The Crown has presented a thorough evidential matrix, including commercial CCTV records, witness eyewitness accounts from store staff, and corroborative forensics relating to items recovered in your possession at the moment of arrest. There was an initial not guilty plea at your first appearance on 5 March 2025, but this was amended to a guilty plea at a hearing held on 14 September 2025, following the receipt of further detailed evidence. While that admission alleviates some of the burden on witnesses and court resources, the timing of your plea falls within the category often described in case law as a “late” guilty plea. This carries implications for any mitigation in sentencing credit, as emphasised in R v. Khan [2022] EWCA Crim 1156 wherein the Court of Appeal restated that the timing of a plea reflects the offender’s acceptance of responsibility and influences the degree of reduction. Turning momentarily to ancillary case law, in R v. Milton [2019] EWCA Crim 1873, dealing with offences involving theft from charitable institutions, the court noted that while the monetary value was modest, the reputational damage and disruption to charitable operations warranted enhanced custodial considerations. Of course, that judgment is factually distinct, but the principle of aggravated harm through victim vulnerability is broadly instructive. Similarly, R v. Owusu [2020] EWCA Crim 902 involved a repeat offender found guilty of aggravated commercial burglary, a more serious offence bearing little direct relation to the present facts but noteworthy for its statement on public protection concerns arising from repetitive acquisitive offending. Further, R v. Carlyle [2018] EWCA Crim 562 concerned possession of a bladed article in a school car park—a matter unrelated to your case save for highlighting the courts’ firm stance on offences potentially endangering vulnerable groups, underscoring the contextual weight courts afford such factors in sentencing assessments. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. Post-arrest, the police established through intelligence-led surveillance and forensic examination a pattern to your activities. The consistency of your methodology emerged clearly: timed visits to midweek shopping days, selective targeting of unstaffed aisles, and the use of concealment tactics. Multiple staff statements attest to a growing atmosphere of trepidation among employees at the targeted outlets. The cumulative financial impact, while individually minor per incident, amassed to a figure significantly exceeding the £1,500 mark, invoking greater prosecutorial attention. Mr H used the bottom compartment of his niece’s pram to hide razor cartridges and protein supplements. Of note, the evidentiary package submitted included a victim personal statement from the manager of a local pharmacy, expressing the demoralising effect your conduct had on staff wellbeing and morale, challenges to managerial scheduling, and the economic burden borne by the business after repeated shrinkage. Such statements serve as important reminders that victim impact in shoplifting cases extends beyond the monetary. Regarding your background, you are aged 34. You carry previous convictions for theft-related matters, notably a caution in 2021 for shoplifting and a conviction for handling stolen goods in 2018. Your personal history reveals periods of unstable housing, unemployment, and intermittent engagement with substance use services, though there is no diagnosis of serious mental illness. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. Within the psychiatric and psychological assessments obtained pursuant to the court’s direction, Dr Olivia Miller — a consultant forensic psychologist instructed at the defence’s request — reports your presentation as consistent with borderline personality traits, impulsivity, and maladaptive coping mechanisms. While not suggesting psychosis or major mental disorder, Dr Miller highlights longstanding difficulties with emotional regulation and low tolerance for distress, factors which may bear upon motivations but do not mitigate culpability. The report recommends structured interventions focusing on cognitive-behavioural approaches, impulse control, and engagement with local addiction services. The Department of Probation has prepared a comprehensive pre-sentence report, authored by Probation Officer Sophie Lin, which was made available to all parties ahead of this hearing. The report points to medium risk of reoffending with a focus on acquisitive offending patterns. It also laments your inconsistent participation with voluntary support offers and noted difficulty maintaining stable accommodation, a recognised criminogenic factor. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. The report references your family circumstances briefly; you have a sister residing in Birmingham with whom contact is intermittent. Letters submitted on your behalf from your sister and a social support worker at the Peterborough Homeless Outreach Service convey sympathy and hope for your rehabilitation but are cautious about unrealistic expectations. Notably, the letter from the outreach service worker speaks to the strain on local housing support schemes, which are operating at near maximum capacity. The chronic shortage of affordable and supported housing in the region is well-documented, with waiting lists extending for years for suitable placements, further exacerbated by a rise in street homelessness. Such context is relevant to overall assessment but not a fresh excuse for persistent criminality. The court recognises environmental pressures but equally holds steadfast to the principle that personal responsibility remains paramount. The defendant used a magnetic device to disable the security tag, and this was later recovered when Mr H was arrested. Switching briefly to procedural observations, I comment on recent innovations trialled within the Crown Courts of the East of England, particularly the measured adoption of technological solutions to expedite case management. Electronic disclosure systems, enhanced digital evidence presentation, and remote witness facilitation have yielded some efficiencies, albeit tempered by perennial challenges of uneven internet connectivity in rural circuits. I also note the recent refurbishment of Court 1 at Peterborough Crown Court, which included improved audio-visual aids and an ergonomically designed judge’s bench. While marginal to sentencing considerations, such improvements contribute positively to the judicial process and participant experience. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. Turning to the wider social implications, one cannot ignore the broader societal backdrop to this offending pattern. Nationally, the past decade has witnessed considerable shifts in retail security technology, consumer behaviour, and community policing priorities. The rise of self-service checkouts, contactless payments, and increased video surveillance have altered the landscape, but criminal methods adapt swiftly—thus the importance of continued vigilance. Moreover, the court shares awareness of the pressures faced by shop workers, many reliant on minimum wage jobs, vulnerable to physical and emotional strain, and increasingly disillusioned by repeated encounters with theft. The cumulative cost of such offences imposes upward pressure on pricing, insurance premiums, and ultimately consumer access. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while blinding cameras using aerosol paint, triggering distress and security concerns. The Crown has presented evidence that you previously participated in a local diversionary programme targeting first-time or low-risk offenders, focused on restorative justice and community service. Unfortunately, the programme concluded with your cessation of compliant engagement and immediate resumption of offending upon conclusion. This fact adversely colours any mitigation based on reduction of culpability or prospects for rehabilitation and is a pertinent aggravating factor. The court must balance community safety with the necessity for a sentence sufficiently robust to denote the serious nature of persistent acquisitive offending. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. In considering sentence, I am mindful of the sentencing guideline stipulations. Factors aggravating your culpability include persistence, prior offending, disregard for warnings, and the impact — both economic and psychological — on retail staff. Mitigating factors are limited, primarily your eventual guilty plea and some evidence of personal difficulties, though none sufficient to diminish criminal responsibility. Recent jurisprudence informs that custodial sentences are appropriate where offending demonstrates significant planning, repeated breach of trust, or where community-based interventions have been exhausted or declined. However, this court remains conscious of the overrepresentation of similar offenders in custodial institutions and the need, where possible, to deploy proportional alternatives balancing rehabilitation and public protection. It is essential to reiterate that sentencing powers are exercised not merely to punish but to prevent reoffending and promote reintegration within society. The court welcomes the probation service’s willingness to recommend structured programmes targeting offending behaviour, and will consider such in full at the formal sentencing hearing. Finally, I must address the issue of credit for the late plea. As earlier noted, the timing of the guilty plea bears on any discount applied to sentence length, reflecting judicial recognition of early acceptance of wrongdoing and substantial savings in court time and emotional cost to victims. In assessing your plea timing, I note it was entered some months into the process, only after the prosecution presented an unassailable case. The sentencing discount will thus be appropriately limited. I shall adjourn the matter to permit receipt of the updated pre-sentence report, incorporating any new information from probation and clinical professionals, and will impose sentence accordingly on the date set. The sentencing remarks issued today, 17 October 2025, are delivered in open court, Court 1 at Peterborough Crown Court. A full transcript has been prepared in compliance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules and will be entered on the court record. The defendant is advised of the statutory right to appeal within 28 calendar days following sentencing, pursuant to section 108 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions apply under section 4(2) of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999. Legal costs remain to be addressed at the conclusion of proceedings. These are the orders of the court.
