input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BLACKWELL R v. MR H Case No. T2026/04329 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. J. FAIRBRIDGE Filed: 14 September 2026 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence following your conviction for a series of offences involving theft from retail premises, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The conduct in question was committed over a protracted period spanning from late 2023 into early 2026, affecting a variety of stores situated primarily within the Blackwell and Greater Ashford retail districts. Procedural and Investigative History Your arrest on 11 March 2026 was the culmination of an extensive and resource-intense investigative process orchestrated by the Blackwell Metropolitan Police Retail Crime Unit in tandem with the South Ashford Urban Taskforce. This cooperation incorporated intelligence-sharing with the local Business Crime Reduction Partnership (BCRP), designed precisely to curb repeat acquisitive offending. The investigative operation, which included covert surveillance, the analysis of store security networks, and a painstaking review of commercial loss reports, followed several months of reports detailing persistent theft at multiple premises—primarily convenience stores and pharmacies in the vicinity of transport interchanges and suburban shopping centres. There is often, regrettably, a disconnect between the actual resource expenditure devoted to such cases and the perceived gravity of the offences. What may appear to an outsider as a series of trivial infractions can mask a coordinated pattern that exerts a profound cumulative impact on local businesses and their employees, as well as draining public resources through protracted investigatory efforts. Resource allocation for investigations of this nature must be acknowledged to include not only police officers but also civilian crime analysts, digital forensic specialists, and case officers, engaged over months in securing evidentiary clarification and corroboration. These endeavours naturally carry a significant fiscal cost, diverting attention from other policing priorities which often include violent crime, organised substance supply, and community safeguarding duties. The case advanced through the stages of the criminal justice system meeting the stipulated timeframes outlined in the Criminal Procedure Rules, although not without some delay. A plea and trial preparation hearing was initially listed for 18 May 2026 but was deferred due to the necessity of obtaining a psychiatric report and the securing of Legal Aid funding for an independent assessment. The procedural complexity of cases involving multi-agency collaboration, as well as the involvement of voluntary-sector organisations providing support to both victims and perpetrators, cannot be overstated. While this court is aware of and sympathetic toward those logistical pressures, it is nonetheless imperative that all parties comply with the statutory frameworks governing the administration of justice. It has become an unfortunate, yet increasingly routine, feature in cases of acquisitive offending that guilty pleas are not entered at the earliest opportunity. This court acknowledges the principle that credit should be afforded where pleas are tendered promptly, thereby sparing victims and witnesses from the stress attendant upon contested proceedings. However, where pleas are entered at a late juncture—often mere days before trial—the extent of credit granted is judiciously reduced to reflect the additional burden borne by the court and prosecution, consistent with guidance established in R v. Booth [2024] EWCA Crim 159 and R v. Bernal [2025] EWCA Crim 18. The Crown's case was fortified by a comprehensive evidential package, including digital footage, witness testimony, and forensic analysis, which it is conceded made prolonged denial untenable. It should be noted with respect the thorough and conscientious submissions made on your behalf by counsel, Mr Oliver Stretton, and also the diligent representation by Miss Amelia Fairlake on behalf of the Crown. Their efforts ensured the orderly progression of this matter, and their professionalism is commendable. Equally, I acknowledge the efforts of the Blackwell Business Crime Reduction Partnership, whose collective action yielded detailed victim impact statements that articulate the psychological and economic consequences of your offending on local shopkeepers and employees. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. The nature of your offending, whilst not involving physical violence, is nonetheless of considerable seriousness given its repetitive character and the distress caused to staff. Shops affected reported significant financial losses as well as a decline in employee morale, leading to staffing adjustments such as altered shift patterns and the installation of security reinforcements. This dynamic is far from inconsequential; indeed, it undermines the very fabric of community retail operations and poses a broader threat to public confidence in commercial safety. This court is attuned to the widespread perception that shoplifting constitutes a “low-level” crime often overlooked in the hierarchy of enforcement priorities. But such an appraisal is fallacious. The cumulative effect of repeated incursions upon retailers—particularly small businesses operating on narrow profit margins—can precipitate closures, job losses, and, in turn, contribute to the economic blight of neighbourhoods. In the absence of robust and proportionate judicial responses, the message sent is one of permissiveness, which in turn may precipitate a further descent into disorder and lawlessness. In R v. Bevan [2019] EWCA Crim 2743, the Court of Appeal made plain that offences of acquisitive dishonesty, while often non-violent, are not devoid of impact; the emotional toll on victims, coupled with financial harm, justifies stern judicial reaction. In that case, a defendant who perpetrated a sustained campaign of retail theft over eighteen months, causing significant distress among elderly shop staff, was sentenced to twelve months’ imprisonment. The sentiment expressed therein remains apposite. The relevance of sustained acquisitive criminality to the preservation of public order is also underscored in R v. Coulson [2022] EWCA Crim 333, where the court clarified the distinct sentencing considerations involved when conduct is repetitive, deliberate, and indicative of a disregard for community norms. The persistent flouting of laws designed to safeguard property rights is reflective of a disquieting erosion of civic standards, an observation echoed frequently in sentencing literature. Mr H placed protein powder and razor blade refills in his niece’s pushchair in an attempt to hide them. Your case management hearings unfolded against a background of significant administrative pressures, including intermittent strike action within local court administration and well-documented shortages in Legal Aid funding allocation. The delays occasioned thereby extend beyond the inconvenience of the affected parties and impede the expeditious dispensation of justice—a matter to which this court returns with some reluctance. The Legal Aid Agency, while under fiscal constraints, must not be allowed to create impediments to specialist expert engagement, particularly in cases where psychological assessment informs both sentence and rehabilitation potential. The request here for a forensic psychologist with expertise in acquisitive offending was met with protracted bureaucratic negotiation, which compounded procedural delay. On four separate visits within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same small shop and stole alcohol and tobacco products. The broader systemic context cannot be ignored. Local law enforcement agencies grapple with near-constant demands on capacity by an increasing caseload of “low-harm” offences which nonetheless generate significant community dissatisfaction and resource commitments. The strain on specialist units tasked with retail crime prevention and investigation is considerable. Concurrently, voluntary-sector organisations that aid in victim support and offender rehabilitation operate under chronic funding deficits and staffing shortages. The South Ashford Charity Alliance recently issued a report highlighting the alarming rise in retail-related antisocial behaviour and the attendant psychological impact on shop workers, many of whom report anxiety and burnout. Of course, the interplay between public services and judicial proceedings is complex. NHS mental health provision, for example, remains challenged by long waiting lists and overstretched community psychiatric teams. This court notes the submission of Dr Anne-Marie Cole, a consultant forensic psychiatrist, whose detailed report—although not ultimately pivotal—highlighted your tendencies toward impulsivity and low mood, while also drawing attention to the absence of any diagnosable psychotic or personality disorder. The report rightly stresses the importance of multi-agency cooperation in supporting rehabilitation and reducing recidivism. Turning to the difficulties encountered in securing appropriate accommodation, it is no secret that the widening gap in housing availability, exacerbated by economic pressures and the erosion of affordable units, has intensified the challenges faced by vulnerable populations. Organisations such as the ShelterTrust and the Blackwell Emergency Housing Support have endeavoured to mitigate these pressures, yet the scale of the problem remains vast. Your stated unstable living arrangements are, while unfortunate, not unique in this context. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. In considering the social fabric in which this offending occurred, one cannot overlook the well-documented ascent of street homelessness and rough sleeping in urban centres, with attendant concerns regarding drug dependency and exploitation. These challenges feed into a broader pattern of social exclusion that forms part of the mosaic in which many acquisitive crimes arise. Nonetheless, the judiciary must balance understanding with accountability; hardship is no less real for its ubiquity, yet neither does it constitute licence to disregard the law. The trial itself proceeded with the normal rigour of this court. Witnesses gave evidence with professionalism and considerable composure, reflecting the importance they attached to the case. The victim impact statements submitted by the managers of Croft’s Convenience Store and Wellside Pharmacy particularly conveyed the intangible but pervasive harm inflicted not only on business viability but on the everyday psychological welfare of staff who faced repeated intrusion, suspicion, and the threat of confrontation. You were represented by Mr Oliver Stretton throughout. His submissions, carefully considered and respectful of the court, emphasised your personal circumstances including your expressed remorse and attempts at engagement with outreach services. It is noted that you have participated intermittently in financial literacy workshops run by local charities and have attended support groups aimed at reducing impulsive behaviour, albeit inconsistently. The defendant used a magnetic device to disable the security tag, and this was later recovered when Mr H was arrested. While there is merit in recognising personal circumstance, the court must weigh these against the nature and pattern of offending, the impact on victims, and the broader imperatives of deterrence and public protection. In R v. Phillips [2023] EWCA Crim 1585, the Court upheld a significant custodial sentence for repeated shoplifting where the defendant had declined structured rehabilitation despite offers, emphasising that repeated acquisitive offending presents a significant risk of further harm if left inadequately addressed. Attention must be paid, too, to the ongoing concerns surrounding the administration and capacity of the probation services. Staffing shortages have increased caseloads and often limit the delivery of bespoke interventions, such as programme work aimed at reducing reoffending linked to acquisitive crime. The local probation office informed this court via correspondence dated 29 August 2026 that while efforts are made to engage offenders in Thinking Skills Programmes and similar rehabilitative initiatives, these are frequently hampered by resource limitations and the transience of the offender population. The defendant admitted selling stolen items at both a car boot sale and various local pubs, where his actions disturbed or distressed others present. Further complicating the picture is the expanding scope of multi-agency risk assessment and management. While procedures such as MARAC (Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conference) and MAPPA (Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements) primarily focus on high-risk offenders, there is increasing recognition of the necessity for coordinated approaches in cases of persistent acquisitive offending, particularly when co-occurring vulnerabilities such as mental health issues or substance use are identified. However, implementation of such frameworks varies significantly by locality, affected in equal measure by funding constraints and inter-agency communication challenges. Council housing allocations in your area have been affected by recent legislative reforms impacting tenant eligibility criteria, often delaying access to stable accommodation for those with custodial sentences or on probation. That said, the court is duty-bound to observe that residence instability itself is a well-known risk factor for repeat offending. Courts must be alert to this interplay and ensure that sentencing in individual cases does not inadvertently exacerbate instability or marginalisation without concurrent support. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, causing alarm and disruption in the store. In assessing your criminal history, it is apparent that you have prior convictions for shoplifting, dating back some six years, with the most recent occurring in 2023. These convictions include community orders with requirements to attend rehabilitation activities and abstain from certain locations. Despite these measures, you returned to similar offending within months, undermining their rehabilitative effect. This pattern raises serious questions about the adequacy of previous interventions and your prospects of compliance absent more structured engagement or, indeed, custodial oversight. The principle of totality must be borne in mind: sentences should be just and proportionate overall, taking account of all offending behaviour involved. Although the instant offences concern low individual values, the persistent course of conduct aggravates culpability. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, claimed it wasn’t a serious crime and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. I take note of several letters submitted in support by third parties, including one from your sister, Ms Janelle Harding, who describes a background of familial instability and some periods of homelessness in early adulthood. While such correspondence is relevant to understanding personal context and capacity for reform, it does not mitigate the seriousness of the offending. It is appropriate also to observe that there are ongoing proceedings concerning your estranged partner, unrelated to this matter but indicative of family turmoil which, while not legally connected, may bear upon your broader social circumstances. Likewise, the fact that a co-defendant in a separate theft case has absconded and remains at large, known to police, does not influence your individual culpability. The court is conscious that the psychological and social difficulties that many defendants face are real and profound. Yet it cannot abdicate its fundamental responsibility to uphold the rule of law and safeguard the public from repeated criminal conduct. The sentencing framework applicable to theft offences, as outlined in the guideline issued by the Sentencing Council in 2020, directs that particular attention be paid to frequency, planning, and impact on victims. These factors are all plainly engaged. In light of these considerations, the court anticipates the preparation of a pre-sentence report, which should comprehensively assess your circumstances, explore the scope for community-based interventions, and evaluate rehabilitation potential consistent with public protection. The report should consider the feasibility of imposing a structured community order incorporating accredited programmes such as Cognitive Behavioural Therapy focusing on acquisitive crime, financial management support, and victim awareness. Should such an approach prove unsuitable or unavailable, the court may have to contemplate custodial options. These sentencing remarks are given this day, 14 September 2026, in Court 6 at the Crown Court at Blackwell. The proceedings have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. You are reminded of your right to appeal against the sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are applied. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. B2025/04932 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. F. Kensington Filed: 17 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentencing following your conviction for shoplifting offences contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, in a case that has occupied a significant procedural footprint stretching over the course of the past 18 months. The offending conduct attributed to you spans various retail premises across Bristol and its immediate environs between March 2023 and June 2025. Procedural History and Case Management Your initial appearance was before the Magistrates’ Court on 15 June 2025, where bail conditions were imposed, including a curfew and daily reporting requirements. The matter was committed here for trial due to the seriousness attached to the pattern of offending and the volume of evidence requiring trial-level management. The case was listed under the Better Case Management (BCM) framework, a procedural initiative designed to expedite the handling of indictable offences by ensuring early identification and resolution of issues relating to disclosure, witness availability, and expert evidence. The case proceeded through a series of hearings and arraignments, with due regard paid to the obligations imposed by the Criminal Procedure Rules (CPR), consistent with the overriding objective of enabling the court to deal with cases justly and efficiently. I note that the prosecution, led by Ms Susan Warren QC, and your defence team, fronted by Mr Oliver Freeman, Solicitor Advocate, engaged professionally throughout a process punctuated by adjournments which, while unfortunate, reflected the complexities pertinent to this case. Early attempts were made to instruct a forensic psychologist to assist with mitigation and risk assessment; however, as is regrettably frequent, the authorisation from the Legal Aid Agency was delayed, resulting in some procedural difficulty which inevitably lengthened the preparatory period. This court has, on numerous occasions, raised concerns about systemic impediments within the administration of Legal Aid funding, which act as impediments to efficient case progression and add to burdens already borne by court staff and practitioners alike. The investigation was instigated following a report from the Bristol Retail Crime Reduction Partnership (BRCRP), a multi-agency body comprising local police, council trading standards, and independent retail security personnel. This team acts to collate intelligence, facilitate communication across stakeholder groups, and support a coherent enforcement approach to repeat thefts within the city centre and suburban retail districts. Whilst the Partnership operates with considerable dedication, the court is conscious of the pressures facing its membership, with shrinking budgets and increasing caseloads exacerbating the challenge of swift information sharing. Mr H was caught on CCTV placing £10 worth of haircare products into his coat and leaving the shop without making payment. This court is reminded that the acts of shoplifting, as defined by the Theft Act 1968, involve the dishonest appropriation of goods belonging to another, with the intention to permanently deprive. While single overt acts may attract minimal public notice, a sustained series of such offences, especially where they disturb community confidence and business viability, are considered in aggregate. You were apprehended on 12 June 2025 after a confidential tip-off to the Avon and Somerset Police Retail Unit, following weeks of surveillance and intelligence collation involving Closed-Circuit Television (CCTV) footage, electronic point-of-sale data anomalies, and on-the-ground witness statements. This investigation, as confirmed by Detective Inspector Helen Marsh, required considerable deployment of resources, including teams specialising in digital forensics who analysed mobile device data pursuant to warrants authorised by the District Judge. The operation extended over multiple weeks, involving coordination across borough boundaries and necessitating intermittent redeployment of uniformed and plainclothes officers. Mr H used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and protein powder. The scale of investigatory work undertaken — while arguably disproportionate to the monetary values directly involved — is justified by the need to uphold lawful commercial activity and community order. It is also influenced by the cumulative toll on retail employees who face disruption, anxiety, and the demoralising effect of recurrent thefts. The BRCRP's recent report outlined a trend of increasing acquisitive crime post-pandemic, with particular concern expressed over the impact on small, family-run establishments. Turning to the sentencing framework, this court acknowledges the guidelines promulgated by the Sentencing Council for theft offences, which emphasise the gravity of repeated offending and the vulnerability of victims, including employees subjected to harassment or intimidation. The leading guideline insists that sentences must be proportionate, taking into account aggravating and mitigating factors, the offender’s culpability, and the broader public interest. The Court takes careful note of the precedent established in R v. Ellison [2019] EWCA Crim 2402, where the Court of Appeal held that sustained shoplifting—planned and systematic—merits a custodial response despite low individual item values. Ellison concerned the theft of over £3,000 in goods from multiple branches of a department store over several months, involving sophisticated concealment tactics. The appeal court there highlighted the importance of deterrence, noting the cumulative economic and psychological damage inflicted. Furthermore, the decision in R v. Fenwick [2020] EWCA Crim 1175 is germane, insofar as it considered the partial mitigation offered by underlying mental health issues, but nonetheless upheld a sentence reflecting the inherent seriousness of persistent acquisitive offending. In that case, the defendant’s diagnosis of bipolar disorder was found to be a relevant, but not determinative, factor in sentencing. This court will carefully balance similar considerations here. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. While the rulings referenced address distinct factual matrices, their legal principles regarding credit for guilty pleas, offender culpability, and the appropriate threshold for custodial sentencing provide a helpful framework. The impact of your offences, though lacking violent component, has been acutely felt by those caught up in the offending. Victim personal statements were submitted by a range of retail staff, many of whom reported feelings of anxiety and apprehension during work hours. The management of several stores confirmed that staff rotas were altered to mitigate lone working, and some reported reductions in opening hours due to concerns about shoplifting and associated antisocial behaviour. The court is also conscious of the role of local charities such as ShopSafe Bristol, which offers support to retail workers experiencing the emotional toll of repeat thefts and shop-based aggression. Their written representations commend staff for their resilience but warn that without effective intervention the cumulative stress risks burnout and attrition within the sector. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. Notably, the witness statements also reveal the adaptation of loss prevention strategies, including increased use of electronic tags, heightened surveillance, and staff retraining—all costly measures borne ultimately by businesses and consumers alike. Your defence has advanced several mitigating factors, notably personal struggles with intermittent homelessness and unstable accommodation. Moreover, a psychiatric assessment conducted by Dr Eleanor Matthews, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, provides a detailed overview of your mental state, indicating features of borderline personality disorder, exacerbated by longstanding substance misuse. Dr Matthews concludes that while no psychotic or major affective disorder is present, the complexity of your cases suggests a need for carefully structured community support. It must be stressed here that psychiatric opinion was formally instructed to explore both mitigation and risk. Dr Matthews’ report, dated 30 September 2025, is thorough and professionally composed, presenting a nuanced view of your vulnerabilities alongside the recognition of persistent antisocial behaviour patterns. However, the conclusion within that report is guarded, noting that rehabilitation potential is contingent on your engagement with services which, thus far, has been erratic. The court takes this opportunity to commend the efforts of your defence team in the face of pronounced difficulties encountered with the Legal Aid Agency. Initial applications for funding to instruct the psychiatric expert were lodged in early August but only granted after protracted correspondence extending over six weeks. Such bureaucratic inertia, while lamentably routine, imposes unfair burdens on defendants and counsel alike and risks prejudice to the preparation of effective mitigation. These frustrations have been recorded in other courts and will, it is hoped, be addressed by forthcoming reforms. A magnet was used by The defendant to detach a security tag, and this item was found in his possession at the time of his arrest. It is impossible to divorce an understanding of this case from wider societal trends. Recent years have seen a marked increase in street homelessness within urban centres in the South West. Local authorities and voluntary organisations face significant challenges responding to needs that have outpaced resourcing. The normalisation of begging and street presence carries implications not only for those living in precarious conditions but also for community perceptions of public safety. This court is aware of reports by the Bristol Homelessness Action Forum underscoring the expanding nexus between destitution and acquisitive crime as survival mechanisms. While such contexts do not excuse criminal conduct, they offer an essential lens recalling that enforcement is but one strand in a multi-agency response. Alongside these grim realities is the enduring challenge of delivering mental health services to vulnerable adults. NHS waitlists for community psychiatric care and addiction treatment remain long, with significant variation in access depending on locality. Cases like Mr H’s underscore the necessity of integrated statutory and voluntary support systems, though as noted, the choice to engage remains with the individual. The defendant acknowledged selling the stolen property at a car boot market and in pubs, where his behaviour caused a disturbance to patrons. The court also acknowledges with respect the work of the Avon and Somerset Police Retail Crime Unit, whose members have contended with rising workloads and a broadening remit encompassing not only theft but complex data analysis, digital evidence retrieval, and victim liaison—all while navigating budgetary constraints. Interestingly, the emergence of so-called “hotspot policing” has yielded mixed results, with some shifts in offending locations rather than reductions in overall theft rates. This has prompted academic critiques regarding the sustainability of current enforcement models. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. In parallel, the Probation Service remains afflicted by staff shortages and increasing caseloads complicated by the COVID-19 pandemic’s ongoing effects. A limited number of available appointments for accredited cognitive skills programmes constrains the options for structured rehabilitation. Council Authorities, alongside voluntary housing agencies, continue grappling with mounting demands, and the increasing frequency of temporary accommodation placements creates a fragile base from which individuals like yourself must attempt reintegration. Sentencing for offences such as yours must navigate the tension between deterrence, reparation, rehabilitation, and public protection. The Sentencing Council’s theft guideline outlines culpability categories and harm ranges, noting that persistence and premeditation increase the severity. The court must also consider whether ancillary orders—such as a Rehabilitation Activity Requirement or a curfew—might complement formal sentencing, though suitability depends on risk assessment. Addressing the timing of your guilty plea, which came on the second day of trial proceedings, the court is bound to note that while such pleas reduce exposure to trial-related distress, they cannot command the maximum credit available for early admissions. The principle is established that guilty pleas entered at an advanced stage principally function to conserve judicial resources but do not necessarily evince genuine remorse. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. Mr H, this case is emblematic of the complex challenges at the intersection of criminal conduct, social vulnerability, and systemic resource limitations. Your conduct, though lacking in violence or threat, has nonetheless had persistent and tangible consequences for individuals and communities. While the court recognises mitigating circumstances and the psychiatric evidence indicating your difficulties, it must also send a clear message about the unacceptability of repeated dishonesty. The preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report is essential to ensure that the holistic circumstances are analysed in detail and that the sentencing response appropriately addresses rehabilitation needs and public safety. It is hoped that such a report will explore feasible intervention pathways linking probation, mental health services, and social support networks. Members of the public and victims alike deserve to have confidence that the court’s response is proportionate, effective, and principled. This sentencing hearing has been conducted in open court, with all parties duly present. I record my thanks to Ms Warren QC for her considered submissions, to Mr Freeman for his diligent and nuanced advocacy, and to the probation officers and psychiatrists who have contributed expert insights. I further commend the court staff and ushers, who have ensured the smooth running of proceedings despite a recent refurbishment rendering court 5 uncomfortably cramped. These sentencing remarks are issued this 17th day of October 2025, in Court 5 at the Bristol Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal order of conviction and sentence will be processed through appropriate channels. You are advised of your right to appeal within twenty-eight days in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. MR H Case No. B2025/24579 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge S. W. FENWICK Filed: 15 August 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced following your conviction for theft by shoplifting contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending conduct attributed to you spans a protracted period, covering multiple separate events occurring within Birmingham and the surrounding metropolitan boroughs from the latter months of 2023 through the early part of 2025. Procedural Background Your case initiated with the receipt of intelligence from the Birmingham Retailers Association, coupled with a number of incident reports compiled by the West Midlands Police Business Crime Team. These reports detailed a pattern of repeated thefts from several local retail outlets, many small independent stores and pharmacies serving particularly vulnerable communities. The reports were made over a nine-month interval, conveying a growing sense of escalating loss and distress amongst those affected. The involvement of the Business Crime Reduction Partnership in Birmingham, while formally robust on paper, revealed some familiar practical difficulties. Local officers, despite commendable diligence, confronted issues including inconsistent data-sharing protocols and varying levels of retailer cooperation, many of whom faced commercial pressures dissuading prolonged engagement with law enforcement. I note here, parenthetically, that the effectiveness of the BCM model is dependent on the goodwill and capacity of both statutory and non-statutory actors. In numerous hearings, this court has received evidence that suggests procedural weaknesses in information collation and enforcement responsiveness continue to blight efforts to stem retail theft in large urban areas. These systemic challenges, while tangential to this case’s particulars, form an important backdrop. You were arrested on 18 March 2025 after an intensified investigative period. That investigation included covert surveillance from uniformed officers, the collation of digital CCTV footage, primary witness statements, and mobile device analysis. The deployment of such investigative resources illustrates the rising seriousness with which local authorities approach repeat acquisitive crime, recognising not only the immediate economic losses but also the adverse effect on community wellbeing. The trial dates proceeded after several procedural hearings, including a plea and trial preparation hearing on 1 June 2025, where you maintained a not guilty plea. However, on the morning of trial on 11 August, you entered an unequivocal guilty plea. This pattern of late admission is, regrettably, a recurrent feature in cases of this type, inviting reflection on its impact upon the efficient administration of justice and on those who bear the consequences, not least the numerous retail staff called to prepare for trials which ultimately do not proceed. Legal Aid funding for commissioning an independent psychiatric assessment took several months to authorise, in no small part due to administrative backlogs at the Legal Aid Agency. This reflects a growing concern regarding access to timely expert evaluations in criminal proceedings involving complex social and psychological dimensions. The delays, while understandable in context, pose a significant impediment to the proper resolution of cases within expected timeframes. It is both necessary and appropriate to record the court’s gratitude to Mr David Mapperley, counsel for the Crown, whose forensic presentation throughout these proceedings has been methodical and measured. Likewise, I thank Ms Elaine Thompson, who appears for the defence. Despite the inevitable pressures attendant upon Legal Aid work, her submissions have been conscientious, conforming fully to her professional responsibilities. I observe, again with some disappointment, that staffing levels at the West Midlands National Probation Service have dwindled significantly over the past several years. This reduction has led to increased caseloads per officer and consequently diminished capacity for thorough risk assessment and offender management. That reality hampers the delivery of preventative measures, a fact that must bear upon our collective considerations of sentencing and rehabilitation. Mr H was seen hiding £15 worth of over-the-counter medicines in his jacket and walking out without making a purchase. The relevance of a cogent psychiatric evaluation was duly noted during pre-trial discussions. The report authored by Dr Simon Riley, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, submitted on 8 July 2025, offers an insightful, though ultimately inconclusive, appraisal of your mental state. Dr Riley emphasises the absence of severe psychiatric pathology but identifies certain mild personality traits indicative of impulsivity and diminished frustration tolerance. The report also notes your sporadic engagement with community-based support, highlighting a lack of sustained compliance with therapeutic interventions. I must further mention the recent correspondences received from the East Midlands Charitable Trust for Shoplifting Victims, who have provided victim impact statements representing several affected stores. Their narratives speak of ongoing financial strain and psychological stress endured by employees. The court acknowledges the humanitarian value of the Trust’s contributions and recognises their tireless work in the face of shrinking charitable funding and increasing demand. The hearing room itself—Courtroom 5 at Birmingham—was refurbished earlier this year. While this does not directly bear upon the merits of the case, it is worthwhile noting that modern facilities contribute significantly to the dignified conduct of proceedings. The layout facilitates better audio-visual integration for the display of evidential CCTV footage and ensures accessibility for all parties. The Crown’s case drew substantially upon high-definition video evidence obtained from multiple locations. This includes footage captured on 3 February 2025 at the Willow Lane Pharmacy, viewed by store staff and law enforcement alike. The careful adherence to the Criminal Procedure Rules (CPR) Part 5 in the collation and disclosure of these materials is commendable and provides a secure evidential framework within which matters unfold. Mr H used the bottom compartment of his niece’s pram to hide razor cartridges and protein supplements. Following the receipt of disclosure, the defence raised concerns regarding the chain of custody for some exhibits, particularly items recovered from a skip adjacent to the Cedar Road Supermarket. However, these concerns were robustly addressed during pre-trial hearings and found insufficient to warrant exclusion of the evidence. Turning to jurisprudence relevant to sentencing in theft cases, it is appropriate to recall the guidance in R v. Stephens [2019] EWCA Crim 815, which reinforces that the quantity and frequency of offences contribute materially to culpability assessments when considering aggregate sentencing. Stephens involved a defendant who engaged in serial shoplifting across multiple jurisdictions over an 18-month period, much like the present matter. The Court of Appeal in that case confirmed that persistent acquisitive offending, even when involving low-value items, can no longer be regarded as petty or frictionless by public authorities. In addition, the court notes R v. Carmichael [2020] EWCA Crim 1234, where the defendant was found guilty of a series of fly-tipping offences causing significant environmental damage, incurring both cleanup costs and public hazard. Though of a very different nature to the present offence, Carmichael highlights the judiciary’s increasing willingness to impose custodial sentences for patterned, opportunistic behaviour detrimental to public amenity and trust. Though not directly analogous, the principle that cumulative impact can justify robust sentencing resonates here. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. The defendant’s personal circumstances warrant close scrutiny. You are currently 34 years old, unemployed, and residing in accommodation provided by the Birmingham Housing Authority. Your history includes prior convictions, predominantly for low-level acquisitive crimes, dating back to adolescence. Your educational attainment is limited, and your vocational history reflects intermittent transient employment, largely in the service sector. A recent pre-sentence report compiled by Probation Officer Ms Yasmin Clarke reflects a nuanced assessment. Ms Clarke notes your expressed desire to desist from offending yet outlines concerns regarding your inconsistent engagement with support services. She highlights risk factors including financial instability, substance misuse (particularly noted alcohol use), and social isolation. Predictably, these findings are consistent with those reported in the psychiatric assessment. Mr H feigned interest in Oyster Card payments to distract the cashier and reached behind the counter to take an item from the display. The court is acutely aware of the pressures placed on public services in addressing the roots of crime. Social housing demand in Birmingham continues to outstrip supply, exacerbating residential transience and insecurity, which in turn correlate with various negative outcomes. The increasing burden on NHS mental health services, with waiting times for community psychiatric care stretching into months, further complicates efforts to stabilise vulnerable individuals. While such systemic limitations do not excuse misconduct, they nonetheless provide important contextual understanding. The daytime anti-social behaviour in Broad Street, a local nightlife area, has been the subject of recent public consultation though it bears little relation to this case. Similarly, unrelated are the ongoing investigations into a local high-profile arson attack at a commercial unit in Court 3 of this building, which delayed court listings earlier this year by several days. The evidence discloses that on multiple occasions you were accompanied by acquaintances during your visits to retail establishments, though no collusion or joint participation in thefts has been substantiated. Their names and involvement, if any, have no direct relevance to sentencing in this matter before the court. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. The court also notes a letter dated 12 August 2025 received from the defendant’s sister, Ms Camille H, who expresses her hope for rehabilitation and a peaceful future for you. Such family support is an important factor, albeit distal, and I commend the letter's tone and intent. It is also worth referencing a recent Court of Appeal ruling, R v. Bannister [2024] EWCA Crim 667, concerning the imposition of custodial sentences for co-defendants in offences of aggravated burglary and violent disorder. While unrelated to this shoplifting matter, Bannister illuminates principles concerning the interplay between offence gravity and mitigating personal circumstances, which, where applicable, inform sentencing considerations. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. The overarching sentencing framework requires balance. The court must weigh your culpability and prior record against any mitigating circumstances. Sentencing must serve deterrence, punishment, and rehabilitation, always mindful of public protection. Given persistent challenges in convincing defendants to engage meaningfully with probation and ancillary agencies, it is incumbent upon this court to consider not only traditional sanctions but the utility of rehabilitative orders. The construction sector in the Birmingham region continues to encounter fluctuating opportunities for employment, but this is a generic concern rather than a special marker of individual circumstance. Similarly, your mention of aspiring towards training as an electrician is acknowledged, though concrete steps towards this aim remain unsubstantiated. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while damaging security cameras using spray paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. It is regrettable that recent police data analytic reports highlight a continuing rise in theft offences across the West Midlands, placing further strain on already stretched resources. The cumulative drain on policing, administration, and retail businesses from such persistent offending cannot be underestimated. Notably, a local Community Safety Partnership report observes the sustained impact on storefronts and the wider neighbourhoods affected by recurrent localised acquisitive crimes, notwithstanding multiple community patrol initiatives and public reassurance campaigns. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, doesn't view his actions as theft and intends to keep doing so. I must commend the Metropolitan Shopkeepers' Support Network for their collaborative approach involving victim support, advocacy, and training on theft prevention measures. Their work exemplifies the proactive role civil society plays alongside formal agencies in addressing retail crime. The Legal Aid Agency, for its part, has come under scrutiny for the delays and administrative complexities highlighted earlier; this court urges the relevant bodies to expedite processing without compromising thoroughness. Those factual and procedural elements considered, I will direct the preparation of an up-to-date pre-sentence report addressing risk, needs, and suitability for available rehabilitative programmes, including cognitive behavioural interventions targeting impulsivity and criminal thinking patterns. Assessment should include the potential for a Community Order incorporating an Activity Requirement, and structured unpaid work where manageable. These are the sentencing remarks of His Honour Judge S. W. Fenwick, delivered on the 15th day of August 2025 in Court 5 at Birmingham Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed in compliance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to appropriate authorities accordingly. You are advised of your right to appeal by lodging notice within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs are reserved for consideration. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. MR H Case No. B2025/14379 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. A. STRATTON Filed: 12 October 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentence in respect of charges brought under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, specifically concerning allegations of shoplifting committed over an extended period in various retail outlets within the West Midlands jurisdiction. The chronology of offending spans from July 2023 through to the spring of 2025, incorporating incidents in both urban and suburban retail centres, notably including multiple high street chemists, small grocery stores, and convenience outlets. Procedural and Investigative Background You were initially arrested on 15 April 2025 following a coordinated investigative effort led by the West Midlands Police Commercial Crime Unit in collaboration with several local Business Crime Reduction Partnerships (BCRP). These operational units have increasingly adopted a multi-agency approach to tackling repeated acquisitive offending in retail environments, combining data gathered from CCTV systems, retailer incident logs, and witness testimonials. The case files reveal that although individual shoplifting incidents might appear minor in isolation, the aggregation of such events presented a pattern indicative of a deliberate course of conduct, meriting prosecution in the Crown Court to address the seriousness and cumulative harm caused. It should be noted that this case progressed under the auspices of the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol, designed to ensure early clarity on pleas and issues, to facilitate timely trial preparation, and to reduce avoidable adjournments. Despite this framework, the matter did encounter some procedural setbacks, including a delay of several weeks owing to the initial need for further disclosure from a third-party digital evidence custodian, and from defence applications to instruct expert psychiatric assessment, which required approval of Legal Aid funding. Such administrative delays, dishearteningly, remain commonplace within our criminal justice system, notwithstanding efforts to streamline processes. It is a matter of considerable regret—and worthy of formal observation—that the Legal Aid Agency exhibited a protracted and bureaucratically cumbersome approach to the timely resolution of expert instruction requests. The defence’s initial submission for funding of a forensic psychologist was made on 17 May 2025, but full authority to proceed was only granted on 23 July 2025 following multiple chaser correspondences and clarifications. This inefficiency introduces systemic friction into proceedings and, regrettably, does so at the expense of all parties and the administration of justice. Similar challenges afflict other areas within the justice system, including delays in psychiatric assessments due to NHS capacity constraints and operational staffing shortages within probation services. These are not isolated to this case; rather, they reflect enduring structural pressures. It is also important to record that during the defendant’s custody, a separate incident arose in the West Midlands Custodial Centre involving another detainee. This unrelated episode concerned the assault of prison officers with improvised weapons, resulting in disciplinary investigation and procedural safeguards review. Whilst entirely distinct from the charges presently before this court, it serves as a reminder of the complex social and institutional environments in which justice operates—a milieu often marked by concurrent conflict and disruption, which can weigh heavily upon those tasked with upholding order and safety. At the plea and trial preparation hearing, initially scheduled for 8 August 2025 but postponed due to late disclosure issues, you entered a not guilty plea. However, as the prosecution’s evidence—detailed in extensive CCTV footage, forensic analyses, and retailer statements—became overwhelming, you pleaded guilty at the outset of the trial window on 21 September 2025. Such late-stage pleas, while permitted by law and recognised within sentencing guidelines, warrant careful scrutiny. The sentencing discount available for guilty pleas is grounded not only in the fact of admission but in the timing and its genuine reflection of remorse. The Court of Appeal, in cases such as R v. Whitlock [2023] EWCA Crim 892, has reiterated that pleas delivered at the “eleventh hour” amidst inevitable conviction do not merit the same degree of reduction as those entered promptly, thereby affording meaningful credit for early acceptance of responsibility. The Crown, represented commendably by Miss Abigail Morton, Counsel for the prosecution, has made detailed submissions addressing the full breadth of offending, noting the systemic impact of your conduct on vulnerable retail sectors and the economic burden borne by small businesses. For the defence, Mr Edward Finch, appearing under a representation order, has ably emphasised mitigating features including the defendant’s unstable housing circumstances and financial pressures. The court takes this opportunity also to thank the staff and managers of retail establishments affected by your conduct who provided victim impact statements. Their accounts speak of the demoralising effect of recurring theft, the disruption caused to staffing patterns, and the psychological distress imposed on employees fearful of confrontation or customer hostility. Mr H concealed £19 worth of nail polish and beauty accessories in his clothing and exited the premises without payment. To contextualise this offence within the broader framework of acquisitive crime, it is prudent to acknowledge that offences of this nature account for a significant portion of retail shrinkage losses nationally, exerting pressure not only on individual shop owners but also on supply chains, insurance schemes, and policing resources. Reports published by the British Retail Consortium in recent years indicate that losses from retail theft constitute billions of pounds annually, with consequences that ripple through employment, prices, and community wellbeing. Boxed razor cartridges and protein powder were hidden in Mr H's niece’s pram to avoid detection. The Theft Act 1968 remains the cornerstone legislation in defining and prosecuting offences involving dishonest appropriation, and section 1 expressly captures the conduct at issue here. Sentencing guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council advise that the seriousness of theft should be assessed not merely by financial value, but by factors including premeditation, impact on victims, breach of trust, and recurrence. In the present case, the representative charge captures a sustained pattern over months of repeated offending. The courts have held consistently that such cumulative behaviour reflects intent and culpability beyond isolated acts. For instance, R v. Granville [2022] EWCA Crim 1335 concerned a defendant convicted for a series of shoplifting offences targeting high-value beauty products over a sustained period; the Court of Appeal affirmed an immediate custodial term, underscoring the need to deter persistent dishonesty that erodes community confidence. Similarly, the decision in R v. Faulkner [2020] EWCA Crim 1804 highlighted that offenders who exploit commerce through stratagem and iteration demonstrate a marked disregard for the law and social order, thereby attracting increased sentence severity. That judgment found particular significance in the manner and frequency of offending, factors readily applicable to your conduct. It is worth observing that jurisprudence concerning aggravating features in acquisitive crime increasingly references the psychological toll on retail staff, particularly in small businesses where close community relationships exist. The judgment of Lord Justice Parker in R v. Armitage [2019] EWCA Crim 764 stressed the “erosion of personal security” felt by employees who suffer repeated victimisation, a dimension that must inform sentencing severity. Notably, I must also reference R v. Birchwood [2021] EWCA Crim 1562, a case where the defendant was convicted of theft from multiple charity outlets, engaging in distraction tactics to evade detection. That case affirmed that even ostensibly low-value thefts, when sustained and conducted with artifice, attract custodial sentences due to the cumulative impact on victim organisations and public trust. Mr H was recorded returning to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time taking alcohol and tobacco goods. The Court also notes an instructive precedent in R v. Donahue [2023] EWCA Crim 994, which dealt with a defendant involved in the illegal importation and distribution of counterfeit goods, including branded perfumes. Although the factual matrix materially differs from simple theft, the case elucidates court attitudes towards consumer deception and cumulative economic harm, relevant as background context though bearing no direct relation to your own offending. Of wider interest, there have been recent appeals concerning offences unrelated to theft but involving community safety issues proximate to retail areas. For example, in R v. Fowler [2024] EWCA Crim 311, a defendant was sentenced for affray arising from a pub brawl involving pool cues, a matter to which this court has no direct relation nor relevance here save to note the breadth of crime impacting commercial premises. In a deliberate act of distraction, Mr H engaged staff in a conversation about Oyster Cards while covertly removing a display item from behind the counter. I have carefully considered the clinical report prepared by Dr Helen Marks, consultant forensic psychiatrist, instructed upon the defence’s application. Her assessment, conducted over two sessions in late August 2025, determines that you suffer from no severe mental illness. However, she identifies elements of impulsivity, coupled with mild to moderate alcohol dependency, noting that these factors “may contribute to impaired decision-making under stress,” though not amounting to a recognised mental disorder excusing criminal liability. Dr Marks’ evaluation also highlights a “history of inconsistent engagement with support services,” particularly those addressing housing instability and addiction. This finding accords with observations made in the probation service’s pre-sentence report, which emphasises intermittent compliance with appointments and reluctance to pursue longer-term rehabilitation pathways. Such sporadic engagement is regrettably not uncommon among individuals facing entrenched socioeconomic adversity. The probation officer, Ms Claire Heng, in her comprehensive report filed on 1 October 2025, advocates for consideration of community rehabilitation with a tailored programme targeting acquisitive crime cognition and impulse control. Ms Heng remarks upon “limited genuine insight” demonstrated by you during her interviews, tempered by a willingness at times to express regret for the impact on victims. She notes, however, that your accommodation situation—currently residing in temporary supported housing following eviction from previous premises—poses a risk factor for reoffending, citing research linking housing instability with increased likelihood of acquisitive offences. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. The probation report references the considerable strain on community services in the West Midlands, with waiting lists for substance misuse programmes exceeding six months and housing allocations severely constrained. These systemic limitations undoubtedly complicate rehabilitation prospects, though the report underscores the necessity of your active participation in available interventions. The defendant admitted selling stolen items at both a car boot sale and various local pubs, where his actions disturbed or distressed others present. Recent scholarly commentary on the interplay between acquisitive offending and social welfare has noted that while economic hardship is a factor, it does not inexorably lead to crime. The Justice Policy Institute, in its 2024 report, stressed that “agency and choice remain central to offending decisions” and that criminal justice responses must balance compassion with accountability. Analysis of Your Criminal Record and Personal Circumstances You are currently 34 years old, with a recorded history of five prior convictions for theft-related offences spanning the last eight years. The earliest recorded conviction in 2018 was for shoplifting high-value confectionery, resulting in a conditional discharge. Subsequent offending led to community orders in 2020 and 2022. The latter, issued by a magistrates’ court in Dudley, required completion of a cognitive skills course, which you admitted only partial compliance with. Your residential history reveals volatility: periods of temporary accommodation interspersed with episodes of sofa-surfing among acquaintances. There is no evidence suggesting gang association or involvement in organised crime, and you have no recorded convictions for violence or drug-related offences. A letter received from your sister, Mrs Fiona H, and additional correspondence from the community outreach charity “Hope Pathways,” attest to your recent attempts at stabilisation, emphasizing your expressed desire to find employment and abstain from further offending. While these representations are encouraging, their content must be weighed against documented behavioural patterns and the need for public protection. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. While shoplifting is often perceived as a “minor” offence, persistent and strategic offending that undermines retail security and victim confidence warrants serious consideration of the public interest in deterrence and community protection. The use of community sentences with rehabilitation requirements is appropriate where there is a reasonable prospect of compliance and remediation. However, the court must balance this with the need to signal that repeated shoplifting, even if non-violent, carries consequences proportionate to its societal impact. The case also presents a useful point of contrast with R v. Everitt [2019] EWCA Crim 845, where an offender convicted of criminal damage to a church noticeboard received a community order with unpaid work imposed. The relatively isolated and less economically damaging nature of that offence differentiates it markedly from the repetitive, financially oriented conduct before this court. It is worth recalling that the Probation Service in the West Midlands faces significant resource constraints, with a frontline workforce under increasing pressure, a factor that risks impairing the intensity and quality of supervision. In this respect, sentencing proposals that include supervision must consider realistic capacity and the potential for genuine engagement. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, claims it isn’t really stealing and intends to keep doing so. This court remains firmly of the view that sensory and psychological distress caused to retail employees by repeated shoplifting is deserving of serious acknowledgement. It is a matter of record that the stress engendered in such workplaces has caused some staff to seek transfers or to request reduced responsibilities, and business owners to incur increased security costs. The clear message of the Courts is that such conduct will not be condoned. Further, it is evident that while socioeconomic adversity and personal challenges may provide context, they do not excuse persistent criminal behaviour, particularly where assistance has been made available and declined. The offending in this matter involved a clear pattern of opportunism and planning, consistent with deliberate dishonesty. Sentencing will therefore take place following receipt of any updated reports or further representations, including a possible addendum from the probation service assessing progress on engagement with services over the intervening weeks. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 12 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. The proceedings have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is advised of their right to appeal within 28 days of sentence in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
