input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT HARTFIELD R v. MR H Case No. H2025/15479 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge D. J. KENWORTH Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentence upon a charge of theft, specifically multiple counts of shoplifting from various retail establishments over a protracted period. The offending conduct, as charged, is contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, and reflects a sustained pattern rather than isolated lapses. The offences occurred over an eighteen-month timeframe in the Hartfield metropolitan area and its immediate environs. Procedural History You were initially taken into custody on 5 May 2025 following an investigation that spanned several months and involved coordinated efforts by the Hartfield Metropolitan Police, alongside the Hartfield Retail Crime Task Force. This multi-agency approach involved the collation of store incident reports, digital evidence including CCTV footage, and employee statements, some of whom were compelled to provide detailed witness accounts under cross-examination during preliminary hearings. The collaborative apparatus assembled to address such behaviour invokes not only law enforcement but also retail security consultants and community liaison officers. The Hartfield Business Crime Reduction Partnership played a pivotal role, maintaining communications with affected merchants, analysing trends, and advising on best practices to reduce losses. Such partnerships, while theoretically demonstrating promising frameworks for crime reduction, frequently encounter practical challenges such as staff turnover, variations in data recording standards, and uneven financial backing from participating outlets. You elected to enter pleas of not guilty at the first listing on 18 June 2025, triggering the setting of a plea and trial preparation hearing in accordance with the Better Case Management regime. The Court noted with some measure of approval that all parties proceeded with reasonable expedition, notwithstanding the regrettable delays occasioned by Legal Aid representation orders and the late appointment of defence counsel. As is often the case in matters relying on forensic identification techniques, your legal representatives prudently sought an independent expert assessment, which was delayed by several weeks due to administrative backlogs in the Legal Aid Agency’s processing, a regrettable but familiar pattern. The second hearing, held on 15 August 2025, confirmed your intention to change your plea to guilty, a decision communicated shortly before the hearing commenced. While the court acknowledges that such guilty pleas serve to streamline proceedings and relieve witnesses of the distress associated with testifying, the timing unfortunately restricts the scope of discount applicable. As the Court of Appeal elucidated in R v. Holden [2023] EWCA Crim 1582, such last-minute admissions, absent compelling mitigating circumstances, attract significantly reduced credit. I take this opportunity to reiterate commentary on the persistent systemic issues affecting the justice system’s capacity to deliver fair and timely resolution. The delays caused by funding authorisation for expert psychiatric evaluations, as well as constraints within the probation service due to chronic under-resourcing, continue to impair the administration of justice in cases much like this one. These institutional challenges underscore the complex social ecology within which offending arises, but do not excuse it. Not least because repeated offending imposes direct burdens upon victims and indirect costs upon overstretched public services. The court also notes the recent refurbishment of Courtroom 4, completed earlier this year. While the physical environment of justice is tangential to substantive matters, it is a symbol, perhaps, of ongoing efforts to uphold dignity, decorum, and accessibility within the judicial process. Equally noteworthy is the continued commendable professionalism of the court ushers and clerical staff, who, despite rising caseloads and administrative complexity, maintain order and furnish procedural explanation to parties in language accessible to lay participants. The statutory framework governing theft is well-established, resting on the foundational principles set out in the Theft Act 1968. The offence requires proof of dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with intent to permanently deprive. Theft encompassing repeated incidents with calculated intent and planning attracts greater seriousness under sentencing guidelines, reflecting not only the tangible loss but also the wider psychological impact upon victims and communities. Considerable guidance is sourced from the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on theft, which underscores factors such as the frequency of offences, premeditation, and the vulnerability of The victims or locations targeted. The aggravating features of repeated offending, especially when directed at small independent retailers or specialist outlets, have been shown in authorities such as R v. Fenwick [2020] EWCA Crim 1825 to justify custodial sentences reflective of the cumulative harm. Though Fenwick concerned an offence of shop theft conducted under duress, its dicta regarding proportionality in sentencing remain instructive here. There is also instructive precedent in R v. Telford [2022] EWCA Crim 2134, where the Court upheld a sentence of immediate custody for thefts from community pharmacies, noting the heightened effect on staff morale and security concerns arising from targeted repeat offending. While the present charges do not include violence or threat, they are not entirely without impact beyond economic loss. Furthermore, although not germane to your own conduct, the court recalls the judgment in R v. McDermott [2019] EWCA Crim 908, involving wilful fire-raising at a local church hall, which emphasized the court’s duty to consider societal implications when imposing sentences even where direct physical harm is absent. Such cases serve as cautionary markers, reminding the court and public alike that low-level offences, if untreated, erode the social fabric. Turning to scholarly opinion, the evolution of sentencing principles over the last decade has been informed by a shifting landscape of criminal justice policy. The Better Case Management initiative, referenced earlier, was introduced following Lord Justice Briggs’ seminal Review (2016), which advocated for earlier case resolution and more effective resource allocation. While that reform has yielded improvements in some jurisdictions, the present case also demonstrates ongoing areas for procedural refinement, particularly in addressing Legal Aid bottlenecks. There is, moreover, a rich tradition of appellate decisions underscoring the interaction between mental health considerations and sentencing. Notably, in R v. Bellamy [2018] EWCA Crim 1207, the Court examined the limits of mitigation where psychiatric diagnosis intersected with persistent offending, concluding that clinical need does not diminish the court’s obligation to protect the public. Although your own clinical reports, which I shall discuss shortly, do not disclose major mental illness, that case frames the broader judicial approach well. The court is called, implicitly, to situate your offending within a wider societal tableau marked by rising economic precarity, fluctuating employment patterns, and increasing strains on housing services. Hartfield’s municipal homelessness figures have risen steadily in recent years, with temporary accommodation placements often lasting beyond statutory maximums due to acute shortages. Local food banks face demand far exceeding capacity, something reported in recent correspondence from Hartfield Community Aid, which also notes pressures on volunteer staffing. It bears mention that the Hartfield retail sector has, over the last five years, witnessed a slow attrition of independent shops, displaced in part by online commerce and rising business rates. This market transformation affects not only economic dynamics but community cohesion, as small retailer participation is integral to neighbourhood vibrancy. The converse – an environment in which persistent petty theft cycles endure – risks destabilizing this fragile equilibrium. There have been recent policy forums on the role of multi-agency panels, including Hartfield’s Local Crime Reduction Strategy Group, which continues to grapple with data-sharing limitations under GDPR constraints. Such restrictions hinder the prompt identification of repeat offenders and the deployment of tailored interventions; a problem noted elsewhere in the country, as highlighted in the Home Office’s “Review of Data Integration in Crime Reduction” (2024). Your case was also briefly delayed due to a court-wide adjournment resulting from a fire alarm activation in the adjacent Court 5 complex on 22 September, necessitating an evacuation and subsequent re-listing. This incident, while unrelated to your case specifically, showcases the operational vulnerabilities inherent in historic court buildings juxtaposed against modern digital courts elsewhere. At the initial hearing, you were remanded on conditional bail with a curfew order, reflecting the court’s assessment of the risk of reoffending and potential interference with witnesses. Throughout this period, probation and police liaison officers reported compliance with bail conditions, albeit with intermittent reports of non-attendance at appointments. Such compliance, while to be noted, should not be conflated with genuine behavioural change but rather regarded as procedural adherence. Mr H hid £17 worth of grooming items under his jacket and walked past the tills without stopping to pay. On the subject of your antecedents, the probation records indicate three prior convictions for similar offences within the last seven years, all relating to theft under £200. There is one recorded instance of a community resolution imposed in 2023 involving theft from a supermarket, though the record suggests subsequent breach thereof. No indication exists of gang affiliation or organised crime nexus, nor is there any record of violence or intimidation associated with your offending. Mr H hid boxed razor blades and protein powder among his niece’s belongings in her pram. The court received a comprehensive pre-sentence report prepared by Ms Joanne Sinclair, probation officer, who carefully considered risk, personal circumstances, and potential for rehabilitation. Notably, Ms Sinclair emphasises that your engagement with probation services has been, at best, sporadic. Attempts to initiate cognitive behavioural interventions met with limited attendance and frequent cancellation. The pre-sentence report further remarks on your reported history of unstable accommodation and significant periods of unemployment. You acknowledge reliance on state benefits and some occasional informal cash-in-hand work. The caseworker’s summary flags ‘low motivation for change’ as a significant concern. In addition to the probation input, a contemporary psychiatric evaluation was commissioned, with the report provided by Dr Elsie Byers, consultant psychiatrist at Hartfield Mental Health Trust. Dr Byers’ assessment concluded that no major mental illness is evident. She describes your presentation as ‘personality traits consistent with impulsivity and low frustration tolerance’ but explicitly excludes diagnosable personality disorder or psychosis. The report recommends that any engagement with structured community programmes focus on addressing impulsive behaviour and underlying social determinants. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. Letters of support submitted on your behalf include one from Ms Hannah Lewis of the Hartfield Outreach and Support Network, who speaks of your ‘occasional attendance at group sessions’ but acknowledges inconsistent engagement. A statement from your sister, Ms Tamara H, was also tendered, highlighting familial tensions but expressing hope for positive progression should appropriate support be secured. It is worth noting the continuing operational challenges experienced by community support agencies locally. In a recent parliamentary briefing, the National Probation Service highlighted chronic staffing deficits and reported caseloads frequently exceeding recommended limits. Coupled with reductions in third-sector funding, these constraints curtail the availability of intensive supervision or specialised interventions. Mr H pretended to ask a question about Oyster Card payments in order to distract staff, then reached behind the counter and took a display item. Victim personal statements from managers and staff across the affected retail outlets have been submitted. They reflect a microcosm of the wider harm occasioned by your offending: increased anxiety, redistribution of workload to cover shift absences caused by stress, and heightened security measures including shelf locking and door alarms. While your actions did not entail physical confrontation, the psychological impact is nonetheless material. One victim impact report from the proprietors of a family-run chemist in Hartfield town centre details how staff changes were accelerated to mitigate exposure to your presence, resulting in financial and operational disruption. The court is cognisant of the wider implications of such repeated offending, notably in the cumulative drain on public resources - from investigative time to administrative processing and the indirect consequences for retail insurance premiums. It bears noting that in R v. Maddox [2019] EWCA Crim 1961, the Court emphasised the significance of the knock-on effects of repeated retail crime, even where individual theft values were modest. The defendant removed a security tag using a magnet, which was later recovered during his arrest. The Crown’s Submissions Ms Lydia Farr, counsel for the prosecution, has submitted that this court should impose a sentence reflecting the cumulative nature of the offending, its persistence despite previous warnings and interventions, and the demonstrated impact on victims. She emphasises that community orders with unpaid work and programme requirements may be appropriate but stresses that the threshold for custody should not be discounted lightly. The prosecution notes your late guilty plea, acknowledging some discount but reminds the court of the limited early opportunities afforded to the defence. Ms Farr further highlights the necessity of deterrence in a case typified by systematic evasion of lawful constraints. Mr Oliver Dwyer, appearing for you via a legal representation order, has submitted mitigating factors, including your unstable housing, unemployment status, lack of previous custodial sentences, and acknowledgement of responsibility. He contends that these factors militate strongly against immediate custody and advocate for a community penalty incorporating rehabilitative interventions, subject to the court’s approval. Mr Dwyer draws attention to personal challenges, including episodes of homelessness and reported past substance misuse, which, though not directly linked to the offences, provide context indicative of broader vulnerability. Citing the judgements in R v. Parker [2021] EWCA Crim 1034 and R v. Clarke [2023] EWCA Crim 1087, Mr Dwyer advocates for proportionality and rehabilitation in sentencing, reminding the court of the Human Rights Act considerations implicit in custodial decisions. He also notes your cooperation post-arrest and willingness to engage with support services as a positive step, emphasising the role of community sentences in reducing recidivism. The defendant disclosed that the stolen goods were sold at a car boot sale and in pubs, where his conduct caused unease among customers. Observations on Public Policy and Service Constraints It is incumbent upon the court to observe that the demand for community sentences exceeds supply, and the capacity for tailored programmes is frequently outstripped by case volumes. Waiting lists for cognitive skills courses and substance misuse programmes in Hartfield have, at times, extended to twelve months or more. This delay undermines rehabilitative prospects and compounds public safety risks. Notification of statutory duties to protect public welfare and prevent reoffending requires critical balancing against the finite resources of probation, courts, and ancillary services. Despite numerous reform proposals, including the 2024 Ministry of Justice Efficiency Plan, substantial challenges persist. An unrelated matter of record is the ongoing investigation into corruption within the local probation office, currently under internal inquiry and external oversight by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Probation. While unrelated to this case, such institutional instability casts a shadow on service delivery. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while damaging security cameras using spray paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. The facts of the offending are as follows. Over the course of the eighteen-month period leading to your arrest, you committed multiple acts of shoplifting from retail premises primarily within Hartfield’s central business district. The offences included a sequence of thefts from convenience stores, pharmacies, and independent merchants, marked by frequent return visits and use of distraction techniques, including commanding staff attention while concealing items. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. On several occasions, your conduct involved removal of security tags and calculated evasion of staff surveillance. The value of stolen goods in individual instances was low, but cumulative losses resulted in tangible economic harm and psychological distress to victims. While your demeanour during police interviews was cooperative in the later stages of investigation, earlier denials delayed resolution and imposed additional investigatory burdens. In consideration of all material before the court, including the probation assessment, psychiatric evaluation, victim impact statements, legal submissions, and your antecedents, I have yet to determine the appropriate disposal. Given the complexity of factors and the necessity of ensuring a sentence tailored not only to punishment but also promoting rehabilitation and preventing reoffending, I shall order a further pre-sentence report. This report will also consider any updated information you may provide following engagement with support services. The final sentence will be imposed at a hearing to be listed shortly following receipt of that report. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 October 2025, in Court 4 at the Crown Court at Hartfield. The proceedings are transcribed and recorded under the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal within 28 days of sentencing pursuant to relevant statutory provisions. No reporting restrictions under sections 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 or associated legislation are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. MR H Case No. T2026/05849 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge J. M. PENDLETON Filed: 17 October 2026 Mr H, you are before this court to be sentenced following your conviction for shoplifting, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending relates to a series of thefts committed over the course of nearly two years, principally within the Birmingham city centre retail district, but extending to several neighbouring town centres. The matter has been listed before me for sentencing following your admission of guilt at the plea and trial preparation hearing on 22 September 2026. Procedural History and Overview Your initial arrest took place on 11 February 2026 after a protracted investigation led by the Birmingham Business Crime Taskforce, a multi-agency unit combining local policing resources with the Retail Theft Intelligence Section. This collaborative effort involved coordination with other bodies including the West Midlands Trading Standards Department and the regional CCTV Operations Unit. The investigation, which encompassed a review of diverse evidence streams such as closed-circuit television footage, point of sale records, and witness statements collected over a 14-month period, culminated in charges being brought against you in mid-March 2026. In these environments, one might naively assume that the availability of visual surveillance technology would simplify evidentiary collection and case preparation. However, as has been well documented in academic and judicial circles alike, the raw presence of video footage is rarely sufficient on its own. The quality of such images varies dramatically. It is not uncommon, as this court has observed in previous matters, for footage to suffer from distortion, obstructions, or misaligned timestamps, rendering it frequently unreliable in isolation. Indeed, the judicial experience has shown that securing a coherent narrative from such disparate recordings often requires the painstaking cross-referencing of multiple camera angles, store incident logs, and employee recollections, a process both time-consuming and costly. It is a truism that the police and prosecution frequently must devote substantial resources to what might superficially appear to be 'minor' offences — a term which belies the real human, economic, and communal cost of such thefts. The misapprehension that petty theft occupies a lower rung on the ladder of criminal harm dismisses the lived experience of retail workers, many of whom endure persistent anxiety and stress as a consequence of repeated thefts on their premises. These impacts ripple outward — affecting store profitability, potential job security, and local consumer confidence alike. The Better Case Management (BCM) framework was engaged from the outset to ensure efficient case progression in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Rules. This court notes with measured satisfaction that despite the chronic under-resourcing that characterises many contemporary public services, the case documentation was filed in advance of hearings as required and that liaison between the various agencies involved proceeded without undue obstruction. It is worth noting, however, that this procedural efficiency is regrettably not the norm. So much judicial time is otherwise consumed by adjournments related to missing paperwork, delayed expert reports, or contested applications for legal aid funding. This brings me to the matter of funding. The Legal Aid Agency’s handling of requests related to your defence has been, with no small degree of regret, problematic. The initial application to instruct an independent forensic psychologist was submitted on 3 April 2026, yet was not authorised until 15 June 2026. This two-month delay, accompanied by intermittent requests for additional clarifications and documentation, is emblematic of a wider malaise within the system that undermines timely justice, imposes unnecessary burdens on counsel, and causes distress to defendants and victims alike. As the court has previously noted in similar contexts, such administrative inertia is inimical to the proper functioning of the justice system and warrants urgent remedial attention. Before turning to the specifics of your offending, I must acknowledge the ongoing contributions of certain voluntary sector bodies with whom you have had some contact during these proceedings. In particular, the Birmingham Retail Staff Support Network submitted a letter to this court on 4 October 2026 outlining the challenges faced by shop employees in the wake of repeated theft incidents. Their efforts to engage with affected individuals, provide counselling, and advocate for improved working conditions are commendable and deserve formal recognition in these remarks. Additionally, the Midlands Community Reinvestment Project has provided reports concerning local economic impacts of high retail shrinkage rates — including increased prices that inevitably affect vulnerable shoppers. It is notable that these agencies operate under significant financial constraints, reliant on grants and volunteer effort, yet nonetheless maintain a constructive dialogue with the criminal justice system. You entered a plea of not guilty at your first appearance, which was subject to the listing of a contested plea and trial preparation hearing. At the plea hearing on 22 September 2026, shortly before trial was due to commence, you elected to plead guilty. It is therefore necessary to address the credit to be awarded for that guilty plea, which, given its timing, is to be considered in light of established appellate authority. The Court of Appeal has on numerous occasions considered the principle that early guilty pleas deserve greater recognition, serving both to conserve public resources and to relieve victims and witnesses from the burden of giving evidence. The decision in R v. Elliott [2022] EWCA Crim 993 is apposite. There, the court stated that while credit for a guilty plea is a well-established mitigating factor, “the timing of that plea and the factual context in which it is made are matters of judicial discretion to be exercised with a careful balancing of interests.” Similarly, in R v. Kaur [2023] EWCA Crim 45, the court underscored the diminished credit available where a plea is entered at a late stage, particularly when evidentiary disclosure has long been complete and the plea is seen as tactical rather than demonstrative of genuine remorse. Having said that, while your plea was not at the earliest point in the process, it nevertheless brought the matter to a conclusion sooner than a contested trial would have permitted, thus achieving some degree of procedural economy. The credit you receive will be adjusted accordingly. The law and sentencing guidelines applicable to theft offences of this kind are well established. The Theft Act 1968, at section 1, defines the offence succinctly: the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving the other of it. The Sentencing Council’s guideline on theft offences, last updated in 2022, provides the framework within which offences of this character are assessed, taking into account factors such as the value of the goods taken, the frequency of offending, the impact on victims, and any aggravating or mitigating features. As a matter of context, the guideline expressly recognises that repeated or organised shop theft causing persistent distress or economic loss can justify custodial sentences, even where the sums involved are individually modest. It is both instructive and necessary to consider certain case law developments, although the factual matrices in those cases may be materially distinct from the present circumstances. For example, the widely-cited decision in R v. Maidstone [2019] EWCA Crim 370 considered an offender who engaged in a course of shoplifting over a period of several years, targeting supermarket chains with sums totalling in excess of £18,000. That case emphasised the need to take a proportional approach, balancing the offender’s personal circumstances against the public harm caused, and upheld a sentence of twelve months’ custody suspended for two years, subject to supervision and unpaid work requirements. Another illustrative judgment is that in R v. Campton [2021] EWCA Crim 887, where the defendant was convicted of trafficking stolen goods after an operation involving stolen electronics sourced from multiple retail outlets. The court in Campton stressed that organised or commercialised shoplifting merits a more severe response, reflective both of the degree of premeditation and the broader impact on the community, including distortion of legitimate market activities. While there is no suggestion here of such commercial operation, the case serves as a useful backdrop for evidencing the escalating seriousness with which the courts treat such offending. Turning from legal authority to the facts before this court, I must now set out the particulars as reflected in the evidence provided to the trial and the pre-sentence reports commissioned. Mr H placed £18 worth of bath and body items inside his coat and left the store without attempting to pay for them. Mr H attempted to hide boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in the undercarriage of his niece’s pushchair. The facts establish a clear pattern of repeated and opportunistic theft over a sustained period, involving multiple retail outlets including high street chains and local independent shops. The thefts involved goods frequently targeted for their easy resale value: personal care products, over-the-counter medicines, and electronics accessories. This is characteristic of a particular modus operandi commonly seen in such cases, as noted by the Birmingham Retail Crime Partnership in their analytic brief issued on 31 August 2026, which highlights the growing sophistication of what might once have been regarded as impulse theft. Mr H was recorded returning to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time taking alcohol and tobacco goods. An important feature noted in the Crown’s evidence was the apparent use of concealment techniques, including layering clothing to obscure items, and in some instances, coordinated timing to coincide with busy periods or staff changes. It is also recorded that on occasion, you adopted apparent pretext conversations on mobile phones, thereby attempting to reduce staff vigilance — a tactic unfortunately all too familiar in such circles. Community impact statements provided by multiple shop managers detail the disruption caused, including increased anxiety among staff, the need to alter rotas, and an understandable reluctance to work unsupervised during vulnerable hours. The psychological toll, while intangible, is no less real for those affected. One witness, an employee at a modest independent pharmacy in Digbeth, spoke movingly of how your repeated visits instilled a palpable sense of dread amongst the team, a distress compounded by the fear that management might not fully appreciate the severity of the issue. Such victim impact is rightly regarded by this court as a material aggravating feature in determining the appropriate sentence. Mr H pretended to ask a question about Oyster Card payments in order to distract staff, then reached behind the counter and took a display item. The defendant removed a security tag using a magnet, which was later recovered during his arrest. If one were to pivot briefly to the operational context of the agencies involved in your case, it bears mentioning the considerable strain placed upon the West Midlands Probation Service and local policing teams. The increased volume of acquisitive crime has contributed to elevated workloads, staff shortages, and a deficit in resources available for diversion or rehabilitative programmes. This systemic pressure has been extensively documented in the Annual Review of the West Midlands Criminal Justice Board (2025), which outlines the challenges faced in accommodating specialist interventions in a climate of austerity and high demand. These observations do not excuse individual conduct but serve to situate it within the broader environment of ever-decreasing institutional capacity. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. An independent psychiatric report ordered pursuant to the defence’s application was prepared by Dr Sylvia Lane, consultant forensic psychiatrist, whose assessment was received on 13 September 2026. Dr Lane observed that you exhibit no major psychiatric disorder but identified enduring difficulties with impulse control and emotional regulation. She commented that your engagement with social support networks has been inconsistent and that there is a risk of continued offending absent targeted intervention. Dr Lane expressed the view that community-based rehabilitative efforts focusing on impulse management and cognitive behavioural approaches could offer some benefit, provided that sufficient motivation and support structures are available to secure meaningful engagement. However, she cautioned that premature optimism about voluntary compliance in such cases is often misplaced. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while blinding cameras using aerosol paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. The court also acknowledges the social and personal difficulties you have experienced, including periods of insecure housing and episodic employment. While such hardships undoubtedly present challenges, they do not provide an automatic or sufficient justification for criminal conduct. The principle that hardship does not equate to licence remains firmly embedded within criminal justice jurisprudence and policy. A recent local authority report commissioned to assess the availability of support services for individuals at risk of recidivism found that while a modest array of options exists — including housing advice, debt counselling, and substance misuse programmes — demand far outstrips supply. This mismatch inevitably results in wait times and crisis points, reducing the likelihood that all defendants in your position will access interventions promptly or effectively. Nonetheless, the existence of such services is not to be dismissed and the recalcitrance or failure to engage with them when offered weighs heavily against considerations of mitigation. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, said it was no different to borrowing and has no intention of stopping. In the course of these proceedings, an unusual procedural matter arose. It was noted that your co-defendant in an unrelated case involving possession of offensive weapons was present in custody at the same time. This person’s case, involving an affray outside a licensed premises in Erdington with the use of pool cues as weapons, is entirely distinct from yours and bears no causal connection. While such overlap in the court roll sometimes causes confusion, this court is satisfied that no evidential or procedural overlap affects your determination. Equally, seen in the context of community-based schemes, the recent operation “Shield” conducted by the West Midlands Police involved patrols targeting fly-tipping activities on green belt land around the Solihull district. Its broader aim to reduce environmental crime is valuable but unrelated to your charge, serving only to illustrate the expansive scope of policing demands in the region. In sentencing, this court must weigh a range of factors derived from statute, precedent, sentencing guidelines, and the specific circumstances of the case. A custodial sentence, although severe, is not invariably the default for shoplifting offences. However, where the offending represents a deliberate, repeated pattern causing tangible harm to victims and the community, custody becomes an increasingly proportionate response. Having considered all material, including the reports from probation services, psychiatric assessments, victim impact statements, and counsel submissions, I find the following features to be particularly cogent. The clear pattern of prolonged offending despite previous warnings or interventions; the adverse impact on retail workers and the local economy; the late plea of guilty providing only partial mitigation; and the limited engagement with support mechanisms offered — these collectively weigh heavily toward a custodial outcome. That said, I note your youth at the time of the earliest offences, your expression of regret in court, and some open acknowledgement of the pressures contributing to your behaviour. These factors serve to tilt the scales marginally towards suspending or limiting the term of custody, subject to considerations of future compliance and rehabilitation. In accordance with standard protocol, I hereby order that a pre-sentence report be commissioned without delay. This report should encompass a thorough assessment of your personal circumstances, risk of reoffending, and suitability for any community-based interventions, including but not limited to cognitive skills training, restorative justice, and employment support schemes. The probation service is requested to pay particular attention to devising a tailored package of interventions aimed at addressing impulse control difficulties and opportunities for social reintegration. It is hoped that this report will furnish the court with the necessary detail to arrive at a sentence that both protects the public and provides a realistic prospect of reducing future offending. I express my thanks to Ms Zoe Fenton, who appeared on behalf of the Crown, and to Mr Samuel Norris, who has represented you under a representation order. I record once again my concern at the delays caused by the Legal Aid Agency’s tardiness in authorising expert assessments. I also thank the court staff who have maintained order and facilitated smooth progress throughout these proceedings, notwithstanding occasional staffing shortages and scheduling constraints. The courtroom itself was recently refurbished, with new security features installed, which although tangential, have contributed to an improved environment for all participants, which merits passing mention. Finally, I remind you that these sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 October 2026, in Court 8 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT EASTBOURNE R v. MR H Case No. T2025/15739 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge D. J. Eldridge Filed: 19 October 2025 Mr H, you appear today before this court to be sentenced for a representative count of theft under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The indictment relates to a course of conduct involving repeated shoplifting offences over a period extending from mid-2023 to early 2025, committed at multiple retail premises within the boroughs of Eastbourne and Hastings. Procedural History The matter came before the Crown Court following your arrest on 17 March 2025. Your detention followed a lengthy multi-agency investigation coordinated by the Eastbourne Borough Police Retail Crime Unit alongside local business security teams and the Sussex Business Crime Reduction Partnership (BCRP). The partnership had collated detailed incident reports, customer complaints, and undercover operations data over more than 18 months. They sought to identify patterns of repeat offending that had a disproportionately detrimental effect on independent and small-chain retailers within the seaside commercial zones. Such investigations into low-level but persistent retail theft demand significant allocation of limited policing resources. Officers tasked with these cases, who might otherwise address violence or organised crime, are frequently engaged over extended periods with detailed evidence gathering; this includes obtaining and reviewing hours of CCTV footage, interviewing store staff and witnesses, and cross-jurisdictional information sharing. The burden on police and retail partners reflects not only the material loss but also the intangible costs borne by employees and communities. As is well documented, an area which suffers repeated instances of retail theft commonly reports increased staff anxiety, high absenteeism, and a diminished sense of safety that may precipitate reduced service hours or closure. It is to the credit of the BCRP that they managed to sustain engagement with both law enforcement and retailers throughout the protracted investigative phase, despite significant challenges including staff turnovers and stretched operational capacity. Your arrest was the culmination of covert surveillance and an intelligence-led operation that included authorised mobile phone data extraction approved by the Senior Investigating Officer and an independent judicial authorising magistrate under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000. The resultant evidence, including multiple CCTV captures and witness statements, presented a compelling case which led to your formal charge. Following your initial custody and interviews under Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 protocols, you were charged with eight counts of theft and subsequently arraigned in the Magistrates’ Court on 21 March 2025. Because of the perceived complexity and volume of evidence, the matter was committed to the Crown Court for trial or plea. The case was listed under the Better Case Management (BCM) pilot initiative aimed at expediting the preparation and hearing of cases with comprehensive evidence sets. No less than four pre-trial hearings were convened between April and September 2025, each scheduled in consultation with the parties to ensure compliance with disclosure obligations and to permit the exchange of defence materials, including expert reports. The Legal Aid Agency’s administration in this case was, regrettably, marked by repeated delays, particularly concerning applications for funding to commission forensic psychiatric analysis and cognitive assessment. This situation is unfortunately emblematic of the systemic challenges faced by practitioners in securing timely authorisation for expert involvement, as has been noted in recent Parliamentary Select Committee enquires on legal aid funding efficiency. Your defence attorney, Mr Jonathan Blythe, instructed under a Legal Aid scheme, made laudable efforts to mitigate these bureaucratic impediments, resulting in a late but comprehensive psychiatric report being submitted on 30 September 2025. I acknowledge Mr Blythe’s continuing professionalism under these conditions. Ms Sylvia Arden appeared for the Crown Prosecution Service and advanced an unambiguous case against you. The matter was first listed for plea and trial preparation on 12 June 2025. At that hearing, you entered a not guilty plea, with the case being adjourned to allow for further evidential disclosure and expert reporting. However, on 15 September 2025, shortly before the trial window was due to open, you altered your plea to guilty on the single representative count. It is a regrettable yet familiar pattern that defendants in persistent acquisitive crime cases often maintain denial until the weight of evidence, including forensic corroboration and multiple witness statements, makes contest untenable. The courts recognise the conventional discount for early guilty pleas as an incentive for early admission of responsibility, which may spare victims and witnesses from the rigours of trial. However, where pleas are delayed until near trial, the discount must appropriately reflect the timing and motivation rather than be viewed as an unavoidable right. The Court of Appeal has repeatedly emphasised this principle: see R v. Benfield [2024] EWCA Crim 1543 and R v. Silverton [2023] EWCA Crim 2101. A comprehensive review of sentencing authorities underscores the judiciary’s imperative to hold the balance between rehabilitation on the one hand, and deterrence and public protection on the other. In R v. Fletcher [2022] EWCA Crim 889, the Court of Appeal upheld the imposition of an immediate custodial sentence where persistent dishonesty was accompanied by a manifest lack of remorse or engagement with rehabilitative services. Conversely, R v. Kirkland [2023] EWCA Crim 801 reiterated the necessity of proportionate sentencing reflective of the offender’s social and psychological circumstances. There is, of course, an expanding corpus of jurisprudence addressing the intersection between mental health, addiction, and risk assessment in offences of this nature. In R v. Matthews [2019] EWCA Crim 1156, the court elucidated that while underlying vulnerabilities may inform sentencing disposition, they do not detract from accountability where the risk of reoffending remains high and community safety cannot be assured. More recently, in R v. Harper [2024] EWCA Crim 330, the engagement failure with community psychiatric resources weighed heavily against the appellant’s plea for leniency. Mr H was seen hiding £15 worth of over-the-counter medicines in his jacket and walking out without making a purchase. It is important to reflect on the operational context in which offences such as those under consideration occur. Retail theft, though often minimised or dismissed as trivial, imposes a ripple effect that reaches well beyond the immediate loss of goods. Local shops frequently operate on tight margins, and persistent theft undermines their viability, sometimes precipitating closures that erode the social fabric of high streets and community cohesion. Clerks and assistants bear the brunt of confronting offenders, absorbing not only financial but also emotional strain. The Safer Eastbourne Partnership, a multi-agency initiative tasked with reducing acquisitive crime, submitted a detailed community impact statement. This report draws attention to the deleterious effects of recurrent shoplifting on staff morale, with some employees requesting transfers or resigning due to stress and fear. It notes, pertinently, that while offences are low-value individually, their cumulative effect is significantly disruptive. Boxed razor cartridges and protein powder were hidden in Mr H's niece’s pram to avoid detection. The Sentencing Council’s Theft Offences Guideline (2024) remains the authoritative framework guiding judicial approach. The guideline categorises theft in bands reflecting harm and culpability, acknowledging factors including victim vulnerability, use of deception, breach of trust, planning, and sophistication of offending. The repeated nature of conduct and its economic and psychological impact weighs heavily towards the upper range of seriousness. Additionally, it is appropriate to consider the Sentencing Council’s Overarching Principles Guideline, updated last in 2023, which directs courts to impose sentences commensurate with public protection while encouraging intervention where suitable. Rehabilitation and reduction of reoffending underpin many community orders, but only when the offending pattern and defendant’s circumstances allow. It would be remiss to overlook the noteworthy developments in court administration pertinent to this matter. Eastbourne Crown Court has recently concluded a major refurbishment of its courtroom audio-visual facilities, facilitating improved access to video evidence and digital exhibits. While peripheral to substantive justice, such enhancements serve the delivery of fair and expedient trials. In the current pandemic-impacted climate, courts have contended with fluctuating operational constraints, staffing shortages, and sporadic adjournments, including a brief suspension following a staff Covid outbreak in Court 1 during early 2025. These external factors notwithstanding, the parties are commended for adherence, as far as possible, to scheduled listings. Your case was delayed in part due to the unavailability of an appropriate forensic psychiatric expert, a predicament linked to the limited number of qualified consultants willing to accept publicly funded instructions. This scarcity impairs timely justice and burdens the system, a problem regularly raised by the Criminal Bar Association and echoed in recent Ministry of Justice consultations. Within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same shop on four occasions, each time removing alcohol and tobacco without paying. Consideration was also given to an application for ancillary matters involving the examination of co-defendant behaviour in an unrelated matter. I note that a former flatmate of yours was subject to separate proceedings involving possession of a bladed item on school premises, the subject of R v. Langford [2022] EWCA Crim 1349. That offence bears no connection to your conduct and must be disregarded in assessing your culpability. Similarly, references in the case file to a prior landlord noise abatement notice served upon your accommodation’s owner in 2023 are extrinsic and irrelevant to the Court’s deliberations. No evidence suggests this impacted upon your offending. Notwithstanding the apparent complexity of the criminal justice process, this case stands as a demonstration that cooperative work between agencies—police, courts, legal representatives, and community groups—can yield cohesive procedural outcomes with integrity. On one occasion, Mr H asked staff about Oyster Card payments as a distraction, then leaned behind the counter to take a display item. As part of the pre-sentence assessment, a report was prepared by the probation service, addressing your background, previous offending, social circumstances, and risk of reoffending. The report speaks to a history of unstable accommodation, marked periods of unemployment, substance misuse including intermittent dependency on alcohol, and intermittent engagement with voluntary support services. However, the report identifies significant gaps in your receptivity to sustained intervention, noting missed appointments and periods of lost contact. The report further references the “Thinking Skills Programme” and “Enhanced Thinking Skills” initiatives, which have been introduced nationally as cognitive behavioural interventions targeting reasoning deficits implicated in patterns of acquisitive offending. While potentially beneficial, your current levels of engagement suggest cautious optimism at best. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. The psychiatric evaluation conducted by Dr Marian Telford, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, while noting no major psychiatric illness, identifies features consistent with an impulsive personality disorder and low mood exacerbated by social isolation. While no formal diagnosis of major depressive disorder was made, Dr Telford observed that instability of housing and lack of family support contribute to ongoing vulnerability. Despite recommendations for social work support and engagement with local alcohol support charities, your record suggests ambivalence, limiting the practical effect of such clinical advice. The probation service also highlights that no evidence was found of involvement in organised crime, coercion, or human trafficking, and that no child safeguarding concerns have been raised in relation to your household. I acknowledge the letter submitted on your behalf from a local charity, The Brighton and East Sussex Homeless Outreach Trust, which underlines the precariousness of your current living arrangement. The letter, while supportive, cautions that the ongoing risk of eviction and extreme weather exposure pose an urgent housing challenge. The impact of this instability on mental health and behaviour is recognised, notwithstanding the Court’s expectation of personal responsibility. In line with longstanding precedents, it remains essential that sentencing targets both the needs of the individual offender and the broader imperative of public protection. Rehabilitation-focused sentences retain their place; however, community measures must be effectively tailored and credible in terms of prospect of compliance. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. It is essential to record a brief reflection on the broader climate within which courts like this operate. The significant pressures levied upon public services—including probation, mental health, and social care—have escalated markedly in recent years. Increasing caseloads and reductions in resource allocation challenge the capacity of front-line workers to maintain consistent engagement and deliver bespoke interventions. In this vein, I must commend the efforts of the local probation team who, despite these constraints, have committed substantial time to preparing thorough reports and supervision plans for this court. Similarly, thanks are due to the staff of the Sussex Business Crime Reduction Partnership, whose victim liaison work exemplifies professionalism and care in circumstances where collective resolve is often tested. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, causing alarm and disruption in the store. Turning to ancillary jurisprudence relevant to sentencing duration, although your offences bear no connection to matters involving arson, the Court of Appeal decisions in R v. Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624 and R v. Bhandari [2023] EWCA Crim 412 provide instructive contrasts in addressing sentences for calculated and escalating criminal behaviour marked by public risk. In both cases, custodial sentences were affirmed where the scale and degree of harm warranted restriction of liberty for a significant term. While these cases do not map directly onto your conduct, they emphasise the principle that judicial discretion must always account for the protective function of sentencing alongside rehabilitation. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. In concluding, I remind you of the well-established parameters within which the judiciary operates. Sentencing is not conducted in isolation from the societal context but is fundamentally an exercise in balancing the competing objectives of retribution, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. Summary The facts as admitted disclose a persistent and deliberate pattern of shoplifting over an extended timeframe, marked by planning and disregard for lawful boundaries. The impact upon victims—small retailers and employees alike—has been palpably adverse. Your personal circumstances afford some mitigation, but your lack of meaningful engagement with available support services weighs against a wholly lenient approach. A plea of guilty, while welcome, was tendered at an unusually late stage; thus, the credit for that plea will be calibrated accordingly in sentencing. I shall therefore direct that a comprehensive pre-sentence report be prepared by the National Probation Service. The report is to examine in detail the suitability of community orders incorporating rehabilitative programmes such as cognitive skills training and supervision aligned with mitigating your offending triggers. It shall also consider accommodation stability, substance use treatment engagement, and potential restorative justice interventions. While the possibility of custodial sentence cannot be excluded in light of the pattern and persistence of offending, the Court remains open to options that advance both your rehabilitation and the protection of the community. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 19 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Eastbourne. Proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be conveyed to the appropriate authorities. You are advised of your right to appeal within 28 days, pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. No order as to costs is made at this stage. These are the orders of the court.

The indictment presents a representative count, which stands for a series of like offences committed against various businesses. The defendant is hereby reminded of the right to appeal against conviction or sentence within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT ROYAL BARKING R v. MR H Case No. RB/2025/14429 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. A. LANGLEY Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H, you come before this court for sentence following your conviction for offences of theft by shoplifting, in breach of section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The conduct spans a significant period between November 2023 and June 2025 and was committed across a range of retail outlets within the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham as well as neighbouring wards. The offences represent a sustained course of dishonesty and calculated theft that has caused genuine distress among victims and wider repercussions within local business communities. Procedural Overview The case was originally charged at Barking Magistrates’ Court following your arrest on 28 June 2025. You were detained under investigation subsequent to a multi-agency inquiry coordinated by the Barking and Dagenham Retail Crime Partnership and the Metropolitan Police Service’s Specialist Crime Unit. Intelligence was gathered over a period exceeding fourteen months, incorporating evidence from numerous local businesses, CCTV footage, police patrol logs, and witness statements. Upon committal, the case was passed to this court for sentence pursuant to the Crown Court allocation scheme due to the scale and complexity of the offending. Your initial appearance in this court occurred on 7 July 2025, when you entered a not guilty plea. A plea and trial preparation hearing followed on 22 August 2025, at which point defence counsel indicated that a guilty plea would be forthcoming. However, the final admission of guilt was not tendered until the first day of trial on 15 September 2025, following detailed review of prosecution evidence and a pre-sentence psychiatric assessment. The court, recognising the pattern of late pleas in similarly situated cases, notes the effect on the efficient administration of justice and will, in due course, give appropriate credit for your eventual admission of responsibility. It is important to observe that this court was informed that the Legal Aid Agency’s processing of applications for expert psychiatric assistance in your case was protracted and marked by considerable procedural delays. The initial request for funding to instruct Dr Sarah Eastman, a forensic psychologist with expertise in acquisitive offending, was submitted on 16 July 2025 but only approved following numerous correspondence exchanges on 3 September 2025. These delays, while regrettable, underscore systemic challenges in resource allocation and administrative procedures within the legal aid framework, which continue to impact the timely resolution of cases involving vulnerable defendants. At all hearing stages, the court has benefited from the professional diligence of Ms Laura Benson, appearing on behalf of the Crown, and Mr Daniel Roberts, your instructed counsel on a legal aid funded basis. Both counsel have made detailed submissions directed at ensuring that sentencing reflects the balance between public protection, personal mitigation, and the overarching principle of proportionality. The cooperation demonstrated by prosecution and defence teams is noted with appreciation. The court also acknowledges the engagement of community support organisations, notably the Barking East Neighbourhood Support Network, whose written submissions provide insights into the broader socio-economic context in which offending occurs, without seeking to excuse it. Their efforts to support both victims and offenders reveal the complex web of interdependencies involved in addressing acquisitive crime. The Theft Act 1968 remains the principal legislative source governing offences such as those before the court. Shoplifting, while often perceived as a low-level offence, has evolved substantially in its patterns and methods, prompting the Sentencing Council to issue updated guidelines on theft offences in 2023. Those guidelines reinforce that repeated offending, targeting of vulnerable premises, and the aggravating impact on victims and local commerce properly attract increased custodial considerations. Cases such as R v. Fairbairn [2019] EWCA Crim 465 illuminate the court’s approach to repeated shoplifting where the defendant exhibits persistence despite prior sanctions and community interventions. There, a sentence of 21 months’ immediate custody was upheld, reflecting the destabilising effect on small businesses and workforce morale. Similarly, the decision in R v. Cheung [2022] EWCA Crim 1307 highlighted the court’s recognition of the cumulative harm inflicted by serial theft from independent retailers, emphasizing the psychological distress on staff and the erosion of community trust. In comparative terms, cases involving offenders with prior convictions who breach bail or community orders—as in R v. Connors [2021] EWCA Crim 990—are illustrative of reluctance to desist and warrant sentences that convey clear denunciation and deterrence. While your circumstances diverge in specifics, these authorities form the backdrop against which the present sentencing exercise must be viewed. Mr H placed £18 worth of bath and body items inside his coat and left the store without attempting to pay for them. It is well-recognised that serial acquisitive offences, though often involving items of modest monetary value, propagate disproportionate social harm. The aggregate effect of sustained dishonesty corrodes the operational viability of small and medium enterprises, fosters an atmosphere of suspicion and vigilance, and contributes to a deterioration of public order. Staff often face increased pressures, leading to disrupted work patterns and operational constraints that erode service quality and employee welfare. Indeed, retail crime reduction forums have repeatedly documented the strain placed on in-store and security personnel forced to contend with frequent losses, the deployment of enhanced security measures, and the psychological toll exacted by exposure to persistent offending. From a prosecutorial standpoint, there is a growing imperative to approach such offending not as isolated lapses, but as patterns indicative of underlying risk and recidivism. Your case falls precisely into this categorisation. This court is mindful of the challenges faced by law enforcement agencies in managing the competing demands posed by acquisitive crime alongside serious organised and violent crime. The allocation of investigative resources to secure your prosecution demonstrates the priority accorded to such offences. Notably, electronic evidence was gathered through a carefully coordinated partnership between police digital forensic units and local retail security teams, highlighting the evolving nature of intelligence-led policing. Mr H deliberately used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and a container of protein powder. Your personal circumstances, as detailed in the Probation Service’s pre-sentence report dated 10 September 2025, reflect a complex interplay of adverse experiences, economic hardship, and intermittent engagement with support agencies. You are recorded as currently unemployed, residing in temporary accommodation provided by the Barking Housing Association, and having a limited support network. The report sensibly observes that while you suffer no recognised severe mental health disorders, there persists a degree of emotional dysregulation and impulsivity that may have contributed to your offending behaviour. Critically, the report emphasises variable compliance with offered support, particularly in relation to debt counselling and alcohol misuse services. The court notes with concern that despite multiple outreach attempts, your engagement has been sporadic, limiting the effectiveness of therapeutic and rehabilitative interventions. It is essential to reaffirm that the existence of such services does not in itself absolve an offender of responsibility; rather, successful rehabilitation depends on meaningful uptake and sustained participation. Correspondence from the Barking Homelessness Prevention Team, received on 5 September 2025, underscores the acute pressures exerted on local housing provision, with substantial waiting lists and a predominance of temporary accommodation placements. This context, while undoubtedly challenging, cannot excuse or justify persistent offending. The capacity constraints across statutory and voluntary sectors are a sobering reality, reflecting broader social fractures rather than individual excuses. In this vein, the court reflects on the position taken in R v. Murphy [2020] EWCA Crim 789, where challenging life circumstances were acknowledged as mitigating factors but did not preclude the imposition of immediate custodial sentences given the public interest in deterrence and denunciation. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. Incident-specific Considerations and Victim Impact The Crown has adduced testimony and victim impact statements from staff at the affected retail outlets, which form a central part of the sentencing picture. Victims describe heightened anxiety during work, shifting schedules to avoid lone working, and in some cases, the withdrawal of staff from previously routine duties. Such disruption has economic and emotional implications that extend beyond the immediate value of stolen goods, diminishing workplace morale and fostering an environment of fear and uncertainty. One victim statement, from the manager of Eastwood Pharmacy, was particularly measured, reflecting professionalism yet acknowledging the lingering sense of vulnerability occasioned by repeat thefts. Staff turnover is noted to have increased, attributable in part to these sustained pressures. Moreover, the theft of certain over-the-counter pharmaceutical products carries potential health risks for the wider community by depleting available supplies. Mr H used a question about Oyster Card transactions to divert the shopkeeper’s attention, then leaned over the counter to take a displayed item. The defendant employed a magnet to detach a security tag from the item, and the magnet was located when police searched The defendant. Parallels with Co-defendant and Associated Case Elements It is relevant to record that related investigations uncovered offences committed by third parties associated with the same retail locations, including one individual charged with dangerous driving in the course of fleeing police, and another facing charges of aggravated criminal damage to shop frontages. None of these acts are attributed to you personally, and there is no evidential basis for holding you accountable for these collateral matters. Nonetheless, the court is mindful of the cumulative impact of multi-faceted offending on public perceptions of safety and order. Additionally, a co-defendant in related proceedings recently received a custodial term for supply of controlled substances, an offence distinct in nature and separated from the theft charges that are the subject of your sentencing. It is important that your sentence reflect your conduct singularly and not become conflated with those associated proceedings, save for insofar as they illuminate the wider context of the offending environment. Your family dynamics, as explored in various reports, reveal little direct involvement, though correspondence from your sister, Ms Janine H., submitted in mitigation, reflects concern for your wellbeing and encouragement towards rehabilitation. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. The psychiatric report prepared by Dr Sarah Eastman is thorough and professionally composed. It indicates no diagnosis of major mental disorder but identifies moderate difficulties with impulse control, intermittent periods of low mood, and traits consistent with borderline personality features. While not sufficiently severe to warrant direct hospital-based treatment, Dr Eastman recommends structured psychological interventions focusing on cognitive-behavioural techniques aimed at improving emotional regulation and decision-making. The report also highlights your ambivalence towards engagement, suggesting that motivational interviewing and peer support groups may assist in fostering longer-term change. The availability of such specialist programmes within the probation service varies and is contingent on current caseloads and funding. It is regrettable that these resources are limited, as demand often exceeds supply. Recent publications on prison mental health indicate growing recognition of the difficulties offenders face in accessing consistent and meaningful support. A report by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) in 2024 has called for enhanced coordination between health providers and criminal justice agencies to better manage cases with complex needs. While such initiatives offer promise for the future, the present case requires sentencing in the context of existing structures and available services. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and confronted shop staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, causing alarm and disruption in the store. This court is acutely conscious of the need to protect the public, deter further offending, and promote rehabilitation. The balance between denunciation and therapeutic opportunity is a delicate one, particularly where offences are non-violent yet persistent, and where the offender’s social circumstances both invite sympathy and caution. The Sentencing Council’s guideline for theft offences articulates a starting point that reflects culpability and harm, adjusted for aggravating and mitigating factors. In your instance, aggravation arises from repetition, breach of prior conditions, and impact on vulnerable premises. Mitigation includes personal difficulties, absence of violence, and a belated guilty plea. Guidance from R v. Neville [2018] EWCA Crim 1294 advises that early engagement with rehabilitation and genuine acceptance of responsibility should attract appropriate credit, but that such factors do not diminish the need for community protection where offending is entrenched. Additionally, the role of unpaid work requirements, financial penalties, and structured activity within community sentences must be calibrated carefully against risk and likelihood of compliance. Community rehabilitation orders have proven effective in reducing reoffending in many acquisitive crime contexts, provided requisite supervision and support are maintained. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. In light of the foregoing, I shall defer sentence to allow the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by your appointed probation officer. That report should include assessment of your suitability for community programmes targeting acquisitive offending, mental health and substance misuse support, and any viable restorative justice avenues. It should also consider risk of reoffending and public protection needs. Sentencing will be fixed upon receipt and consideration of that report. In the interim, the court hopes you will reflect on the gravity of your conduct and embrace the opportunity for positive change. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Royal Barking Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to relevant agencies pursuant to statutory obligations. You are reminded of your right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
