input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT CHELSEA R v. MR H Case No. T2025/14327 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. F. Bartholomew Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H, you appear today for sentence before this court in respect of a charge of theft, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending in question pertains to a series of thefts from multiple retail establishments in the Kensington and Chelsea area, spanning a period of approximately fourteen months. The Crown contends that your actions comprise a clear pattern of deliberate and persistent dishonesty directed at businesses providing essential goods and services within the community. Procedural History Following initial reports from local retailers identifying a pattern of repeated losses, a coordinated investigation was initiated by the Kensington Business Crime Reduction Unit in conjunction with the Metropolitan Police Service’s Borough Crime Team. The investigative phase encompassed a mixture of covert surveillance, confidential source intelligence gathering, analysis of multiple CCTV systems across borough StoreWatch schemes, and targeted interviews with witnesses and staff. This multi-faceted approach typifies the current paradigm of law enforcement where partnership working is essential given constrained operational resources. Such efforts represent not only considerable police time and expenditure but also require patient coordination among numerous agencies whose monthly workloads continue to expand without proportional augmentation in funding or personnel. Mr H concealed £19 worth of nail polish and beauty accessories in his clothing and exited the premises without payment. These investigations, however resource-intensive, play an indispensable role in upholding the integrity of the retail environment—particularly at a time when economic pressures on small businesses continue to escalate. The growing phenomenon colloquially referred to within police circles as “shrinkage” — the combined effect of theft, administrative error, and supplier fault — poses an ongoing challenge to sustainable retail operation and local employment. It is not uncommon for law enforcement teams to grapple with the competing demands of deploying assets to both high-profile violent crime and persistent low-level acquisitive offences, yet both categories attract legitimate public concern. As defined in R v. Shepherd [2019] EWCA Crim 1234, the prosecution of repetitive theft offences must balance considerations of proportionality with the evident cumulative detriment caused to victims. On 12 March 2025, you were apprehended by police officers following an incident at a high street pharmacy in Fulham. At that point, officers conducted a search resulting in the seizure of items later identified as stolen property. Your subsequent interview under caution was initially marked by a denial of involvement; however, further evidence — notably matching CCTV footage and exhibits recovered from your place of residence — undermined that position. Charges were formally preferred on 25 March and the case was listed for hearing at the Crown Court under the Better Case Management protocol. It is worth noting, notwithstanding, that this matter did not proceed without some delay. The court registry records demonstrate that adjournments were necessitated on occasions owing to defence Counsel’s applications for additional time to secure Legal Aid instructions and for the commissioning of an independent psychiatric assessment. Such procedural itineraries, while regrettable, are not uncommon in cases involving vulnerable defendants or where expert input is complex and time-consuming. The court is, however, mindful of the imperative to balance the accused’s rights to a fair and timely hearing with the systemic need to avoid undue prolongation of proceedings. Your initial plea at the plea and trial preparation hearing on 14 May was one of not guilty. Subsequent disclosure of further evidence — including witness statements from store personnel and more extensive forensic linkage — has since prompted you to enter a guilty plea on the morning of trial, on 1 August 2025. The court would remind all parties that the principles governing guilty plea discounts are well settled. As in R v. Bancroft [2020] EWCA Crim 1052, the timeliness of the plea is critical; earlier admissions permit more meaningful savings in court time and resource, as well as sparing witnesses the ordeal of attending trial. A late plea, entered only after the Crown’s case becomes irrefutable, attracts proportionately reduced credit. This approach was further reinforced in R v. Cromwell [2023] EWCA Crim 86, where the court highlighted that procedural gaming diminishes the weight of any plea mitigation. The court is aware of the broader context in which retail theft occurs, characterised by a gradual yet unmistakable escalation in frequency over recent years. This trend has coincided with socioeconomic challenges, including increased homelessness, food insecurity, and mental health difficulties among the urban populace. While some offenders may be drawn into offending due to acute deprivation or addiction, others may exploit systemic vulnerabilities or the reduced presence of security personnel in smaller shops. The proliferation of “no questions asked” return policies by some retailers also complicates the recovery of stock and positive deterrence. However, it must be underscored that such contextual factors do not exculpate criminal conduct. The rule of law dictates individual accountability, and this court cannot condone persistent breaches of public trust, nor the disruption caused to legitimate business activity, however modest the immediate monetary value. Mr H used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and protein powder. Reference is made to the Local Government Act 1972 which established the framework for modern borough councils, including Kensington and Chelsea. This local authority has, over the years, developed partnership arrangements with law enforcement and business stakeholders designed to share information on repeat offenders and apply targeted interventions such as civil injunctions and community protection notices. The so-called Community Safety Partnerships thus convene regularly to address priority crime issues, including shoplifting hotspots identified through intelligence-led profiling. Despite these initiatives, challenges remain in adequately resourcing effective responses in light of competing demands such as anti-social behaviour, public nuisance, and violent crime. Within this framework, the Crown submits that your offending contributed to both direct financial loss and an atmosphere of unease amongst shop staff, some of whom have reported feeling anxious about lone working or subject to intimidation when approaching suspected offenders. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. It is appropriate here to acknowledge the efforts of the Safer Streets initiative, which, since its inception in 2022, has sought to reduce acquisitive crime through environmental design improvements such as increased lighting, installation of facial recognition cameras, and increased patrols in known “hot spot” zones. The scheme’s evaluation reports indicate some success in reducing overall theft-related incidents, but also document displacement effects where offenders shift activity to less monitored precincts. The court notes the trial involved extensive use of digital evidence and analysis of behaviour patterns through data mining, reflecting the emergent role of technology in crime investigation. In assessing sentencing, this court proceeds under the guidance of the Sentencing Council’s Theft Offences Definitive Guideline (June 2018), which sets out factors including harm, culpability, and offender characteristics. The court has also considered caselaw such as R v. Greaves [2017] EWCA Crim 2155 that examines the gradations of harm and mitigating factors relevant to repeat theft cases. Mr H feigned interest in Oyster Card payments to distract the cashier and reached behind the counter to take an item from the display. The defendant brought a magnet to the scene and used it to take off a security tag; this was later found in his possession when arrested. It is noted that notwithstanding the apparently low immediate value of purportedly stolen items, the cumulative effect upon retailers can be substantial. Economic losses impact not only proprietary profit margins but also retailer willingness to employ front-line staff, invest in customer service, or maintain store viability, particularly in deprived areas. The strain on policing resource occasioned by serial shoplift offenders like yourself should also not be underestimated. When officers are assigned to low-value theft investigations, their diversion from other pressing duties impacts overall community safety and responsiveness. Furthermore, prolonged investigations yield considerable administrative overhead with collation of evidence, witness statements, and forensic analyses all contributing to increased burden. From the defence side, submissions were made emphasising your challenging social background, including a reported history of childhood neglect, intermittent homelessness, and struggles with substance dependence. Letters submitted by charity workers and social support organisations testify to periods of engagement with crisis accommodation and addiction counselling, albeit with limited sustained success. The court is conscious of the importance of recognising social determinants as part of a holistic assessment of offending behaviour. However, as the Court of Appeal observed in R v. Morton [2015] EWCA Crim 1033, personal circumstances, while relevant to mitigation, cannot outweigh the demands of public protection and the need for deterrence in repetitive acquisitive offending. The defendant admitted selling the stolen items at a car boot sale and local pubs, disturbing customers. The recently completed psychiatric report by Dr Victoria Addison, consultant forensic psychiatrist, has been of considerable assistance to the court. Dr Addison’s report was thorough and professionally informed, detailing your mental health history, including episodes of depression and complex trauma, while concluding that no major psychotic disorder is present. The report identifies impulsivity and impaired judgement influenced by substance misuse as contributing factors. Dr Addison recommends community rehabilitation with close monitoring and integrated support for substance misuse, but cautions that untreated risk factors may lead to further offending. The report also addresses the relevance of your mental health status to culpability and sentencing, concluding that diminished responsibility is not applicable in these circumstances. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while damaging security cameras using spray paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. The probation pre-sentence report further advises on your current housing instability and low levels of compliance with prior community orders, noting that your engagement with support services has been inconsistent and sometimes reactive rather than proactive. It suggests that rehabilitative efforts should include cognitive behavioural interventions addressing thinking and decision-making patterns, combined with financial management support and drug treatment programmes. The report stresses the need to balance rehabilitative aims with robust supervision to protect the public and reduce reoffending risk. The court acknowledges persistent challenges faced by the Probation Service in resourcing and supervising individuals with complex needs. Recent national audits have highlighted staff vacancies and turnover, resulting in increased case loads and diminished individualised attention. Despite these systemic issues, probation officers continue to demonstrate commendable commitment. Appreciation is also due to the staff of local charities such as the Chelsea Homelessness Project and the North Kensington Outreach Service, whose voluntary sector work provides critical front-line assistance to vulnerable individuals in pathways away from offending. As an aside, the court notes with concern the ongoing pressures faced by NHS mental health services, which have seen growing referral lists and protracted waiting times, particularly in community mental health teams serving high deprivation areas. The reach of crisis teams remains limited, and inpatient beds are scarce. These structural factors both exacerbate the challenges of effective support and must be factored into any realistic understanding of service user pathways. On a separate note, it is worth recording an earlier unsuccessful attempt by Legal Aid to authorise funding for an independent neuropsychological evaluation. Despite repeated submissions from defence Counsel, delays of up to six weeks were incurred while requests underwent multiple reviews and clarifications, underscoring systemic inefficiencies known to courts and practitioners alike. While ultimately resolved, such holdups add to the litigation burden and risk undermining procedural fairness through elongation of timetables. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, said it was no different to borrowing and has no intention of stopping. Turning now to sentencing considerations, the court reminds itself of the principles outlined in the Sentencing Council’s Theft Offences guideline. The offending in this instance features persistent and premeditated dishonesty, exploitation of weaknesses in retail security, and repeated breaches of previous community-based disposals. While the value of stolen property may be modest per incident, the frequency and cumulative impact belie a significant level of culpability. The fact that staffing and operational adjustments were necessitated at targeted retail premises reflects broader community consequences beyond the immediate theft value. The recorded late guilty plea diminishes the mitigating credit to which you might otherwise be entitled. The court is mindful, however, of the indications of remorse expressed through counsel and the willingness to engage with rehabilitative services post-arrest. These are positive signs, albeit tempered by the history of similar interventions failing to prevent reoffending. The necessary balance must be struck between punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. Custodial sentences, while appropriate in some cases of acquisitive crime, are reserved for those where harm or culpability reach high thresholds, or where community orders have repeatedly failed. Given the present facts and available reports, the court is minded to consider community-based sentencing options incorporating structured supervision and behavioural intervention requirements. However, a custodial element cannot be excluded outright. It is therefore ordered that a comprehensive pre-sentence report be compiled forthwith by your probation officer. This report should address risk assessments, tailored therapeutic recommendations, potential engagement with substance misuse services, and feasibility of compliance with rehabilitation activity requirements or unpaid work. It should also consider any safeguarding concerns, including the potential impact of housing instability on your offending risk. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 August 2025, in Court 6 at the Crown Court at Chelsea. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal sentencing hearing will take place upon receipt of the pre-sentence report and any additional representations. You are advised of your right to appeal any sentence imposed within 28 days in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged on this matter pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT CHELSEA R v. MR H Case No. CR2025/13458 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge C. F. LANGLEY Filed: 3 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced for an offence of theft, specifically multiple counts of shoplifting, an acquisitive crime which has been committed on numerous occasions across a protracted period. The offending relates to actions taking place predominantly in the boroughs of Chelsea and Kensington, spanning from late 2023 through to the spring of 2025. The court’s task today is to impose a sentence commensurate with the gravity of the offending, the impact upon victims, and wider considerations of public protection and rehabilitation. Procedural Matters This matter has a somewhat lengthy procedural history. Your case was initially listed for a Plea and Case Management Hearing (PCMH) on 19 May 2025 before His Honour Judge M. R. Downing, following your charge in April. Owing to delays in obtaining Legal Aid funding for your chosen defence solicitors and subsequently a request for an expert psychiatric report, the matter was adjourned on two separate occasions. The second adjournment was also necessitated by a late disclosure relating to CCTV footage from an independent convenience store, which required further review. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT WINDSOR R v. MR H Case No. W2025/08437 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge D. P. RICHARDS Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you appear for sentence following your admitted involvement in a series of offences amounting to theft from retail premises, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending spans a period covering the latter part of 2023 through to early 2025 and implicates multiple retail outlets within the Windsor and Maidenhead area, including several independent shops and pharmacy chains. Procedural History Following your arrest on 28 February 2025, which resulted from a multi-agency initiative spearheaded by Windsor’s Safer Streets Taskforce, your case was progressed to this Crown Court after representation of the prosecuting authority that the volume and persistence of the conduct warranted trial at the higher court level under the Better Case Management (BCM) arrangements. The BCM protocol, as the court and practitioners are well aware, is designed to facilitate the early clarification of evidential issues, promote case progression with due expedition, and reduce unnecessary adjournments. The criminal case management adopted here involved a series of preliminary hearings, the first being conducted remotely on 11 March 2025, at which your solicitor indicated that an initial plea of not guilty was to be entered. This plea was maintained at a subsequent hearing on 14 April 2025, despite the Crown serving a comprehensive disclosure package including digital evidence, witness statements, and CCTV footage purportedly showing your repeated presence at various crime scenes. We find ourselves, unmistakably, in an era characterised by a slow but relentless unraveling of the social order — a period in which the small but persistent transgressions of civic norms have become not only more visible but more frequent. Reports of petty theft, once seen as sporadic or isolated, now speak to a broader pattern of disregard for personal and communal boundaries. The toll of drug-related harm, meanwhile, is borne not just by the individuals involved but by the already overextended institutions charged with holding together the basic infrastructure of public health and safety. One senses, in everyday encounters and quiet observations, a fraying of the once-cohesive threads that held neighbourhoods together: a declining willingness to look out for others, to engage in the quiet acts of reciprocity that make collective life tolerable. These developments manifest not only in the uptick of minor offences but also in the creeping normalisation of behaviours once held to be beyond the pale of acceptable conduct. It must be stated, of course, that the function of the court is not to offer sociological commentary or to diagnose the state of society — but it would be equally disingenuous to pretend that offences occur in a vacuum, untouched by the wider forces that shape the habits, expectations, and moral horizons of the individuals who come before us. It is an unfortunate reality that the late plea you entered, on the morning of trial on 30 July 2025, reflects a familiar pattern to this court. While pleas at this stage remain within your rights, the timing carries implications for the degree of credit afforded and the resultant sentence. The Court of Appeal’s pronouncement in R v. Pearce [2019] EWCA Crim 576 remains instructive: late pleas rarely signify genuine contrition and often serve to conserve prosecutorial and witness resources only in a limited sense. A number of plea and trial preparation hearings were listed; the initial hearing on 19 June was vacated when Legal Aid delays obstructed the timely provision of funding for a psychiatric evaluation sought by your defence team. It is with no small measure of frustration that the court must once again comment upon the consistently slow and cumbersome performance of the Legal Aid Agency in authorising expert reports, here resulting in a delay of no less than five weeks. Such bureaucratic inertia undermines the smooth administration of justice and disproportionately impacts defendants reliant on state-funded representation. Your defence counsel, Mr Gareth Davies, has been diligent in pursuing your interests despite these obstacles, for which the court acknowledges his professionalism and tenacity. Likewise, Ms Elizabeth Carr, appearing on behalf of the Crown, has conducted herself with commendable clarity and judiciousness, ensuring that the requisite balance is struck between the interests of the state and the defendant. In the course of pre-trial preparation, the court received several letters from support organisations, including the Windsor Outreach Network and Shopkeepers’ Association, reflecting both the cumulative impact of retail theft upon small business proprietors and the ongoing challenges faced by charitable bodies striving to mediate conflict and provide rehabilitative avenues. These agencies report strain due to increased caseloads and reduced funding, painting a sobering picture of the ecosystem within which such offending occurs. Complaints concerning the availability and timeliness of interpretation services also emerged during the period leading to the trial. On 21 May, a scheduled hearing was rescheduled due to the late arrival of an appointed interpreter. While this matter was swiftly resolved, it underscores the operational pressures currently confronting court administrative functions, particularly amid ongoing workforce shortages exacerbated by retirements and recruitment challenges. I note with some interest and indirect relevance that this court’s facilities, refurbished earlier this year under a multi-million-pound capital scheme, now boast enhanced digital capabilities, including integrated evidence presentation suites and improved public seating — developments that, while peripheral to the present case, signify the judiciary’s commitment to providing a dignified and effective environment for litigation. One must also bear in mind the evolution of the jurisprudential landscape concerning offences of theft and dishonesty. Over the last decade, the courts have witnessed a rebalancing of sentencing principles with an emphasis on proportionality, rehabilitation, and an informed understanding of social context, without sacrificing deterrence or the protection of victims. The Sentencing Council’s guideline for Theft Offences (Definitive 2019) provides the current framework, highlighting factors such as the value of property taken, the number of victims, and the sophistication or planning involved. Of particular note is the consideration given to offences targeting vulnerable establishments, including those serving disadvantaged populations or dependent upon community goodwill. This reflects a jurisprudential sensitivity borne of experience and the recognition that the ripples of harm from acquisitive crimes radiate beyond the immediate proprietor and impact the social fabric. In approaching your sentence, I have had regard to all these considerations, alongside the detailed pre-sentence report prepared by Probation Officer Ms Fiona Crampton, dated 2 October 2025. Ms Crampton’s appraisal indicates a mixed picture: you are assessed as presenting low to medium risk of serious harm but medium risk of reoffending, with identified underlying issues including episodic substance misuse, intermittent housing instability, and difficulties sustaining employment. Community-based support services, notably the Thames Valley Alcohol and Drug Support Centre, have previously engaged with you but report limited success. These agencies, constrained by budgetary pressures and overwhelming demand, face significant hurdles in offering sustained engagement, a challenge likely aggravated by your sporadic participation. Mr H was seen slipping £11 worth of personal hygiene products into his jacket before leaving the shop without paying. Included among the documents submitted by the defence is a report by Dr Simon Leary, consultant forensic psychiatrist, assessed at your request. Dr Leary’s evaluation, conducted over three sessions in July 2025, notes no formal psychiatric diagnosis but identifies a tendency towards impulsive behaviour and a mild depressive disorder. His recommendation underscores the potential benefit of structured cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) targeting both offending behaviour and underlying emotional regulation difficulties. Mr H concealed boxed razor cartridges and a tub of protein powder beneath items in his niece’s pram. It is regrettable that opportunities for earlier intervention, potentially mitigating progression or escalation, appear to have been underutilised or declined. In considering your background, I have reviewed representations from family members and associates, including a letter from your sister dated 15 September 2025 that speaks to periods of unemployment and housing precarity, alongside moments of genuine effort to seek lawful employment. While personal testimonials invariably introduce subjectivity, they offer invaluable insight into the lived realities underpinning offending. Though the facts of the case focus on theft, it is incumbent upon the court to consider broader behavioural patterns and their implications for risk and rehabilitation. The landscape of acquisitive crime is multifaceted, reflecting intersections between socio-economic distress and personal agency. Within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same shop on four occasions, each time removing alcohol and tobacco without paying. It is not lost on the court that your offending places a burden on multiple public agencies and charities, whose resources are finite and whose capacity to respond is variably constrained. There is an institutional fatigue evident in many such bodies—manifest in waiting lists for mental health services, overstretched probation teams, and the consistent need to prioritise cases based on risk and urgency. The Probation Service, as a whole, continues to grapple with recruitment and retention challenges, with recent figures indicating a near 15% vacancy rate nationally. This has consequences for caseload sizes and the quality of supervision able to be offered. Mr H feigned interest in Oyster Card payments to distract the cashier and reached behind the counter to take an item from the display. In R v. Maynard [2017] EWCA Crim 1342, the Court of Appeal reaffirmed that the persistence of acquisitive offending, especially without engagement with rehabilitative provision, signals the need for custodial intervention in cases where alternatives have been exhausted or deemed unsuitable. Though your case is less serious in value or violence than Maynard, the principle remains salient: sustained dishonesty is a matter of concern regardless of scale. Reference may also be made — albeit with limited direct application — to R v. Duvall [2020] EWCA Crim 876, which dealt with dangerous driving offences resulting in grievous bodily harm. While the factual matrix differs substantially, the case illustrates the judiciary’s role in balancing community protection against the prospect of rehabilitation, a tension equally present here. Within the sententious corpus, attention is also drawn to R v. Graham [2021] EWCA Crim 1101, which addressed the sentencing of a defendant convicted for fly-tipping on Green Belt land, resulting in environmental degradation assessed at considerable public cost. While your offending bears no environmental dimension, the case is instructive in demonstrating that offences impacting community resources or public confidence sometimes warrant enhanced sentences despite lacking personal injury elements. The defendant used a magnet to remove a security tag, and that same magnet was recovered when Mr H was taken into custody. The court has also reviewed victim impact statements from proprietors and staff of affected premises. These statements describe not only pecuniary loss but the emotional toll of confronting repeated theft. Staff report diminished morale, heightened anxiety, and, in some cases, the necessity of altering working patterns. The North Windsor Business Association has submitted a detailed memorandum voicing concerns about retail shrinkage and its knock-on effects for local employment and economic vitality. Such material serves to humanise the offences and to remind all parties that acquiescence to such behaviour is neither mandated nor appropriate amidst broader societal challenges. The concept of community reparation, as encouraged by the Sentencing Council's guideline on Theft Offences, is relevant. It strikes a chord with the restorative justice principles increasingly embedded in contemporary sentencing practice, balancing accountability with the opportunity for repair and reintegration. Though I am mindful of your personal difficulties, including intermittent homelessness and sporadic employment, these must be weighed against the persistent nature of your conduct and apparent reluctance to fully engage with support mechanisms proffered. The defendant disclosed that the stolen goods were sold at a car boot sale and in pubs, where his conduct caused unease among customers. An observation on the broader context may be warranted. The local constabulary continues to express concern about finite resources being diverted to what they term “non-serious” crime, including acquisitive juvenile and adult offending. This trend places additional strain on neighbourhood policing teams already facing heightened demands in relation to serious violent crime and organised gang activity. That said, the Windsor Business Crime Reduction Partnership appears to have functioned with notable efficacy in this matter — collating information, facilitating victim liaison, and coordinating multi-agency responses without undue delay or friction. The court records its appreciation for their work. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, triggering distress and security concerns. In terms of personal mitigation, counsel has drawn attention to your composition of a letter to the court expressing remorse and acknowledging the impact of your actions. The letter was carefully written, legible, and evidently the product of sincere reflection. Though such correspondence cannot substitute for tangible behavioural change, it is taken into account. Additionally, your previous criminal record includes minor traffic offences and two convictions for possession of cannabis, both from some years prior and of limited present relevance. There is no indication of any gang affiliations or involvement in violent crime. The impact of your offending does not extend to physical harm or threats, but the court notes the psychological strain on victims and the economic costs. The court is conscious, however, that in sentencing it must calibrate a response proportionate to the gravity of the offences and cognisant of the prospects for rehabilitation. Mr H stated in interview that he frequently takes items, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. In concluding these remarks, I emphasise that sentencing in cases of repeated retail theft requires an approach that balances public protection, deterrence, and the encouragement of desistance. While community sentences remain appropriate in many cases, where evidence suggests limited engagement or significant risk of reoffending, custodial sentences may be justified. At this juncture, the court will direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by probation that specifically addresses your history, risk factors, social circumstances, and the availability of structured community interventions. Attention should be given to cognitive skills programmes, substance misuse treatment pathways, and any housing support necessary to underpin effective rehabilitation. I will adjourn sentencing until such time as the report is completed and filed. This will allow all parties to consider fully the options and enable me to impose a sentence reflective of the totality of circumstances. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 October 2025, in Court 6 at the Crown Court at Windsor. Proceedings have been recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to section 108 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

In the context of acquisitive offending, it is important to recall the court’s duty to consider the cumulative impact of repeated thefts on victims and the wider community. While often characterised as “non-violent” or “minor,” the broader social cost—losses sustained by small businesses, increased insurance premiums, and the cascading effect on staff wellbeing—are far from trivial. The court acknowledges the support provided by the Bristol Retail Crime Partnership, who submitted a detailed victim impact statement describing not only financial loss but the disruption to business continuity and employee morale occasioned by persistent shoplifting. The Retail Crime Partnership also notes ongoing staffing shortages and increased turnover in front-of-house roles, which they attribute partly to the stress arising from such repeated incidents of theft. Mr H was witnessed removing the tags from £13 worth of makeup and tucking it into his inner pocket before leaving the store without payment. This series of offences took place across a variety of retail premises, including one independent pharmacy and two convenience stores widely regarded as vital to the local neighbourhoods they serve. The modus operandi exhibited a degree of planning and sophistication beyond mere opportunistic pilfering, including the use of distraction methods and concealment in garments. CCTV footage demonstrated your repeated presence, often at times coinciding with shift changes or periods of lone staffing. Mr H placed protein powder and razor blade refills in his niece’s pushchair in an attempt to hide them. Public order and safety in commercial spaces are often vulnerable to such breaches. The courts are cognisant that acquisitive crime has a corrosive impact upon the retail sector, leading some businesses to adopt costly preventative measures, including increased security staff, installation of physical barriers, and reduced opening hours. While these measures impose financial burdens, they are symptomatic of a broader sense of insecurity prevalent in many urban centres today. Of interest, though irrelevant to the present proceedings, the court records that a nearby shop suffered significant criminal damage in a separate incident last year. That matter involved a third party unrelated to you and resulted in a custodial sentence for criminal damage to a listed building (R v. Ashton [2024] EWCA Crim 1587). While the case highlights the interplay between various forms of offending within tightly knit communities, it has no bearing upon your culpability or risk profile. Across three weeks, Mr H visited the same small retailer four times, stealing alcohol and tobacco on each occasion. The facts disclose a persistent pattern of thefts perpetrated across a six-month span, with some instances involving the removal of security tags or the use of items to obscure surveillance. Staff declarations indicate that some employees were left fearful of repeat encounters, leading to increased absenteeism and changes in shift patterns. The court has received a comprehensive psychiatric report prepared by Dr Helen Forsyth, a consultant forensic psychologist instructed by the defence. Dr Forsyth’s evaluation, conducted through a combination of clinical interview and psychometric testing, indicates that you exhibit traits consistent with chronic impulsivity and mild depressive symptoms. There is, however, no evidence of severe mental illness or cognitive impairment that would diminish responsibility. Importantly, Dr Forsyth emphasises your lack of engagement with available community resources and support, noting that you have declined offers of referral to addiction services or financial counselling, despite documented material hardship. These observations align with the probation pre-sentence report, which depicts a medium-risk profile for further acquisitive offending but no significant risk of harm to others. Dr Forsyth’s report also elaborates on the potential benefits of targeted offender rehabilitation programmes, including cognitive-behavioural therapy and motivational interviewing. Such interventions, she suggests, could assist you in managing impulsive tendencies and redirecting financial pressures into lawful conduct. The court welcomes these recommendations, which will be considered in the sentencing process. Mr H created a distraction by asking about Oyster Cards and took advantage of the moment to remove a display item from behind the counter. Your personal circumstances bear some relevance. You are 34 years old, currently unemployed, and living alone in privately rented accommodation. The pre-sentence report records a history of unstable housing, with prior intermittent stays in temporary supported lodging. While not directly related to the offending behaviours, such instability often exacerbates vulnerability and social exclusion. The court is mindful that the local probation teams face increasing caseloads and diminished resources, which place limits on the intensity and frequency of supervision. Nevertheless, recent innovations, including digital monitoring tools and bespoke community interventions, have demonstrated promise in mitigating repeat acquisitive crime. The effectiveness of these must be balanced against individual motivation and compliance. It is also of note that the recent coronavirus pandemic had profound implications for mental health services and social support networks, a fact referenced in many presentence reports nationally. The disruption to in-person contacts and reduction in charitable funding have left many vulnerable individuals underserved at precisely the moment of greatest need. While that context does not excuse criminal behaviour, it forms an essential backdrop to current sentencing considerations. The defendant deliberately used a magnet to take off a security tag, and the magnet was later found during his arrest. The court recognizes the wider social context in which these offences occurred. We live in a period marked by increasing economic uncertainty, high inflation rates, and the ongoing effects of the so-called ‘cost of living crisis’. These variables contribute to mounting pressures upon individuals at the margins. Such factors, understandably, inform the mitigation put forward on your behalf. Despite this, it is important to reiterate that hardship does not equate to licence. The law remains clear that the preservation of public order and respect for the rights of others must be maintained. Theft from small businesses disproportionately affects those least able to absorb losses and undermines social cohesion. There exists also a growing phenomenon of so-called “social media shoplifting challenges,” particularly among younger cohorts, which some observers believe contribute to normalising such behaviours. While no evidence suggests your involvement in these trends, the court notes the challenges they present to law enforcement and community safety initiatives. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. Turning to the sentencing framework, the court is guided primarily by the Sentencing Council’s definitive guideline on Theft Offences (Definitive Guideline issued April 2022), which sets out the factors relevant to assessing culpability and harm. Aggravating factors such as a pattern of offending, targeting of vulnerable premises, and the disruption caused to victims weigh heavily. Mitigating factors include timely guilty pleas and demonstrable engagement with rehabilitative services. The sentencing pool available includes custodial sentences, community orders with requirements such as unpaid work or rehabilitation activity, or in less serious cases, fines or conditional discharges. Given the history and pattern disclosed, the court is inclined to view immediate custody as a possible outcome, though deferral is warranted pending receipt of updated reports. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. The court also notes correspondence from the Bristol Safer Neighbourhood Team expressing concern about the rise of shop theft and its impact on local business owners and the community. Their letter highlights the emotional toll on retail workers, including anxiety and fear arising from repeated theft incidents, and encourages sentencing outcomes that underscore deterrence. Turning briefly to comparative case law: in R v. Lyndon [2023] EWCA Crim 845, the Court of Appeal upheld a sentence of 14 months’ imprisonment for a defendant with a similar offending profile involving organised theft rings targeting retail chains. While that case included aggravating features such as use of accomplices and intimidation, it demonstrates judicial willingness to impose custodial terms where offending is persistent and impacts multiple premises. Also relevant is R v. Freeman [2024] EWCA Crim 1902, where the Court distinguished between low-level opportunistic theft and calculated, repeated courses of conduct. There, the imposition of a community order augmented by cognitive skills training was upheld for a defendant without prior convictions and demonstrable steps toward engagement with support services. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. Victim impact statements submitted describe not only the quantifiable loss but also the broader disruption—inventory management challenges, staff redeployment, and increased security costs. One independent pharmacist, affected by one of the thefts, noted the psychological strain endured by front-facing staff, many of whom reported stress-related absenteeism. Such evidence underscores that theft, even in the absence of direct violence, carries substantial harm. Inquiries made with local charities assisting vulnerable adults confirm that multiple agencies remain engaged with you, albeit with mixed success. Notes reveal sporadic attendance at debt management workshops and a reluctance to maintain consistent contact with housing support services. While commendable attempts have been made to engage you, the apparent reticence to sustain such involvement is disconcerting. Notably, the probation service has flagged concerns arising from the 2018 case of a co-defendant (not yourself) in another matter involving assault and possession of an offensive weapon, factors unrelated to your offending but occasionally cited in adjacent files. This court emphasises that no such elements pertain in your case. The court is also aware—purely as an extraneous matter—that one of the retail outlets targeted by your offending was recently the site of a separate arson attack by an unrelated individual, resulting in extensive property damage and a custodial sentence of three years for the arsonist (R v. Craven [2025] EWCA Crim 2105). While this does not relate to your case, it exemplifies the complex interplay of risks facing local businesses and the importance of clear accountability for those who impact community safety. Finally, it is worth commenting on the broader implications for the community. Acquisitive crime undermines public confidence, fosters insecurity, and imposes costs ultimately borne by consumers and honest traders alike. The court must approach sentencing in a way that balances individual circumstances with these wider public interests. I will adjourn sentencing to permit the preparation of a full pre-sentence report, including consideration of suitable rehabilitative options. The report shall give due regard to your mental health, financial status, housing stability, and likelihood of compliance with community-based interventions. Particular attention should be paid to identifying any services that might address the underlying drivers of your offending, be they economic pressures or impulsivity. I remind all parties that sentencing credit for a guilty plea has been limited due to its timing, in line with judicial direction and established principles. I will welcome, however, any further representations or material that might inform an appropriate and proportionate sentence at the next hearing. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. Proceedings have been recorded under Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal transcript will be prepared and made available to the parties. You are advised of your rights of appeal against conviction and sentence within 28 days, pursuant to relevant statutory provisions. No reporting restrictions apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/14862 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge D. F. MORLAND Filed: 13 November 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today to be sentenced for offences of theft from retail premises, pursuant to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The charge concerns repeated shoplifting carried out over a protracted period spanning from approximately late 2023 through to the spring of this year, with incidents occurring at various commercial establishments within the Brighton and Hove area and adjacent retail zones. Procedural History and Case Management You were arrested on 5 May 2025 following an extended enquiry conducted under the auspices of the Sussex Retail Crime Reduction Taskforce. This multi-agency initiative, incorporating uniformed officers, plain clothes investigators, and intelligence analysts, was formed with the explicit aim of addressing a discernible increase in repeat shoplifting offences affecting small to medium-sized retailers. Intelligence reports indicated a pattern involving a lone male fitting your description repeatedly entering shops to remove goods without payment, leading to accumulating losses and staff distress. It is appropriate here to acknowledge that this investigation involved a complex collation of disparate pieces of evidence, including CCTV recordings from several disparate locations, witness statements, and a review of regional trading patterns. The collation process itself reflects the increasing bureaucratic demands placed upon law enforcement agencies in the contemporary landscape. The record-keeping requirements, not limited to traditional paperwork but expanded to digital databases, video cataloguing, and interdepartmental communication protocols, underscore the resource-intensive nature of even relatively low-value theft cases. Within this framework, the case was allocated to this Crown Court under the Better Case Management (BCM) protocol designed to promote early identification of issues, more efficient case progression, and, ideally, swift resolution for the complainants and the defendant alike. The initial listing took place on 20 May 2025. Subsequent case management hearings were held on 24 June and 12 August, during which directions were given and adjustments made to accommodate expert reports and new disclosure. These occasions highlighted the procedural intricacies inherent in coordinating legal aid permissions and ensuring compliance with the Criminal Procedure Rules. The court notes, with some degree of exasperation, that applications for legal aid funding to permit instruction of a forensic psychiatrist were subject to repeated adjournments. The original request dated 18 June was delayed pending administrative review, with substantive approval only conveyed in early August, thereby elongating the preparatory timeline and necessitating a short adjournment of the sentencing hearing. This pattern is regrettably not unique; a consistent theme in this court’s dealings has been the persistent difficulty practitioners face in securing timely and adequate expert input due to systemic constraints within the Legal Aid Agency. Such delays are more than administrative inconveniences—they impose adverse consequences on case progression, exacerbate uncertainty, and cloud prospects for rehabilitation planning. During the plea and trial preparation hearing held on 26 August, you initially entered a not guilty plea, electing to challenge the Crown’s case despite the surveillance evidence presented. It was not until the morning of the final trial listing on 1 October that you indicated an intention to plead guilty. The Crown advises that this resulted in a plea discount commensurate with the timing, reflecting the principles articulated in R v. Lawson [2019] EWCA Crim 541 and further refined in R v. Stewart [2023] EWCA Crim 1872. The court references the general principle that any reduction in sentence due to an eventual guilty plea is closely correlated to its timing; a late plea, such as this, just prior to trial, typically attracts significantly reduced mitigation. This development—while within your rights—is regrettable. The cost in officer time, witness availability, and court scheduling is not trivial. Victims and retail staff have had to endure prolonged uncertainty, with the attendant stress and disruption this causes. The Crown’s outlines and submissions on this point have been clear and cogent. Notably, evidence was provided that the files compiled for the case ran to over 1,200 pages once all disclosures, statements, and exhibits were assembled. This evidences the disproportionate administrative burden even relatively modest offence cases carry. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. The Facts and Impact on Retail Environments Your offending profile, as established by the material before this court, indicates a calculated and repeated course of shoplifting, targeted across multiple premises, including convenience stores, pharmacy outlets, and discount retailers. The items appropriated were frequently small in individual value, yet cumulatively represented a significant loss to businesses already under strain from logistical disruptions and wider economic pressures. It cannot be overstated that retail theft, while sometimes viewed socially as a victimless offence or one of low seriousness, has very tangible consequences. Shop staff report that such persistent theft necessitates an increase in security measures which can ripple through store operations, including increased staffing costs, reduced hours, and in some cases relocation or closure. Many such businesses operate on tight margins, and the knock-on effect of lost stock and disruption is substantial. The court also notes that repeated shoplifting incidents contribute to a broader climate of insecurity and disquiet within the local community, potentially diminishing public confidence. Further to this, the court has received written representations from the Sussex Retail Alliance, emphasizing the strain placed on independent retailers who frequently fall outside the ambit of corporate security investment. Their submissions are measured and detailed, underscoring the compounding economic and psychological harm caused by ongoing theft incidents. The national picture reflects this local experience. Data published by the Association of Convenience Stores shows that in 2024, retail crime levels increased by 8.4% relative to the previous year, with a particular uptick in shoplifting offences targeting health and beauty products—items reportedly taken in your case. The Retail Crime Index also indicates that proactive responses at local policing level, while improving, face persistent resource challenges. Such context, while not determinative of individual culpability, frames the seriousness with which the court must approach the matter. Mr H deliberately used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and a container of protein powder. The court further acknowledges that this offence takes place against a broader backdrop of changes in public attitudes to retail security and policing. There is a well-documented tension between increasing security measures—which, though often necessary, may affect public access and privacy—and the imperative to maintain open and welcoming retail environments. It is incumbent upon everyone to recognise their role in sustaining these environments, and theft fundamentally undermines the social compact that supports them. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. The Defendant’s Personal Circumstances and Expert Assessments Turning to your personal circumstances, the court has before it a psychiatric evaluation prepared by Dr Evelyn Moreno, consultant forensic psychiatrist, and a probation report compiled by Ms Keisha Abbott. Both provide valuable insights into factors relevant to sentencing, including risk of reoffending and potential for rehabilitation. Dr Moreno's report—prepared following a comprehensive assessment in late September—provides that you display no evidence of a major psychiatric disorder but notes traits consistent with chronic impulsivity and moderate substance misuse, specifically alcohol dependency of a degree potentially influencing decision-making processes at times of offending. Dr Moreno is candid in her conclusion that while no illness as such is present to diminish responsibility, your difficulties with impulse control and substance use pose an elevated risk factor. The report recommends structured community treatment if viable, acknowledging that engagement with such services has been erratic in the recent past. An addendum by Dr Moreno references the challenges presented by local NHS mental health service waiting lists, noting that while adult addiction services have improved, capacity remains insufficient to address all need promptly. This contributes to a risk of relapse and sustained contact with the criminal justice system. Ms Abbott’s probation report, provided last month, details your long history of low-level theft offences and notes multiple failed attempts at diversionary schemes. It further highlights your unstable housing situation and sporadic employment history—weighing these factors alongside protective ones such as noted family support and expressed willingness to comply with court-imposed conditions. She underscores that your previous breach of community orders indicates a pattern of non-compliance that must be given due weight. Your engagement with probation services prior to this prosecution has been described as “limited and inconsistent,” and attempts to refer you to vocational retraining programmes were not taken up. The report advocates a thorough and tailored rehabilitation package post-sentence. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. Background and Contextual Observations on Public Services and Systemic Pressures It is instructive to consider the wider pressures on public services that intersect with cases such as this. The Probation Service, under significant strain due to increased caseloads and staffing shortages nationwide, likewise suffers from reduced capacity to provide bespoke management and monitoring. Current National Probation Service publications warn of risks associated with overcrowded caseloads, particularly for clients presenting with complex needs—including those with substance misuse and impulse control challenges. This constellation of factors not only complicates effective offender management but also prolongs the cycle of offending and supervision lapses. Similarly, local housing services in Brighton continue to report acute shortages of affordable and stable accommodation, with pressure on temporary housing stock at crisis levels. It is therefore unsurprising that defendants such as yourself report precarious living conditions, which in turn can act as a compounding factor in criminal conduct. The relationship between housing insecurity and acquisitive crime is well explored in criminal justice research—but it remains no defence. Courts must balance understanding of social determinants with recognition of individual accountability. On a related front, the current climate for retail businesses is beset with challenges. Reports by the British Retail Consortium highlight increased losses due to theft, especially in independent outlets unable to afford advanced security systems. Despite coordinated efforts such as local Business Crime Reduction Partnerships (BCRP), successes remain partial and fragmentary, often subverted by fluctuations in funding and personnel turnover. Frontline retail workers, many employed on zero-hours contracts or in part-time posts, bear considerable emotional burden, often experiencing elevated stress and anxiety linked to recurrent offending incidents. The defendant deliberately used a magnet to take off a security tag, and the magnet was later found during his arrest. The court is mindful, too, of repeated case law emphasising deterrence as a core principle in sentencing for theft offences. In R v. Kendricks [2022] EWCA Crim 1141, the Court of Appeal affirmed the necessity of sentences that convey unequivocal censure where organised or persistent thefts undermine community safety and economic stability. Similarly, the guidance issued by the Sentencing Council in 2023 stresses the need to balance proportionate punishment with opportunities for rehabilitation, in cases where underlying vulnerabilities may exist but are not determinative of culpability. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. Discussion of Related Case Law and Relevant Jurisprudence While the primary charge is theft, it is impossible or unwise to consider this case in isolation from related jurisprudence, some of which involves more serious offending by co-defendants or other parties linked marginally in procedural terms. For instance, in R v. Lomax [2018] EWCA Crim 1328, the Court contended with issues surrounding group offending involving both acquisitive crimes and instances of criminal damage to private property. Although none of that conduct is attributable to you, the case illustrates the risk of escalation inherent in patterns of low-level offending left unchecked. Equally instructive is R v. Faraday [2021] EWCA Crim 1979, concerning a defendant convicted for aggravated vehicle theft whose sentence was influenced by a prior history of multiple small-scale thefts, including shops and public transport fare evasion. The interplay between the offences demonstrated a pattern of escalating criminality, further relating to use of stolen property. While such facts are outside the present charge, they offer cautionary context on the dangers of recidivism. The Court also acknowledges the significant proliferation of co-defendants in recent regional cases—some of whom have faced charges ranging from affray following public disturbances, possession of bladed articles in school car parks, or environmental offences exemplified by fly-tipping on adjacent greenbelt land. None relate to you directly, but remain part of the larger constellation of acquisitive and public order crimes that challenge policing and judicial resources locally. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and challenged shop workers while damaging security cameras using spray paint, prompting serious safety fears among staff. The court has before it statements from affected store managers and employees, attesting to the impact your actions have had on their personal wellbeing and operational confidence. These statements reflect not only financial loss but also anxiety, residual fear, and in some instances, increasing reluctance to work unsupervised or during later shifts. The economic and psychological toll cannot be overstated. One representative letter, from a community pharmacy facing persistent targeting, speaks eloquently of the erosion of trust and security: “Our staff feel scrutinised for suspicion of theft, yet the real threat comes from repeated offenders who take advantage of our goodwill and the limitations of current security measures.” These observations are echoed across several premises, some of which have had to introduce costly security upgrades or impose reduced opening hours. The court also recognises the work of local voluntary bodies such as the Brighton Retail Support Network, which provides frontline assistance to victims of retail crime, including advisory services and emotional support. Their submissions speak to the increasingly fraught atmosphere in which employees operate and the consequential demand on charity resources. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, said it was no different to borrowing and expects to do it again soon. The offences before the court must be viewed as a sustained and systematic course of conduct, reflecting a high degree of planning and contingency. While there was no direct violence or threats, the impact on staff morale and business viability is serious. Your personal circumstances—though challenging—do not excuse the persistent nature of the offending, nor do they justify failure to engage meaningfully with available support mechanisms. Sentencing guidelines for theft offences emphasise proportionality, deterrence, and rehabilitation. The court will consider all relevant factors, including the late guilty plea, risk assessments, and the potential for structured community interventions. I note the defence’s submissions advocating for non-custodial measures focussed on rehabilitation, enhanced supervision, and integrated support services. I equally acknowledge the Crown’s emphasis on the need for denunciation and public protection. Given the complexities identified—your background, offence pattern, victim impact, and available professional input—it is appropriate at this stage to receive a detailed pre-sentence report. I specifically request that the probation service consider all available rehabilitative options, including cognitive skills training, substance misuse treatment, and employment support pathways. The report should address risk, compliance likelihood, and suitability for community-based sanctions versus custodial disposals. I will therefore adjourn for sentencing pending receipt of this report and any further representations. These remarks are issued this day, 13 November 2025, in Court 5 at Brighton Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is informed of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentence, under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions provided by section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
