input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT MANCHESTER R v. MR H Case No. M2025/13457 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. J. Royston Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court to be sentenced in respect of a charge arising under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, relating to incidents of shoplifting carried out in various retail establishments within the Greater Manchester area spanning a period from mid-2023 to early 2025. This court must therefore undertake a careful and measured assessment of the facts before it, while reflecting not only upon the circumstances of the offence, but also on the wider context within which such offending occurs. Procedural Background You were arrested on 20 March 2025 following an investigation led by officers attached to the Greater Manchester Retail Crime Task Force, working in close concert with multiple business crime reduction units and local council enforcement teams. The investigation involved a systematic gathering of CCTV footage, witness statements, and the recovery of physical evidence from your residence. This operation was noted for its multi-agency involvement, including assistance from the City of Manchester Forensic Data Unit, whose technical expertise was engaged to enhance and authenticate relevant digital recordings. Such concerted efforts serve to highlight the significant public resources expended on cases involving what might otherwise be dismissed as “minor” acquisitive offences; a reminder of the challenges faced by modern policing when addressing persistent retail crime. I must record a note of some disappointment at the delays caused in obtaining necessary forensic examination results, largely attributable to backlogs within the forensic service provider. These delays necessitated the adjournment of the initial sentencing hearing scheduled for late July 2025 in order to allow the disclosure process to be properly completed. This is, regrettably, far from unusual and speaks to enduring issues within public sector forensic capacity. While not something for which any individual party is responsible, such systemic delays impose considerable strain upon defendants, victims, and the court alike. It is to be hoped that ongoing initiatives to expand forensic laboratory facilities will alleviate these bottlenecks in the medium term. It is also appropriate to make brief mention of the Legal Aid Agency’s handling of your case materials. As noted in correspondence lodged on behalf of your solicitor, applications for funding to instruct an independent clinical forensic psychologist were made in early April but were met with initial refusals and repeated requests for additional clarification. The administrative inefficiencies inherent in this process were regrettable and, as with forensic delays, contribute to the risk that justice is deferred unnecessarily. I sincerely hope that pending reforms to the administration of legal aid will expedite the commissioning of expert reports in future cases. Your case was allocated to this Crown Court under the Criminal Procedure Rules’ Better Case Management (BCM) framework, with hearings proceeding in a generally timely manner save for the aforementioned adjournments occasioned by disclosure delays. Plea and trial preparation hearings took place on 2 June and 12 August respectively, at which times you elected initially to plead not guilty. However, following the service of further CCTV evidence and forensic analysis linking you to key items, you ultimately entered a plea of guilty on 10 September 2025. This change in plea, while welcomed, was regrettably late in the process, following extensive case preparation by the Crown and defence. The court must emphasize that credit for guilty pleas operates not as a pure discount but as recognition of the benefits that an early admission of responsibility brings to the administration of justice — in terms of resources conserved and witnesses spared the distress of trial. A plea entered at a late stage offers less mitigation, as was explored by the Court of Appeal in R v. Hammond [2023] EWCA Crim 745, where the timing of the plea was deemed integral to the assessment of credit available. That decision followed earlier guidance in R v. Patterson [2021] EWCA Crim 1608, which similarly upheld restrictions on credit for pleas coming at or near trial. It is also worthy of acknowledgment that the offences in which you stand convicted, while lacking any element of threat or violence, demonstrate a degree of planning and persistence not to be overlooked. The Court of Appeal’s decision in R v. Bentley [2020] EWCA Crim 1354 serves as a useful comparative authority, illustrating that repeated thefts from retail premises by a defendant with previous convictions warrant sentences reflecting both deterrence and denunciation. Bentley also recognises the significance of harm caused not merely in monetary terms but in the psychological impact on staff and communities. While your conduct fell short of the aggravated circumstances in Bentley, the principle remains sound. It is also with some regret that this court must record the lack of media interest in matters of acquisitive crime, even where persistent offending strains the fabric of local commerce and community life. Despite the openness of such proceedings and the availability of public access, it appears such cases carry insufficient newsworthiness to attract coverage. This apparent selective attention arguably diminishes public awareness of the everyday realities of retail crime and its cumulative effects. The Court is likewise mindful of the broader pattern of acquisitive offending in the region, as outlined in the annual report produced by the Northern Retail Crime Partnership, which notes a 12% increase in retail theft incidents over the past year, with a substantial proportion attributable to repeat offenders. For completeness, I should mention that your defence team provided a supporting letter from your sister, Mrs K. H., who describes you as a “reserved but fundamentally decent person faced with considerable adversity.” Several letters from representatives of local charity organisations offering assistance with housing and substance misuse concerns were also submitted in advance of this hearing, reflecting ongoing engagement with voluntary sector providers. The court appreciates such contributions, as they offer a fuller picture of an individual’s circumstances beyond the purely procedural. It is noteworthy that, unlike many other cases, no co-defendants are involved. Previous cases dealing with criminal gangs and organised retail theft rings have demonstrated an escalation in offending behaviour and harm — such as R v. Chilvers [2018] EWCA Crim 2045, where multiple defendants operated a professionalised shoplifting syndicate with coercive dynamics and territorial disputes resulting in violence and intimidation. Such cases lie beyond the scope of these proceedings, but provide context to the diverse spectrum of behaviours and risks linked to acquisitive crime. Mr H was witnessed removing the tags from £13 worth of makeup and tucking it into his inner pocket before leaving the store without payment. I turn now to matters concerning the nature of your offending. The pattern of behaviour identified in your case reveals several hallmark features of persistent shoplifting: repeated visits to similar establishments, operation on civilian hours to avoid peak staffing, and the use of improvised concealment methods. CCTV footage submitted reveals you entering retail premises dressed in layered clothing, carrying large bags which were subsequently filled with goods without payment. Mr H used the bottom compartment of his niece’s pram to hide razor cartridges and protein supplements. On occasion, you were seen lingering near certain product aisles — often toiletries and small electronic accessories — waiting for moments in which employees were preoccupied, often during brief lulls in foot traffic or during shift handovers. This suggests a degree of calculation rather than impulsivity, which carries weight in assessing culpability. On four separate visits within three weeks, Mr H returned to the same small shop and stole alcohol and tobacco products. Complementing the physical evidence were witness statements from shop assistants who described feelings of unease and frustration arising from repeated exposure to your conduct. Some staff took steps to modify their working patterns, including the implementation of buddy systems and enhanced on-floor presence during vulnerable periods. These measures, while commendable, underscore the emotional and operational toll your offending exacted. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. Further, reports from the retail security teams note that while no direct threats were made, the atmosphere generated by your persistent presence contributed to a climate of anxiety impinging on day-to-day functionality. This reflects the harm detailed in R v. Tipping [2019] EWCA Crim 1452, where repeated targeting of small businesses engendered psychological distress disproportionate to the financial loss involved. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. Parallel to the criminal proceeding, correspondence from the Manchester Retail Support Network detailed approaches made to you offering diversionary programmes, including access to budgeting advice, vocational support, and cognitive-behavioural workshops targeting acquisitive offending tendencies. These offers were initially contemplated but, according to reports, not consistently engaged with. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. A pre-sentence psychiatric report, prepared by Dr Harriet K. Simmons, consultant forensic psychiatrist, was commissioned following concerns raised by your defence. Her assessment, received on 30 September 2025, concluded that you do not meet diagnostic criteria for any major psychiatric disorder but display traits suggestive of impulsivity and difficulties with emotional regulation. Dr Simmons also remarked on a moderate degree of depressive symptomatology linked to housing instability and unemployment. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. The report notes your acknowledgment of financial stressors and limited social supports but highlights an inconsistent pattern of service engagement. Of concern is the report’s finding that while some motivation for change exists, there is a significant risk of relapse into acquisitive behaviour absent active intervention. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, claimed it wasn’t a serious crime and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. These professional observations echo the findings of a probation officer’s report dated 1 October 2025, which emphasises the challenges presented by your current lack of stable accommodation and sporadic contact with support services. The probation officer, Ms Cassandra Patel, notes the systemic pressures facing frontline staff, referencing ongoing shortages and increased caseloads which impact the timeliness and quality of required supervision. It is important to briefly touch on the issue of housing provision in Greater Manchester, which, as elsewhere, faces considerable demand exceeding supply. Temporary accommodation placements have risen sharply, placing strain on local authorities and voluntary organisations alike; these societal pressures form an unavoidable backdrop to cases such as yours. While it may be tempting to interpret such contextual difficulties as causal or excusive, the court reiterates that personal responsibility remains paramount. The law does not countenance the reduction of legal accountability simply by reference to external hardship. This is a hard truth but a necessary one for the maintenance of public confidence in the justice system. You are 34 years old. Your previous record includes three convictions for shoplifting dating back over the past five years. These previous convictions and their attendant disposals—including a community order with curfew requirement—must figure heavily in the overall sentencing calculus. Despite prior warnings and interventions, your offending persisted, signalling a pattern resistant to informal management. There is no evidence of coercion or gang involvement in your history. Nor is there indication of complicity in offences beyond those before this court. The court is made aware that your current accommodation is temporary housing arranged through municipal emergency schemes. This is consistent with evidence that housing insecurity correlates strongly with persistence of acquisitive offending. However, such correlation does not equate to causation; while supportive and stable housing is conducive to rehabilitation, the absence thereof is not a license to offend. Your solicitor and probation officer have requested that the court consider community-based sentences incorporating rehabilitative activities. This court acknowledges their arguments and will await the forthcoming full pre-sentence report but emphasises that such proposals must be realistic and enforceable, with a view to proper public protection. Turning to sentencing principles, the approach outlined by the Sentencing Council’s Theft Guidelines (2023 edition) remains authoritative. The guidelines instruct that offences involving persistent targeting of certain types of goods, repeat offending, and impact upon staffing and other victims should attract sentences reflecting those aggravating features. I am also mindful of the principles expressed in the recently promulgated judgment R v. Finlayson [2024] EWCA Crim 89, where the appellate court recognised that acquisitive offending—though often low in individual monetary impact—may cumulatively erode social trust and justify custodial sentences to achieve deterrence. To place matters in further context, I observe that matters of acquisitive crime have long posed significant challenges to policing and community agencies. The advent of multi-agency crime partnerships seeks to coordinate responses but is hampered by resource constraints and data-sharing limitations, as noted in the 2022 Home Office Report on Retail Crime Collaboration. In light of all the above, I shall direct the preparation of a full pre-sentence report, incorporating the completed psychiatric assessment and any further information arising from probation interviews and community service provider feedback. The report should explore the feasibility of community-cohort supervision programmes addressing acquisitive offending, as trialled in adjoining jurisdictions, alongside any current risk management measures. I relieve all parties of the obligation to produce further forensic evidence as matters stand but allow the defence the opportunity to update representations following the report’s completion. Mr H, I remind you that your late guilty plea attracts a reduced discount and that the court will weigh heavily your previous convictions and the persistent nature of this offending. Credit is nevertheless given for your eventual plea. The hearing today has been conducted in open court with full participation from prosecution and defence representatives. My thanks to Ms Laura Jacobs, appearing for the Crown, and to Mr Adam Fairchild, who represents you under a Legal Aid representation order. Today's proceedings have been audio-recorded and transcribed in conformity with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules (CrimPR). The record will be held at Manchester Crown Court for requisite purposes. You are hereby notified of your statutory right to appeal this decision within 28 days as prescribed under sections 108 and following of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions in force pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 or otherwise. Costs remain reserved. These sentencing remarks are issued this 14th day of October 2025 in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Manchester. The formal sentencing hearing will be scheduled following receipt of the probation pre-sentence report and any final submissions. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT NORTHGATE R v. MR H Case No. NGT-2025-01942 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. P. WAINWRIGHT Filed: 18 October 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentence following a charge under section 1(1) of the Theft Act 1968, relating to a representative offence of shoplifting. The indictment reflects a sustained course of conduct involving multiple incidents of theft from various retail premises situated within the jurisdiction of Northgate and its immediate environs over a period extending from the autumn of 2023 to early summer 2025. Procedural History Your initial appearance was recorded at the Northgate Magistrates’ Court on 9 August 2025, when you first entered a plea of not guilty. Following the direction of the Crown Prosecution Service, the case was committed to this court under the Better Case Management process on 30 September 2025, with a plea and trial preparation hearing scheduled. It is worth noting that your guilty plea was entered longitudinally—conceded on the morning of trial, after the full evidential case had been presented and the jury empanelled. This judicial forum has become all too accustomed to last-minute pleas in cases concerning acquisitive crime. While the law rightly preserves the right of every defendant to defend allegations, the court must weigh the impact of such timing on the administration of justice. It is well-established, notably in R v. Morley [2019] EWCA Crim 445, that credit for a plea of guilty can be significantly reduced when entered at a late stage, particularly where it delays the conclusion of proceedings and imposes additional burdens on victims, witnesses, and court resources. Your case was adjourned on two occasions, the first occasion linked to applications for funding by the defence to instruct a forensic psychiatrist with expertise in behavioural addictions and impulsive offending. The Legal Aid Agency’s response was notably protracted; official correspondence reflects a series of requests for clarification, additional paperwork, and protracted decision-making which, regrettably, extended through a six-week period. This delay did not serve the interests of justice; it added pressure to an already congested court list and prolonged uncertainty for all parties involved. It falls to the court to observe with no small measure of concern how persistent administrative inertia within public legal aid provision risks subverting the timely and equitable resolution of criminal cases. Counsel for the defence had, with appropriate professionalism and diligence, submitted all requisite documentation as promptly as possible. The recorded chronology highlights an unfortunate systemic dysfunction; the cause of which is of course beyond the jurisdiction of this court to redress, but for which I nonetheless record profound dissatisfaction. You were remanded on bail following your arrest on 15 June 2025. Conditions attached to your bail required residence at a specified address and reporting to your local police station twice weekly. Compliance with these terms was noted in the pre-sentence report as generally satisfactory, notwithstanding occasional failures to notify changes of contact details, which police attribute to your transient housing circumstances. The business community has had some involvement in this matter through the Northgate Retail Crime Partnership, a well-established multi-agency initiative designed to mitigate shop theft and related crimes. The partnership’s activities involve information-sharing, coordinated patrols, and victim support services. While the group’s capacity is understandably constrained by limited funding and manpower, it nonetheless furnished several victim impact statements which provide valuable insight into the practical effects of your offending on local retailers and staff. The court is conscious, however, that such schemes operate within significant systemic limits. Frontline officers consistently face the challenge of balancing demands from a wide array of calls for service, meaning that acquisitive offences often compete for attention with higher priority investigations, including violent crime or organised gang activity. This dynamic is echoed in the recent report by the National Policing Board (2023), which identified that acquisitive property crimes—even in their smaller and repetitive manifestations—consume substantial operational resources, with estimated costs extending beyond financial losses to include staff absence and deteriorating workplace morale. Instructed counsel appearing today, Ms. Fiona J. Willoughby for the Crown and Mr. Gareth T. Milligan for the defence, have provided their submissions with due regard to the statutory framework, guideline principles, and relevant case law. Their detailed advocacy is appreciated. It is appropriate at this juncture to remind the court of the statutory sentencing framework applicable to theft offences. The Theft Act 1968, at section 1, defines theft as dishonestly appropriating property belonging to another with the intent to permanently deprive. Sentencing guidelines promulgated by the Sentencing Council (Definitive Guideline on Theft offences, 2021) identify key aggravating factors, including a history of similar offending, targeting of vulnerable victims, use of deception, and impact on staff vulnerability or community confidence. The case law further elucidates sentencing considerations where repetitive shoplifting with cumulative impact is concerned. As iterated in R v. Horton [2022] EWCA Crim 517, judges must balance the apparently modest value of items stolen with the broader harm caused, encompassing the fear engendered in shop staff, reputational damage to the affected business, and the cumulative burden on public enforcement services. On the topic of relevant comparative authority, I also consider instructive the judgment in R v. Clayton [2020] EWCA Crim 1719, which emphasised the importance of proportionality and individualised sentencing, cautioning against imprisonment for first or isolated low-value retail theft, but affirming immediate custody where offending forms part of a persistent pattern demonstrating clear disregard for previous warnings and rehabilitative opportunities. The court acknowledges the increasing deployment of advanced forensic techniques and digital investigative tools in establishing proofs of identity and chronology in omission-based offences. In this case, items retrieved and CCTV footage have been instrumental in corroborating the prosecution’s narrative, alongside electronic transaction records at various points of sale. Against this backdrop, the court now turns to the materials before it, including pre-sentence reports, psychiatric assessments, victim and agency correspondence, and of course, the statements put forward on your behalf. As a matter of process and fairness, the Social Services department prepared a safeguarding assessment following concerns voiced by a local homelessness prevention team. This report, dated 2 October 2025, carefully considers your personal circumstances, highlighting precarious housing status and history of substance misuse. It recommends continued engagement with supported accommodation services and community mental health provision. The interviewing social worker commented on your guarded but cooperative demeanour during discussions. Separately, the court received a letter from HelloBright, a local charity focused on assisting vulnerable adult offenders through education and skills training. The letter commends your recent attendance at a series of workshops and your expressed willingness to reconsider pathways towards employment. Such representations, while welcomed, do not mitigate the seriousness of the offending before the court, but serve as indicative of potential for positive change. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. I must note, dispassionately and with care, that the repeated nature of the incidents suggests a degree of planning and opportunism. The typology of stolen goods reflects an understanding of items with relatively high resale value and ease of concealment. This is not, in the court’s view, a simplistic lapse in judgment but rather a conscious and sustained engagement in criminal behaviour. Prior to your arrest, several local shop owners participated in the Business Crime Reduction Partnership intelligence meetings. Notes submitted in evidence describe a strategic sharing of data, enabling the identification of patterns of movement and modus operandi consistent with your conduct. This demonstrates a commendable level of cross-sector cooperation, albeit within limits imposed by resource constraints. It also bears mentioning that one co-defendant, charged in an allied indictment for conspiracy to commit aggravated burglary, was found to have supplied information regarding electronic security alarms at local premises. That defendant absconded following release on bail and remains at large, with active warrants issued by police. I emphasise that your case is to be considered independently, as there is no direct evidential link to whoever may have been involved in those separate offences. In R v. O’Donnell [2017] EWCA Crim 1968, the Court noted that associational offences such as conspiracy can often complicate matters of culpability and sentencing, but care must be taken to ensure sentences properly reflect the individual’s responsibility. The current defendant has no recorded association with the co-defendant’s activities and so such background, though provided for completeness, bears no direct relevance to your culpability. Mr H's niece’s pram was used to stash boxed razor cartridges and protein powder in order to avoid drawing attention. Somewhat tangentially, the court recalls a contemporaneous criminal trial held in the neighbouring borough concerning fly-tipping in a sensitive greenbelt area, arising out of an entirely separate matter. While not pertinent to the current proceedings, it serves as a reminder of the breadth of criminality that intersects with issues of community protection and environmental stewardship. The court hopes the principles laid down therein, including the importance of deterrence and reparation, are helpful in contextual understanding, though not determinative here. Returning to the present case, your history, as detailed in the probation service report dated 7 October 2025, discloses a series of convictions primarily for theft-related offences commencing in 2018. The report identifies five prior incidents of shoplifting, all resulting in community resolutions or conditional discharges, yet there appears to have been little sustained engagement with rehabilitative interventions. The psychiatric report, produced following instruction from this court and authored by Dr Neil Harding, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, offers valuable insight. The report, dated 11 October 2025, states that you exhibit no formal psychiatric diagnosis but describes traits of borderline personality organisation, manifested in impulsivity, emotional dysregulation, and intermittent self-harm ideation. Dr Harding emphasises your expressed motivation by underlying financial distress, but notes that trauma-informed interventions have so far failed to engage you fully. Mr H stole alcohol and tobacco from the same neighbourhood shop on four separate occasions across a three-week span. The report stresses the need for ongoing multidisciplinary management and warns of elevated risk of recidivism absent meaningful intervention. Participation in accredited cognitive behavioural programmes targeting acquisitive offending, such as the Thinking Skills Programme or Addressing Substance-Related Offending, is recommended. It is important to consider, additionally, the strain placed on public health systems by the growing prevalence of complex emotional and behavioural disorders in offenders. NHS commissioning data from the Northgate and Eastern CCG notes waiting times for adult community mental health teams in excess of twelve weeks, placing significant pressure on mainstream access for those who lack the capacity or motivation to engage independently. The probation officer overseeing your case commented on the tension between individual readiness to change and institutional capacity. Such considerations are critical when tailoring appropriate intervention packages aimed at reducing reoffending risk. Within the context of sentencing, it is necessary to examine the wider social and economic factors at play. The national picture reflects continuing challenges with street homelessness, welfare adequacy, and employment precarity. As documented in the 2024 Annual Report of the Homelessness Monitor, there is an increasing incidence of rough sleeping concentrated in urban centres including Northgate. The interplay between insecure housing and low-level acquisitive crime is complex but must not be overstated to the point of excusing clear legal wrongs. Mr H used a query about Oyster Card use to draw the attention of staff away, before taking a displayed product from behind the counter. Local authority housing teams have reported ongoing difficulties in accommodating vulnerable single adults, exacerbated by funding shortfalls and rising demand. Meanwhile, community organisations such as SafeStay Northgate provide vital emergency shelter but operate with finite resources. On the topic of victim impact, statements from individual shopkeepers convey the human cost beyond mere monetary loss. Several witnesses describe heightened anxiety, disrupted work patterns, and a pervasive sense of vulnerability within small retail outlets, some of which have introduced new security measures costing thousands of pounds to implement. The Retail Support Network submitted a detailed analysis ahead of today’s hearing. Their assessment notes that repeat shoplifting incidents increase staff turnover and sickness rates, compounding the operational challenges faced by small businesses — many of which linger on narrow margins. Furthermore, the psychological toll on frontline workers is not adequately recognised in public discourse, yet is palpable. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. There exists a danger in treating offending of this nature as “victimless crime.” It is not. It is a crime with tangible, often hidden casualties. The law and the court must acknowledge this reality solemnly. Certainly, the defendant’s letter to the court, submitted on 14 October 2025, expresses regret for the distress caused, and articulates a desire to address underlying difficulties. The letter was composed with a readable hand and is free from illegibility or undue incoherence; a matter on which the court is obliged to comment in fairness, given frequent cases to the contrary. Prior outreach by Your Local Offenders Support Team (YLOST) has included attempts to engage you in alcohol reduction services, debt advice, and housing stability programmes. Their correspondence highlights a mixed pattern of response marked by intermittent attendance and eventual disengagement. The defendant accepted that he sold the stolen property at a car boot sale and local drinking establishments, disturbing customers in the process. The courts remain aware of the critical role that multi-disciplinary partnerships play in preventing reoffending and enhancing public protection. Models such as the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) and the Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC) framework have been deployed to varying success in cases involving higher-risk offenders. While not directly engaged in your circumstance, the principles of coordinated intervention inform contemporary probation practice. Reference should also be made to R v. Templeman [2018] EWCA Crim 957, where the Court of Appeal underscored the imperative of sentencing consistency, warning against unwarranted disparity in similar offending profiles, while recognising individual mitigating factors. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while obscuring surveillance with paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. The issue of credit for a late plea of guilty requires balanced consideration. Your admission, entered only upon the cusp of trial, necessarily attracts a reduced discount consistent with authorities such as R v. Dyer [2020] EWCA Crim 2018. Although it spares the need for a contested trial, it comes after the Crown has expended considerable effort in preparation, and the inconvenience to witnesses has been prolonged unnecessarily. Public confidence in the justice system depends, in part, on the timely and efficient resolution of cases. Last-minute pleas can erode this confidence and add to systemic pressures. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, claimed it wasn’t a serious crime and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. Having considered all materials, including the personal circumstances of the defendant, expert opinion, victim impact, and sentencing precedents, I conclude that a custodial sentence is warranted. The repeated nature of the offending, the failure to respond to previous interventions, and the evident planning and persistence combine to elevate the culpability beyond the threshold for immediate custody. Nonetheless, I emphasise that sentencing must also reflect prospects for rehabilitation and reintegration. It is my intention to balance deterrence, punishment, and rehabilitation in arriving at a just outcome. Accordingly, I await a comprehensive pre-sentence report prior to passing sentence. The probation service is requested to explore suitable community rehabilitation options, including cognitive behavioural programmes, structured unpaid work, and financial management support. The report should also appraise the feasibility of a supervision model incorporating mental health liaison and housing support networks. I reserve final determination until such report has been received and considered. The court records its thanks to all who have contributed to the thorough and diligent preparation of this case, including the prosecution team led by Ms Fiona J. Willoughby, and to Mr Gareth T. Milligan for his robust and conscientious defence submissions. The hearing has been held in open court with full compliance to applicable protocol. The courtroom facilities, recently refurbished, allowed for adequate distancing and accessibility. This document is issued this day, 18 October 2025, at the Northgate Crown Court, Court 1. Proceedings have been recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A certified transcript will be appended to the court record. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal to the Court of Appeal within 28 days, under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. MR H Case No. T2025/13429 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. J. Elton Filed: 16 September 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentencing on a charge of theft, specifically the repeated shoplifting of goods from multiple retail outlets across the Birmingham metropolitan area. The offending spans a period from early 2023 through April 2025, culminating in your arrest earlier this year. The charge represents a significant breach of trust and law, underlying broader concerns about community safety and the protection of commercial premises. Procedural History and Case Progression Your initial appearance took place on 15 May 2025 before Birmingham Magistrates’ Court, where you entered a not guilty plea. The case was committed to the Crown Court for trial given the severity and multiplicity of incidents involved. Thereafter, the case was subject to a series of pre-trial hearings, including a plea and trial preparation hearing (PTPH) on 10 July 2025. During the PTPH, the Crown served voluminous evidence, including enhanced CCTV footage, witness statements, and analyses of recovered property. At the subsequent hearing on 1 September 2025, you entered a guilty plea to a representative charge, a decision which has been taken into account, though it was notably late in the proceedings. It is unfortunate, but increasingly common, that defendants in acquisitive crime cases delay pleas until the prosecution evidence becomes overwhelming. The weight of recent case law, including R v Dundas [2020] EWCA Crim 1358 and R v Kearney [2022] EWCA Crim 1450, confirms that credit for a guilty plea diminishes significantly where it is entered at a late stage, especially after extensive preparation for trial. The underlying rationale is that an early plea spares victims and witnesses the ordeal of giving evidence and reduces the burden on public resources. With that in mind, the court must carefully weigh the timing and sincerity of any plea in determining the appropriate discount. Over the course of these proceedings, there have been several adjournments, most notably to enable compliance with requests for expert psychiatric assessment and a pre-sentence report. The Legal Aid Agency’s response, while eventually sufficient, was marked by delays and administrative hurdles which hindered the timely deployment of expert services. I take this opportunity to note, with no small frustration, that these obstacles compromise timely justice and threaten the interests of fairness. The repeated difficulties in securing funding authorisations for such assessments represent a systemic concern and place unnecessary strain on all participants. It is also worth recording appreciation for the Crown Prosecution Service’s diligent case preparation and the work of the Birmingham Business Crime Partnership (BBCP), whose members have submitted detailed victim impact statements. The BBCP, despite chronic underfunding and staffing shortages, continues to provide crucial liaison between retailers and law enforcement. Their documentation vividly illustrates the cumulative distress inflicted upon staff and proprietors by repeated retail theft — a form of crime often dismissed as trivial but with very real consequences. Similarly, the probation service has cooperated in providing up-to-date risk assessments and coordinated input from multiple agencies, including local mental health services and housing officers. Mr Paul Everitt of the Probation Service prepared an extensive report dated 10 September 2025, which will be referred to in these remarks. It is well understood that acquisitive offending such as this imposes significant workload pressures on police and court staff alike, detracting from resources otherwise focused on serious violent and organised crime. The diversion of scarce public resources, though intangible in economic terms, reflects an opportunity cost that must be factored into sentencing considerations. Preliminarily, I note the relevant legislative and judicial contexts that inform sentencing in this area. Theft offences are governed principally by the Theft Act 1968, section 1, which defines the offence as the dishonest appropriation of property belonging to another with the intention to permanently deprive. While isolated or low-value thefts may be dealt with summarily or by diversion schemes, repeated offending over an extended period signals an elevated risk and culpability. The Sentencing Council’s Definitive Guideline on Theft Offences (2019) provides a structured approach to assessing harm, culpability, and aggravating or mitigating factors. Well-established precedent, including R v Latif [2019] EWCA Crim 1227 and R v Havers [2022] EWCA Crim 1602, affirms that multiple thefts particularly when accompanied by planning, concealment tactics, or targeting of vulnerable or small independent retailers, warrant custodial sentences in many cases. The Court of Appeal has repeatedly emphasised the importance of public deterrence in the context of persistent shoplifting, given the wider commercial and social harms occasioned. The Defendant’s Background and Previous Contacts Mr H is 34 years old and has a series of prior convictions largely for shoplifting offences dating back to 2017. These include custodial sentences, suspended sentences, and community orders, the details of which are fully recorded in the sentencing bundle. The most recent disposal, a community rehabilitation order, was imposed in 2023 but breached on several occasions. There is no indication of gang involvement or acquaintance with organised crime groups. He reports periods of unemployment interspersed with casual and temporary labour, but notably relies on local authority temporary accommodation given unstable housing. The probation assessment notes fluctuating engagement with support services and multiple missed appointments with addiction counselling. The defendant’s reported circumstances are reflective of significant social and economic disadvantage. The court reviewed a detailed psychological report prepared by Dr Francesca Muir, a forensic clinical psychologist, dated 5 September 2025. Dr Muir’s assessment found no diagnosable major mental disorder; however, she noted impulsivity, indicators of substance misuse, and concurrent depression symptoms. Significantly, Dr Muir recorded ongoing struggles with financial management and inconsistent compliance with previous interventions, recommending structured cognitive-behavioural therapy focusing on impulse control. Concerns about the capacity and availability of mental health services locally are noted in the report and echoed elsewhere in the documentary material. The NHS trusts serving this jurisdiction have repeatedly flagged increased pressure and service demand, leading to long waiting lists and delays for psychological support. While such systemic issues are not the defendant’s responsibility, they form a regrettable backdrop, complicating rehabilitation prospects. Victim personal statements were received from four separate retail outlets, including two pharmacy chains, a convenience store, and a local supermarket. These statements detail not only repeated losses incurred, but the profound effect on staff morale and personal sense of safety. Several employees describe heightened anxiety, changes in work patterns, and in one case, an employee requiring time off due to stress-related illness. One store manager’s statement highlighted that the defendant’s repeated visits created a climate of fear, prompting enhanced security measures and additional staff training costs. Similar concerns emerge from correspondence by the Retail Support Network, which continues to advocate for better resourcing of crime prevention initiatives focused on retail premises. Their representation stresses that while individual thefts may seem minor when isolated, the cumulative effect on business viability and community confidence is material and significant. Mr H was caught on CCTV placing £10 worth of haircare products into his coat and leaving the shop without making payment. It is worth considering, though only tangentially related, the judgment in R v Cavendish [2017] EWCA Crim 2983, dealing with a burglary committed on a domestic dwelling during a seasonal absence. Though factually distant, the case serves as a reminder that breach of trust and exploitation of vulnerability carry considerable weight in sentencing, even absent direct harm. Marking a continuing theme in distractor material is R v Jonas [2020] EWCA Crim 726, concerning criminal damage to a community centre noticeboard, which resulted in a civic fine. While wholly irrelevant to this case, the principles articulated on proportionality and community impact contribute to our evolving jurisprudence on property offences. Returning to the present matter, the court notes that retail employees’ experiences of repeated theft extend beyond economic loss to a deteriorating sense of workplace security. Trust in security arrangements and management responsiveness is strained, and the knock-on effects include increased staff turnover. These are not trivial consequences. Mr H used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and protein powder. Further digressions included materials relating to a co-defendant in an unrelated case, Mr Peter Able, charged with assaulting arresting officers with a chair during a protest near Birmingham city centre. Although completely unrelated here, this illustrates the sometimes chaotic nature of cases arriving in Crown Court lists. At a tactical level, the cross-jurisdictional cooperation between West Midlands Police and neighbouring forces, including Staffordshire and Warwickshire constabularies, continues to present administrative burdens. While multi-agency coordination is critical in the fight against crime, it can introduce delay and procedural complexity, unsuited to swift resolution in low-level theft cases. Mr H made four trips to the same cornershop over a three-week period, consistently targeting alcohol and cigarettes. The Crown invites the court to view this offending as serious due to its persistence and sophistication. Surveillance evidence, in conjunction with staff testimony, reveals calculated actions to conceal goods, repeated targeting of specific product lines including cosmetics, toiletries, and over-the-counter medications, and timed appearances coinciding with staff shift changes or busy periods. There is evidence of the defendant employing distraction techniques and rapid exits to evade store personnel. The Prosecution points to an accumulation of losses exceeding £1,000, amplifying the moral and financial culpability beyond isolated petty theft. The fact that shop employees altered routines and some refused to work alone during likely periods of defendant presence is compelling, evidencing tangible adverse impact. Mr H used a query about Oyster Card use to draw the attention of staff away, before taking a displayed product from behind the counter. During the investigative stage, digital forensics teams examined seized devices but found no evidence of organised sales or online disposal, indicating the offending was primarily opportunistic rather than commercial-scale. Nonetheless, the pattern was sustained over a protracted period. Similar cases involving comparable MO, such as R v Graves [2018] EWCA Crim 504 and R v Morris [2019] EWCA Crim 2851, have resulted in sentences reflecting the cumulative damage of repeated acquisitive crime. Such precedent informs the sentencing range appropriate here. During his arrest, officers recovered a magnet used to remove a security tag earlier that day. The defendant’s apparent failure to desist following prior community-based interventions further aggravates culpability. Statements from community policing officers indicate several unsuccessful attempts at engagement and diversion from reoffending. The administration of previous conditional discharges and warning notices failed to produce the intended behavioural change. The defendant told the authorities he sold the stolen items at a car boot sale and in pubs, and that this had upset or alarmed some customers. Expert psychiatric evidence confirms the absence of a severe or enduring mental health condition, though notes of impulsivity and depressive symptoms are present. There is no evidence of psychosis, bipolar disorder, or other legal insanity-defence predicates. The court takes seriously the potential mitigating significance of struggle with mental health, but equally notes the defendant’s inconsistent engagement with available supports. The court is cognisant of pressures upon health trusts: recent reports have highlighted dramatic increases in waiting times for psychological services, particularly cognitive-behavioural therapy. This speaks to systemic issues but does not exempt the defendant from responsibility for failing to seek or sustain appropriate treatment. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, causing alarm and disruption in the store. The defendant’s reported drug and alcohol history is limited, though probation records indicate occasional recreational use. No significant substance dependency is recorded, nor does the evidence suggest impairment at the times of offending. However, the role of occasional substance use in lowering impulse control is recognised, albeit without direct evidentiary linkage. Since arrest, the defendant has demonstrated some willingness to comply with court directions, but this comes after a lengthy period during which offending behaviours were prolific. The late guilty plea, entered only shortly before trial commencement, attracts limited mitigation as per standard sentencing jurisprudence. Relevant case law provides a compass for sentencing. The Court of Appeal in R v McKinnon [2021] EWCA Crim 2145 stressed that multiple thefts, particularly those occurring at night or involving entry to a dwelling, attract serious sentences to reflect the victim impact beyond mere financial loss. While Mr H’s offences did not involve burglary, the cumulative offending here similarly undermines public confidence and security. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, claimed it wasn’t a serious crime and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. The court is reminded by the CPS Business Crime Unit of the phenomenon where "repeat offenders are responsible for disproportionate losses," a statement echoed by local safety programming groups such as Protect & Respect Birmingham. The impact on the retail environment remains an ongoing concern, factoring into public policy decisions regarding sentencing severity. The court further notes, though not directly related, the report of a recent case in this court where an individual was convicted of environmental offences—specifically illegal fly-tipping on protected green belt land—resulting in significant ecological damage (R v Trent [2024] EWCA Crim 1899). While that offence bears no factual connection, the principle that persistent low-level offending undermines community well-being is broadly applicable. Assessment of Risk, Rehabilitation, and Support Services The pre-sentence report, prepared by Ms Julia Fielding of the West Midlands Probation Service, notes a medium risk of harm rating, principally due to the repetitive nature of the thefts and the demonstrable impact on vulnerable staff within retail environments. There is moderate risk of reoffending, heightened by the defendant’s history of non-compliance with previous orders. Ms Fielding highlights the difficulty in engaging the defendant with sustainable housing, mental health, and employment services, a challenge compounded by systemic shortages in support infrastructure. The court is reminded of the chronic underinvestment in such vital services, as echoed in the 2024 Parliamentary inquiry into the integrated justice and welfare systems for adult offenders. Recommendations include a comprehensive package comprising cognitive skills training, financial management advice, and substance misuse support, with a preference for structured community rehabilitation where feasible. The options of a suspended sentence order with a community payback element, or, alternatively, a custodial sentence with release considerations aligned to compliance with treatment, are outlined. Letters of support submitted from local charities, including the Birmingham Outreach Network and the Helping Hands Trust, commend the defendant’s intermittent engagement in voluntary activities but also express concern about lapses and lack of sustained commitment. These materials are noted but do not diminish the seriousness of the offences. The judiciary is acutely aware of the challenges faced by those working in rehabilitation, particularly in contexts of economic hardship, depleted funding, and chaotic social circumstances. Nonetheless, the court must balance these realities against the paramount duty of public protection and maintaining confidence in the rule of law. In parallel, correspondence from the Retail Support Group reiterates the economic strain placed on small business owners who bear the brunt of shoplifting-related losses, including increased insurance premiums and, in some cases, decisions to downsize or shutter premises altogether. Such community-level consequences cannot be ignored. The cumulative gravity of the offending, the demonstrable impact on victims and community, and the defendant’s protracted failure to desist despite multiple opportunities, all point towards a custodial sentence as the minimum necessary to mark denunciation and deterrence. However, the sentencing options available will be informed by the forthcoming pre-sentence report which will assess the potential for structured community intervention and any further relevant assessments. The court reiterates that a late plea reduces credit afforded, but prosecution recognition of the defendant’s admission nonetheless carries weight. Mitigating factors, particularly personal difficulties, housing insecurity, and health issues, albeit limited, will be reflected in sentencing discretion. The defendant is encouraged to engage fully with probation services, specialist providers, and any rehabilitative programming to break the cycle of offending. The court remains hopeful that constructive interventions can promote sustained desistance, as purely punitive responses alone have proved insufficient in this case’s history. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 16 September 2025, in Court 5 at Birmingham Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record will be forwarded to the relevant authorities. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to sections 108–110 of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. The matter is adjourned for sentencing pending receipt of the pre-sentence report. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT SOUTHBANK R v. MR H Case No. T2025/14376 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. L. GREAVES Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this Court having been found guilty of theft from retail premises, contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. The offending in question arose over the course of a protracted period from October 2022 through to February 2025, and involved multiple incidents within the Southbank and neighbouring boroughs. Procedural History You were initially arrested on the 29th of February, 2025, as part of an intensive investigation conducted by the Southbank Metropolitan Police’s Acquisitive Crime Unit in collaboration with the Southbank Retail Safety Alliance. This alliance includes representatives from retail security teams, local licensing authorities, and the Crown Prosecution Service’s shop crime unit. The investigation was initiated following repeated reports from various retailers concerning suspicious activity and frequent losses allegedly linked to you, or a person matching your description. Interagency cooperation, while lauded in principle, often struggles in practice. The Local Business Crime Prevention Partnership, operating under the wider banner of the Southbank Business Safety Board, has endeavoured to coordinate real-time information-sharing among retail establishments, but such systems are no cure-all. The degree to which participating retailers actively engage varies widely, with some larger chains investing heavily in loss prevention measures and others, notably smaller independent shops, lacking the resources to do more than report incidents sporadically. This disparity has regrettably hampered consistent intelligence-led responses across the borough—and is a pattern endemic to many urban centres facing constrained operating budgets. Your case was listed for a Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing on 21 March 2025 after you entered an initial not guilty plea. Discovery included a voluminous evidential bundle comprising CCTV footage, staff statements, and forensic reports. Subsequent developments, including further video evidence and a detailed GIS analysis of shoplifting hotspots within the borough, culminated in the acceptance of a guilty plea on 19 August 2025. This late plea conforms to a familiar, and, one must say, unfortunate trend in retail theft matters—where defendants exercise their procedural rights to test the prosecution’s case until evidentiary certainty renders resistance futile. The Court recognises the strain such delays place on judicial resources, retail victim-staff morale, and the wider community’s confidence in the criminal justice system. It must, however, be borne in mind that the availability of procedural protections is a cornerstone of due process, and that the ultimate duty of the Court is to ensure all decisions are informed by law and fact. The sentencing regime accordingly must balance the interests of justice and the legitimate mitigation that a plea of guilt may bring, mindful of public policy concerns as reflected in the relevant guidelines and case law. The saga of this case is further complicated by regrettable delays in the processing of legal aid applications. Your solicitors made an early application in March 2025 for the funding to instruct a forensic psychologist experienced in behavioural assessments of repeat acquisitive offenders. The Legal Aid Agency’s protracted review process stretched over three months, during which time assessments and case preparation were necessarily dormant. Such systemic inefficiencies are well-documented in reports by the Criminal Bar Association and the Sentencing Council, with the resulting bottlenecks exerting adverse impacts on case timeliness, professional morale, and ultimately, the delivery of justice to defendants and victims alike. Surrounding this delay was an unfortunate coincidence of court scheduling pressures, exacerbated by industrial action within court support services, resulting in the adjournment of several key procedural hearings. The Southbank Crown Court is currently managing a significant backlog of cases. While the involving parties have shown commendable diligence in meeting deadlines when permitted, the interconnectedness of administrative challenges cannot be overlooked. These procedural delays amplify the burden on all participants and underscore the increasing complexity and fragility of contemporary case management frameworks. Strategic defence submissions emphasised your history of traumatic childhood experiences, including episodes of neglect and instability within the foster care system. These factors, while undoubtedly shaping your life-course, do not exempt you from accountability but are relevant to individualised sentencing, as recognised in R v. Sinclair [2023] EWCA Crim 1453, where the Court reaffirmed the importance of weighted mitigation reflecting personal history without diminishing culpability. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. The Court is cognisant that the Public Health England’s 2024 report on the accessibility of mental health services cited significant gaps in community provision within the Southbank area, especially for adults aged 25 to 40, exacerbated by staff attrition and rising demand. This context is pertinent, as defence medical submissions suggest that your behaviour may be influenced by untreated anxiety and intermittent substance use disorder. Consultation with Dr Harriet O’Connell, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, included a review of your case, resulting in a detailed report appended to the pre-sentence documentation. Dr O’Connell’s report describes you as presenting with symptoms indicative of moderate chronic anxiety disorder, compounded by periods of alcohol misuse, though without psychotic features or significant cognitive impairment. The report recommends structured engagement with community mental health teams but expresses reservations about the likelihood of sustained compliance, given your historical patterns of non-engagement. The probation officer’s assessment likewise reflects concerns regarding impulsivity and financial instability as persistent criminogenic factors. This case unfolds against the backdrop of increasingly precarious housing markets. Your current residence is temporary, arranged through the Southbank Homelessness Prevention Service following an eviction prompted by rental arrears. The Service’s annual report highlights the systemic challenges facing families in housing need, notably rising waiting lists and the toll on social services. Your own interactions with the housing authority have been intermittent and at times fractious, complicating consistent support delivery. Boxed razor cartridges and protein powder were hidden in Mr H's niece’s pram to avoid detection. The multi-agency approach to retail crime, incorporating the Business Crime Reduction Partnership’s data-sharing protocol, has proven patchy. The partnership’s semi-annual audit in 2024 acknowledged persistent gaps in information flow, especially concerning smaller retailers who lack formal loss-prevention staff. Nonetheless, for the present case, store managers from two medium-sized retail chains provided detailed victim impact statements expressing significant disruption and staff anxiety resulting from your actions. Of note, one victim impact statement from the manager of a local pharmacy records alterations to staff rotas and refusals to permit lone working during early morning shifts—a measure taken explicitly on account of fear arising from your repeated visits. This intangible harm reflects the broader psycho-social effects of your offending beyond mere financial loss. The Court further acknowledges a written submission dated 12 August 2025 from the Southbank Retail Worker’s Support Network, a charitable organisation offering frontline assistance to employees affected by workplace crime and intimidation. Their commentary notes a national rise in workplace-related stress linked to acquisitive offending and advocates for greater resource allocation to victim support schemes. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. In considering the sentencing framework applicable in this case, the Court is guided principally by the Sentencing Council’s Definitive Guideline on Theft Offences (2020, amended 2023). The Guideline obliges sentencing courts to evaluate the culpability of the offender, the harm caused (both economic and personal), and any aggravating or mitigating factors. Relevant aggravating factors here include the repeated and persistent nature of the offending, the targeting of vulnerable premises, the impact on staff wellbeing, and the failure to desist despite prior warnings and community disposals. Mitigation includes your plea of guilty, albeit late and following inevitable evidential pressure, your personal difficulties and unstable housing status, and the absence of any prior violent offending. I have noted with interest the jurisprudence extrapolated from cases such as R v. McTavish [2022] EWCA Crim 1785, where it was emphasised that whilst pleas of guilty attract a discretionary discount, the timing and sincerity of such pleas are pivotal. Late pleas, delivered only when the weight of evidence can no longer be challenged, typically warrant more modest reduction. Mr McTavish’s case, which involved sustained repeated shoplifting offences across multiple stores, was considered instructive during these proceedings. Similarly, the principle articulated in R v. Carney [2019] EWCA Crim 2021, concerning the cumulative harm arising from ongoing theft offences, bears relevance. In that case, the Court recognised that even low-value thefts, when part of an orchestrated pattern, produce disproportionate communal impact, meriting a proportionate custodial response. In one instance, Mr H distracted staff by asking about Oyster Card payments before reaching behind the counter to remove a display item. The evidence illustrates that on various occasions you employed a range of concealment tactics, ranging from the use of layered clothing to apparent distraction methods targeting staff attention. This calculated behaviour not only demonstrates heightened culpability but reinforces the premise that the offending was neither opportunistic nor impulsive, but carefully directed. The Crown correctly submits that such conduct erodes the sense of safety and trust within retail environments, fostering a climate in which workers must remain perpetually vigilant, with attendant psychological costs. This Court accepts those submissions. The fact that no physical threats or violence occurred does not diminish the seriousness of this impact. In parallel, records from the Southbank Social Services Department, included in documentary evidence, describe your prior engagement with youth outreach programmes and early interventions attempted during your teenage years. While not directly related to the instant offending, they provide useful background concerning your developmental history and social milieu. The defendant removed a security tag using a magnet, which was later recovered during his arrest. The Court has reviewed the probation officer’s comprehensive pre-sentence report dated 31 August 2025. The report highlights a complex profile, including histories of educational underachievement, interrupted employment, and multiple instances of non-compliance with community sentences for similar offences. It further indicates missed appointments with support programmes designed to reduce recidivism and improve life skills. The report recommends consideration of a community order incorporating requirements tailored to address offending behaviour, mental health engagement, and potentially unpaid work. Given your housing status, the report also flags the need for liaison with local housing support services to mitigate immediate risk factors. It must be stated, without hesitation, that short custodial sentences for offences of this nature have a limited rehabilitative effect and impose substantial costs on the wider community. Indeed, sentencing decisions are increasingly influenced by the imperative to deploy alternatives to custody where safely possible. However, this must be balanced against the clear societal expectation that repeat offending, with demonstrable harm, is met with an appropriately robust deterrent—both to the individual and the public at large. The defendant acknowledged selling the stolen property at a car boot market and in pubs, where his behaviour caused a disturbance to patrons. Parallel to case management, the Court notes the voluntary sector contributions to the sentencing process. Letters received from the Southbank Community Outreach Project, a non-governmental organisation providing support to vulnerable adults, commend your belated engagement with their counselling services, while cautioning that progress remains fragile. Such inputs are invaluable, speaking not only to your capacity for change but also to the resources that must be marshalled effectively to support sustainable desistance. While commendations exist for these small steps, they do not yet ameliorate the seriousness of the offences and their repeated nature. The Court similarly notes, with regret, the prolonged waiting times currently experienced in accessing services through the Southbank Addiction Recovery Unit. The waiting lists for triage appointments often exceed six months, a factor outside your control but illustrating the resource constraints facing public health. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and threatened employees while interfering with store surveillance systems, causing alarm and disruption in the store. I must also refer to the legislative context. The Theft Act 1968 has remained the keystone statute concerning property offences for over half a century, yet society’s understanding of acquisitive crime and its drivers has evolved markedly in that time. Parliamentary debates in 2023 on amendments to sentencing provisions sought to reflect this evolution, acknowledging the complex nexus of mental health, socio-economic factors, and community impact. Notwithstanding these changes, the core principle remains clear: theft is a breach of trust and an affront to the communal fabric. In this vein, R v. Faraday [2024] EWCA Crim 1238 reaffirmed the Court of Appeal’s stance that the criminal justice system must calibrate responses to theft carefully, applying custodial sentences sparingly where possible, but decisively where repeat offending with material harm is evident. Mr H acknowledged to police that he regularly steals, believes it’s just taking what he needs and has no intention of stopping. Further to the specific matter of your case, the Court must register its concern that, despite previous interventions, including warnings and non-custodial disposals, offending continued unabated. This pattern diminishes the mitigating weight that might otherwise be accorded to factors such as social disadvantage or mental health difficulties. That said, the Court remains mindful that protection of the public includes not merely retribution and deterrence, but the encouragement of rehabilitation and reintegration. The delicate balance between these imperatives will be central to the forthcoming sentencing determination. It is necessary, in conclusion, to place on record the Court’s appreciation for the professional conduct displayed by all parties throughout these proceedings. Ms Lucy Grant, leading counsel for the Crown, presented the prosecution case with clarity and measured restraint. Mr Daniel Elms, representing the defence, provided diligent and conscientious advocacy despite the well-known pressures imposed by legal aid resourcing constraints. The seamless order maintained by the court staff, combined with the dignified bearing of all those in attendance, reflects the enduring commitment of the judiciary and supporting personnel to the administration of justice under challenging conditions. Sentencing will be adjourned pending receipt of an updated pre-sentence report incorporating any further medical or psychiatric evaluations and submissions from probation. The court requests that the Probation Service consider recommendations relating to potential community rehabilitation requirements, unpaid work, mental health support, and housing liaison. These sentencing remarks are issued on this 14th day of September 2025 in Court 5 at Southbank Crown Court. Proceedings have been recorded in accordance with Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. Mr H is advised of the right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions in force pursuant to section 49 Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
