input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT SHEFFIELD R v. MR H Case No. S2025/13426 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. G. DALRYMPLE Filed: 23 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court for sentence following your conviction for an offence under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, namely shoplifting from several retail establishments over a period spanning late 2023 through to early 2025 within and around the Sheffield metropolitan borough. The offence was tried here following your guilty plea entered at the close of the Crown’s case. Procedural Overview Your initial appearance occurred on 12 March 2025 at the Sheffield Magistrates’ Court, where the charge was first laid. The case rapidly moved to this Crown Court venue pursuant to the Crown Court allocation scheme, the matter having been identified as requiring detailed consideration of prior offending and complex evidential material. A plea and trial preparation hearing was scheduled for 14 May 2025 before the Honorable Recorder W. Bridges. At that hearing, no application was made by the defence to change the plea, and a trial date was set. However, on 2 July 2025, you entered a guilty plea following the service of additional prosecutorial evidence including digital forensics, CCTV footage, and witness statements. The late plea occasioned discussion as to appropriate reduction in sentencing credit. The administrative flow of this case, although punctuated with significant engagement from the parties, was affected by several adjournments. These included a three-week delay due to Local Government strike action impacting court staffing levels and the reluctance of the Legal Aid Agency to swiftly authorise funding for a psychiatric assessment requested by your counsel. These procedural intricacies are illustrative of systemic pressures currently confronting the administration of criminal justice. While such systemic concerns are extrinsic to your individual case, they provide context to the protracted nature of proceedings at a time when the courts face unprecedented demand coupled with resource limitations. A noteworthy feature within the broader landscape is the operation of the Sheffield Business Crime Forum, an umbrella initiative comprising police, local council officers, retailers, and community groups aiming to coordinate responses to neighbourhood crime. While the Forum’s efficacy is occasionally hindered by staff fluctuations and competing priorities, it was substantially engaged in collating intelligence relevant to your offending pattern. The Forum’s Crime Reduction Officer contributed to the prosecution’s investigative approach, facilitating the gathering of surveillance evidence and witness liaison. Their activity was documented in correspondence submitted with the prosecution’s trial bundle dated 15 August 2025. The court is mindful of the enduring challenges faced by police officers assigned to city centre patrols, where persistent acquisitive offending imposes a disproportionate administrative and operational heaviness. As noted in the recent internal report by South Yorkshire Police’s Operational Command Unit, front-line officers frequently balance emerging violent crime and the complexities of licensed premises compliance alongside addressing the seemingly never-ending tide of shop theft incidents. This case exemplifies the resource-intensive efforts expended on what some might term “low-level” criminality but which, cumulatively, exacts a heavy toll on both public confidence and retail viability. Mr H, during the course of these proceedings, your legal representation has been consistently provided by Mr Michael Gowers of Sheffield Legal Aid Services. I acknowledge and thank Mr Gowers for his thorough submissions and professional conduct. Likewise, the Crown has been ably represented by Ms Emma Lupin, whose clarity and precision in outlining the evidential merits and public interest considerations have been duly noted. Turning to a more general observation concerning the Legal Aid Agency, it is unable to escape the court’s notice that the procedural delays in approving expert instructions in this matter were regrettably emblematic of a wider trend. Such delays place undue strain on defence counsel, hamper timely justice, and in effect, may compromise effective advocacy. It is hoped that ongoing reforms within the Legal Aid system will address these deficiencies, preserving the fundamental principle of fair trial. The facts of this case, as presented before the court at trial, arise from a pattern of conduct involving the systematic removal of goods from retail premises over approximately seventeen months. Through the collation of CCTV footage from multiple stores, witness accounts, and forensic analysis of discarded packaging and clothing, a consistent modus operandi emerged. As the Crown outlined in opening, your actions were not singular or spontaneous acts but rather formed a deliberate and sustained course of conduct. Mr H was observed placing £14 worth of cosmetics into his jacket lining before exiting the store without payment. Each theft, while individually of modest financial value, when viewed cumulatively, reflects persistent intent to deprive the owner of goods. This court has frequently remarked on the fallacy of equating low monetary value with triviality. The cumulative loss borne by retailers, along with the intrusion on staff and disruption to customer experience, constitutes a significant public harm. The Retail Theft Sentencing Guidelines, paragraph 3.5, expressly caution courts against treating repeated low-level shoplifting as inconsequential. Indeed, the discharged obligation imposed by the Theft Act not only protects tangible property rights but safeguards the integrity of community commerce and the dignity of workers subjected to the stress of victimisation. It warrants mention that investigations were spearheaded by Detective Inspector Lucy Fairbanks of the South Yorkshire Acquisitive Crime Unit, whose team carried out an evidence-gathering operation that incorporated covert observation, deployment of technological assets, including transport metadata, and liaison with Business Crime Reduction Officers. The sophisticated nature of this investigative response underscores the seriousness with which such offences attract official attention. Mr H used his niece’s pram to conceal boxed razor cartridges and protein powder. It is significant that on multiple occasions you were identified leaving premises with goods concealed yet lacking payment, frequently exploiting busy periods and staff distraction. This indicates a premeditation inconsistent with unwitting or impulsive action. Procedural complexity arises when considering the extended surveillance undertaken, which involved coordination between local transport authorities’ CCTV control rooms and private security firms employed by the retailers. The collation of this digital evidence, while voluminous, established a compelling nexus to your person and supported the charge beyond reasonable doubt. The court takes judicial notice of the ongoing debate regarding better utilisation of technology to combat retail crime, as articulated in the Home Office report “Digital Policing and Retail Crime 2024,” but also affirms the necessity of balancing privacy rights and evidential sufficiency. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. It is also noted that your choice of target goods commonly included high-demand personal care products and over-the-counter medications—items often vulnerable to resale on informal markets. The impact of this is twofold: losses to business and contribution to black market activity that may fuel wider societal harms. Equally troubling are the consequences for those employed in the affected premises. Staff have reported increased anxiety, reduced workplace morale, and the need to undertake additional security responsibilities without commensurate support. In a deliberate act of distraction, Mr H engaged staff in a conversation about Oyster Cards while covertly removing a display item from behind the counter. Mr H was found to have used a magnet to bypass a security tag, with the device recovered at the time of arrest. Turning to the documented victim impact, the court has had the benefit of statements from several store managers and employees who spoke of the toll your repeated offending took. One manager notably remarked that persistent theft led to increased security costs, forced adjustments in staff rotas, and sadly, contributed to a decision to reduce opening hours. This, in turn, diminishes community access to vital goods and fuels a sense of insecurity in neighbourhoods. The Retail Support Network, a voluntary sector body engaged by several affected shopkeepers, provided a report to the court setting out the broader consequences of recurring shoplifting. While their role is ancillary, the insight they bring paints a picture of a sector under pressure, grappling with financial uncertainty and workforce retention difficulties. The distress experienced by victims as recorded in these statements must be given weight. While the offences did not involve threats or violence, the psychological impact of repeated dishonesty and intrusion into workplace safety is often underestimated. The defendant disclosed that the stolen goods were sold at a car boot sale and in pubs, where his conduct caused unease among customers. Development of the case and prosecution strategy was, in part, modelled on the recommendations set forth in Williams and O’Connor (2019) concerning the use of intelligence-led policing and offender management to effectively tackle repeat retail offending. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. The court also notes that your offending persisted despite prior warnings and an out-of-court disposal issued in late 2023 by the Sheffield Community Resolution Group. This prior intervention was unsuccessful in deterring you. The failure of such community-based measures to stem your conduct signals a need for more robust judicial response. Mr H admitted to police that he steals regularly, claimed it wasn’t a serious crime and said he will carry on regardless of consequences. A psychiatric assessment was commissioned following your counsel’s application, a report having been prepared by Dr S. Raman, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, and lodged with the court on 8 September 2025. Dr Raman concluded that, whilst you do not suffer from a diagnosable mental disorder that would disrupt criminal responsibility, there are traits of heightened impulsivity, emotional dysregulation, and a mild but untreated substance use issue, notably alcohol misuse. Dr Raman also noted your lack of engagement with available support services and expressed concerns about your limited insight into the consequences of your offending. The Pre-Sentence Report, compiled by Probation Officer Ms Angela McPherson on 18 September 2025, echoes these findings. She highlights your unstable housing situation and lack of meaningful employment. While acknowledging some steps you have made towards recovery and stabilisation, the report urges structured supervision and consideration of rehabilitative programmes targeting acquisitive offending and impulsivity. The strain on Probation Services nationally is well recognised. Notably, Sheffield Probation Trust currently operates with 15% fewer officers than last year, and waiting times for community programme commencement have increased. Despite this, Ms McPherson reports readiness within local provision to accommodate your case, subject to sentencing direction. The offence falls squarely within the Sentencing Council guideline on Theft, dated July 2022, which emphasises that persistent offending and targeting vulnerable or small independent premises can constitute aggravating factors. It is appropriate to remind that in R v. Sterling [2023] EWCA Crim 387, a defendant with a comparable offending pattern was subject to an immediate custodial sentence owing to recidivism and failure to engage with diversion schemes. The Court of Appeal there underscored the principle that community tolerance towards repeat property crime has limits, particularly where the deterrent effect of earlier sanctions has failed. Reference is also made to R v. Honeywell [2024] EWCA Crim 221, in which a custodial sentence was imposed on a young offender involved in a series of shop thefts that significantly disturbed local commercial stability despite low individual values. Of note is the Court’s consideration of R v. Davidson [2021] EWCA Crim 1149, where the Court observed that delayed guilty pleas, especially those entered only at trial, should attract reduced reductions in sentence credit. The principle that an early plea reflects genuine remorse and saves court time is well established and applies here. Historical context to theft law may be found in the foundational cases dating back to the Theft Act 1968’s enactment, including the seminal authority R v. Ghosh [1982] QB 1053, though its test for dishonesty has since been modified by Ivey v Genting Casinos (2017) UKSC 67, which set the prevailing legal standard. It is thus noted that your course of conduct offends against these legal parameters both in theory and practice. The Sheffield Crown Court itself has undergone a refurbishment project earlier this year, modernising the main courtroom where your trial was heard. This upgrade included state-of-the-art audio-visual systems and improved accessibility, designed to facilitate the orderly and fair conduct of proceedings. It is regrettable that, on the day of your plea, there was a brief delay of 20 minutes caused by the late arrival of an interpreter assigned for an unrelated matter listed later on the afternoon roster. Whilst not directly impacting these proceedings, such occurrences are symptomatic of wider workforce shortages in court services. The court is made cognisant of the fact that this case attracted minimal press or public interest, a phenomenon noted in several recent local proceedings. In an age where media focus often gravitates toward high-profile or violent offences, the slow attritional harm caused by repeated petty crime receives scant attention despite its enduring community impact. Mr H, I am also obliged to mention that your sister, Ms Bernadine Williams, provided a character reference pleading for leniency, indicating that you have familial support which may be pivotal in your rehabilitation. The report from the Westborough Community Food Bank likewise testifies to your occasional engagement with social services aimed at assisting those with unstable income and housing. In the final assessment, the court must balance the seriousness of the offence, the cumulative impact on victims, your personal circumstances, and the wider public interest in deterrence and rehabilitation. You have, regrettably, demonstrated a pattern of deliberate offending over a lengthy period, accompanied by a degree of resistance to prior attempts at diversion. Your late plea, entered only after significant evidence was amassed, attracts a modest reduction in sentencing credit. The aggravating factors of persistence and the ripple effect on vulnerable small businesses and employees weigh heavily. Nevertheless, your engagement with some community supports and the psychiatric observations suggesting potential for intervention counsel consideration of a structured community sentence. I shall therefore order the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report, incorporating an assessment of the feasibility and appropriateness of sentence options ranging from a community order with relevant rehabilitation requirements to custodial disposals where justified. The report should particularly address suitable cognitive behavioural programmes aimed at offending behaviour, any necessary addiction treatment pathways, and risk management considerations. I express my gratitude to all who have contributed to the material before me, including prosecution and defence counsel, police investigators, probation, and voluntary sector contributors. These sentencing remarks are issued today, 23 September 2025, in Court 5 of the Sheffield Crown Court. The record of proceedings has been duly transcribed and entered under Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal against sentence within 28 days, pursuant to section 108 of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT WINDSOR R v. MR H Case No. W2025/08321 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. J. Kensington Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court today for sentence in respect of a charge under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, namely a course of conduct involving the theft of goods from multiple retail premises over a significant period. This court has been presented with a detailed but complex bundle of evidence, reflecting extended investigative efforts and broad cooperation amongst several agencies. It is essential at the outset to emphasise that while the offences concern relatively low-value items, the cumulative impact and repetition of this conduct attract serious judicial consideration. Such offending can have disruptive economic and social consequences well beyond the immediate loss or displacement of goods. Procedural History The matters leading to the charge relate to incidents spanning from early 2023 through to March 2025. Arrest followed an investigation culminating on 12 March 2025, subsequent to intelligence-led work conducted by the Windsor Borough Police and the Thames Valley Retail Crime Partnership. I note that this case was allocated to the Crown Court under the Better Case Management (BCM) regime, an initiative designed to reduce avoidable delays and promote early identification of contested issues. The case management timetable was generally observed, though the court is mindful of some unavoidable adjournments necessitated by ongoing expert assessments and late disclosure applications. These are, regrettably, not uncommon in cases requiring multi-agency liaison and forensic expertise. Such delays, while frustrating to all involved, are the consequence of the procedural safeguards necessary in complex matters; the court appreciates the efforts of all parties to minimise disruption. The investigative phase benefitted from the use of advanced analytic techniques, including cross-referencing incident reports with anonymised mobile data and retail point-of-sale discrepancy logs. This methodological richness enabled a more comprehensive case to be presented. Such an approach, though resource intensive, exemplifies modern policing’s move toward data-driven enforcement aimed at disrupting persistent offending patterns before they further entrench. This case draws attention, again, to the pressing challenge faced by retail premises, particularly smaller independent traders, whose limited resilience to theft-related loss strains increasingly fragile business models. Applications under Legal Aid funding arrangements to instruct an independent psychiatric expert and a forensic accountant to consider the financial impact of offending were submitted by the defence in good time but unfortunately experienced protracted administrative processing. The Legal Aid Agency’s delays in granting authority to instruct these experts resulted in the hearing scheduled for 20 August being vacated and the matter relisted for today’s sentencing hearing. Such delays, while understandable given the thoroughness desired in oversight, risk impeding the timely delivery of justice. This court would echo wider judicial calls for reform of these procedures to prevent unnecessary bottlenecks. Both prosecuting and defence counsel have conducted themselves professionally throughout, and I record my thanks to Mr Simon Haynes appearing on behalf of the Crown and to Ms Felicity Warner representing the defendant under a legal aid order. The court also thanks the court clerk and ushers, who have facilitated the smooth running of proceedings notwithstanding the pressure on court listings nationally. Within the wider context, Windsor Crown Court serves a diverse and densely populated area, marked by a mixed socio-economic profile and a retail sector that includes both large commercial chains and smaller niche shops. Recent years have seen an increase in reports of acquisitive crime, a pattern reflected nationally. This underscores the relevance of the sentencing processes here in delivering outcomes that balance the interests of justice, the needs of victims, and the statutory aims of rehabilitation and public protection. The court is also cognisant of wider concerns about rising street homelessness and social vulnerability in the local area. The issue has been the subject of recent public health and law enforcement briefings, drawing attention to the interrelationship between social exclusion, mental health needs, and offending behaviour. Though the court does not intend to conflate these broader social challenges with individual culpability, the context in which offending occurs may have bearing upon sentencing considerations. The case law which guides sentencing in offences of theft is well-established, with the starting point legislated and refined through successive Court of Appeal decisions. Of note, R v. Firmin [2022] EWCA Crim 1557 affirms the importance of proportionality and the recognition that, while low-value offences may attract custodial sentences in some contexts, the nature and impact of the offending remain paramount. Similarly, in R v. Duval [2019] EWCA Crim 334, the Court endorsed tailored community approaches where rehabilitation prospects are tangible and the public risk manageable. These authorities frame the legal compass within which this court operates. Attention is drawn to the sentencing guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council, updated as recently as 2024, which give direction on theft offences. The guidelines categorise offending per its seriousness, considering factors such as the value of goods, planning and sophistication, offending frequency, and impact upon victims. Particularly relevant here is the emphasis placed on the cumulative nature of offences and the acknowledgement of the psychological distress caused to retail staff, especially when persistent offending disrupts normal business activities and staff wellbeing. The Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 and subsequent amendments, alongside the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012, frame aspects of sentencing discretion and the deployment of community-based sanctions. The court notes that Mr H is in receipt of state benefits due to financial hardship but is reported to have had several opportunities to engage with support services relevant to his circumstances, with varying degrees of compliance. The court also received detailed victim impact statements from several local retailers, documenting the operational challenges posed by repeat shoplifting. One such statement, submitted by the manager of a chemist on High Street, described the efforts to install additional CCTV and store layout changes designed to deter thefts, as well as increased employee stress levels and turnover. These submissions, collectively, illustrate that even offences of modest individual value can carry wider consequences. They serve as a sober reminder that offences of this nature are not victimless. Mr H placed £16 worth of skincare products into his coat lining and exited the premises without attempting to pay. It is pertinent to observe that the court heard from a senior officer of the Windsor Business Crime Reduction Partnership, who provided an outline of joint efforts to address retail crime in the borough. He described the ongoing challenges faced in the face of limited staffing levels exacerbated by recent recruitment difficulties across the constabulary. The chronic understaffing of frontline teams inevitably constrains the immediacy and scope of response to acquisitive offence reports, as resources must also be stretched across other priorities including violent crime, road safety, and counter-terrorism. The officer’s testimony underscores the system-wide pressures that cases such as this impose. It was also brought to the court’s attention that the defendant is currently under the supervision of the Probation Service following a prior community order for theft-related offences. The Probation Officer’s report, considered in advance of this hearing, notes an inconsistent engagement pattern and highlights concerns regarding financial management and social isolation. The report reflects an up-to-date risk assessment placing Mr H within a medium risk of harm tier, with the potential for reoffending remaining a substantive concern. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. It is worth noting that this court has, in other cases, wrestled extensively with the challenge of appropriate credit for guilty pleas entered late in the proceedings. While the law rightly encourages defendants to admit guilt at the earliest opportunity, the courts cannot treat belated pleas afforded solely by the weight of overwhelming evidence as evidence of genuine remorse. The legal framework as explained in R v. Stamford [2018] EWCA Crim 1340 provides ample guidance on the degrees of credit available dependent on plea timing and circumstances. In the present case, Mr H entered his plea shortly before the trial window, limiting the discount to which he may properly be entitled. A detailed psychiatric report was obtained from Dr Fiona Rickwood, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, whose evaluation was exhaustive and professionally conducted. Her conclusions indicate that while no major mental illness is present, there is evidence of mild depressive symptoms, manifesting as low mood and reduced motivation. Dr Rickwood noted tendencies toward impulsivity and emotional instability but stopped short of diagnosing a formal personality disorder. She further emphasised that appropriate psychological support services are available locally, but uptake has been minimal. Dr Rickwood recommended engagement with cognitive-behavioural therapy tailored to addressing impulsivity and decision-making deficits, as well as social support interventions targeting isolation. The report also outlined the pressures on mental health services regionally, with waiting times for psychological therapies extending beyond average targets nationally. This reflects a marked increase in service demand post-pandemic, coupled with workforce shortages noted in the NHS workforce census 2025. The court commends the efforts of clinicians and coordinators striving to maintain care standards amid these constraints. Over a three-week period, Mr H visited the same local shop on four occasions, stealing alcohol and tobacco each time. It must be emphasised that the law does not personalise systemic shortcomings, but neither can those realities be ignored when considering rehabilitation pathways. It is therefore incumbent on the probation and social services to ensure access to suitable supports, bearing in mind the practical difficulties posed by capacity limitations. In reviewing previous relevant case law, the court recalls R v. Sinclair [2020] EWCA Crim 1429, which concerned a defendant convicted of burglary and repeat thefts targeting vulnerable small shops. The Court of Appeal endorsed a custodial sentence where members of the public had been left "intimidated and fearful," and where the defendant's engagement with rehabilitation programmes had been minimal. In contrast, R v. Metcalfe [2021] dealt with a defendant with schizophrenia involved in an arson offence; that case reinforced the delicate balancing act required in considering sentenced infractions committed in the context of serious mental illness, promoting a therapeutic custodial approach. Neither set of circumstances mirrors Mr H’s exactly, but both inform the wider jurisprudential context. I also note the precedential judgments concerning the reduction of credit for guilty pleas. The principle set out in R v. Danvers [2017] EWCA Crim 2920 is salient here: the earlier the plea, the more credit afforded, reflecting not just procedural saving but an indication of insight and remorse. Mr H diverted the attention of shop staff by inquiring about Oyster Card services, using the opportunity to remove an item from the display behind the counter. This case typifies the strain inflicted on front-line retail workers, who are too frequently overlooked as victims of crimes that, while lacking overt violence, inflict significant psychological and practical harm. The court takes due account of the testimony from store employees, noting increased anxiety and diminished feelings of safety, which align with observations from the British Retail Consortium’s 2024 Crime Survey report. The psychological impact of repeated theft on staff wellbeing must be recognised as part of the harm continuum. The court must consider the defendant’s personal circumstances, well documented in the probation pre-sentence report and medical assessments. Mr H is aged 29, currently unemployed, and residing in temporary accommodation provided by the local council. There is a history of unresolved housing instability coupled with sporadic engagement with welfare support services. His family situation is described as fractured, with limited contact. A letter submitted by a local charity supporting individuals with complex needs in Windsor was also tendered. The letter endorsed the defendant’s previous engagement with programmes addressing substance misuse and mental health but noted recent disengagement. The charity expressed willingness to renew support post-sentence if appropriate. During his arrest, officers recovered a magnet used to remove a security tag earlier that day. The home environment within which a defendant lives can be a material factor in both offending and rehabilitation prospects. This court acknowledges the recurring themes of poverty, hardship, and exclusion that populate much of the casework before us. And yet, courts must remain vigilant against conflating context with excuse. As observed in R v. Langridge [2019] EWCA Crim 1047, personal adversity, while significant in mitigation, cannot eclipse responsibility for choices made. Among the procedural observations pertinent to this hearing are some minor irregularities in administrative record-keeping, including discrepancies in date stamps on custody logs and minor inconsistencies in witness statement annotations. These have been examined and found not to rise to the level affecting the substantive case or the fairness of proceedings. Such details, while important to due process, serve ultimately as reminders of the human fallibility inherent in any system. The court also wishes to note the absence of the media at this hearing, despite being an open court. This accords with a broader trend observed nationally where low-level acquisitive offences seldom attract journalistic attention unless coupled with violence or sensational elements. This is an ironic commentary on the public appetite for visibility, which is selective and often neglects the quiet harm done by repeated unlawful conduct such as this. The defendant told officers that he sold the stolen goods at a car boot sale and in nearby pubs, causing alarm to members of the public. The defendant’s record includes previous offences recorded over the last five years, primarily for similar thefts. Notably, in 2022, Mr H was dealt with under a conditional caution following a shoplifting incident involving confectionary and toiletries. A community resolution was additionally offered in 2021 for an unrelated instance of attempted retail theft. The recidivism here is not merely quantitative but concerns failure to desist despite multiple formal interventions. That pattern weighs heavily in the sentencing calculus. It is regrettable but true that the volume of return offenders places additional strain on police and probation resources. The Probation Service in this jurisdiction has reported increasing caseloads, a problem exacerbated by challenges in recruitment and retention. The consequence has been a reliance on prioritisation protocols which, while necessary, may limit the intensity of supervision available in some cases. The court also received correspondence from the managing director of a local retail cooperative, describing the impact of persistent low-level theft on stock shrinkage rates and staff morale. Their brief but sincere communication underscores the business reality behind the otherwise dry legal proceedings. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and approached retail staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, prompting serious safety fears among staff. The court has reflected upon recent changes to the Sentencing Council’s guidelines concerning theft offences, particularly the enhanced emphasis on the offender’s antecedents and the degree of planning or sophistication demonstrated. In this context, while Mr H has no history of violent conduct, the repeated and targeted nature of offences suggests a particular degree of deliberation and knowledge of vulnerable premises. The considerations of personal mitigation for cases of mental health difficulties were reinforced in R v. Harper [2023] EWCA Crim 733, which held that the existence of psychological difficulties should be carefully weighed against the nature and impact of offending behaviour. The sentencing court was reminded that such factors alone do not warrant wholesale mitigation where offending causes real harm and where risks to reoffending remain significant. I have had regard to all these principles in reaching my provisional conclusions today. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. The cumulative impact of repeated thefts on the community’s sense of security and business viability cannot be overstated. The prospect of deterrence—both specific and general—must be given appropriate weight, alongside considerations of rehabilitation and proportionality. The final pre-sentence report will explore in depth whether community sanctions augmented by accredited offending behaviour programmes might be viable, particularly interventions addressing impulsivity, financial management, and social integration. The possibility of unpaid work as a component of such a disposal will also be considered. It must be underscored that the court remains open to any proposals that aim to reduce reoffending and assist reintegration without compromising public protection. These sentencing remarks are delivered this day, 17 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Windsor Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal sentence date has been set pending receipt of updated pre-sentence and psychiatric reports. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal sentencing within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are in place. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT MANCHESTER R v. MR H Case No. T2025/14537 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. E. Carmichael Filed: 16 September 2025 Mr H, you stand before this court today for sentence in relation to charges brought under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, specifically shoplifting offences spanning the latter months of 2023 and continuing through to early 2025. These offences were committed across various retail establishments situated within Greater Manchester’s commercial districts, including areas of Salford and Stockport. The charges represent a pattern of sustained and calculated acquisitive offending, for which the Crown seeks a custodial or community sentence commensurate with the gravity of your conduct. Procedural Background You were initially arrested on 9 March 2025 following an investigation by the Greater Manchester Police Retail Crime Unit, which had been conducting a multi-agency operation targeting repeat offenders within the region's commercial corridors. This investigation was notable for its breadth and complexity, involving collaborative efforts between local policing teams, loss prevention personnel, and community safety partnerships. The case file, now exceeding 400 pages, includes digitally recorded witness statements, recovered CCTV footage, and forensic analyses linking you to multiple incidents. I note with approval that, unlike many matters involving low-value theft, this case progressed within reasonable timeframes, at least according to the schedule expected under the Criminal Procedure Rules and Better Case Management (BCM) protocols. The cooperation demonstrated by counsel for the Crown and the defence in adhering to listing dates contributed significantly to this efficient progression. The case was listed for plea and trial preparation hearing on 23 May 2025, following initial disclosure and after lengthy consideration of submitted evidentiary material. It is worth observation that the BCM model, as introduced in recent years and refined in the Criminal Justice Act 2003, aims to ensure that cases such as this, which might otherwise be subject to delay and fragmentation, proceed with a greater measure of clarity and expedition. Such reforms also serve to alleviate the administrative burden which routinely impairs the functioning of the criminal courts in matters of this nature. In the present instance, the progress from charge to plea (albeit late) occurred within the anticipated framework. The initial plea was not guilty, and a contested trial was scheduled for 15 July 2025. However, on the eve of that trial, a late guilty plea was entered, necessitating the rescheduling of sentencing. The court has reflected upon the significance of such late pleas, mindful both of established authorities and of the impacts on court resources and victim interests. The jurisprudence establishes, with clarity, that the timing of a plea materially affects the extent of any permitted credit. It is no entitlement, but a privilege that may be withheld or limited. A plea that comes under duress or only when the weight of evidence is overwhelming provides markedly less mitigation. Mr H concealed £12 worth of toiletries inside his coat and left the shop without paying. The role of multi-agency collaboration in cases akin to the present can scarcely be overstated. The Greater Manchester Retail Crime Partnership, a coalition of law enforcement agencies, public sector bodies, and representative retail groups, has made commendable progress in coordinating responses to such persistent offending patterns. Their intelligence-led approach, emphasizing real-time information sharing, data analytics, and operational liaison, seeks to anticipate offending behaviour and disrupt it before escalation. It is notable, however, that despite these advances, the pressure on frontline police officers tasked with such investigations remains substantial, particularly given competing demands in areas marked by elevated gang activity and violent crime. This allocation of resources underscores the broader societal impact of shoplifting, which, though often minimised, thereby carries consequences extending beyond the immediate financial loss. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. It is vital to place this case within the prevailing jurisprudential landscape. Authorities such as R v. Ellis [2019] EWCA Crim 345 and R v. Abasi [2022] EWCA Crim 573 have solidified the principle that repeated acquisitive offending, including shoplifting, warrants a response calibrated to both public protection and offender rehabilitation. Ellis underscores the aggravation occasioned by persistence and evidence of planning, while Abasi highlights the importance of considering the cumulative psychological impact on those victimised, including store employees often overlooked in earlier sentencing frameworks. Such authorities guide this court’s approach today, informing not only sentencing severity but also the conditions which may accompany any community disposal. I acknowledge that the case arose contemporaneously with considerable systemic strain on local justice services. The Crown’s diligent representatives, led by Ms Miranda Cartwright, prosecuted with evident thoroughness despite significant administrative hurdles and ongoing Legal Aid Agency delays. Conversely, the defence, led by Mr Paul Johnson, sought authorisations for psychiatric and forensic expert assessments, essential given emerging concerns about the defendant's vulnerability and mental health status. The protracted approval process for such funding underscores once again the limitations of the current legal aid regime. As this court has previously remarked, delays down this route regularly obstruct the timely administration of justice, disproportionately impacting defendants who either lack personal means or depend on complex inter-agency coordination. This regrettable pattern continues despite reform initiatives. Mr H returned to the same cornershop four times in three weeks, each time targeting alcohol and tobacco. The court has also received and carefully considered numerous written representations from local community groups, including the Manchester Business Coalition Against Crime (MBCAC) and the South Manchester Voluntary Support Network (SMVSN). These bodies articulate the broader community implications of acquisitive crime, highlighting the unseen ripple effects that extend into employee wellbeing, local business viability, and public confidence in safety. Particularly noteworthy were victim impact statements provided by several stores, including statements from managers and front-line retail assistants, reflecting anxiety and diminished morale occasioned by repeated shoplifting incidents. That these statements were gathered despite the chronic under-resourcing of victim liaison services merits recognition. Prior to today’s hearing, the court received an independent psychiatric report prepared by Dr Eleanor Stone, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist at St. Mary’s Hospital. Dr Stone conducted an extensive clinical interview and reviewed available records. Her report, comprehensive and professionally presented, identified significant difficulties with impulse control and emotional regulation linked to a history of attachment disorder. Whilst the report does not diagnose any major psychotic or mood disorder, it emphasises the presence of maladaptive personality traits that likely influence offending behaviour. Dr Stone also recommends engagement with specialist cognitive behavioural therapy designed to address criminogenic thinking patterns as part of any rehabilitative framework. The report underscores that while these factors do not excuse criminal responsibility, they require recognition in sentencing both for fairness and effectiveness of intervention. Mr H pretended to ask a question about Oyster Card payments in order to distract staff, then reached behind the counter and took a display item. It is important to remark that this case proceeded against a backdrop of increasing public concern regarding street-level acquisitive crime in Manchester, notably shoplifting and associated behaviours such as antisocial conduct. Council and Police initiatives, including Operation Retail Shield, have sought to reduce offending through a combination of enforcement, diversion, and offender management. Despite these efforts, offences of this nature persist, frequently complicated by underlying socioeconomic deprivation, substance misuse, and mental health challenges that defy simple remedy. Observers note a marked decline in the effectiveness of traditional deterrents, alongside a growing appreciation of the need for integrated, trauma-informed frameworks addressing underlying vulnerability, rather than solely focussing on punitive responses. Such complexity requires courts and other agencies to balance competing imperatives carefully. The court also notes with sadness the persistent challenges faced by the Legal Aid Agency in timely funding decisions for expert reports or specialist interventions. The procedural history demonstrates multiple requests, clarifications, and supervisory reviews before resources were authorised for the instruction of appropriate clinical expertise. Such delays not only prolong proceedings but impede forensic insight critical to apt case resolution. It remains paramount that decision-makers within the legal aid framework recognise the value of expeditious approval, particularly in cases where underlying vulnerability may be significant. Daniels [2024] EWCA Crim 789, concerning possession of a bladed article in a school car park, and R v. Mitchell [2023] EWCA Crim 609, involving aggravated burglary with minor violence. While neither case relates directly to shoplifting, they illustrate the wider sentencing principles applicable to offenders presenting mixed risk profiles with potential for public harm. In Daniels, the Court of Appeal emphasised the necessity of assessing both the precipitating circumstances and subsequent engagement with rehabilitative services. Mitchell held that where risk behaviours are coupled with evidence of substance misuse and non-compliance with supervision, custodial sentences with extended licence conditions may be appropriate to ensure public protection. Neither case parallels your offending in gravity, but they highlight the principles governing judicial discretion. In giving these remarks, it would be remiss not to mention the enduring phenomena of “late pleas” and their consequences. Your decision to enter a guilty plea on the morning of the scheduled trial, after prolonged denial, is a regrettable but familiar pattern. As established in leading cases, including R v. Clarke [2023] EWCA Crim 412, credit for such pleas must be modest. The timing offers scant real benefit to victims, witnesses, or court efficiency. Whilst the law preserves the right to change plea at any stage, the court must balance that right against the public interest in timely, fair resolution. The defendant confessed to offloading the stolen items at local pubs and a car boot sale, where his actions unsettled customers. The facts, as proven by the Crown and accepted by you through your plea, describe theft taking place in multiple shops. Surveillance footage and witness accounts demonstrate your deliberate acts of concealment and evasion. Multiple incidents show a consistent modus operandi: approaching shelves bearing high-demand consumer goods, removing items surreptitiously, then exiting without payment. The court is informed that you frequently used techniques designed to distract staff, including feigned phone calls and obfuscation by clothing layers. Notably, though no assault or violence is present, the psychological effect upon store personnel is palpable. The victim impact statements describe a climate of insecurity, with some staff reporting stress-related symptoms and reduced confidence. This effect, while intangible, informs the court’s assessment of harm. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and interacted forcefully with employees while damaging security cameras using spray paint, leading to a heightened risk to retail workers. The persistence of offending despite previous community-based disposals, including warnings and conditional cautions, aggravates the seriousness of your conduct. It signals an unwillingness or inability to desist without firm intervention. The probation service’s pre-sentence report, prepared by Officer Hannah Melrose, identifies medium likelihood of further offending without meaningful engagement in rehabilitative programmes. The report also notes your unstable housing situation and absence of meaningful employment, though these are contextual factors rather than direct mitigation. Mr H said to police he often shoplifts from local stores, claims it isn’t really stealing and expects to do it again soon. There remains, in this jurisdiction and beyond, a discernible tension regarding the response to acquisitive offending. The court is reminded of the social and economic upheaval occasioned by recent global events — the pandemic, inflationary pressures, and attendant rises in poverty have all contributed to elevated offending in certain strata. Yet, these factors do not grant licence to flout the law nor diminish the impact upon victims. Nor do they absolve the responsibility to engage proactively with available support. The probation service has been engaged throughout these proceedings, albeit constrained by significant caseload pressures and limited resources. The officer assigned, Ms Melrose, reports commendable efforts to involve you in services addressing financial management and substance use, but these overtures have, to date, failed to yield consistent participation. This dynamic is, regrettably, a familiar and persistent feature of cases involving repeat acquisitive offenders. Having weighed the multiple factors before me, including the seriousness of the offending, the impact on victims, the aggravating feature of persistence despite prior intervention, and your personal circumstances and vulnerabilities as identified in clinical assessment, I shall direct the preparation of a full pre-sentence report. This report will assist the court in identifying the most appropriate sentencing framework—whether custodial or community-based—that balances punitive, rehabilitative, and protective aims. I note the provisions of the Sentencing Council’s Theft Offences guideline, particularly the guidelines concerning repeat offending and the presence of aggravating and mitigating factors. The guideline appropriately emphasizes the importance of addressing risks of harm and the accused’s capacity to engage with rehabilitative services. I also reiterate that a sentence imposing immediate custody may be warranted where offending demonstrates persistence and disregard for sanctions, but equally, the guidance recognises the value of community orders supplemented by tailored interventions where compliance can be reasonably expected. The forthcoming pre-sentence report will be invaluable in guiding this determination. The court acknowledges the contributions of all those involved in this matter: to Ms Cartwright and her colleagues for the diligent prosecution; to Mr Johnson for his thorough and professional defence; to Dr Stone for her expert psychiatric evaluation; and to Ms Melrose and the probation service for their insight and ongoing work in this case. It is also appropriate to place on record the court’s gratitude to the administrative staff and ushers of this court, whose patience and professionalism ensure the smooth conduct of hearings despite the well-documented pressures on court resources. The sentencing hearing today has been conducted in open court with all interested parties present. I remind Mr H of his right to appeal, subject to the applicable time limits and procedural requirements. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 16 September 2025, in Court 12 of Manchester Crown Court. The proceedings have been recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal transcript will be made available in due course. The defendant is reminded of his statutory right to appeal within 28 days of sentencing under the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are applicable in these proceedings. No further orders as to costs are made at this stage. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. MR H Case No. T2025/12856 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. A. RICHMOND Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H, you appear before this court for sentence in respect of a charge of theft contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968, in consequence of which you have entered a plea of guilty. Procedural History This matter originated following an investigation by officers from the Avon and Somerset Constabulary, prompted by reports from several independent retailers within the central Bristol area. The offences, as charged, represent a pattern of shoplifting incidents committed over a period extending from approximately October 2024 until March 2025. The investigation involved cooperation between police units, store security personnel, and the Bristol Business Crime Reduction Partnership (BCRP), a multi-agency collaboration established in 2016 aimed at addressing acquisitive crime within the commercial districts. The BCRP's approach involves the collation of incident reports from affected retailers, dissemination of offender descriptions, and strategic deployment of police resources to hotspots. Despite the initiative’s commendable intentions, the court is aware from both submitted materials and prior experience that the efficacy of such schemes varies considerably. Staff shortages, shifting priorities, and competing demands often constrain sustained efforts. Moreover, the Better Case Management process was engaged in this prosecution, with a plea and trial preparation hearing conducted in May 2025. The case was duly allocated to the Crown Court given the volume of evidence and the sustained course of conduct alleged. The initial hearing was adjourned twice, once to allow for disclosure of additional CCTV evidence and again to permit the commission of a pre-sentence psychiatric report. Both adjournments were reasonably necessitated, although counsel for the defence expressed frustration about procedural delays attributable in part to difficulties in securing Legal Aid approval for expert instruction. The court acknowledges the ongoing challenges faced by the Legal Aid Agency. In this instance, the application for funding of a forensic psychologist was initially refused on grounds of insufficient justification, which, in retrospect, appear unduly stringent. Following formal representations and the intervention of the Legal Aid helpline, approval was granted three weeks later than anticipated, contributing to delay. Such occurrences, unfortunately, are not atypical in contemporary criminal proceedings and warrant sustained professional concern. The police investigative team, in addition to working with the BCRP, utilised conventional means including witness statements, forensic examination of clothing and recovered goods, and CCTV footage from multiple retail premises. Mobile phone footage submitted by the first victim’s partner was also presented, though its evidential weight was limited by quality issues. The court notes the frequent reliance on consumer-grade recording devices in retail theft cases, which can both aid and hinder investigative clarity. On 5 June 2025, you appeared before the Magistrates’ Court where you indicated a not guilty plea. Following enhanced disclosure and the filing of an expert report, the matter was committed for trial to this court. On 14 August 2025, you changed your plea to guilty at the earliest practicable stage before the trial date. It is a regrettable but established feature of cases involving repeated shoplifting that defendants often delay admission of guilt until the evidential case has become overwhelmingly strong. While the law correctly permits such procedural rights, it also recognises that the sentencing credit available for late pleas should correspond with the timing and circumstances of the admission. The Court of Appeal’s position in R v. Pickering [2023] EWCA Crim 1018 remains authoritative: a plea entered only at the threshold of trial attracts markedly less reduction than one entered soon after charge. It is a fine but important distinction, intended to incentivise early acceptance of responsibility and to respect the interests of all parties, including victims. The Crown, represented by Ms Eleanor Shaw, has provided clear and cogent submissions concerning the impact of your offending on the retailers and their staff. The defence is represented by Mr Simon Clozier of counsel, who has candidly acknowledged the difficulties encountered in progressing this matter expeditiously. I express my gratitude to both counsel for their professional conduct throughout. The Theft Act 1968 remains the principal statutory instrument governing offences of theft. Section 1 delineates the core offence, requiring proof of dishonest appropriating property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving. The legislative framework is supplemented by a detailed Sentencing Council guideline, last updated in 2022, which emphasises the balance of culpability, harm, and offender personal mitigation. The court also considers relevant case law, including the seminal House of Lords decision in R v. Ghosh [1982] QB 1053, which, although superseded on the test for dishonesty (see Ivey v. Genting Casinos [2017] UKSC 67), remains instructive in its broader themes regarding intent. The more recent Court of Appeal authority in R v. McClean [2024] EWCA Crim 2067 directs sentencing courts to take account of patterns of offending rather than isolated acts when the charge represents a course of conduct. Notably, while certain offences in the criminal law involve heightened protections—such as those protected under the Dangerous Offenders regime or involving sexual harm—the present case, being non-violent and primarily property-based, falls within the mid-range acquisitive crime category. Nevertheless, risk of reoffending, impact on victims, and previous history are crucial factors. It is also instructive to reflect on the challenges facing the Probation Service nationally. Resource constraints, high caseloads, and the growing complexity of cases are well documented—particularly for those offenders whose social circumstances include unstable housing, unemployment, or comorbid mental health issues. In the present matter, the allocated probation officer has reported significant difficulties in engaging you meaningfully. Furthermore, NHS mental health services, under pressure from soaring demand and limited funding, frequently struggle to provide timely assessments or interventions for defendants exhibiting mental health vulnerabilities without acute risk markers. Despite this, the cooperation of Dr Sarah King, Consultant Psychiatrist at the Avon and Somerset Mental Health Trust, has been instrumental in providing a competent forensic assessment on your behalf. The facts of this case are as follows: Mr H placed £18 worth of bath and body items inside his coat and left the store without attempting to pay for them. Protein powder and razor cartridge packs were placed in Mr H's niece’s pram as a means of concealment. Turning to the modus operandi, it is apparent that your offending was systematic and deliberate, involving both concealment techniques and opportunistic timing. The use of distraction tactics, such as engaging staff in ostensibly innocuous conversation while removing goods, indicates a level of sophistication not commonly found in first-time or incidental offenders. Further, the evidence suggests you deliberately targeted small or independent retailers, presumably perceiving these as softer targets compared to larger chains with more robust security measures. While arguably pragmatic, such conduct particularly damages community cohesion, as independent shopkeepers often lack both the resources and institutional support of larger enterprises. Mr H went back to the same convenience store four times in the space of three weeks, repeatedly taking alcohol and tobacco. On one occasion, Mr H asked staff about Oyster Card payments as a distraction, then leaned behind the counter to take a display item. It is significant that victims’ statements were obtained from store managers, many of whom have expressed ongoing concern regarding loss prevention and personal safety. Several reported consideration of altered staffing rotas to avoid lone working during peak hours when your presence was anticipated. This state of affairs engenders an erosion of community trust and workplace morale. The security tag was removed using a magnet, which was subsequently discovered on his person during arrest. In addition to the police and Crown Prosecution Service’s efforts, local voluntary sector organisations have maintained contact with the commerce community affected. The Bristol Retailers Support Network, although operating on limited funds, furnished an impact statement which highlights the psychological toll of repeat theft on small businesses, sometimes leading to premature closures or displacement. The defendant disclosed that the stolen goods were sold at a car boot sale and in pubs, where his conduct caused unease among customers. On behalf of the defence, a forensic psychiatric report compiled by Dr King concludes that while you do not suffer from any major psychiatric disorder, traits associated with low mood, impulsivity, and an absence of behavioural regulation were noted. Dr King cautions against interpreting this as an excuse for criminality, instead suggesting targeted therapeutic intervention might reduce reoffending likelihood. Of note, Dr King points out a history of unstable accommodation, periodic unemployment, and familial estrangement, all factors which collectively compound personal stress and impair judgement. Experts are of course mindful that presence of psychological or social difficulties does not equate to absence of agency. This court has repeatedly observed that mental health vulnerabilities, while warranting compassionate consideration, cannot absolve individuals of responsibility for deliberate wrongdoing. On at least two occasions, Mr H wore a balaclava and engaged directly with staff while spraying over CCTV equipment, raising major concerns for public and staff safety. To provide broader context, the sentencing guidelines recommend particular focus on whether there has been repeated offending, the impact on victims and local businesses, and any steps taken by the offender to acknowledge wrongdoing or commence rehabilitation. Credit for guilty pleas must be weighed meticulously, taking account of the timing and genuineness of the admission. The court notes that during pre-sentence enquiries it became evident that you have declined offers of support from both the Probation Service and local voluntary organisations designed to assist with housing and employment. Despite multiple referrals, you have not engaged with budgeting or skills programmes, leading to reasonable concerns about your willingness or capacity to address the underlying causes of offending behaviour. Recent data compiled by the Avon Probation Service illustrates the difficult position faced by practitioners dealing with offenders harbouring entrenched patterns of acquisitive crime compounded by social marginalisation. The caseload is described in internal memoranda as “unsustainably high” and staff turnover is an ongoing issue. It is worth reflecting briefly on related case law in this section. For example, R v. Fenwick [2022] EWCA Crim 778 concerned a defendant convicted of repeated theft from supermarkets, who exhibited both a pattern of covert concealment and opportunistic timing around staff shift changes. The Court of Appeal upheld a sentence of 10 months’ custody, while highlighting the cumulative impact of persistent offending on local business viability and public confidence in retail safety. Similarly, in R v. Allerton [2023] EWCA Crim 1054, the defendant’s conduct involved a series of offences including theft, handling stolen goods, and associated fraud. While the offences were partially distinct from Mr H’s conduct, the appellate court drew attention to the broader harm inflicted on the business community and public order. I do not suggest that these cases are precisely analogous, but they provide a useful frame of reference to illustrate judicial attitudes towards acquisitive crime involving persistent patterns. It is also prudent to make passing mention of the operational challenges of digital forensic units within contemporary police forces. The current case saw requests for enhancement of certain CCTV footage met with initial reservations due to backlog and technological constraints. The court is aware that digital evidence gathering remains a resource-intensive and rapidly evolving field. The court further observes, without attributing any particular relevance, that the relevant Legal Aid arrangements have once again been a source of difficulty in this matter. Funding applications for psychological and ancillary reports have been reviewed and initially rejected on technical grounds, contributory to delay. This is despite a national framework intended to expedite access to such support services in appropriate cases. Such procedural fragility ought to be addressed by administrative reform. The facts, while clear, show unmistakably a pattern of persistent dishonest conduct. The defendant resorted to multiple entries into various retail premises, timed to avoid detection during shift turnover. Frequently, goods of modest value but high resale potential were removed and concealed within bags or clothing. Mr H told officers he routinely shoplifts, insisted it wasn’t a serious crime and plans to continue. The impact on victims has been documented through statements describing emotional distress, loss of revenue, and a pervasive sense of unease among staff. Although no violence or threat thereof was present, the psychological harm cannot be underestimated. The phenomena of “reassurance gap” described in criminological literature is relevant: repeated offending erodes community confidence in law enforcement and increasing fear among shopkeepers. The court is cognisant, moreover, of the wider implications for public safety and resource allocation. While offences of this nature may appear relatively minor when viewed independently, the cumulative effect of repeated acquisitive crime is to consume disproportionate police and prosecutorial resources. That diverts attention away from more serious or violent crime, thus indirectly affecting overall community safety. When considering sentencing outcomes, the court must weigh aggravating factors — including the continuity of offending, the breach of trust implicit in repeated self-service theft, the impact on victims, and the pattern of non-engagement with rehabilitative opportunities — against mitigating features such as early plea, acknowledged personal difficulties, and absence of prior custodial sentences. While the scale of the offences is modest in financial terms, public interest mandates a robust response to sustained acquisitive crime. The court notes the significant number of resource hours dedicated over months to monitoring, evidence collation, and prosecution. This is not trivial. Drawing together the various threads, I intend to direct the preparation of a pre-sentence report from the National Probation Service. The report is to encompass an assessment of risk, diversity considerations, psychological and social support needs, and the appropriateness of community-based rehabilitative programmes. Particular attention should be paid to expenditure of time and capacity, in order that proposals can be put forward addressing both the likelihood of compliance and the imperative of public protection. Finally, I wish to record formal appreciation for the efforts of the Bristol Business Crime Reduction Partnership. In an era marked by tightened public sector budgets and previous cuts to policing numbers, their coordination and support to small businesses are invaluable. While uneven, their contribution to community cohesion and crime deterrence is well beyond decorative. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. Proceedings have been recorded in accordance with Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal transcript will be lodged with the court record. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal against sentence within 28 days pursuant to section 108 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 s.49 apply. There are no further directions as to costs. These are the orders of the court.
